author: BurntToasTJ.com
review: Hogwarts Legacy is the latest addition to the Harry Potter franchise and it has already taken the gaming world by storm. The game is set in the 1800s and offers players the opportunity to experience life as a student at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. Players get to create their own character and embark on an adventure filled with magic, mystery, and friendship.One of the most appealing aspects of Hogwarts Legacy is the level of detail and immersion in the game. The developers have done an exceptional job of recreating the magical world of Harry Potter, with stunning environments, intricate character designs, and a captivating storyline that draws players in from the very beginning. The game's graphics are top-notch and truly bring the world of Hogwarts to life.Another aspect that sets Hogwarts Legacy apart from other games in the franchise is the level of customization available to players. Players can choose their own House, customize their appearance, and even choose their own wand. This level of customization allows players to truly make the game their own and feel a deep connection to their character.In addition to the customization options, the game also features a wealth of spells and abilities for players to learn and master. The combat system is intuitive and engaging, allowing players to cast spells and defend themselves against dangerous creatures. The magic system in the game is well thought out and adds a level of depth to the gameplay that is not often seen in other games.The game's storyline is also noteworthy. Players get to experience life at Hogwarts as it unfolds, with new challenges and adventures around every corner. The game features a cast of familiar characters, as well as new ones, and the voice acting is excellent, adding to the overall immersion of the game. The storyline is well-written and engaging, with twists and turns that will keep players on the edge of their seat.One of the best aspects of Hogwarts Legacy is the sense of community it fosters. Players can interact with other students in the game, join clubs and attend classes together, and even compete in duels. The game features a co-op mode, where players can team up and explore the world of Hogwarts together, which adds a new level of excitement to the game.In conclusion, Hogwarts Legacy is an exceptional game that will delight fans of the Harry Potter franchise and newcomers alike. With stunning graphics, a captivating storyline, and a wealth of customization options, the game offers a truly immersive experience. The level of detail and care that has gone into creating this world is evident in every aspect of the game, and it is sure to captivate players for many hours. If you're a fan of the Harry Potter universe or just looking for a new and exciting game to play, then Hogwarts Legacy is definitely worth checking out.

author: MustacheMan2009
review: Hogwarts legacy is a game to distract you for a bit. You can run through the entire story, by itself without other content the game offers, probably in a bout 10-15 hours depending on how good you are in combat and how fast you can access the fast travel system. That being said, I have almost 100% the game (achievement wise) within' the 60 hours I have played it. The combat is simple yet complex in it's hidden combos it hints at within' the dueling fates system. E.x. being, "Slice a frozen enemy." Besides helping you perform devastating combos with different spells though, there is no real use to the system besides getting a completion bonus for completing a certain amount of them. I don't believe this game has much replay-ability, which is fine for me, but if you were curious about a NG + mode, there is not one. The story is great, but I wouldn't play through it more than once. Side quests are fun yet simple and can be summed up like this- Find person in trouble, Ask what's going on, Be told someone else can do it and not to risk your life, Go however many meters to objective, Obliterate the enemy or collect the item they need, Come back and announce you pwned the quest, They act shocked, Then you can extort them for more of a reward or just say lol you're welcome. They do have some lore attached but it's only to the side quest that you're doing. Not much trivia after the fact if you catch my drift. One thing I love is the interactions with the NPC's after doing certain actions. They start speaking of your accomplishments as you continue to do things around the world. Same goes with enemies. An example being releasing a certain enemy type from spider webs, and then they start talking about it in battles with that enemy type for the rest of the game. Very cool the first couple times.... then they just repeat themselves and never stop mentioning it lol. A special feature that became old a bit to fast unfortunately. The open world is also filled with various puzzles and activities to do. After a while though, it almost feels like a chore and loses meaning once you obtain the challenge log's reward for doing a certain amount of whatever lies on the map for you to do. Speaking of the challenge log, that is where a lot of the fun lied for me. It's almost like a scavenger hunt that tells you exactly what to do at the start of it. There are five different categories, each being named after different aspects of the game. Exploration, Combat, Field Guides, ETC. Each has a said amount of tiers that award you with different things. Some being inventory space, others being cosmetics for your equipment (which you can change at ANY time ANY where in the game.) After you complete them, there aren't many achievements left to the open world besides doing every single one of the Merlin Trials littered throughout the region though. So for me, once I completed it, I sort of lost my momentum playing the game. There's plenty else in this game that you can explore and discover, and if you're curious but not sure to get it or not? Wait for a sale, always a safe bet. The game is worth every penny spent. Although I don't think I'd buy the DLC or deluxe edition. Not really needed in an RPG in my opinion.

author: Z4nterox
review: Let's start with an important piece of information: I am absolutely obsessed with the world of Harry Potter. Like many of you, I grew up with the stories, read the books, watched the movies, went to Hogwarts and never really left. I've read all the fanfics (in a general sense, not ALL fanfics of course) and every time I read about Hogwarts it's like coming home.  This game fails at almost everything it should do as an RPG. There is absolutely no depth to this game, the characters, or the story. The open world is completely pointless. Now that I've played it and experienced it, would I buy it again?Yes, but not at full price. Wait for a sale. That's why this review is marked "not recommended".Because, after all, it's still a lot of fun running around Hogwarts or Hogsmead; or just fighting enemies with magic. There's no denying that. Is it a game that I will remember? One of those you never quite leave behind? A little bit, but only because it's Harry Potter and I keep imagining what it could have been. Do you leave that aside? No, then it's not.All in all, the biggest feelings I have about this game are the following: Disappointment at what it is and sadness/longing at what it could have been. It's all right? Not the best I've experienced but definitely not bad either. It was original, I'll give the developers that. Don't think about the logic behind some of the things that happen and it's all good. It was entertaining.Really annoying for me were the interruptions in the narrations of the individual questlines."Hey, something super important and really exciting is happening right now. We need to act right now!""All right, great. What happens now, what do we do, who do I have to kill?""I'll make a plan and then send you an owl. Until then this suuuper important and exciting thing will just have to wait. Bye.""..." Yeah, no. It's an RPG without the RP. Your choices have almost no impact. Learning the unforgivables? You're a hero! Blackmail everyone and be a total arsehole? You're a hero!!! The only decision that matters comes at the very end and decides which of the three endings you get. You start at Hogwarts as a fifth year. Everyone else has already been together for 4 years, making friends, creating their groups, and getting caught up in house rivalries. You  be the new awkward guy who doesn't know anyone and has only one job: To get off your butt and try to catch up with your classmates and maybe make some friends in the process.Instead, you're instantly good at EVERYTHING. Flying like a pro? No problem. Killing dozens of enemies left and right? Sure. Unforgivable curses? Yep. Brew potions, grow plants, and rescue and care for animals without fail? Absolutely! You're a Mary Sue character. The chosen one of the chosen ones.To sum it up: You make absolutely no sense and are definitely not human. Sebastian: "Hey, you're new? Be my best friend. Here's my life story."Natty: "Hey, you're new? Be my best friend. Here's my life story."Poppy: At least reasonably well written. The only character I somewhat cared about. You're a Slytherin? Natty  doesn't care. Still, instant best friends.You're a Gryffindor? Sebastian  doesn't care either. Again, Sebastian and Natty don't act or behave like people. They have no depth, no initial character arc, no real history. Poppy is not completely exempt from this either. Why does this game have an open world? Can someone please explain this to me, because I really don't get it. The world adds absolutely nothing to this game. It is full of pointless tasks without end. Take the Merlin trials for example. There are 95 of them. 95! And they are completely pointless. These trials are not hard, not engaging, not fun. They're just time-wasters with an unskippable ending-animation.Aside from that, the open world feels dead. Sure, there are smaller "villages" and enemy camps and such, but they don't really add anything to the game. At least for me, they don't. This is one of those of open world games that shouldn't have an open world. Strangely devoid of life. That's one way to describe Hogwarts. There are no students other than fifth graders, except for a few underclassmen as quest givers. Where are all the other students? I don't know, just disappeared, I guess.The NPCs that are around are dummies. They stand around doing the exact same thing over and over again. How many times are you going to run up the wall? All day, every day! The brawling armors have more character than these students. To be fair, there are quiet a few funny encounters between those students.And where the hell do these guys sleep? Not in their beds, that's for sure!And then there are the classes. Or what should be classes. Instead, it feels like kindergarten or something, but definitely not like classes at supreme school for magic.And rules don't matter to you. Magic in the corridors? Yes, please. Wearing a school uniform at Hogwarts. Boring!Pain. Pure and utter pain.You may be a wizard, but I guess you've never heard of backpacks with space expansion charms. Your inventory is almost always full. You'll either have to return to a merchant every half hour or start destroying stuff. I can't remember a worse game in this regard. And don't even get me started on the gear itself. I found legendary gloves at level 16 and didn't have to swap them out until level 36. ‘Nuff said. Just don't try to think anything through logically here. I mean, sure, it's magic and all. But still: "Hey, you. My husband, a fully trained wizard with a lot of life experience, was killed by a troll. He had a locket on him. Could you, a completely untrained fifth year Hogwarts student, please go and kill the troll to get the locket back?""Yeah sure, no problem." "So, character,  you really need to get off your arse and catch up to your classmates.""Yes, Professor Weasley. Oh, open world. Bye Hogwarts."  One: Alohomora. Why is there a freaking minigame for Alohomora. I don't remember Hermione getting out her gamepad and wiggling the sticks around to open doors. And the minigame isn't even hard, in any way! It's simple: you turn the sticks until the gamepad vibrates, hold that position for a while, see a non-skippable animation/scene change, and the door is open. Every single time. And there are a whole lot of locked doors. There are even locked doors behind locked doors. I've already mentioned the Merlin trials. The menus and transition sequences into the menu and between menus are really not the fastest either.

author: EnforcerKiller
review: As someone who has never read a Harry Potter book nor seen any of the movies, this is an absolutely fantastic first dive into the world of Hogwarts for me. From the very beginning of the game, I was immediately drawn in by the atmosphere, cutscene quality (especially the characters) and the background music. It gave me the feeling that this is gonna be a good game just from the first 10 minutes of play. After 15ish hours of the game (have not finished it yet nor do I think I'm anywhere near finishing it), I can safely say this is my GOTY pick for the moment. It's funny to think about, since before the game released, I was heavily skeptical of how the combat and the dialogue looked, but it turns out I was worried for nothing after all.There is one major complaint, however. The optimization is not great. For reference, I'm running a 3080 with 32 GB DDR4 RAM and a 7700k. The only outdated part in the list is the 7700k. Before the day one patch, my performance was a very unstable 20-80 fps at Medium-High settings. I've only done minimal testing after the day one patch, but my first experience was my game crashing alongside my GPU due to a VRAM overflow. Before the crash, I noticed that my performance was significantly better, so it was really upsetting when I ended up crashing after a decent first impression. After that I switched everything to Medium, which lead me to slightly better performance without the crash this time. I still have to do more testing to come to a definitive conclusion, but overall I do not think it's well-optimized, especially with how much VRAM it hogs for no real reason.

author: Japani69Katti
review: Do you want to experience the wizarding world in the 1800s? In Hogwarts Legacy you get to be a student in Hogwarts who holds the key to an ancient secret that threatens to tear the wizarding world apart. You get to embark on an epic journey through familiar and new locations as you explore and discover magical beasts, customize your character and craft potions, master spell casting, upgrade talents and become the witch or wizard you want to be.Hogwarts Legacy is a potterhead's wet dream manifested into a wonderful experience of a game which offers a detailed and impressive recreation of Hogwarts and it's neighboring regions, which are packed to the brim with things to discover, things to collect and lore to seek and read.Some negative about the world building and everything in it, it's a collector's dream. That's not for everyone for sure, there is a lot of repetition and the map is quite big with not as much variety as there should be. I enjoyed the collecting myself, as I really like collecting things, but it's definitely something that you need to be aware of.There is a great amount of customizing when creating your own witch or wizard, with good range of skin colors and cosmetics and even a way to change the pitch of the voice options. Changing the pitch does make the voice sound a little bit robotic in my opinion, but it isn't too bad, and is a nice addition. You also have your own "homebase" that you can decorate and customize with a lot of options. The combat is nice and smooth, but can be easily exploitable, especially after you receive the unforgivable curses. There is a way to heal spam and the AI of the enemies is not that smart which makes the combat sometimes really, really easy. Sadly the named foes and quest bosses lack in uniqueness with no real variety in their combat abilities or behavior either. The story progression feels surprisingly smooth and portrays the growth of the main character very well where you get to hone your talents and improve. The progress of time is very well portrayed with the changing seasons and the day and night cycle. The main story itself is quite interesting, but has an underwhelming finale that leaves you wondering how your choices affected the other characters around you.There is also some inconsistencies that are minor annoyances, like if you use an unforgivable curse in public, no one bats an eye. Your friends do mention that they do not like you using them if you are fighting with them, but otherwise there is no real repercussions for them, which makes them less unforgivable.There is a great variety of side characters in the game that are very well built and are quite likable and unique from each other. The writing of the friendship quests is interesting and shows the growth of the main character's friends as well as how it affects the main character themselves.For me, the game took some over 90 hours to complete to 100% on normal difficulty, with all collections filled and challenges completed, as well as the few extra achievements that are given when you reach the map chamber with a character from each of the houses. I also spent a lot of extra time wandering around and taking screenshots, which boosted my hours a little bit. There is really no replay value to the game, since there is no different endings or choices to make. All of the collectibles can be acquired on one playthrough and the other 3 playthroughs only take about 2 hours each to reach to the map chamber.Is this game worth it then? Yes, absolutely. It's a fantastic game, filled with content and is definitely the best game made of the franchise up to date, in my opinion. There is certain political issues regarding the game, but you can enjoy the game and still not support those ideals.as an ending note, I wan't to add that be you a man, a woman or anything in-between or outside of, you are loved. You are appreciated by me and many others and I hope that you get to live your life the way you want to live it.

author: OVERWATCH SUCKS
review: After having finished the game this morning, Hogwarts Legacy is no different from any Ubisoft game you have played in the last 15 years. The game is boggled with meaningless side quests, and the story is lackluster. With the Harry Potter IP, so much more could have been done. I am just disappointed.I do not understand who made the choice to remove any actual sort of customization to a game like this. You select character preset, and change their hair, eye color, etc. That's it. No ear shape, nose shape, jaw, nothing. Seeing as most other games offer that at the bare minimum, it's hard to see why they removed it. They lock it into a sense of realism, which is weird for a fantasy game. If I want green skin, I should be able to have green skin. The main draw of the game, Hogwarts, is both a blessing and a curse. The animations of the stairs building, ghosts popping in and out, and the joyful music playing are probably the best parts of the game. That's all there is to it however, It just looks good. You cannot interact with any of the students. It's like an amusement park attraction. The only option is to walk around, observe, and eat an apple. The only other game I played set in an environment like this was Bully, and that game offered way more freedom than the developers here have allowed. It's hard to immerse yourself when you're pretty much watching a movie about your character, rather than actually playing as them.The story is nothing special. It's not bad, but I was not excited to keep playing it. Can't say much else without spoiling.I know I should not say the Witcher 3 side quests are the cream of the crop, as that is just overstated at this point, but it is what it is. I can't help to compare them to the cookie cutter ones we got here. Go collect 6 gobstoppers for this kid. Go find this obscure cliff from the mirror to find a chest with ugly glasses in it. Ubisoft-type missions and heavily prevalent. Side missions have no multiple endings, and they always end up predictable.In Hogwarts, you will get into plenty of scraps. a good ol' bout with some real scum. You will have to use your spells to blast your foes, so hopefully there's lots of them, right? Well, there's only  spells. Yes, you hears that right, only . That's without even mentioning that you can only equip 4 spells at a time. They took the Mass Effect Andromeda route of limiting your combat for the sake of, i don't even know. With only 4 at a time, I felt extremely limited in what I could do. The animations themselves are great, but when looking at a game like Elden Ring, who has  spells, and the game isn't only a wizard game, you realize that much more could have been done. Skyrim even has  spells. And just like Elden Ring, that game has much more than just magic. Also, after comparing the difficulties between hard and normal, it is only a health bar difference. Enemies will damage you more, and you do less damage. Underwhelming if you ask me, when you could have had them use more strategy in taking you down.I know people won't like this, but Forspoken magic looks a lot better than this game. No one has actually played it, so no one has actually seen how good it looks.This is by far the worst part of this game. Everything is locked behind a level based lock. most of Hogwarts Legacy is hidden behind locks that you must progress the story to unlock. You cannot explore at your own pace. I say it again, the developers choose when you get to have fun. It is a shame, as the world is beautiful. Riding the broomstick is amazing, I spent a lot of time just riding around. Mounts are great as well, love the threstral mount that I got from the deluxe edition.This one is a little nitpicky, but the doors feel weightless. Your character just pushes them open extremely fast, its honestly very jarring. The huge doors in the fountain area open effortlessly, which is extremely weird to me.This is the one thing that has left me completely confused. You only get XP by collecting lore scrolls around the map. WHY? No XP from defeating monsters, no growing stronger from your battles, you have to click left on the D-Pad, listen for a bell noise, and find a scroll to level up. I hate it. Don't forget the flying scrolls that you just grab out the air effortlessly. Hogwarts Legacy brings nothing new to the table. The graphics are the best part of the game, everything else is a either a weird gameplay decision, or a mechanic jacked from another game, yet done far worse. I would say this game is good of you love Harry Potter, and do not really play video games. Otherwise, this game is way overpriced for what it offers, and you may get bored easily once the initial honeymoon phase wears off around a few hours.

author: Chinosky
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a game filled with content and variety of activities but it is also a perfect example of why you should go for quality over quantity when you absolutely have to make that choice. Almost every activity in this game ranges from okay to pretty good for the first couple of hours after which it becomes unbearable, boring and tedious and that coupled with the fact that there are hundreds of those activities, that really takes a toll on you. The side activities are boring, the combat is kind of unique but extremely repetitive (as it really doesn't matter what enemy you are fighting), the puzzles are mostly childish (some of them are okay though), the open world is needlessly huge and feels incredibly dead, the story and characters are cringeworthy (thank god you can skip the dialogues) and the RPG mechanics are tacked on and completely underdeveloped which is why the get in the way of having fun rather than reinforcing it. It is not all bad though, Hogwarts itself looks amazing and genuine and it really feels like the poured their hearts into designing it, Hogsmeade is also decent and the season changes were a nice touch. The room of requirement and the whole vivarium gameplay was also a cool edition but that kind of customization is not interesting for me personally, especially when it doesn't feel rewarding at all as the combat (even on Hard difficulty) is pretty easy. The unforgivable curses are properly overpowered and fun to use but as the choices in this game don't matter at all those curses are treated as everything else in the game and that was disappointing. The looting is also stupid as it is completely random which more often than not robs you of feeling any sense of reward after exploring something hidden and hard to find. At the end of the day, this game wore me out completely even before the halfway mark and I had to force myself to get to the end of it which I really shouldn't have done.  So I personally recommend this game to only the Harry Potter series' fans who only wanted to have a huge, Triple A, open world HP game where they could just fly around, explore Hogwarts and perform some iconic spells, for the rest of us who are looking for a unique, fun open world experience this is NOT it my friends, if not for the amazing Hogwarts design I'd say that this is a proper UBISOFT-style open world title as all the same tired, tedious and boring tropes and design choices are in full throttle here.

author: Mr.Ora[N]ge
review: is the best Hogwarts magic game of all time. I had a lot of fun playing this game, I liked it, although it has its problems.I pre-ordered the game hoping it wouldn't be terrible. And I did not regret it, I waited and passed it in 49 hours.The game has pretty nice graphics. I played on ultra settings without RTX. Particularly pleased with the castle, which was very well created by the development team. A stunning castle, with many details and secrets.The open world also pleases with its beauty. In addition, it is quite large and even filled. The village of Hogsmeade is also done very well, the developers deserve respect.The game Hogwarts Legacy takes place at the end of the 19th century and tells about the students of Hogwarts. Your character is a student holding the key to an ancient secret that threatens to tear the magical world apart. You are belatedly accepted into Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry and soon discover that you are no ordinary student: you have the rare ability to sense and manipulate ancient magic. Only you can decide whether you will protect this secret for the good of all or succumb to the temptation of more sinister magic.Hogwarts Legacy is an open-world, single-player action role-playing game with multiple difficulty and accessibility options. Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry will offer classes such as spells, defense against the dark arts, herbology and potions.When creating a playable character, the player can choose their appearance, faculty, and gender. Players can customize their character's voice, body type, and wand type. Leveling up gives the player access to talents, upgrades, and skills. The game also features environment customization elements where players will be able to customize the Room of Rescue as they level up in the game.The player's character will learn to cast various magic spells, brew potions and master combat abilities. As you progress, players will be able to develop their own special fighting style. In combat, items purchased or crafted can be used to harm enemies or create obstacles or enhance the player's character. There will be taming, grooming and riding magical beasts. Dragons, trolls, hippogriffs, and nifflers are shown as creatures that can be interacted with in the gameplay video. Some creatures can be used in combat, such as the mandrake to stun enemies.The gameplay is quite interesting and multi-level, although it does not seem so at first glance. To understand the whole essence and feel it - you just need to try it yourself.The game has a lot of different collectibles that you can collect, although this is not mandatory. At the same time, some gathering helps to open new abilities, expand your inventory, or give you some things. I wasn't able to collect all the collectibles because there are so many of them (about 760), but at the same time I completed all the challenges.Many players will not like this game, many will not even try it, but those who still pass it will get an interesting and new experience, because there are very few games in this genre. If you watched the Harry Potter movies or you just have an interesting Hogwarts, I advise you to go through this game and not listen to anyone.

author: Buffy
review: Hogwarts has never been more beautiful than this. The graphics, the music, the ambience is near perfect. However this is where the praise ends, because this golden palace is filled to the brim with sh*t.The major problem:There is no immersion. You are a perfect Mary-Sue without any backstory, everyone loves you, there is no friction at all, there are no consequences, there are no friendships or romances, there is simply nothing that defines you and your journey through Hogwarts other than the fact that you are perfect and chosen. All other characters - bar Sebastian - are lifeless and dull, interchangable really. Almost every corner reeks of cut content (the mechanics for Quidditch are there, but it wasnt finished, Sebastian clearly is supposed to be a romance, the other three "companions" however werent finished at all, most noticably in Poppy and Amit.)Instead minigames and "riddles" are thrown at you at any moment to breath some life into this, but unfortunately it only breaks the immersion more. Again you are the only one to solve these riddles, because you are perfect.The other big issues:To this day I am having severe graphical issues. The first 2 weeks this game was almost not playable due to poor performance. Now the performance is alright, but textures dont load or load extremely slowly. Even on medium settings.The combat is fun for like an hour or so, then it gets tedious extremely quickly, because there are only like 5 enemy types or so.I dont even wanna go into detail when it comes to the overall storyarc. Its so bland, I just wonder how people like that can call themselves authors and how anyone can greenlight that crap. Overall this is the biggest disappointment since Cyberpunk for me.

author: Ryzzie
review: Before publishing a review for a game, I like to take my time and experience a good amount of what the game has to offer. Unless of course, the game has major issues that need to be adressed immediately. Thankfully Hogwarts Legacy is not one of those games, we don't have to beta test this game and wait 6 months to a year for the developers to actually finish it. Look at what happens when a publisher actually gives a development studio time to finish a game, instead of forcing it out the door early. This game just shows the importance of getting a game right the first time.Hogwarts Legacy has become one of the best games I have ever played, and one of my favourite games of all time. Incase you don't realise how big of a statement that is for me, I have been playing video games since I was 4 years old, and since then I have played thousands upon thousands of games. Honestly, I'm not a big Wizarding World fan, but I did watch the Harry Potter trilogy for the first time in 2021, and loved them. This game has given me a reason to explore this universe in more depth, and is pulling me in to become a fan of the Wizarding World. Rarely do I ever stop in games to read descriptions about characters, locations, objects and the such, but in this game I found myself stopping to do that quite often. I would spend a few minutes reading about a historic figure in Hogwarts, or about one of the many rooms in the castle, and I learnt so much more about this universe by doing so.The combat is incredibly fun and satisfying, to be as effective as possible you will need to pull off combos to deal the most amount of damage in a short period of time. You can evade enemy attacks by either rolling or blocking incoming spells/melee attacks, pressing the deflect button quickly will deflect an incoming enemy spell in a random direction, but if you hold the deflect button while an enemy is casting, you can deflect their spell right back at them and stun them. With larger enemies, you will need to dodge to succesfully avoid damage. Sometimes enemy wizards/witches will have shields to protect them, these shields are colour coded in connection with your own spells, for exaple if an enemies shield is purple this means you will have to cast a purple spell to break their shield, this is an excellent way of making button mashing/click spamming useless, since no player will be able to push random buttons and win every enemy encounter. Overall combat is fantastic, and also visually stunning.The music is beautiful, and perfectly compliments what is happening on the screen. A peacful and relaxing tone of music for exploration which sets your mind at ease, to intense and lively music during combat. Games like these just show you how important good music in games is, how they can elevate the moment and give you a better experience because of it. Not much else to say about the music other than it being excellent.When you get to explore Hogwarts for the first time, it really makes you appreciate this amazing universe that J.K. Rowling has created. Hogwarts itself is extremely beautiful, every area within the castle is visually stunning and unique. If you are someone that has always dreamed of exploring this universe, you will not be disappointed. You can also explore the area surrounding Hogwarts, if that wasn't enough there is also seasonal weather which completely changes the aesthetic of the map visually, and even certain aspects of the castle.Another thing I love about this game is how it rewards the player for exploration, the game encourages you to explore because doing so will grant you superior gear, wand attachments, potions, money and all kinds of collectables. The world feels immersive, NPC's will partake in certain activities depending on where you are, students will be browsing and reading books in the library, having lunch and talking to one another at a table, teachers will be going through school work in their classroom among many other things. This creates a more immersive experience for the player, further investing them into this world.There are no microtransactions in Hogwarts Legacy, this needs to be emphasised and commended. These days it is such a rare sight to see games that don't include microtransactions. Microtransactions ruin every game that they are a part of, I will always have respect for developers/publishers that refuse to put microtransactions into their game.Overall I think Hogwarts Legacy is a fantastic game, even if you aren't a fan of this world there is still a lot of enjoyment to be found within it. My hope is that the developers can continue to support and update this game adding more content to it. Imagine if they add a multiplayer mode where you can play Quidditch with, and against other players, if they ever do I will be there. Cooperative dungeons would also be pretty awesome. I'm very excited to see what is in store for Hogwarts Legacy in the future.

author: ♪ piekz
review: holy... hear me out. Not a harry potter fan, nor the target generation, but still starving for an atmospheric open world game once in a while. Selling this as an rpg is extremely questionable. Graphics 10/10, amazing details and atmosphere, must have had a horrendously good budget. But then .. with such a level of potential ... then ... under the hood, a game where no decision seems to have weight, not a single piece of gear dropped having any impact (you can regularly just visit the vendor to buy highest gear quality on your level, which are mostly reskins anyways, anything below highest quality being vendor food), any combat situation being easily manageable even on hard (coming from i.e. gw2 elementalist) and a story ending in just -well- ... meh. Also, the UI sometime, forced minimap rotation, locked cursor on page swaps...I decided to finish it since i liked the visual design a lot, found it neat in many occasions and had that 'now I am invested'-feeling and wanted to see the ending. This is barely an rpg, maybe an open-world'ish adventure, that does not remotely come close to cyberpunk, witcher or even good old gothic or oblivion in terms of depth, complexity and freedom. Probably worth it if you are a diehard fan of the franchise and want to experinece an interactive part of the harry potter universe.

author: Jinkins (ò.ó)
review: Edit: Recent patch has now fixed most of the crashing issues, no crash for 3 hours.Edit2: I can play fine now with about a crash every 5 hours, mostly happens when loading a cave or such. I will now say i Recommend the game due to less crashing and fun gameplay. In it's current state i cannot play for very long before the game closes down on me. I have a 2080/i5 7600K, 16gb RAM. I should be able to run this game. It's the first game i've had frequent crashes on since buying the PC. Temps are fine, i've tried all the tricks available online. Sadly nothing helps. author: BILLIE WESKER
review: All politics aside this is a solid game. The creator is entitled to their opinion.The ultimate love letter to the Wizarding World. Been dying to play this since its first announcement. I've read all the books countless times and seen the movies more times than anyone. This truly makes you feel like a wizard and has that whimsical dark feel to it. I love how you can choose to be good or evil with no consequence. Haven't had this kind of system since Fable 2. The way I play I'm pretty much a school shooter with magic. Psycho Mode. Love the tonal shift from School which reminds me of Bully to everything outside the safe zones which become ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ killing floors. I also love how sadistic you can be towards everyone. For once we have a game that truly doesn't feel like anything else. Entirely unique as things should be. One of the best RPGs since Skyrim. I actually feel like doing everything there is to offer. So immersive. Highly recommend it. Of course another 10/10 in my eyes.Avada Kedavra!!!!

author: Jason Plays
review: I have not watched the movies or read the books, just wanted to get that out of the way from the top....This is an awesome game with a ton of stuff to do in it. The map is much bigger than I thought it would be and the locations are detailed as hell. The combat is pretty deep, but not insanely so. Don't come in thinking you are getting some really deep RPG mechanics. Same thing for the armor / clothing in the game. The gear has stats but it is a very surface level system. That is all ok for me, the game plays really good and everything feels really good and polished. Not having watched the movies, all of the stuff in game is new to me. You can tell that the developer did all they could to cram in as much as they could for the Harry Potter world and it shows. If you are a fan of the books / movies it will be awesome, and if you don't care about any of that stuff it is still a very good game. If you are interested then jump in, it's pretty good.

author: Fenrir Deimos
review: I am not a HP fan but I was pretty excited about this game. It's the first major non-movie-tie-in game in a setting that is, admittedly, is a pretty original one. No matter what you think of Wizarding Worlds or whatever it's called, you can't deny that the setting itself is pretty unique and unlike anything else among the major IPs nowadays. And on this, the game delivers. The world is vibrant and interesting, the atmosphere is great, the architecture is beautiful and it's all filled with a lot of small details that make it really a blast to explore. At least for the first 5-8 hours of gameplay. However, personally, I quickly lost interest in the game because it gets bogged down by a lot of... inconsistencies and problems. First, about what I call “inconsistencies”.Don’t be fooled by the marketing campaign. The game DOES NOT deliver on its promise of making you feel like a Hogwarts student. As a matter of fact, the game has pretty much nothing to do with the magic academy student-like experience. The game tries to pretend that this is what it is about at first, but you will quickly realize that it’s just a poorly chosen “aesthetic” that is dissonant with everything else in the game and, for this reason, does not work at all. The game’s story is completely inconsistent with what you’re doing and how it forces you to behave in it. The best example to illustrate my point would be a particular side quest I found in Hogsmead about 7 hours into the game.An adult woman, about in her 30s-to-40s from the looks of it, is asking the main character to “follow the butterflies” into the Forbidden Forest, because she’s interested where they lead and is herself scared of going into the Forest because… of her Hogwarts background. The teachers told her that Forbidden Forest is off limits to students because there is a lot of dangerous stuff there that will get her killed as students are not yet prepared to deal with it.Let me emphasize. A grown woman who studied at Hogwarts and knows for a fact that entering the forest is forbidden to students and is scared to go there because she doesn’t want to get killed by dangerous stuff out there… asks a Hogwarts student to go into Forbidden Forest. Not because she’s desperate, not because this is a matter of life and death to her… but because she is curious where the butterflies fly off to. Unbelievable. She’s not the only one who will ask the main character, a Hogwarts student, to do stuff that is in direct violation of Hogwarts rules in a way that doesn’t even imply that it would be breaking the rules. Quests like that are everywhere in the game. The characters will ask you, a Hogwarts student, to kill deadly Acromatulas, collect stuff in the Forbidden Forest or take on a camp full of dark wizards without even remembering that they are talking to a student. Even teachers will do that. But then when we need to go to the restricted section of the Library, suddenly the rules are in place again and you have to sneak around the librarian lest she tells on you to the headmaster. I just returned from butchering an entire village worth of dark wizards and I’m being threatened to be told on to the headmaster?This is the core of the problem, I believe. The gameplay systems are centered around chopping up powerful dark wizards for a regular Saturday morning exercise, but the game never acknowledges it is something a student should neither be capable of nor even attempt to do. So it doesn’t let me feel like a student, because I’m clearly more powerful and involved in dangerous stuff than a student should be, but it also doesn’t make me feel like a powerful wizard because Mrs. Scribner threatens to tell on me to the headmaster and I am supposed to take it as a serious consequence for my character. What am I supposed to feel while playing Hogwarts Legacy, then? I have no idea. So I just stopped caring. The game would be much better off if you played as an adult wizard instead of a student. But no, of course, the marketing team needs to make false promises about how this game will let you experience the joys of being a magic academy student. This is what the “Wizarding World” is about, right? This way we’ll be able to attract the core fanbase without actually making the game for them! The worst part about this is that they were right - just look at the number of positive reviews and concurrent players. They’ve played us for absolute fools!Now onto the “problems”. Many people have already stated them in other reviews. Technical issues on PC (although I, personally, don’t have many issues. The game plays at stable 60 fps for me on medium settings. On a laptop. But I digress), collection quests being the main thing you will do in the game, lack of expected features like Quidditch and so on. I don’t believe these are really all that important or take away from the game as much as the other problems I mentioned,  so I won’t focus on all that.My biggest gripe with the game aside from what I already stated above is its UI/UX and Inventory systems. They are a disaster. You’re being littered with pointless clothing items that don't have any differences between them aside from one stat number. And you get a new, slightly better item like every five minutes. So you’re forced to open inventory (which is not instant, you have to wait until the effects animation plays out) to change the item to get that 2 extra defense. Every five minutes. The “layer” setting that changes the items' looks only applies per item instead of overall. So you have to manually change the looks for every item you equip every time. Every five minutes. That is unless you prefer looking like a clown - in googly eyes glasses, a pointy hat, and a colorful star-riddled merlin-ish cloak. If you want to craft a potion, which you can only do in a specific location, you have to wait 15-to-90 seconds for the potion to finish cooking. There’s no way to make it brew faster. There’s no mini-game or anything. Just waiting. Oh, and you also can’t put several potions in a queue either. So you can’t dump ingredients for 10 potions at once and go explore to pick up all of them later. No, you have to craft one potion at a time and wait 15-to-90 seconds for it to finish so that you can brew another one. What a waste of time. One special type of cancer that is present in this game is the locking of quick bars behind the talent tree. You get more spells than your quick bar allows you to have already at 2-3 hours into the game, but the ability to unlock talents (and with them a second quick bar) only becomes available after 8-10 hours. And you can’t use spells without a quick bar, so you have to open a menu (and wait for the animations to play out. Again) every time you need to reassign Reparo to Lumos or whatever else is required for solving a puzzle. And you have to do it quite often.All of this disrupts the flow of the game. Instead of playing, enjoying the combat, or exploring you’re stuck dealing with slow menus. This review is written after I played for about 10 hours. That is what the game says in my save file. But you might notice that it says 17 hours on my steam profile. The additional 7 hours are most likely spent in these menus. Yeah, It really adds up.Overall, gameplay-wise, aside from the things I mentioned, it’s a pretty solid open-world RPG-like game. It’s neither better nor worse than any other open-world game available at the moment. It’s just the same as all of them. I will not try to evaluate if it's a good thing or a bad thing. It’s a matter of preference, I guess.  But the game has too many issues regardless so I wouldn’t recommend getting it at full price. Especially if you’re a Harry Potter fan who wants to “feel like a student at Hogwarts”. You won’t get this experience in this game.

author: Tenebres
review: I had high expectations and was curious on how the developers would implement gameplay into the world of wizards. However, the more I play this game, more disappointed I become. Review is not final as I'm yet to finish this game, I'll update it once I'm done with it. Now, let's begin.GOOD sides.1) Environment - very well re-created world of Hogwartz and its surroundings, beautiful landscapes, place is massive, enjoyable to explore. There's a certain focus of attention to details that's been put when creating locations, including funny scenes and moments like two statues slamming each other every time you pass them.2) Music - Love it. Gorgeous music (Except one in Hogsmeade), it perfectly transfers those vibes from HP1-2 games and movies. Very well done.That's really it, at least so far for me. Now, bad sides. There's plenty and I don't care about what others may say, it's my personal taste and belief.BAD sides.1) Boring premise of the main story - yet another "you're a wizard" moment where you're that rare kid with super powers that very few others have. I wish it was more grounded with you being a regular student who got him/herself into trouble with friends and now are trying to solve things you may have ruined to begin with. 2) "Loading doors" - they ruin immersion for me even if the game is installed on SSD but there are a few moments when I can't enter a different location for a few seconds as the location itself is being loaded and thus the door won't open right away. A minor annoyance. 3) Hogsmeade music.4) CHARACTERS. Oh god, why. Game is set in 1800s, it's pre-Victorian era. Yet we have characters from other, far away eastern or/and southern countries. Transgender characters. Lesbian characters. Etc, etc, etc. If you want to make a game that follows nowadays trends, do a setup in 2010s+ year, not in 1800s. Otherwise it completely obliterates all that magical charm that the environment tries to establish by having modern trends clash against it. Absolute waste.5) Cutscenes. Feels very rushed. Some cutscenes are short, some characters reply without any expression or care. Classes last for a few minutes and it's always you doing things. Learn a spell. Click click. Voila, class is over lads. It feels that devs put a lot of effort in re-creating the environment and then they were told: "Yo, you have 1 month to release the game". 6) RPG Elements. It's good to have a variety of items to wear but they also grant you offensive and defensive attributes which force you to constantly "upgrade" your gear. Not to mention that your inventory is limited to 20 items, which is very small. I'd rather have the game make us think and become creative with spells rather than "brute force" your enemies instead. Complete miss on this one imo.7) Camera angle central pivot point is too low. If you make a perfect horizontal view, it'll be on a belly level rather than shoulder level. So when you begin to look around, your own character takes plenty of screen space. 8) Some technical glitches with shading, texture buffering being too slow.9) My character loves to lock his head left or right when running around rather than look where he runs to.10) You have a large variety of spells but you can only have 4 active ones at the time with 1-2-3-4 keys and (at least) I haven't figured out how to add more to the active slots. 11) Whole UI feels like the game was designed for the consoles but was ported to PCs. It's not that bad but its that evident. 12) Population - while the game has day/night cycle, I don't see students & teachers going to their beds in the evening. Location "despawns" populus behind your back. You can be semi-afk staring at a beautiful painting playing a nice melody and suddenly, location is empty because its night. You look around once more, its full again as its morning. But you don't see them coming downstairs or upstairs, they just appear. Its this odd feeling when world is sort of alive but it isnt. Feels more like a checkbox to me at times.Review is yet to be updated once I'm fully done with the game.

author: Gedget
review: It might sound odd but this game helped put away my severe anxiety n depression, and bring out my inner child. I was giddy just exploring hogwarts and seeing all the little details in the castle.I want to thank the developers for making an amazing game and for me to feel like I'm exploring the world all over again. <3

author: Rythli
review: I'm satisfied with the game.  Within the first hour I witnessed a dragon merk someone, and got to hang with Fig Newtons.  Can't get any better than that.Or can it...?  As of a matter of fact it does.  The game does an excellent job easing you into the world.  Although the introductions can be understandable perceived as too slow for some people (the skill tree takes way too long to unlock in my opinion).  Once things begin to kick off it really does fulfill the genuine open world RPG experience even from the perspective of someone that isn't a huge Harry Potter fan.  The final product is certainly better than most Ubisoft titles (and it has achievements too.... look at that).Presentation is important which Hogwarts Legacy fully understands.  My only major complaint is PC performance occasionally stuttering - even after reducing settings to lowest.  Maybe it is my card (RTX 2060), but it does feel unoptimized in some areas of performance.  With that being said, I never felt like the game was "unplayable" due to those issues so hopefully it will improve with future driver updates.  I do think PC port performance criticisms are extremely valid, but the game is still designed well to be enjoyable despite these issues.I don't regret buying it at full price, but nothing wrong with waiting for a sale either.  Definitely earned my stamp of approval regardless.

author: Twitch.tv/Eros_Legacy
review: Hogwarts Legacy is an action role-playing game set in the 19th century before the events of the Harry Potter universe. The player takes on the role of a witch or wizard who uncovers a secret that could change everything in the wizarding world.As a Harry Potter fan, I was blown away by the game's impressive world which has an enormous map full of content to explore. The castle's design is stunning, with intricate details that make it feel authentic. Finding book pages with fun-facts about the world adds to the immersion.The gameplay is versatile, allowing you to choose between stealth or wand blasting to complete missions and points of interest. The combat is simple but can be overwhelming at times. However, the story feels a bit shallow, and your actions don't seem to have much impact on the world around you.Despite the minor flaw in the story, Hogwarts Legacy is an incredibly fun game that kept me entertained for over 100 hours. While it may not have much replay value, the game's price tag is worth it for the hours of entertainment it provides. I highly recommend picking up Hogwarts Legacy if you're a fan of open-world games or the Harry Potter franchise.

author: Von Adder
review: Difficult one to recommend. What small amount of time I have played I have enjoyed, but it's been painful. I have an RTX 2070 Super with all drivers etc up to date, and I have had lots of problems with slowdown, lag and freezing. The frame rate tanks into single figures at times. Graphic issues are also everywhere with pop ins and unloaded textures. I have tried every fix going at this time, and I had got the game into a somewhat playable state. But no more. There are people without issues it seems, but for the most of us, this game is badly un-optimised and needs more than a patch or two. Sadly I'm past the refund window, but I shall hold out and wait for official fixes as there is a lot of fun to be found here, just not today. Save your money and wait a while.

author: Kozzy
review: Played around 3 hours so far, its very well done.Check it out if you enjoy harry Potter OR if you just want a new open world rpg, that isn't just another 'ubisoft' style theme park with a million pointless markers all over. So far the story is good, combat is alot of fun and the graphics are great.Performance isn't to bad, could use a little more optimization but its not as bad as some have said. Mainly atleast for me it comes right as a cutscene starts or ends, rarely ever when I am actually playing.The voice work and music is also very well done, great animations, fun side quests, the puzzles are a blast and its fun to rip around flying with your broom! It's a wonderful game that is alot of fun to play.Thoughts After 10 Hours Now:Positives:- Graphics are great- Atmosphere is very well done- Game world is well crafted with lots to find for people exploring- Combat is a blast and way better than it has any right being, gets better as it goes to- Music is ace- Voice acting is good- Cutscenes are very well done- Animations are slick- Tons of side activities and side quests to do- Controls are good- Flying around is a blast!Negatives:- Performance could be a little better- The story is decent but not amazingGame is amazing and an early GOTY contender, check it out!Can't wait to play more, its an early GOTY contender just like Hi Fi Rush, what a start to 2023 for games, its only Feb and we have two wonderful ones so far, lets hope this continues for most the year :)**Beat the game, I would say it was a 8/10 for me, very good... went in hoping for 7/10, got a better game than I was expecting******The whole game was finished on the Steam Deck, it works great if you use Proton GE-49, turn in game FSR off (but on for steam deck), turn settings to Low but put Textures to Medium). I also have the Vram Fix and CryoUtilities Fix that I did for Midnight Sons, doing this will help on Hogwarts to****

author: The Fell Omen
review: I findmost of the entire game boring. im 10 hours in and im forcing myself all the way through since it was so expensive. Combat is fun at times, but all the loot you get is worthless, the talents are for the most part useless, and the entire game consists of constant, unnecessary, horrible dialogue. Instead of saying "that was some good flying" its 10 voice lines back to back complimenting eachother and talking about their broom for example, I could not care less. The classes are the same thing over and over throughout the whole game and the performance is horrible. The open world is empty and the enemy variety is nonexistent. Its nothing but a game to keep you occupied when you have nothing else to do. I wouldnt buy this unless it was 30$ and even then i'd be hesitant. Wayyyy overhyped, and i think that atleast half of the people saying the game is insane, is just saying it because of the controversy and because they dont want the twitter morons to win. In the beginning its fun but you soon realise that every mission is the same thing. Go from point A to point B while following an NPC that walks slower than your walking speed, sit through 2 minutes of dialogue, go into castle / cave and fight wizards / goblins, get 0 rewards except for the occasional spell you'll rarely use, sit through another 2 minutes of dialogue and tp back to hogwarts to repeat.Solid 6/10Enemy variety: 3/10World design: 10/10Combat: 8/10Graphics: 7/10Optimization: 0/10Immersiveness: 4/10Blue screen count: 4 (literally more in 24hrs than my whole life)Bugs: Beyond countingRandom fps drops: beyond countingNOT a bad game, but in its current state and price, you're better off playing the LEGO games.

author: GRIMM
review: Pros- Tons to do- Great variety in combat- Visually impressive- Overall great audio and sound mixingCons- Hogsmeade performance- No morality system- Lack of real interaction with random NPCs- Too many repeated lines by your characterTo see the full work in progress review, check here:

author: Robin
review: This is probably the final nail in the AAA games coffin for me. The first couple hours are fun and intruiging, as the world looks and feels magical and interesting, however after about 12-15 hours it becomes very boring and shallow and the lack of any real gameplay becomes apparent.You play as Mr or Ms. Ultimate Fashion Sense and Mary Sue (or male equivalent) of the game, who hasn't even attended any magic classes so far in their life, yet somehow excels at all them. No doubt thanks to the very many, and incredibly simple, button presses the players has them do. Somehow uncovering ancient secrets and riddles that are also in plain sight all around the map and require incredibly simple inputs to solve, yet somehow all the wizards and witches in all of history couldn't match the genius of this one 5th year student with no magical education. But hey, it gives the player something to grind at least.So as it turns out you're a master Stargazer/Beast Tamer/Grave Robber/Broom Flyer/ all without training. Also somehow a fighter of no match, seeing how you can single handedly walk into a camp full of grown poachers and dark wizards and kill them all without much issue. And of course, that's what 5th years students do in Hogwards, what could go wrong, right?While the combat is by far the most fleshed out system, even that one feels a bit wonky. First of all, you're limited to sets of 4 spells at once. You CAN switch to different sets of 4 spells any time, but the controls are a bit clumsy. You hold a shoulder button and at the same time press a face button to cast a spell (so far so good) or use shoulder plus  d-pad to switch sets (bit clumsy in the middle of hasted combat, but ok) but for defensive stuff you need to simply press a face button (and of course that overlaps with the attack buttons, except you gotta let go of the shoulder button that you've been holding down all this time). Also you can just shoot your wand with no particular spell by pressing the same shoulder button. So in reality it will often happen that you want to dodge but will instead cast spells and get hit, and you need quite some time to get used to the fact that the same button presses will be both block and attack, depending on the shoulder button. Not the worst system, but doesn't feel very fluent either. Enemy attacks however are also not that great, you will always get a warning "halo" around your characters head that's either yellow or red, depending if you can deflect the attack or need to dodge it. That's nice, as you will often get attack from off screen and couldn't see that otherwise. In practice that simply means you're gonna focus on your characters head for most of the combat and dodge whenever it lights up and them spam spells while it doesn't. While you also need to break through shields using different color coded spells that's about the extent of the depth the system has to offer, worse when there are multiple enemies and you need to try and target a specific one with a specific spell. All in all, combat, despite the range of spells, just never quite feels good.The story is actually quite interesting, however there's so much filler it's getting more and more a chore to press forward. One moment you're uncovering ancient magic or try and sniff out details of a major conspiracy, next you fly around popping balloons or looking for random puzzles in Hogwards. My guess is there's so little actual story they had to draw it out. Either way the pacing is terrible as a result and whenever you think it finally gets going it won't take long before the next stopper and filler period comes in.Graphically the game looks amazing of course. And I think that's pretty much what AAA games are these days, lots of people working and adding lots of shallow systems that look good and don't require much thought. There's tons of small stuff to grind on the map that give small incremental upgrades to your character or gear. Worst of all storage space for picking up gear. So often you're in a dungeon not even able to loot chests because storage is already full and you need to remember next time to go to a shop and sell all gear you don't wear, which takes also unnecessarily long time, requiring a 2 second button hold for each individual item. Yawn. Then there's capturing beasts (or rescuing them, since we're the good guys right?) so you can harvest their fur/feathers/etc so you can upgrade your gear or add magical enhancements. The adding magical enhancements is quite and interesting system as it at least isn't just a simple stat increase on one of the two stats you have (offense and defense. Very creative there) but the tedium surrounding it is annoying. You can also grow your own plants that you can then harvest to then make potions. All actions which have an actual ingame timer ranging from 30 seconds to grow a simple potion to 10 minutes to let stuff grow. The growing makes sense, but making 6 potions is basically just you standing there doing nothing for 3 minutes while a small animation plays out. yaaawwwwnn.Then of course there's the usual problem of animation want to look good and cool, but then sometimes it won't function property in actual gameplay because of terrain that's in the way or next to you etc. It feels like that's almost expected these days in titles such as this, so I guess everyone's used to it by now. Still disapointing.But hey, you get to press a simple input and watch a beautiful 3 second animation play out while grinding small incremental upgrades and isn't that what AAA gaming is all about?

author: DrUG...[D]e@LeR..!
review: This is actually a pretty good game and I'm leaving a negative review to highlight the worst thing about the game (not including performance issues) .Your choices don't matter and don't change the way other characters perceive you .You have the illusion of choice since whatever you say doesn't change anything about the story and all the side characters play no part at anything else , whether you have helped them or not .To summarize it's not a good immersive game when it comes to choices.The rest of the game is amazing and one of the best Open World out there .

author: Divaythmire
review: :  captures what  &  provided since 2001, and what  attempted within the mobile game limitation, and adds .  is .The story of  does not repeat the expected of the Wizarding World, but provides an addition to the lore by exploring Ancient Magic and an enemy from a different race, that many might have failed to ever see as a threat. That said,  by allowing you to comprehensively and exhaustively explore Hogwarts, Hogsmeade, and places beyond the two. After a balanced and pleasant character creation, sadly with a poor voice effect, in case you wish it higher or lower for your male character, you are set on an adventure, only after which are placed within one of the Hogwarts Houses (either by a quick quiz or manual selection). The rooms of the Hogwarts Houses represent their character ideally, making it difficult to satisfy yourself with a sole house alone, wanting you to explore others as well or replay the game differently.You are a student admitted later at Hogwarts, who has a lot to study to reach the level of their fellow students. Personally, I am not much of a fan of receiving special treatment from the professors, however, that comes with beneficial additions, such as a personal room, personal garden, and more; which is also beneficial for the gamers eager to explore this world. I would wish for more interactions during lessons, to really exhaust the desire of attending lessons at Hogwarts. The lessons could focus on a , which are such fun to use against foes.Lessons are a part of story or side quests, which overall does not seem overwhelming, as it is neither short, nor long (around 30 hours at a regular pace). Some side quests do feel like fillers, simply occurring to reference a subject of the Wizarding World without properly exploring it. Most of those quests provide choices, yet most have no meaningful results. However, there are some of , which many gamers within the Wizarding World shall use to satisfy their thirst for being a dark wizard. If you are like me, who does not wish to be a dark wizard, yet wants to explore the forbidden spells out of hunger for knowledge - you are able to.I heard much of , and failed to agree - until I acquired means of transportation, such as a broom. The transportation in  probably is one of the most satisfying I have had in my gaming experience, as you are able to fly over the world below you; you are, however, and hopefully temporarily, unable to look up or down during your transportation. . Aside the broom or beast, you have a convenient set of Floo Network to use as fast travel. I would urge the developers to add an interaction option with the Floo Flame, that automatically opens the map, and perhaps an animation after using it.The broom allowed me to witness the expansion of the world and see the possibilities it provides. Hogwarts was  from the developers; hiding endless secrets that at times either make me laugh (like slapping a flying key into the lock) or awe (such as guiding a moth to a mirror). Both . I would simply wish (beg, actually, if needed) the developers would add a .During your exploration most , memorable, my personal favourite being Dinah Hecat for now. The , yet often I found the non-story-related dialogue functioning as a filler, rather than otherwise. While cutscenes are watchable like a movie, it seems a bit inconvenient to be unable to pause the game during them (nature calls at most inconvenient times).The combat of  is exceedingly satisfactory. With a variety of spells to choose from - . Also inconveniently, you can not walk and cast at the same time, or smoothly vanish and proceed the walk or run (only after a short delay). However, the combat and explore system is rewarding and satisfying, alongside motivating. is the game many wanted since their childhood days. While having a fair share of fixes required, some I mentioned, some I did not, some I failed to detect - it is still a , and I can only hope to see this game improve and turn into a franchise. Also, just me, or the game somehow intensely reminds me of the , that I deeply adore

author: Woargh
review: Note, this review is written within the 72 hours early access and is from a person with very little knowledge about the Harry Potter universe. Therefore I might miss aspects of the game, that a fan would like/dislike.This game is incredible! Far beyond what I expected and I can't get enough! I've never personally seen a game with such wide variety of gameplay, done so well. You'll decorate large rooms and medows, catch magical beasts and care for them, grow plants and make potions, stealth your way into forbidden places and brutally hunt down goblins with your ancient magic. This is only the surface of the game and after 29 hours of gameplay, I haven't even seen half of the world yet.Controls feels great, its easy to change spells and the combat is very satisfying. You'll also encounter a large amount of different puzzles, all of which are very well done and generally easy to figure out. Running on ultra settings, graphics are amazing and the world itself is one of the most beautiful ones I've ever seen. The game needs a bit of optimization, but I haven't personally been effected by it beyond a couple of minor FPS drops. I'm sure a patch will be released soon, so I wouldn't worry about this, but do keep in mind, that this game currently is on the heavy side.This is the type of game I would recommend to everyone. You are sure to find something you'll love here and with the difficulty settings, you can either make this an effortless story or a challenging adventure.

author: Nikki
review: The game is well designed in the sense that the environment looks amazing. However, I was expecting this game to be a more "choose your own story" adventure game. I would've preferred if you started from year 1 in Hogwarts and could make something of yourself i.e, becoming a dark wizard or going into the ministry, your choice of ending. But this provides none of that. Instead, you are thrown into a set linear story path that you cannot divert from, the game isn't necessarily bad, but it is just a waste of opportunity and budget since I don't think another Harry Potter game that is as high quality will come along anytime soon. The graphics are absolutely beautiful to look at, and the cutscenes are well animated but I could not find myself actually getting into the story. I do not want to be special from the get-go, I wanted the game to give us that choice of whether we wanted to make something of ourselves or not.
