author: V
review: Buy 155 deluxe editions and support the dev's for their amazing hard work, i love this game more than i love breathing.... ♥ simple as that.

author: cl0ck&
review: This game has turned out to be a very shallow experience. It doesn't excel at anything it attempts, the story is mediocre with no emotional moments or pay-offs, the characters are uninteresting and as black and white as they can be, the story is very predictable. You have your typical villain and his lackeys, who are bad and yourself and your friends , who are jolly good. There is no depth to anyone. Your choices don't matter in the slightest, the only difference is you're either incredibly well mannered and compassionate, or slightly sassy. The open world is nice and shiny, but in a true Ubisoft fashion it is filled with countless repetitive, uninteresting tasks, which you have to do a hundred times over. Every 'treasure vault' is just a chest with a generic item. You sell 99 % of your items anyway, the tiers of equipment are useless, the mechanic of hidden attributes, which you have to uncover in the Room of requirement, is redundant. The lockpicking system is atrocious. The amount of craftable items is small and the game is easy enough to not really have a need of them anyway. Little events in the world such as a suit of armor destroying another one for humming happened every single time I went through the area. Because of that you can't appreciate it as a little secret/detail if you see it for the twentieth time. Facial animations are pretty bad. The puzzles are not diverse enough. Combat can be fun at times, but the variety of enemies is so small and they only have 1-3 attacks per enemy type. The order in which you do things doesn't influence any dialogue options, finding a fetch quest related item before accepting the quest isn't met with an alternative voice line 'Oh, I already found it', instead you have to go to the same place and pick the item up again to hand it over. The lack of thought that such situations could happen is what differentiates a great game from a bad one, it's all about the little details and they just couldn't pull it off here. Using unforgivable curses results in no consequences for you. Hogwarts legacy was all hype, it benefited greatly from nostalgia, but failed to deliver anything but a mediocre and forgettable experience, which offers zero incentive for a second playthrough.

author: GIAMarcos
review: I guess it is ok. I both love it and hate it as a HP fan. Probably would have recomended it if it didn't crash every 4-30 minutes now. The first ~9 hours were fine, but now it crashes a lot. It feels like it wants to do the world justice, which it does in a lot of cases. But it absolutely doesn't in others.As said by others you don't feel like a Hogwarts student at all. Lessons are very much on the sideline, and only done to get access to some spells and potions. The 'Forbidden Forest' is forbidden, but for some reason you can just go wander into it without any problems. You just have to deal with some spiders and poachers from time to time. The world is gorgeous and Hogwarts itself is massive and you can really get lost there (if you dont use the quest tracker).At the same time it, Hogwarts and to a lesser extend the rest of the world, feels very empty. Yes there are other students and Peeves is doing his usual business but you can barely interact with it. Most of the interaction is meaningless and does not recieve any reaction from others in the same room. You can blast a firespell into a group of students and nothing happens. This makes the game really feel 'on rails'. In the 'Forbidden Forest' you encounter a lot of creatures who do not react to your presence at all! Yesterday I strolled passed a group of Centaurs and they didn't seem to notice me at all. The stuff that is there is very polished and works very well. The combat is fun and engaging. But after a while the things that you cannot do start to bother you. For instance, you can't jump over the railing of a staircase, there are invisible walls everywhere. What year is this? Let me fall to my death by jumping over a railing if I want to. Or at least make the wall look like it is some magic barrier, as if it is a magic protection. Now it just feels lazy.The RPG aspects are a bit shallow (maybe I am spoiled by Skyrim). I don't feel like I have a lot of choice in how to build my character. The gear feels very generic, the talents don't feel like impactfull choices. Just pick the talents for the spells that you use because it straight up upgrades them. I wish the options for combat were more varried. Now it is basically just blast spells. I think a lot more could have been done with potions, herbology, conjuration, transfiguration etc.The more I am thinking about it the more flaws I start to see. I am starting to sound like a salty old man (probably not too far from the truth ;)). But it feels like a game with so much wasted potential! Would probably be a 6.5/10 for me if it wasn't for all the crashes.

author: Superbm
review: i played the game and got harassed :(

author: Nigel Ketchum
review: This is a fun game. I was blown away when I first saw Hogwarts and how insanely detailed and alive it felt. The combat was challenging and very fun with the limited spells that I knew early on. After a few hours of exploring I found that while the castle and surrounding area are very vibrant and alive, there is zero immersion. You're not a Hogwarts student, you're a protagonist who lives in a talking castle. You don't get to actually do anything in the castle. You can't sit at your house table and eat breakfast in the great hall. You don't receive/lose house points for anything. You don't get to participate in any classes, instead you watch a cutscene and get some random quest, which will reward you with a spell. You can't PLAY QUIDDITCH. Every character in the game talks ♥♥♥♥ about the headmaster for not letting them play quidditch because Avalanche even knows that it should already be in the game. Why do you start as a fifth-year? Imagine getting a game like this with seven years of being a Hogwarts student. Instead you're a fifth year and that year never ends, you just stop going to classes.The end of the game was the most disappointing for two reasons.1. As I got towards the end of the game I started to get excited again because all of the quests are preparing you for and leading to your O.W.L.'s. I thought at least I'll get to do this interactive quest to test my knowledge of the HP universe and of the game that I just spent 70 hours on. It's a cutscene. And your character isn't even in it. You don't get grades. All it means is that there are only side quests left to do. 2. All of your choices leading up to the ending mean nothing. It doesn't matter if you learned unforgivable curses and tortured people in front of your teacher, or if you refused to learn any dark magic. You just pick which ending you want and watch a cutscene. If you pick the "bad" ending there are no consequences and nobody knows that you made that choice. Maybe my expectations were too high. I'm a massive Harry Potter fan. I listen to the audiobooks when I drive, when I'm falling asleep, when I'm walking my dog, all the time. I've read/listened to the books at least 15 times but I honestly don't know how many its been at this point. I understand why so many people absolutely love this game because it is fun, but it's lacking so much that I don't think I'll be able to force myself into playing again just to see a different common room.

author: Colonel Patrick Sanders
review: Hogwarts Legacy… Where to start? As one of many it has always been my dream to get a good Wizarding World game. I'm a huge fan of the Wizarding World and Harry Potter. From the books, to the movies and everything around it. And with a smile on my face I can say, this game does not disappoint.I went into the game with little expectations, but was pleasantly surprised. Is it perfect? Well no, but it’s everything I ever wanted from a Wizarding World game. Let’s first dive into the good stuff. The best part of this game is easily the world, and most importantly Hogwarts and Hogsmeade. Both are filled with details, things to explore and references to the movies and books. Of the whole world, Hogwarts itself is easily the best. I even dare to say it’s one off, if not the best location ever made in a video game. Everything is just right. It is full of secrets, puzzles, lore, details and things to explore, it’s correct in comparison to the movies and books and it feels alive. It’s just.. Perfect. The beautifully crafted world, together with great graphics and excellent sound design made exploring everything a joy. One of the games where I did not use fast travel the whole time. I would also like to give a little shout out to the devs for introducing seasonal changes. There’s not many Single player games out there that change the ambiance and decoration of the world based on the season.What the game also does right, is distributing content evenly across the length of the campaign/game. Even 20 hours into the game you’re still unlocking new mechanics, spells and locations. This made it not too overwhelming and constantly gave me a feeling there was still so much to do and dive into. I was also pleasantly surprised by how deep some of these (side)mechanics are. Even stuff that can be ignored completely like potion brewing, beast taming etc can go quite in depth.Combat is also much better than I expected. It never becomes repetitive, is challenging at times and enemies having various shields that need to be broken by specific types of spells, together with the player constantly learning new spells keeps it fresh.I’m also really happy they decided to put in something for everyone. From exploration to combat to flying on your broom to beast taming, to potion brewing and even building your room of requirement and various puzzles. There’s something for everyone to like.Now on to the less good points. The main story is rather weak if you ask me. Some side quests/stories are more interesting then the main story itself, and personally for me it just didn’t click. The missions you do are fun, and the locations you visit are great but the overarching story just didn’t do it to me. I also had trouble fitting it in the Wizarding World because the whole plot around which the story revolves has never been mentioned in any of the books/movies or whatever, and the way it’s proposed here, makes me feel it’s important and special enough to have been mentioned.As I said before, the world itself is well-made and fun to explore, and there is something to see around every corner, but for people who don’t care about 100% completion a big part of it is not interesting at all. I personally think they did well by introducing various puzzles, chests and enemy camps around the map. They don’t feel as repetitive as some other open world games, but in the end it is filler content. They should’ve made the main story take place a bit more around the map, but instead it was rather focussed on certain area’s.Also performance is, at the moment of writing, unstable on PC. I have a high end PC, and even though I run the game on 140fps+ most of the time, at times I get frame drops to like 20fps. Especially during combat this is really annoying and it breaks the immersion while exploring.I do think that if you strip the Wizarding World setting from the game, it’s still a good game, but nothing to write home about and in certain aspects quite average. The wizarding world setting and the attention to detail really is what makes this game.Overall, I would highly recommend this game. It’s not perfect but I think that everyone that even remotely likes the wizarding world/harry potter universe will absolutely love this game. Whether you’re a die hard fan, or just like the movies, you will love the references and attention to detail. The world they created, and especially Hogwarts and Hogsmeade are absolutely mind-blowing and set a new bar for developers.

author: Sephiroth
review: Great idea - bad implementation.Pre-ordered this, deluxe edition an all. Game comes out, terrible performance despite my machine vastly exceeding the requirements. Horrible FPS in hallways in the school and just about every cut scene no matter if the graphics are set to Ultra or Minimum. Can't play so I wait. Devs patch the game saying performance should be better. I load the game back up, issues still present. I quit the game. And wait some more. Another patch - performance issues supposedly patched again. Load the game back up once more....still the same issues. I'm done. I returned this game for a full refund. 0/10. I'm not playing this game with the devs.

author: Infected Ronin
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a MEH game.You want to play a brave Gryffindor, or like me a Slytherin prick? Sure. But it doesn't matter.Choices don't matter in this game. No matter your decisions, the story will unfold the very same way.I guess it would cost too much money to make a story with differents scenario paths based on the house and the choices.So this game has ZERO replay value.Yet the devs made one achievement per house, for reaching a certain point in the game.The Toast of the TownThe Auror's ApprenticeThe Gryffindor in the GraveyardThe Wise OwlThose are 4 Pointless achievements. Devs should have made 1 achievement instead, period.The Alohomora spell is the most tedious thing I have to deal with.Why do I have to deal with this boring mini game for each lock?The tutorial is poorly made, Streamers and I struggled to get the gist of it.It's just an infinite repeat of a big SIGH, I wish you could just disable the mini game, and not waste 1mn each time you have to unlock one of the innumerable locked doors in this game.Do I recommend this game? MEH.Game is good. Fighting is great. Flying is AWESOME!But it feels unfinished.Karma feature, multiple ending based on choices would have made Hogwarts Legacy Game of the year 2023.But you will get the same story, no matter your house, no matter, your choice.So I guess you could say, you decide if I recommend this game or not.

author: Zonnyzone96
review: It's such a great game to play. I've always been excited for a game centered around magic and spells and this game over delivered in every way. The open world, stories and characters got me fully immersed I didn't even know I had been playing for 7 hours straight

author: Someone
review: The type of game that makes you wish you have no obligations or responsibilities so you can just explore, fly, practice magic, and roam the beautiful magical world of Hogwarts and it's surroundings, willingly wanting to spend hours, not turning the music off because you don't want to miss a single effect. everything works for the advantage of the game. the developer took the idea and ran with it in a good way. the stuttering is unfortunately real and painful but I hope it get fixed soon.Looking forward for a sequel.

author: Scardigne
review: PLUG -MOD TO CHANGE TRANS BARMAID TO A MALE - Currently working on a new nexus mod to change the trans barmaid to a male which will be found on the nexus within a weeks time.Don't worry, your kind gestures and awards are saifu with me, I have 21 years in the game design art industry and would love to know your thoughts, as always hope you enjoy the rest of my published mods and I hope you all look forward to the future hogwarts mods.REVIEW -There's still a Potter-esque main story of universe-shaking stakes (one which your fully customisable transfer student inevitably finds themselves at the centre of) but, in a game with over 100 sidequests and dozens more leisurely pastimes, Legacy shines brightest when it leans into emulating the complete Hogwarts experience, sorting hat and all.That's largely thanks to the clear affection (and budget) which Avalanche has poured into its creation of the game's open world, which includes the entire school grounds and surrounding areas such as Hogsmeade and the Forbidden Forest. Whether travelling by foot, broomstick, or Hippogriff, Hogwarts Legacy is an indulgent treat of fantastical tourism for longtime Potterheads, marred only by occasional loading stutters and texture pop-ins that can snap you out of its immersive spell.Much of that fan service will inevitably be lost on series newcomers, of course, but even for those less versed in the wizarding world, Hogwarts Legacy has something to offer. Combat, in particular, successfully adapts the source material's spellcasting into a satisfying battle system that's as much a challenge to your reflexes and tactical skills as it is a spectacle of particle effects and flurrying physics.With over two dozen spells to learn, alongside more advanced actions such as parries and combos, it can be a little overwhelming at first, but – once mastered – Hogwarts Legacy's magical melees showcase both the brutality and the sophistication of wand warfare in a way that the films or books never quite could.This combat pairs nicely with the game’s role-playing progression systems, too, which allow your character to continually evolve across the hundreds of hours you could potentially spend navigating its world. Avalanche generously hands out rewards for your time at Hogwarts, no matter where you might decide to spend it, with a near endless bounty of cosmetic items, talent points, spells, and more to unlock throughout your excursions, both scholarly or otherwise.Not all of this loot holds equal weight or utility, but thankfully it's not the only carrot on the stick to keep you enrolled. The school is nothing without its inhabitants, and the class of 1890 are a rather brilliant bunch, its many pupils a pleasure to spend time with alongside the equally endearing faculty members. Charismatic teachers, such as the scene-stealing charms expert Professor Ronen, will keep you coming back to classes to learn, and there are plenty of other enigmatic figures to encounter, both within the depths of the school's many secret areas and beyond.Voice acting can be a little iffy in places (the male avatar, in particular, comes across as a strange mix of wooden and incredibly posh), and the dialogue doesn't always land — too often dumping lore on the player with reams of exposition — but these blind spots tend to be the exception, rather than the rule. On the flipside, Simon Pegg chews the scenery as uppity Headmaster Phineas Nigellus Black, and the game's soundtrack is fantastic, building off and around John Williams' iconic score rather than overly exploiting it.More broadly, however, Hogwarts Legacy also falls into the same traps as many other big budget, open-world games of its type. With so many avenues for progression, the game can frequently overburden players with convoluted menu management work, as they become weighed down by multiple resource types that bloat out and needlessly complicate the experience.Equally, in a world this big, not every activity feels either important or enjoyable, and there are many spaces that feel unoccupied and lifeless, there for the sake of it rather than to provide any lasting value beyond the surface. Established fans will likely be willing to forgive these more prosaic features, but others may instead come away with the impression of a compromised game not quite able to hold up to the promise of its own ambition.Still, there were plenty of ways in which Hogwarts Legacy could have really botched the spell of delivering on an authentic wizarding power fantasy, especially one burdened by decades of expectations. Thankfully, by resisting the temptations of the live service model (or perhaps avoiding the cautionary tale set by 2020's Marvel's Avengers), Avalanche has conjured up a vision of Hogwarts that – for the most part – looks and feels worthy of its namesake.There may be tension at the seams where it tries to hold the sheer scope of its aspirations together, and its fan service can only do so much to patch over those gaps, but Hogwarts Legacy nonetheless succeeds as an easy – if uneven – time killer. Whether this is your first time to Hogwarts, then, or you already know the way from the Common Room to the Library like the back of your hand, Legacy offers a generous slice of role-playing escapism, not to mention a viable remedy for shaking off those late stage Winter blues.

author: -Yarko
review: This is exactly what we have all been waiting for so long! Rejoice, fans of the Harry Potter universe and welcome to Hogwarts!I've purchased a Deluxe edition, so I had time to evaluate the game from many sides, run around the world, swim in the lake, collect jumping mushrooms, visit battles and start studying dark magic while many were waiting for the official release of the game. - it is incomparable here. Living leaves, grass, living surroundings, waves, paintings. Absolutely everything that caught my eye caused genuine delight. - it's just off the scale! I feel through the screen as if I really am a Hogwarts student. This is one of the few games where I listen to all the conversations of the characters, even if they are talking to each other and not to me. I look at the room, at the team of my faculty, at the world around me and I am absorbed. I didn't have such excitement about games after I passed The Witcher 3.When I'm playing, I want to play even more. "No sleep, I have to see that village over there," and it's every time.The game absorbs, the game captures, the game gives you more and more new each time.  - with animation, of course, they tried. There is a lot of it! Moving chess, paintings (moving not only frames, but also images in them), foliage, grass, clothes. All elements have animation and physics. - let me just say that they delight me. I am amazed and in love. - you know, it's like plunging into real life, where you really do some important things, and not just running around in the form of: find and bring. Everything makes sense here. At least the main quests. They immerse you in the story without any problems, It tells you what is happening and what is needed from you.  - I got the impression that a real person, not a bot, is giving me a task. In conversations with NPCs, you can see their enthusiasm, anxiety, excitement, interest. I would even say that the NPCs here are like real people, yeah, they just perform their algorithm and will not do what you want. Otherwise, they behave like real players. - impressed. I thought for a long time and imagined how it would be implemented. It turned out that it was beyond praise. Again, I will say about the Witcher 3. Very similar emotions from the battle scenes. Spell combinations - you can choose your style of play: go ahead, or act covertly (as far as possible). - A huge number of skins and visual for the main character.• We have been waiting for this game for a very long time• Sometimes the game crashes without any errors. The picture just freezes and that's it, Crashed.Honestly, guys, I'm holding back a lot right now not to reveal all the cards about the game. Among my friends there are both fans of the Harry Potter universe and those who don't like this universe. But I haven't heard from any friend yet that he didn't like the game. We all bought a Deluxe edition and we all have similar emotions. Everyone is delighted.If in doubt about the purchase: watch videos or streams to get an idea.Most likely, I will add some new words in my review when I complete the game by 100%Hello to all Slytherins!

author: General-Mosquito-Spray
review: Absolutely incredible game. Would like to see the game optimized better but to say that the game is unplayable is simply a lie. Running a 3080ti and Im running the game at true 1440p and everything set to ultra and im averaging 60 fps in asset heavy areas. In caves or when Im exploring i get about 100. I was running the game at about 30 to 40 frames with ray tracing on at ultra and at the same settings so I suggest keeping that off. I see frame drops in demanding areas or when loading in a completely new area. People saying this game is literally unplayable are full of it. Unless youre someone that can only play a game at 100+ fps and must play at 4k with everything maxed out with ray tracing on. This is easily one of the best games Ive played in a long while. Theres so much to do and there is so much detail that was put into this game its crazy. Already invested 14 hours into the game and Ive still barely scratched the surface of the story. Highly recommend this game especially if youre a fan of the Harry Potter series. Im not a fanatic by any means but I seeing familiar faces and just seeing parts of the world that was in the films was really fun.

author: Aamta

author: friendlydogguy
review: Game tries to be everything, makes it inconsistent in storytelling and railroads the player. If you wanted to be a Hogwarts student this isn't the game, if you wanted to be a powerful wizard this isn't the game. You're constantly pancaked between being a student subject to your teacher's wrath and killing hordes of evil wizards. This constant flipping makes all characters seem inconsistent and poorly written. Pairing with the fact that even some of the cool sounding quests are ruined by their streamlining. The secret wizard dueling club is just 1v2->1v3->1v4 to winning the tournament! The exploring an old shipwreck to recover someone's family heirloom is swimming out into the water and pressing F over bubbles until you find it. The game's boring, and I don't recommend it at it's current price.

author: ◄ Mystics ►
review: At first i didn't love it, some small quests annoyed me and combat is so diffrerent that i'm used to. After a few hours tho i began to like it more and more. Now i have over 60 hours and surely appreciate all the things in game. No worried to finish it soon, i think it might take 70 hours to just get main quest, but then there are so many places to visit and loot, so many achievments. I'm impressed with combat and side quests It's a really great game, some people might think of it as improved Skyrim with the best magic and flying. 10/10

author: Tsuna
review: I know I was sorted into Hufflepuff. But why is that I make so many Slytherin choices? It has an intense and complex ability talent system. It actually respects it's source material. Given it's massive open world, the astonishing level of detail put into every single asset and animation is truly out of this world. The best part is that if you do see a glitch, you might not know if it's just magic doing it's thing. There are a few performance problems that need to be addressed. But at this point it's to be expected with  any major AAA releases like this. As a big fan of the Harry Potter universe, I can't say enough how this game brings to life my childhood dreams of finally getting accepted into Hogwarts and live in a world full of magic.Regarding the drama and the controversy surrounding this game... I just don't care. :)

author: RavenMad13
review: First, I’ve been truant a lot.  In fact, I haven’t been back to the castle in probably a month of in game time and no one is looking for me.  I don’t have to sneak out, I can wonder all hours of the night, no howlers saying get your butt back to class, and not even my friends are looking for me.  No one misses me at school when I’m meandering the countryside for days on end looking for landing platforms and astronomy tables.  Where is the struggle?  I should have to sneak past prefects and use hidden exits in order to leave the castle at night but alas, those only happen on main quest missions.  Other than that, it’s a free for all.  Second, okay developers what is up with the shadows going crazy all the time.  I have tried playing with all the settings but about an hour after playing the shadows and image layering go haywire.  I have played with settings and everything else, but still weird shadows.  Then I go from human to automaton vocally.  I chose the lower pitch male voice and randomly I sound like a robot.  To fix any of these things I have to completely close out the game and reboot.  Third, there are lots of things to do and at first I was stoked at all the content, but then…I was bored.  It feels like busy work.  There are 3-4 cave designs so once you’ve been down a couple you have been down them all and for very little gain as the gear doesn’t scale to your current level.  Merlin must not have been a clever man because the only challenging puzzle is the cube flipendo one that is more annoying than difficult.  Fourth, poachers and poaching.  So, I can capture a handful of magical creatures so I can harvest their fur, whiskers, and warts to upgrade my gear.  Other than the fact I’m not killing them, am I really any better holding them hostage in my only little menagerie?  I can also breed them and sell them to collectors isn’t that nice?  I must spend 15 minutes grooming and feeding these beasts to get materials which again feels like busy work.  I hate Farmville like timed elements.  Really, if they are giving me a house elf that I can’t free then maybe he should be doing all the feeding and caring and then once a day I can collect the materials from a box?  Then potions, honestly the only one I use is the health potion, because the battles are over before I have exhausted all my spells let alone pulling out a thunder brew.  If I can’t sell potions, then having my own greenhouse in the room of requirement is a waste of time, because I can find all the health potions I need in the world.Fifth, the little things.  I liked having to smack the wings off a key, but I didn’t like after finding everything it was an item that was far below my level so all I really get is a skin.  The prize must match the effort developers.  Scale the gear to level please!  So, here you are walking around at a normal pace in Hogsmeade listening to the sights and sounds enjoying the ambiance, I breeze into the tomes store and wham, I’m now walking like I’m thigh high in the swamps of sadness.  Developers, this is an unnecessary mechanic.  Keep the walking pace the same!  Conversation pace, I wish there was a 2x button because the dialog is slow.  I want to feel engaged enough to listen to their whole rants, but if my eyes can read faster then the pace of the dialog it’s a skip for me.  Speaking of dialog, I would have liked voices that are distinctly goblin and voices that are distinctly dark wizard.  They have variety with so many areas could they have had a distinction with those voices.  No need for a killing curse, because in the end they all die and disappear without ever having to use the killing curse.  If they disappear, they are dead in my book.  Lastly, brooms need stats.  I can’t tell the difference from one to the next, please tell me stats on brooms and why I should bother spending 5k on a broom.In conclusion, not quite sure this game was worth the price for pre-order as I never use my griffin to fly anywhere when a broom works just fine, I think I could have waited until the game was $30.  I wanted to love this game after reading all the books and watching the movies multiple times.  Yet, the more I played the more I became bored.  The side quests of caves, trials, and whatnot all became repetitive and the prizes really didn’t feel worth the effort.  The crafting elements felt unnecessary and I’m a person whose spend 800 hours building settlements in Fallout, so I LOVE building, but I was disinterested in the building mechanics in this game.  The potion crafting felt unnecessary, the beast collecting was another time waster but unfortunately necessary for materials to upgrade.  A game shouldn’t feel like a slog or like work.  I feel this game put in size to make it bigger but, it’s just a lot of time wasting vs. being engaging.Games are meant to be fun or at least have me feeling vested.  The only thing holding me to finish is the fact I paid money for the game.  I don’t even feel a need to do another play-through.  So note to future players, pick the house you want and play how you really want at the beginning because it makes little difference.  You can YouTube all the different endings without the tedium.

author: Amiga500
review: Let me begin with the fact that I am not a Harry Potter fan. I did not read the books,  I watched the first movies 20 years ago because my girlfriend back then wanted to watch them. I did not care much. I dont remember both, neither the movies nor my ex gf.So I started Hogwarts Legacy and expecteded an average and typical open world game - just embedded into the Potter Lore with some neat stuff and NPCs and the typical quest structure.However, after playing the last days and only having finished the first parts I must admit that Hogwarts Legacy gave me RDR2, Skyrim and Deus Ex flashbacks.I did not anticipate having that much fun.Hogwards Legacy is an extraordinary game with astonishing love to details and so much passion. It is a great open world game, the scale sets the bar for immersion and atmosphere really high. I hope Ubisoft takes notes.Why or how is is so great: It is the exploration, the mechanics and how you interact with everything.The sense of wonder, the pure giddy joy that I get with each and every new quest and location, the choice of which activity I want to spend my current gaming session with, the view, the environment, the scale of this game, everything is so well done. The music fits, the sound fits, the fights are a mix of tactical approaches and pure chaos, I love it. The whole ambiente feels organic, it is an audiovisual masterpiece.All quests and storylines feel good and motivate to explore.  I never really get too invested in the story of a game, unless it's exceptional.And yes Hogwarts Legacy does not invent gaming new or again, but it was is exceptional enough in many segments that I find the story and characters interesting and I get dragged into this world.The last years I didn't think I could feel like this exitement and joy about games anymore, but Hogwarts Legacy has well and truly proven me wrong. Thank you Avalanche, Hogwarts Legacy is proof that games are indeed a work of art.It is a game about "magic" that feels magic in so many moments and left me in awe.This is now a 9 of 10 for me and a must buy and must play for Harry Potter fans. Some criticism:- The inventory management is not good.- Most of the time it runs buttersmooth, but in some areas and moments the fps go wild, I get everything from 120 Ultra Raytracing fps down to 50- despite the amazing world and ambiente you have to do the typical fetch and do this and that quests. Hogwarts Legacy uses the established recipe of open world "go walk and work" quests, so do not expect wonders here game design wise.

author: ♥ Mrs.Femmie ♥
review: After completing the main Storyline, Completing all the sidequests and being at 90% completion of the Field Guide. Time to write my review:I'm no Fan of the Harry Potter movies/Books, maybe only watched the movies once or twice.This game was a blast! I had almost the same experience as Elden Ring last year. This game felt like Elden Ring's Little sister and i loved it!Part of me wished there was no ending to this game. Because when i finished the main story i felt hollow inside knowing that the end was near. I Wanna keep playing this game, but with almost the Field Guide at 100% there's gonna be barely anything left to do then do Battle Arenas or raid Bandit camps over n' over. It is to early to ask already for DLCs,I Know Avalanche Software said that there are no plans atm for DLCs, but i atleast hope that the rumors and leaks of POTENTIAL DLCs for Quidditch and a Rumored Missing-Quarter of the map are true.This game is gorgeous and it be a waste to leave this game as it is now without DLCs.- The Combat is really well done- The Character customization is Decent- The amount of Freedom in this game is amazing!- The Outfits and enhancements are neat.I hope for DLCs in the FUTURE!

author: Vandy
review: As a person who never read a Harry Potter book or seen any of the movies I recommend this title. The game is very welcoming to anyone, familiar or not familiar with the series.It has everything an RPG title has: collectables, leveling, gear, stats, etc. So far I really enjoyed the gameplay!

author: PoopLordAlmighty
review: To be honest I am am over all pretty disappointed. Just to put things in perspective, most of us have been waiting for a game like this for a really long time. Open world Harry Potter/Hogwarts game. So I feel like anyone could have came along and produced that game with modern day graphics and we would have been happy regardless. I feel like thats what this is, its really just a sub par story, sub par game, sub par combat, sub par puzzles, with some Harry Potter lore sprinkled on top. I got excited and hoped that maybe I could play out a Dark wizard story line, well this is not that kind of RPG. Its very linear, even if you use dark magic and unforgivable curses it doesn't alter the story at all. Your characters demeanor never changes, he always resembles some soft sensitive, harry potter wanna be student. One moment im using the killing curse, the next moment I am politely accepting a quest to help someone find their lost rabbit. IDK man I just feel like this could have been done so much better. I think the idea of starting as a 5 year was a poor choice, I think basically just stealing the world of hogwarts and then creating some bs story that has nothing to do with Harry was a poor choice. Yea Idk, i was waiting for this game for a long time, overall just pretty disappointed.

review: I am not a Harry Potter fan but this game has me hooked, I can now see that this is how Harry Potter fans feel about their beloved universe.Not once have I felt it a chore to do a quest or whatever, everything I am doing in this game is fun to do, the world is insanely beautiful and animations are very well done then there is combat.To be honest the Devs nailed it, the combat system is awesome it has style and flair is challenging (on the higher difficulties) just having so much fun with this game.To those Harry Potter fans I believe this is the game you have been waiting for, do not let anyone stop you from playing this you may just miss out on the experience you've been waiting all these years for.

author: H. Grypus
review: I finished the main story of Hogwarts Legacy last night, and wanted to finish it before providing my thoughts.  So, without further adieu, as for as AAA games goes, this one takes the cake (and eats it too).  Most AAA titles have been very disappointing, or lack luster.  They don't try new things, and I think HL sets a standard for that in the gaming community.Story: I loved it.  You're a student, and they don't just "forget" that fact and send you on a journey.  From classess, classmates, professors, and nearby villager problems, the game does a great job in melding and cohesively briing together a world.  Side quests, and companion quests also directly link to the main story, usually, in some way or another, and even those that don't, aren't necessarily bad.Side Quests: On the topic of side quests, thank goodness, there are not 7281 fetch quests.  Sometimes games, especially AAA games, fall into this rabbit hole of "more is better" and HL doesn't.  It spreads the quests out, and most usually have a unique story, or something driving them.  Sure, theres a fetch quest, but they aren't all the same *cough cyberpunk cough*.Side "missions": These are where HL lets us down.  Merlin trials, cairns, popping balloons, these are tedious, and unnecessary.  I'd rather half or even 1/3 of the Merlin trials, with actual complex puzzles.  Do better.Characters: Lovely, just lovely.  Each with a distinct personality, even side characters you meet once or twice are just full of life and vigor.  Love it.  There is one companion who gets shafted, I won't say who, but unfortunate.World: $%^# yes, its beautifully designed, flying is MAGICAL, and I truly mean that.  Magical beasts, plants, its all great.  Even decorating your rooms, the amount of features is astounding.Enemies/combat: While there are few enemies, each enemy has really neat interactions, if you're willing to learn them.  Specific spells that affect them, and ways to disable or deal massive damage.  This, along with the general combat, is fantastic.  More variety would be nice, but I do prefer less variety and quality and I think they made the right choice here.Overall, there are some improvements, but not many to say about this game.  I will, very briefly touch on the controversy and negative comments surrounding this game - don't be a bully and don't harass people and pretend you are better person for it.  Education, awareness, and joining local initiatives helps a lot more than hating someone for playing a game.  Do better.

author: Sephorium
review: This game is incredible! The attention that has been paid to every little detail, the graphics are stunning and the gameplay and combat is phenominal.Pros:- The common rooms are STUNNING, the Hufflepuff common room is my favourite it's so earthy, cozy, hobbity and full of plants! The Slytherin common room is lavish and ornate, a bit cold feeling but beautiful. You can even see the kraken in the lake through the underwater windows sometimes.- There's actually so much space to travel, the area surrounding Hogwarts is all open to fly to and filled to the brim with things to do, Merlin trials, dungeons, chests, secrets.- The entire castle is absolutely gorgeous, the textures of the materials used are also amazing, granite, gold, wood. Incredibly lavish and intricate. - The room of requirement is highly customizable, even down to the ambience of the room, dark and gloomy, bright and cozy.- There is full trasmog built into the game, you keep the appearance of anything picked up and can change the look of any item equipped, for free, at any point. Also the uniform options look awesome.- I wasn't sure how the combat would turn out but it's actually SO GOOD! And the talents you unlock later really make you feel so powerful!Cons: (most are super minor!)- There's some issues with performance but there are fixes out there that work and my game is incredibly stable after them.- You don't really have much reason to go back to the common room, you can't sit on the chairs or sleep to pass time.- Some voice lines are reapeated too often, like the floo network lady and Deek. Like I'm glad you're proud of me but you don't need to tell me 50 times a day you wholesome bugger.9.5/10 childhood dreams come true and absolutely worth the price!

author: John McClane
review: the game is just fun. super atmospheric and actually everything i wished =) . NO Quidditch tho !!!!!! =(

author: Echelonia
review: I'm really impressed by this game. I was hoping for a nice open world game and to feel the magic vibes of the Harry Potter universe - but the game is better than I ever thought it would be. I NEVER had perfomance issues and my PC is not even that good tbh ^^ No lags, no freezes. The game looks beautiful and is full of details. It really feels magic and overwhelming on some points. The soundtrack is brilliant! I played the game in German and the translation was perfect. The voice actors did a good job I think :) After around 50 hours in the game I finished the main story line (I did some sidequest in that time, too) and I still have around 40% of sidequests, secrets and so on left to do. Also I think I have to play the story again, at least once more.If you like Harry Potter or the Harry Potter universe, magic, beautiful landscapes, a nice soundtrack and want to play an open world game - this is for you :)

author: Cooly
review: This game is an absolute must for everyone, regardless of whether you know the harry potter universe or not. Everything is excellently worked out in visual and audio areas, good storyline, plenty of options for questing, exploring and decorating, you have flying mounts, puzzles for enthusiasts, plenty of challenge during combat and also provides a lot of fun and playing time.I simply can't think of anything as far as I know why this game wouldn't be worth it. I personally have not encountered any bugs so far, have not experienced any crashes, had some problems with the frame rate in the beginning but not disturbing (disabling ray-tracking was the solution for me) but there will undoubtedly be a fix soon enough update/fix coming soon. The creators of the game are aware of this. In short, wave that magic wand folks and get this game!

author: meow
review: Edit: Der Patch vom 14.02. hat die Ruckler bei hohen Einstellungen behoben. Ultra ist leider weiterhin nicht einwandfrei spielbar, obwohl es das laut den aktuellen Systemempfehlungen sein sollte.Bis zur Ankunft in Hogwarts konnte ich problemlos auf Ultra mit Raytracing spielen. Seit der Ankunft in Hogwarts ruckelt es mal mehr, mal weniger vor sich hin. Besonders betroffen sind hierbei Hogwarts und Hogsmeade. Unabhängig ob es an Denuvo oder der Programmierung liegt hoffe ich auf einen zeitnahen Patch!Wären die ständigen Ruckler nicht, wäre es ein unglaublich gutes Spiel. Die Entwickler haben sehr viel Liebe in Details und Animationen gesteckt. Jede Ecke der Map fühlt sich belebt an es gibt so vieles zu erkunden und zu sammeln. Ein großer Pluspunkt auch fürs Tierwesen fangen & beherbergen und dem Raum der Wünsche, der sich individuell gestalten lässt.+Grafik+Animationen+Sound, Übersetzung+Atmosphäre+Kampfsystem+Schnellreise+Menü Design+Gestaltung eigener Räumlichkeiten+Tierwesen -Schlechte Performance-Charakter Design: keine Langhaar Frisuren

author: Zolnol
review: As a Harry Potter fan: the game looks deep and rich at first but after a few hours it becomes obvious that it's extremely shallow. Everything is an illusion.The RPG elements barely exist - no meaningful relationships and no repercussions for negative player behaviour. Every character that you encounter feels more or less the same, there's very little soul to them. Classes have no depth to them, either just a short cutscene starts, or you learn a new spell and amaze everyone in the class in 30 seconds. Then you're out. No quidditch, plants and potions are pretty limited (less than 10 of both) The Room of Requirement feels like a chore with the low wait times, if you want to be efficient you basically have to go back every half an hour to check on things. The game runs horribly on PC - these graphics have no business making 30 series cards sweat one bit - yet they do, with constant fps drops and overall bad performance. Movement feels clunky, I dread every moment where I have to swim or do parkour. Getting around with the broom is frustrating too, if you don't have a huge grassland under your ass, you'll have trouble landing. Enemies are repetitive and shallow. Puzzles are kindergarten level with no thinking involved. The only time you can't solve a puzzle is because you haven't progressed far enough yet to get the required spell. The only positive things I can mention about this game is Hogwarts and Hogsmeade - they are made really well - although they are also the most stuttery parts of the game which takes away from the enjoyment. The combat feels good too, it doesn't surprise me that these 2 points were the main marketing materials, every other rough part of the game was hidden. Combat also suffers by the extremely broken mechanism that is stealth. After you unlock it you can just wander around camps and one shot everyone for the rest of the game without having to engage in real fights much. This is on the hardest difficulty too. This game had so much potential but at it's current state it's nothing more than cash grab bullcrap for mindless Harry Potter fans who'll defend it with tooth and nails. The game will hopefully get actually developed in the coming years, just like Cyberpunk and the new Warhammer. Looks like nowadays this is the standard for game developers: cash-in early with a game you can barely call early access, then take your sweet time adding all the missing things.I hate that the game is what it is, I wanted to love it so bad - but it crossed a line where I can't turn a blind eye. I will still 100% it and wait for future updates, but my dissapointment is immeasurable and my day is ruined. I feel sorry for the people who's standards are met with the ability of being able to pet mutant looking cats.

author: Sewer Onna Bugeisha
review: Enjoyed This game a lot, i dreamt of having a game like this when i was younger and it really is a lot of fun. However, my experience was ruined when i found out that my choices didn't matter and that the ''evil'' ending literally makes 0 difference since after picking the ending option it just continued on like what i said and did, Didn't happen. I don't recommend this if you wanted a ''real'' Harry Potter RPG, everything is on rails and what you say doesn't matter. it's like playing fallout 4 with magic sticks. but if you like that kinda game where it's basically just let the game force you on it's set path and enjoy the ride, then go ahead. It is really good overall, but after finishing i feel like my fun was taken a dump on and everything i sat through was a waste of time because it wasn't gonna change anything anyway.

author: Novster
review: I found it enjoyable and immersive, with plenty of opportunities for exploration. I also appreciated the implementation of the fight system and the many ways in which you could engage with enemies. However, I was disappointed with the absence of a moral system in the game, as the choices you made in the dialogues did not have any real impact on the NPCs' reactions. I'd like want that my choices to have real consequences for me and a greater sense of moral ambiguity and complexity in the game's dialogue options.Despite this shortcoming, I still found the game to be a good experience overall, especially for fans of the wizarding world. As a game studio's first attempt at this type of game, it is impressive, even if it wasn't entirely unique.I must say that the attention to detail in creating a believable magical universe is remarkable. I really liked the exploration of this world.

author: Liri Brightstar
review: I absolutely love the game! No amount of reviews can explain how beautiful and immersive the game is, you really have to try it yourself. It's really massive and it is everything I expected as a fan of Harry Potter and an open world game like this. I could spend days just exploring Hogwarts Castle alone and I'd only be scratching the surface. The battle system is extremely fun and addicting too! It was such a surprise to use unexpected spells and combine them with other spells during combat, not to mention a lot of combos. Oh and how much I love the main story quest, it's as if I'm watching a movie yet at the same time I am in it. Love the game, years from now this is a game I will still come back to.

author: Kaladin
review: An okay game by itself. A great game if you like the series. They definitely nailed the setting and the combat. Another highlight is the soundtrack. The story is okay but could be a bit more fleshed out (don't expect a deep RPG). Some great "wow" moments though with the set pieces. Tons of side-content that varies in quality. It's all optional so you can skip the usual open world filler (and frankly, there's quite a lot of that). From a technical standpoint the game looks great and runs well for me, but I have a beefy PC.Strongly recommended if you like making cows do 360 mid-air flips with your magic.

author: Kaatosade
review: We're gonna ignore the political snafu and Rowling's inability to pull her moronic head out of her hamster hole. Speaking strictly on the game itself...The PROS:This is a HUGE love letter to fans of the books and films alike. And if you've obsessively read and watched all the Potter media you can consume, like I have since I was but a wee babby, you're going to enjoy it that much more. Hogwarts is a character in its own way, just as much as Harry, Ron and Hermione are, and the people who made this game's version of the famous wizarding school know that. Every single nook and cranny and centimeter of flooring oozes detail. I turned off my minimap and quest directives (I cannot recommend this enough to any player) and let myself get lost in the castle. See a door? Well, it's not a painted wall. You can go through that door, if there's no lock on it (if there is, come back later once you have the spell sponsored by LockPickingLawyer). Every single floor is explorable. It's insane how large Hogwarts feels.The paintings on the walls play music and converse. I walked into the central hall and was gobsmacked by the angry visage of a dragon animated in the stone walls. I chased flying books about like an idiot and had a grand time. I pet every single cat I could see. I ran after a pair of ghosts in a domestic violence incident. I turned a corner, and watches Peeves slap a stack of books out of a student's hands and whip down the hallway, cackling maniacally. When I entered the lavatory, a mirror complimented me on how amazing I looked, and then when I came in later, it told me I had a gross face. Animated suits of armor push and shove each other and make movements in your periphery. Students chatter on about rumors of your adventures and whatever story beats you've finished. I have yet to see one of these random events repeat.Combat is flashy, snappy, and oh-so-much fun. Some complained about how boring and silly the wand combat was in the movies. Worry no more! Once you unlock talents and start investing points into your spells, it gets more visually bright, more chaotic and varied with each point you spend (I suggest first getting the talents that allow more spells to be assigned to the D-pad so switching on the fly is much less annoying). There’s potential for a variety of playstyles here, and I've barely touched any of it yet.If I’d not known who was composing the music for this game, and you told me that John Williams did the scoring, I would have believed you 100%. The folks who worked on the score have clearly done their homework. There's many nods to the film's iconic themes, the instrumentation and style follows directly in Williams' footsteps. It really is that good. It feels like a natural extension of the tracks we've come to recognize from JW, but still easily stands on its own. Sound design is straight outta the movies. It’s a treat.The world is fit to bursting with content. I've only just got to the point in the game where I've unlocked the majority of the main features, and I'm at a loss of where to start. Fly about the castle and admire its architecture? Be a loot goblin and bash down every door looking for someone's private stash? Be a Newt Scamander and care for the magical beasts? Become proficient in the Dark Arts even though it is strictly against my moral code? Obsessively find the best pieces of furniture to decorate my little slice of home in the Room of Requirement? Explore the Forbidden Forest? There is no shortage of things to do. In fact, there's so much to do that it may feel a little overwhelming. Which brings me to...The CONS:While the game is full of things to do and see, much of the content outside the walls of the castle can become predictable. Fetch quests, deliveries, there's a bajllion collectables to find... I've seen people liken this game to Assassin's Creed: Valhalla in this regard, and I can't say I disagree. The Scottish Highlands did not have anywhere near the same amount of attention given to it as Hogwarts did (I can't blame the developers, entirely, there was hardly any source material to build off of outside Hogwarts/Hogsmeade). While the game opens up to the rest of the world fairly early on in the story, you may be like me and not find yourself out in it too much, because it's just not nearly as enjoyable to experience it. The majority of characters are pretty forgettable. I've got a few favorites (harm a hair on Natty or Garlick's heads and I will riot), but even those characters aren't ones that are going to be iconic in any way. I haven't been terribly impressed with the story, either. It’s an average tale, but set in the wizarding world, so at least it's got magic in it. But the tutorial portion of the beginning of the game? Wowza. Wish the rest of the story could be as exciting as that, but regretfully, that doesn't seem to be the case so far. I'm hoping I can come back and update this review about how wrong I was.Everyone and their mother on this Steam page is aware of the performance issues on PC. I don’t doubt it's really bad. Avalanche needs to get in gear and fix these problems ASAP. The PC port has obviously not gotten the same QA as the console versions. Maybe I'm just really lucky, but I have not had any significant performance hiccups, crashes, or glitches (although with this game, you can call the glitches magic!) except twice: entering the Owlery (I probably had 5-8 FPS for a good ten seconds), and the first few seconds of the sorting ceremony cutscene stuttered. That's it! I've had a pretty blissful ride thus far, and I'm working with specs that just barely pass the minimum requirements.Sadly, the NPC's are just as detrimental to the immersion in the game as they are a compliment. While I enjoy eavesdropping on all their conversations, they don't really do anything outside their little bubble within a short range. They don't go to dinner in the Great Hall, they don't go to classes and sit down, and they have very limited interaction with the player’s presence and actions. Actually, I think there's the possibility that the students and faculty get raptured every night, because when I go to my dormitory after dark... every single bed is empty. All the classes are empty. Halls are empty. The Castle is silent, save for the ghosts and armor and portraits. It's rather disconcerting. Where did they go? Why, Avalanche, why are they not able to rest their weary heads at night? How am I supposed to stand over their beds and breathe down their necks if there's no one to stand over? Red Dead Redemption 2 set the precedent for AI pathing and behavior. This game ain't meeting that bar. It tried to jump and busted a kneecap on the bar.In conclusion...It's been a long, long road to get a Wizarding World game in my hands where I can be a witch and get my own wand and an assigned House that isn't stuffed with predatory IAP. It may not be the immersive RPG experience of going to classes and getting to know your peers like a lot of us hoped for, but we have come a long way from Harry Potter on the PS1. I’ve had an unreasonable amount of excitement while playing this, and I can’t thank the developers enough for giving me such a special experience. This game is like biting into a fresh, warm pumpkin pasty and taking a swig of butterbeer. It's so delightful and cozy and FUN.It gets a solid 8.5/10 from me. TL;DR: I have not had a single hour where I didn't have a gigantic, stupid smile on my face for a prolonged period of time. I may need an ambulance. My face hurts. This game's amazing and it's made me forget my need to drink water and eat food to live. I've reverted to the wide-eyed, magic-obsessed seven year old reading Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone on a beanbag in the library. Only Hogwarts Legacy can sustain me now.

review: What an adventure! Ive been nostalgiatripping the entire playthrough. 1000/10 for being able to pet all the cats.10000/10 for cats being literally everywhere. I want to open a chest but accidently pet cat.. Would pet again!

author: Gwenoviere
review: [This is the opinion from one that's never read or seen any Harry Potter series, please bear with me] STORY: the main and side stories so far are really awesome, have a lot of funny, witty, and mysterious feel to them. I love that the story is "audio" to really give the theatrical/cinematic feel to them!GAMEPLAY: I'm really impressed, truely good! The maps are HUGE so brooms, and mounts are a great way to get around (also there's instant teleport/travel which is awesome). Weather has natural changes which is great (not the same weather everyday like some games. COMBAT: Not turn based (thank you!) its real time! Lots of options with combat, dogding, teleporting, blocking and great magic spells. There's also options of stealth, pokemon type plant helpers, potions, the works! The combat and overall gameplay was really thought out. Great level up system too with choosing your playstyle on a tree system (for those who are familiar with assassins creed tree system types).GRAPHICS/ENVIRONMENT: Gorgeous! I have a really really old computer so the specs are below requirement. I had a bit of lag issue (my fault) however I got some memory sticks (min 16GB) to help with that, and instantly the issues were resolved. I would definitely recommend to have at least 16GB to really enjoy the beauty in the game. Besides that everything else was awesome, I love the soft touches and feel to the overall look of it (reminds me ALOT of Fable). The effects are epic with the magic spells and combat, the decor is enchanting with all the pictures and items that move and talk and quack (yes quack). Such a beautiful game I can't express it enough, you'd have to see it for yourself!++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++Summary: Overall I'm very impressed with this game, I feel as though there will be many updates in the future to help iron out any further bugs that may arise (I haven't come across any just yet), but overall I really really really recommend this game for anyone that loves a good story, adventure and magic!! Thank you for this game its really great so far!

author: falc
review: A solid action game, good soundtrack and great graphics. There's a ton of things to improve though.7/10

author: Clayton
review: Not even the dark arts can remove my tongue from Garlick's farter

author: Kodijack!
review: UPDATE:I managed to solve my problems by installing Win11 instead of Win10. The win10 fresh install did nothing. With Win11 + Ascendio3-ini-changes I'm getting 50-144fps in Hogwarts (average 100) and at least 70fps+ in Hogsmeade. All on ULTRA and DLSS (Quality) minus RT.This is much better, but still unacceptable that some random dude and his random ini-changes actually give many more FPS and reduce stutter than the devs. Also this immense fluctuation in FPS is very annoying. Still WAY better than before though.Now I can continue PLAYING the game and maybe change the review...----original review follows----I really really tried, but this is a performance-mess I cannot bear to "play" any longer.At best I'm getting around 50fps when looking at a wall on LOW-everything. Even patched with Ascendio2/INI-tweaked. Most of my play-time is tweaking, restarting, being dissapointed, rinse repeat. I even threw a quick clean-install-windows into the pen. And hell, the massive load-times, including a shader-cache-refill each effing start, don't make it any better.Settings don't really matter, the delta between lowest and ultra means one-figure-fps-gain.And guess what enabling RTX does to the frames? Yup.Luckily I'm no HP-fan (I even dislike HP) or else I'd be VERY upset. The whole thing is very cute, much love in the details and all, exploring the castle is a pure bliss, but this is a joke that gives me literal headaches. I'm waiting for the pirated version now to see if it was Denuvo or just bad optimization.And yeah, "It's all my fault", "I don't know what I'm doing", "50fps is more than enough!", "my rig sucks", "you're stoopid", "the human eye can't perceive more than 30fps" etc. Spare me.

author: SeriouslySpecific
review: So many reviews posted online are wrongfully reviewing this so i'm here to help balance it out. This game gets voted down because of the creator of the IP. Yes, what she did is wrong, but the only relation she has to this is the royalties. This is a game made for Harry Potter fans, and is easily enjoyable by everyone. You can like something without liking who made it. Ignore all those who are trying to oppress and shame you for wanting to play this, their views on this are faaar too ironic to be taken seriously.Now, about the game. I'd give it an 8. It's a fantastic game, but the sheer lack of enthusiasm coming from the main character's voice ruins what could be an amazing story. In my opinion, the side quests are what make this game. This is the first time in a while that I actually enjoyed side quests and side stories, they are so well done and the characters (for the most part) are so well written.I would give this a 9 if it weren't for my own expectation. I was under the belief that the story would be affected by what house you are in. This is only the case in one quest (Hufflepuff has the best version of this quest imo). Other than that and a few dialog lines, your house doesn't make any difference.I completed the story in 28 hours, which included faffing around and side quests, so I probably could have done it in under 25. Usually when I finish the story, I stop playing the game, but I still actively want to complete the side quests, regardless of there being nothing to gain.TLDR; Ignore the haters and the reviews that deduct points due to JKR, this game is a solid 8/10.

author: Amos
review: One of my favourite games I've played in the last 2 years.Absolutely recommended.

author: SOCCHI
review: I've done my waiting, 27 years of it in Azkaban. And I can finally say Hogwarts legacy is everything I expected it to be AND SO MUCH MORE. My inner child feel so loved right now.

author: madhatterand
review: unbelievably good ... easily one of the best open world RPGs ive played that i can think of and I have almost 2k games just in my steam Library. I am not a huge Potter fan , I enjoy the world and what not but im not a fan boy ... but damn is this game good in every way regardless of anything else ... the world building, the immersion, the voice ( except a bartender whose voice lines sound muffled and unprocessed compared to those around her) the graphics, the combat, the story, everything about this game is just so well done it brings back hope that devs arent just shoving out ♥♥♥♥ at every turn... these devs deserve to be praised for the work and effort as well as the final product that they have done. and after 12 hrs i feel like ive barely touched anything in this game, and yet have done a ton! Side note ... not buying this game cause you think somehow one of the richest women on earth is somehow going to be broke if you dont buy the game is silly and only hurts the awesome dev team that created this masterpiece. look past the bandwagons and understand many people put real work and time into this game as well as love for the world the fans created.Any way great game ... buy it now... if you got this far and havent clicked buy then watch ACG's review of this game or press that button now!!FOR THOSE HAVING STUTTER AND FPS ISSUES:Ive found this is the first game that i need to use V-sync on ... fixed all the stuttering... running this game at ultra at 144 ray tracing on ... when i first booted i turned motion blur off, v-sync, and film grain ... cause i dislike all 3 usually. But lag and stutter and over an hour messing with settings, didnt even consider turning on v-sync... almost giving up i turned it on ... NO MORE STUTTER.      oh also turn off UPSCALING... its on by default ... v-sync ON upscaling OFF... bet your game runs like butter after that because upscaling while trying to run native makes your gpu confusedagain running 2k ultra settings with ray tracing...... oh also turn off UPSCALING... its on by default ... v-sync ON upscaling OFF... bet your game runs like butter after that because upscaling while trying to run native makes your gpu confused

author: Phoon v2
review: Unreal. Hours and hours of gameplay, it will keep you busy for a long time. Loads to explore just a fantastic game.Highly recommend!(Writing this review i have 35.5 hours and i'm no where near done or close to finishing the game)

author: Fury
review: Can pet cats. 10/10

author: PocketYoda
review: Honest review on my Core i5 7500 rx580 8gb 32gb some what 7 year old pc, running on high, the game is flawless almost no stutter or problems out side of a water issue that seems to affect Amd cards.. The game itself is a Harry Potter fans dream come true, the game feels and lives like a true student in Hogwarts, the actual day to day life is amazing. The story is fresh and doesn't follow a lot of the standard tropes plaguing modern writing, which is refreshing. The story and extras are easily over 100 hours long and i cannot wait to see what modders do.That said the character generation should have allowed body types and less pandering to certain others should we see but the game as a whole is a solid 8-9/10 in my opinion.Great game buy it asap

I would buy it for all of my friends on steam if I could as a gift and rub it in those half breed's faces and yeah that's exactly what they are HALF BREEDS or if you guys prefer IN BRED ♥♥♥♥♥.Again, a massive thank you Avalanche !!

author: Spud
review: GOTY - I genuinely have not been so easily drawn into a game for far too long, and considering I dislike playing games that originated from movies/books, what this game accomplished is no easy feat.Granted, I spent my 4 hours exploring as there is so much to do without even advancing the story - the environment does an impeccable job in keeping you entertained, you see a ghost staring intently up? Ah, turns out he was gazing at a magical projection of some sort of cosmos - there is just so many little to big things of interest in the world to explore, I find it very refreshing - as in recent years, big games like hitman make a big world but there isn't as much depth and surprise in terms of exploration.I also appreciate how they blended the tutorial into the story-tellin, it was not a boring "here is a training yard, practice this, that and those, then start playing your game".The few interactions I had with the available characters were good in terms of different personalities and considering the dialogue, I look forward to learn more about them in the future.The developers really did a great job with this game, and if they do decide to make another with say, one of the other magic schools in the HP world, I'd be in even if I'm not particularly a fan.

author: Moocow
review: The game is beautiful and rich with story. I haven't had this much fun playing a 1 player game in a long, long time. It kept me glued to my seat and inspired me enough to complete it achieving 100% of the objectives. This meant completing all of the challenges as well as getting all the collectibles.At the moment, I don't believe the game has much replay value, however, it was well worth the price tag for over 100 hours of entertainment. If you honestly break it down it's about 40 cents per hour of entertainment if you took your time to complete everything like I did.

author: kyoko
review: Currently, the game is suffering with really bad performance and stuttering, but what I have to say about this game is not bad at all. This game is probably what any ubisoft open world game wanted to be, the open world is one of the most amazing ones I have experienced so far, every corner of the map has some small details or something happening, when you're walking in Hogwarts or outside, you're going to see small things happening that are enough to make the world feel alive.The story is never a drag, between main story and side quests, everything is fun, everything add details and fully voiced, it's impossible to not feel immersed when playing this game.The character creator is probably the only thing that I wish was better, I feel like it's very limited with how you have to use "standard" faces instead of being able to customize your face. I would also not recommend tweaking with the character voice, only the standard ones work well in general. The combat is one of the strongest points in this game, while a lot of people talked about how "basic" the combat feels, all the movement, spells upgrades, you can basically set up what combo works best for yourself and just have fun with it, the combat feels very dynamic and fast, you can work your way by dodging attacks or parrying, you can move enemies around the battlefield, you can handle any encounter your own way.Personally, I would recommend following a bit of the main story until you unlock more spells, but you can always just do whatever you want in the map and go back to that later.This is probably one of the "must" have games for this year, and you're not going to regret getting this one, it's one of the few triple A games that are worth the full price.

review: Dont listen to the hate, the games amazing. Not sat down and played a game like this in around 20 years (Oblivion). Exploring hogwarts has took me back and im loving every second of it !

author: CeeJaylx
review: 10/10 - Just get the game!!! It's a love letter to the fans of Harry Potter and the Wizarding World. But it's also a breathe of fresh air for gamers who just want an amazing game. The developers paid close attention to details meticulously immersing you into the game; the gameplay mechanic, the soundtrack, the visuals all work together like a sweet symphony.

author: Sapphic
review: Constant gating. Most upset that you can't just be Hermione and study super hard and learn all of the spells without progressing through the main story, which I found predictable and boring. "Open world" my ass. Exploring around and running into locked doors constantly you can't unlock until halfway through the story is not magical. UI requires many extra clicks to get where you want, with slow loading times. I have a state of the art brand new computer and it's crashing constantly.The characters are designed very simply (compare them with something like Dragon Age for example, where even the humans have unique features and strong personalities that are woven into the design) and with poor animation. Their stories are interesting but they have maybe only a line or two of extra dialogue if you want to talk to them more at any given moment. A fair few things are copied over from the movies, while so many things that would be amazing moments or references aren't there.Good combat. I was surprised about that. I would probably rate it slightly positively 6 or 7 out of 10 without the crashes. But feel like it's worth a negative review while those remain.

author: Longes
review: The game is fine. If you really like Harry Potter, then it'll be the best game you've ever played. If you are a normie like me, then it's just a decent game. Not going to blow your mind or anything. The biggest praise I can give this game is that it's clearly high effort. The devs cared about the atmosphere of Harry Potter, about details, about characters, about making a diverse and interesting cast.Gameplay-wise, it is as close to the Bully sequel as we are going to get. Go in with this expectation, not expecting Red Dead Redemption: Wizard or Hogwarts: Torment.Technical issues: no glitches so far. The game is mostly running well on Ultra, but occasionally chugs when it needs to load nearby areas.The bad: voice modulator should have been cut. It's so bad and audibly artifacted. The Trans Character is obviously a female VA with a voice modulator and it sounds as bad as when it's applied to you. The menus are also pretty slow to use, especially when you need to go over the map screen, which takes time to load.The keyboard controls end up being too clunky for comfortable comment - better use the controller.Overall - it's a very solid 6/10 AAA game. Better if you are a big Potter fan.

author: RazorEQX_TTV
review: Definitively at the top of my list for game of the year thus far.   With limited time to play games I always find it hard walk away from the game for IRL stuff.    Love the characters, the graphics, the story, and the skill tree and so much more.   Only downside is the limited spell slots at the start, most likely a limitation of being a console port.  Highly recommend the game!

author: JustCurious42
review: You can't choose your own path, you're locked to be the good hero. Writing is meh, open world content is meh, the whole game is generic. The only good thing is the initial nostalgia/fantasy of being in a HP world but it wares off quickly. Overall not worth the money unless you're a serious HP fan and you feel like you NEED to play this.

author: David0vić
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a very mediocre, generic and formulaic modern open world game that's saved from being a bad game by the Harry Potter license. They've done a good job of recreating Hogwarts and it is honestly really cool being able to fly around and above the castle on your broom seamlessly. I had fun in my first several hours playing the game just exploring the castle and the areas outside around the castle like hogsmeade. The more you progress though the more you realise how little the game has to offer. One of the biggest offenders is how lifeless the world feels with the lack of interaction in general. I compare it to Bully which came out 17 years ago now. When you walk around the school in Bully it feels like you are a part of that world. There is a time mechanic where you need to get to class on time and go to bed on time etc. All the NPC's have their routine they're following making you feel like the world is moving regardless of you being there rather than it feeling like the world is waiting for you like it does in Hogwarts Legacy. The difference between the level of interaction compared to a game released in 2006 is honestly really sad but that's just one of my many complaints. The general lack of role playing is also a big issue, you don't feel like a student in this world at all. You go to class like less than a dozen times from what i recall just to learn spells so you can go on mass killings in the world. The story and writing in general is lackluster, lack of well written characters to latch on to and connect with to pull you through the story. Main character has no personality. No consequences for your actions and choices have zero impact on the outcome in the end. Combat gets extremely repetitive and tiresome. The R2/RT spam is ridiculous i felt like i was on autopilot throughout most of the combat. The lack of enemy variety didn't help either. The gear system is terrible because of the level scaling making exploration pointless knowing you will never find a really good item that will last you dozens of hours because everything is scaled to your level. There is nothing interesting to see outside of Hogwarts and Hogsmeade because of all the bland check list side activities they've added to pad out the length. Boring level and puzzle design in the caves and dungeons. UI feels like it's ripped straight out of a modern Ubisoft game. Graphics are inconsistent, sometimes it looks like a good looking PS4 game and other times it looks like an early PS3 game. The performance is awful because of the amount of VRAM it uses, i had to find a fix online for my RTX 3070 8gb because it ate all my VRAM like it was nothing. Maybe it's justified if the game looked amazing but it doesn't. The game overall doesn't feel like it's a full price Triple A game, it feels like a budget title. Makes sense that the developers last game was Cars 3. 4/10 (Mediocre)

review: Shadow Money Wizard Gang
