author: Mike
review: Spoiler Free. Finished the game in ~50h, nearly 100%, some achievements left, but mostly trivial collectables, all the stories are done.There will be 2 types of people playing this game which will result in two completely different experiences to you, here's how I see it:If you're a Harry Potter fan - phenomenal. The Wizarding World has never been done this well. The scale of the school, the sheer amount of detail, tiny nuances and painstaking attention to detail you would never notice unless you know what to look for. It really feels like the school was a passion project, not a business project. The characters have been done incredibly well, voice acting is top notch (with some exceptions). There is a lot of fan service, a ton of customisation. Everything is going to look great, feel great, play great and you are guaranteed to be hooked. Not much else to tell you, buy it, have a blast and absolutely enjoy the experience, however, please don't read below.If you're not a Harry Potter fan - it falls short as a video game in a lot of aspects. As I'm personally not big on the HP universe, I don't look at the game with rose-coloured glasses and it really shows that the game is lacking. The school is great, but if you were to remove the collectables from it, it's empty. Very few quests will actually make you interact with the school in a more nuanced or deeper way. Basically, it's as wide as the ocean, but as deep as a puddle. There is no curfew, no way to interact with the students. No real school-system, you do whatever you want whenever you want. Even the "Unforgivable" curses are, as someone put it nicely, very forgivable, and you can use them next to your professor and they don't react to it. Your common room exists for about 3 times in the game when you wake up there and has nothing in it. The world around Hogwarts has been beautifully crafted, but again there just isn't much to do, despite looking loaded with markers. There are a lot of collectables scattered around the world, but you soon realise they're copy pasted. I did all 95 Merlin trials (as of now steam shows 0% global achievements so I'm one of the first), and there are only 7 types of puzzles in them(maybe i forgot one idk) and after you do the first 20 you realise they have been just placed all over the world for no reason other than to inflate your playtime. The mini-bosses and camps scattered through the world just give you some blueprint for furniture or a piece of gear. There is a beast capturing system, but in the end its only needed for materials that you use to upgrade gear, which you really don't need to do at all. There are potions in the game, but throughout the whole game playing on the hardest difficulty I used ~20 healing potions total (17 of those in the final fight) and 0 of the other potions as they feel useless.The room of requirement is cool and decorating can be fun, but practically speaking you can plant a bunch of Mallowsweet for the Merlin Trials and that's about where its usefulness stops as you dont need anything else.The enemy variety is lacking. There are mongrels, goblins, humans, trolls, spiders and few suits of armour. They just have a different colour of clothing or some more plates, but they all feel and look exactly the same to fight and get very repetitive very fast. There is also no quidditch, but it makes sense as it would most likely be too hard to make. The main quest is very generic and really not the best piece of writing and there is no choice. Sebastians side story could have been the main quest and it would make more sense. They also advertised Simon Pegg as he plays the Headmaster Nigellus Black, however, the headmaster appears about 4 times total in the game, and only once for more than two sentences, missed opportunity there. That's how I would sum up this game - a missed opportunity to be so much more.I don't mean to dissuade from purchasing the game, I still had fun with it myself and would probably recommend to play through despite all the shortcomings.

author: Chris
review: This review is coming from someone who has completed the main storyline and a good chunk of the side quests. SPOILERS AHEAD.Before I get into why I don't recommend Hogwarts: Legacy, here are the positives:1. The game is generally quite fun and enjoyable.2. Exploration and challenges are somewhat rewarding and give you a variety of cosmetics/buffs that you can apply to your gear.3. A few of the side quest lines are very enjoyable and offer intriguing and in depth story lines with somewhat nuanced characters4. The game is a faithful recreation of the source material5. Length of Hogwarts: Legacy is good - not so long that it becomes tedious (although it sometimes does) but not too short as to feel rushedNow for the negatives, which I feel not many are picking up on:1. The dialogue, voice acting and characterisation for the main characters in particular is absolutely shocking for a game of this calibre. The hero is just TOO good and whilst you can cast unforgivable curses and choose dialogue options that are more negative, it feels so out of place in this game to do those.2. The performance is shocking. I don't expect to be able to run this game at 4K 144fps but not being able to run this game at 1080p on low settings without it stuttering when changing locations is unacceptable.3. The final 1/5 of the game is just a huge disappointment. The final 2 bosses (well, final boss - the second to last boss isn't horrific) are just lazily done. Ranrok in particular is just ridiculous. You spend the whole game learning how to combine spells to devastating effect, then Ranrok just requires you to dodge and spam 3 damaging spells. 4. Saying that, the vast majority of the game is lazily done and here are just a couple of the lazily designed aspects of this game:a) can cast unforgivable curses without ANYBODY, EVEN YOUR TEACHER, saying anythingb) no way to swim underwaterc) dialogue is poor and cheesyd) the system of currency is so lazy - ALL orange items have the same sell and buy value and same for the other raritiesand that is just a few of the lazily designed aspects of the game.5. The entire gear system is just a waste of time really. There is no point upgrading/changing equipment. The rarity of equipment doesn't really matter as the upgrade system is pointless so, so long as you have the highest defence equipment, you'll be fine.That's just a few of my observations whilst playing the game. I should say that I played this on regular difficulty and played it fairly solidly since release. I will also say that I've not particularly taken any notice of the discourse surrounding the game itself and am writing this from a purely subjective point of view.

author: Christian
review: Bought the deluxe edition to annoy the LGHDTV+ community.11/10

author: Droben
review: Pro: Hate against Transsexual Con: Riddles too hard

author: Daroutan
review: It feels like nostalgia hugged a movie. A movie where everyone involved in making it cared. It truly feels like a complete RPG. There are long and detailed side quests, a long main story. Pets for fans of Fantastic Beasts, Mounts and broomstick riding. The combat isn't intense however it is thrilling. Linking spells together in different ways is quite interesting. Clothing appearance customization is available from the very first moment, as soon as you equip your first set of clothes. The map is massive and has many places to explore and discover. As of writing this review, I genuinely am happy I pre-ordered a game for once.

author: Ceceli ♠
review: Disclaimer: this review will be 100% honest, about the good stuff and the bad stuff. You've been warned.They just don't learn. This game has forced TAA and no true fullscreen. Everything looks blurry to the point it makes me feel like I need glasses again. Performance is worse than RDR2, but what would you expect from devs who aren't known for doing Triple A games. Gladly, this isn't a console for peasants. And in the land of PC MASTER RACE we have the option to use Reshade with sharpening to correct that, even though the TAA is still being processed and consuming precious FPS, and even more so because it has f'ing Denuvo. I hope they remove Denuvo once this game gets cracked, because otherwise it would only be pointless and hurt the playerbase.But, putting all of that aside, they gave us a neat option to use AMD FSR 2 upscalling method to bring the game from 720p to 1080p while maintaining the graphics on High and therefore the game remaining beautiful. On a 1080ti with 12700k I get from 75 to 100 FPS. And I can say it's not a port problem because the game is just awful on PS5. People have to play it looking worse than PC on Low settings and with less FPS. Search videos and screenshots to see what it is really like instead of reading what ultra fanboys say on Facebook because their egos can't take it. And they say PS5 is the equivalent of a 3080. Yeah, sure, pumpkin! So there's no reason for buying it on PS5 just to get access to that exclusive mission.Now, story wise, so far it's looking good despite a few flaws. You can grasp that there's a mystery being conveyed, but you have no clue on WTF is going on and where the story is gonna lead you. It just feels a bit lost in itself. But then it starts to shape up and you know what's what instead of feeling like things happened out of thin air without a proper introduction and backstory.Simon Pegg's acting in the role of Hogwarts' headmaster is terrible. He sounds like a soap opera sub celebrity reading a script doing over inflexion in every word. It's not at all like a real person talks and it can come off as cringey. Then there's that student from Uganda that's also super obnoxious to listen to because her phony accent is terrible and her tone of voice and laughs don't match what's going on. But, gladly, as I've seen so far, you'll spend most of your time talking to your professor and mentor, and your friend Sebastian. These 2, plus the main character, are all portraied by very talented voice actors. The main character's voice is very similar to Daniel's voice, so in a way, you get that Harry Potter feeling. Even when you go to Ollivanders, you're treated just like Harry, as if you were the most special person being long-awaited. That was a bit on the nose for me.For the combat, I was surprised. Few people understand that these games - specially Warner Bros games - aren't strictly fighting games. They're more rythm games. And that's fine. You just need to adjust your expectations to it. WB games are not like playing The Warriors, for instance. Anyway, Avalanche Software managed to improve this genre in the most sneaky and brilliant way possible. It's like they brought Guitar Hero to a fighting game. Instead of 5 colors on the toy guitar controller, you have 4 colors in this game, 1 for each action button on Playstation. If this were done thinking on PC, they could have gone up to 5 with no problem since it's pretty feasible to reach the number 5 key. So, essentially, you have to tap those numbers according the colors of yours spells and the color of the enemies' protection spell shields. And this was so beautifully done that they managed, in my opinion, to surpass the misplaced faith in the Souls games, making Hogwarts Legacy much, much more enganging, in all areas, even by not making the same mistakes as well. The combat has so much nuance, possibilities and areas of the brain triggered at once that I shall not talk about it in order to not make this review any longer than it needs to.Lastly, the environment and many side quests. It's like they followed the Marvel's Spider-Man's footsteps on this one. The whole place is beautiful, there's so much attention to detail that it's fun to swing, I mean, fly through the map experiencing all of it. The side quests don't feel like boring chores. They're fun excuses to see everything and level up as oppose to just do a pointless checklist maybe for achievements. For comparison, I tell my friends that Hogwarts is like a GTA, and then you get out to explore the world and there's another GTA. That's how big Hogwarts is. And super detailed! Although not as big, but still super detailed, there is Hogsmeade with several houses and stores to go into for looting or visiting and none of them are copy-paste. I just don't know why they didn't go with Diagon Alley. All you see in this game from Diagon Alley, so to speak, is the inside of Gringotts.This level of effort really shows. Despite wokies being noisy on Twitter trying to boycott this game, it's soaring in sales. As of now, it has reached almost 900k concurrent players on Steam alone!PS.: speaking of wokies, mind you, be careful when posting on Steam Discussions. Steam mods are wokies and they are mad af right now to the point that I got banned for a week from the forum after being called names by more or less 50 people, which I reported and nothing happened, but I, on the other hand, got banned for being "rude". So there goes the Steam moderation selectively grooming the community to be toxic and cancerous by condoning people's bad behaviours and harassing me by banning me for merely being a victim of this arbitrary and corrupted system with zero accountability. Little people on power trips. Go figure. This kind of cancer is making Epic Store look better by the minute! No wonder they don't have forums there.

author: Yari
review: Gameplay is really good but in early access the frame drops were actually horrible to the point it was bothering me so much i had to stop playing at times. Hopefully they get fixed soon but a great game nonetheless

author: Kaipo
review: Great game with a ton of fun. If you ever wanted to explore Hogwarts, for sure I recommend. The story line is pretty fun and it does change up a bit depending on house you choose. However I do agree with some of the individuals rating it negative. I feel like the NPCs are lifeless. One of the most uncanny aspects of the game is when it turns night, the entire school is empty. Even when you go into the sleeping quarters there are no students sleeping. It made the game feel empty in regards to relationships and almost like the NPCs weren't real. That is my only major complaint so far I would have to say.

author: Mason2501
review: I'm completely enjoying this Wizarding World game!  Giving a fresh take before Harry Potter.  Let's build the witch or wizard you want.  Lot of puzzles and exploration quests.  Wizard dueling.   Witcher like monster hunting.  So far I've enjoyed all the cinematic story and cuts scenes.  Feel like your dropped in book from the series.  I'm ignoring any woke SJW cries to boycott this game. Wasn't really on my list as next game to buy. Jumping into to check it out, I'm glad i did and hooked.  On my new rtx4090 am5 7950x gaming PC its max everything with RT and fluid beauty.  The Story style of game is like a tutorial without a super cheesy tutorial. Each quest unlocks new spells, powers and skills making the game more complex. Enough clothing loot to case and upgrade. Use for looks or stats.   I'm exited to explorer more and discover more and learn or fill in all places seen in the books or movies.  You get sorted in a house, so I guess there will a reason to replay the game for that inside part of each house is if you care.  So far feels great. Loving it.

author: Freddo1Kenobi
review: If you are a huge Harry potter / Wizarding world fan, you will find plenty of the things you've read in the books, seen in the movies and they are doing you a huge service by providing a chance of being part of the wizarding world. However, except for the combat, you won't find any overly engaging gameplay, so if you are looking for an intellectual stimulus in forms of puzzles, challenges or an engaging story, you should look elsewhere. This is not a  game, no matter what anyone tries to sell it as in the steam review section. I get that some people are huge fans of the harry potter franchise and world. For you, congratulations, you might have something you will get out of this. For me, as a person who read all the books and watch the movies, enjoyed them, but not much more, this is not worth it. I expected more game, less copy-paste.If you look behind the dress up, this is just a Ubisoft open-world style game that arguably does everything that your average Assassins creed game does, but worse. The game start very slow, which hides some of the open world stuff, and you get sucked into the story because you commit to around 5-6 hours of slow gameplay with many cut scenes. Then it really takes off as you get , start travelling the world, exploring puzzles and getting to do combat with your new earned spells. So hour 6-14 is really where the game shines and you are exploring the world. Hour 14-finish is you realizing that everything that felt new and fresh is what the rest of the game is, anything from 20-60 more hours of it depending on how long you can shut your brain down at a time to just go about it. If you want to do other things than simple fetch quests or the main quest, you do have a few side quests containing some characters that you stick with throughout the game. Of these quests 1 has well written characters with real motives, good voice actors and an impact on gameplay . The main story is just you running around from place to place facing the same generic enemies (there are a few exceptions which were appreciated), and so so so many cutscenes which drags. At the end of it, I felt myself just skipping some of them cause it's just so hard to care about any of the characters in the game, most are so flat.There's not that much more to comment on, the game itself is a collection of mini-games spread out in a mostly empty world and is stringed together by a half-assed story. Although, everyone to their own, if you are just looking for a game to sit with and turn off your brain after school/work and appreciate visuals, this might be it!

author: Leonair
review: I would have to admit that I was pretty hyped about the game. It looked great in the trailersbut beyond that it looked fun.For people that grew up reading Harry Potter books, this would have been as close as you can get to receiving an acceptance letter to Hogwarts. You aren't living Harry's story, you're experiencing your own. Games like that are really good and I hope more singleplayer-storydriven games get released.Graphically, it is pretty damn good. Pretty for certain, beautiful for sure. It does have a few issues here and there, the lighting kind of makes certain hair colors appear washed out. Sometimes the stutter gets so bad that you might want to look directly at the ground for a bit til things calm down and your frames go back up.I overlooked all of that because I ACTUALLY HAD FUN WITH THIS GAME. Normally, bugs like that would dissuade people from getting the game. But I'd have to say, there aren't any other game breaking bugs that I've encountered but your experience may vary. I can only talk about what I got from playing this game.And what I got was a barrel of fun. Exploring Hogwarts castle, flying through the world, walking in to Hogsmeade..All of that was just simply fun. If you've ever gone and visited Universal Studios Japan's Hogwarts area, you'll know what i'm getting at.From getting your wand, getting sorted into your house and seeing your common room..It is almost a complete experience. Learning to cast the spells in class, even better.Combat can both be complex and simple. That's how I personally like it. Simple enough to grasp but complex enough that you aren't stuck just doing the same thing over and over again. You have offensive and defensive spells, as well as killing curses and such. You'll be taught to use them and you'll get to test them out on dummies, monsters, animals and people.The clothes in the game are nicely modelled too, the physics don't feel like they'd glitch out at any moment, it isn't a case like in AC Unity where the cloth physics are stuck in 30FPS but you're running at 60+. Though I would have to say, the variations might need a bit more work. Dressing up in different combinations of cloaks, robes and suits is almost as fun for me as just exploring the world. Sometimes I just look for treasure chests so I can get new clothes.There are puzzles and minigames that will occupy your time if you aren't too keen on doing all of the main stuff immediately. But I would urge you to at least get to the bit where you are taught to use brooms. Fast travel is nice and all but broom travel is 10x better in my opinion. The story can be a hit or miss to some people. You're some chosen one with some grand destiny, all that jazz. Let's ignore all of that and do all of Professor Garlick's assignments. (she's honestly the prettiest and the sweetest character in the game. Fight me)I hope for future story DLC (MORE GARLICK-SENSEI CONTENT PLEASE)The modding community for this game is getting its feet wet and there are some amazing stuff coming out right now if you're willing to put in a tiny bit of effort. (like dropping PAK files into a folder. EZPZ)10/10 Bang for Buck, if you don't have the Knuts to spend on this, I don't know what to tell you.IT IS A FUN GAME. FUN WIZARD FANTASY GAME. LET'S GO. RIGHT NOW.

author: Rak1445
review: To be honest, this game has no right to be as good as it is.For a new, unknown studio to produce an adaptation of an existing franchise... Well, that usually ends in disaster.So why then is this game such an obvious labor or love, full of painstakingly crafted details that keeps surprising you with brand new features even hours into your playthrough, unique quests with replayability potential, vast open world,... It's honestly astonishing and such a breath of fresh air for a big budget studio to not bungle up a game and sell it incomplete with an array of DLC as a dull cashgrab for once.Is it perfect? No. Nothing is. It's not terribly innovative in its gameplay either, but you know what? That's not what the game set out to do, doesn't pretend to be and frankly, what it does, it does pretty darn well.If you're a Potter fan, get this game and let your family know you will be unreachable for the next month or so.If you're new to the universe, this may not be the best introduction, but still presents a solid game in its own right, without requiring previous knowledge of the world (except maybe that magic is real and lives in a wooden stick you swish about to make things go boom).Whether you're an experienced gamer or a more casual enjoyer, the game's difficulty modes are able to accommodate you well. At story difficulty, the game is an open book for anyone to experience, while hard offers solid gameplay and significant challenge for the most demanding of players. There's also a range of adjustments to allow for better accessibility.TLDR - yep, this is the one.

author: Teepi
review: My all time favorite game.

author: Ashes
review: SHORT VERSION1. Denuvo Anti-Temper is in the game without any confirmation that it will be removed despite it already being cracked.2. Currently as of this review, Nvidia has NOT released a proper Game Ready Driver for Hogwarts Legacy.3. Most recent patch notes on Steam (February 25th, 2023) are for the Day One Patch (10 Feb, 2023).4. Optimization is HORRID. Performance is all over the place, the game can be virtually unplayable for some despite their hardware being top of the line and great for people with much worse hardware. Tons of bugs, confusing menus, control issues, controller issues, PC binding issues, in-game bugs etc.,5. Horrible and confusing marketing/communication/support for all versions, especially PC. With multiple accounts and account links being required to redeem things. There are a lot of exclusive items/quests that are/or are going to be unavailable soon as of February 26th. (Including PS exclusive quest, twitch cosmetic drops, pre-order bonuses etc.,)8. Graphics/Art Style/Atmosphere/Music/Sound is absolutely top notch. Truly amazing.7. Gameplay is very hard to describe, some might love it, some might hate it. It’s a mishmash of mechanics from many genres with a Harry Potter theme slapped onto it. I personally think it’s great as for me it ticks all the boxes.LONG VERSIONI received this as a gift from a friend and meanwhile I like the game itself, let me walk you through the current state of what’s going on. From an objective point of view so you can make an informed decision about this product before buying it.The game has severe performance problems, anyone who says it runs fine on their PC without implementing additional workarounds is incredibly lucky. There is no universal workaround because of how it hugely varies depending on your system, programs, overclock settings, bios settings, Windows version, update version for windows. There are people with 4090s getting 50fps, people with 1080Ti's getting 60+ constant, people with RTX3070Tis cards getting 30 on low, while others with those same cards have the roles completely reversed. While others can’t even launch the game. RTX suite features are absolutely botched on PC (This includes DLSS, Ray Tracing, Scaling, DLAA etc.,). In summary it’s an incredibly poor PC release.Warner/Avalanche/Wizarding World/Portkey Games have delved into some very intentionally misleading practices or they are absolutely incompetent. There are a million different people managing this game on social media and the various platforms and currently the state of the game is absolutely horrible on PC despite the “Very Positive” rating on Steam.The community is completely split by hardcore Harry Potter fans who defend it with every tooth and nail and say that it’s a 10/10 game of the year; People who are trying to boycott it because of some political issues with JK Rowling on Twitter over things she said a long while ago;. Others who don’t understand how PC’s work are saying that “You should just upgrade your PC if it runs badly”; Meanwhile some are calling everything a “conspiracy theory” and disregarding factual evidence you can easily find online. The truth is the whole new DLSS 3.1 ♥♥♥♥ and Ray Tracing thing is purely a massive marketing stunt to sell the already problematic RTX 4000 series, the DDR5 platform for PC is completely unstable, all new GPUs have artificially inflated prices. And software companies are trying their best to secure a monopoly by locking their platforms similar to Apple with their Macs and iPhones (e.g. Windows 11 being pushed by Microsoft while having specific hardware requirements that ♥♥♥♥ on old PCs or ruin their performance. Nvidia requiring special PSUs to even use their new RTX4000 series cables etc.,). I won’t bore you with all those details, but you get the gist. Generally I wouldn’t recommend upgrading your PC with the newest gen hardware, but that’s a story for another time. Warner is using the whole RTX thing to sell their game to PC players, because RTX sells) and they make money out of Nvidia and Nvidia makes money out of them. It’s up to you if you want to call this a conspiracy theory or not, but it’s all easily verifiable information with the right questions typed into a google search.

author: thechiliman
review: Revelio simulator+flying on a hippogrif

author: Nycto
review: This game's amazing - brings back sweet memories of PC/PS1 Harry Potter Soundtrack's greatCombat system is simple and easy to handleFull of story and I'm probably still only a quarter the way through

author: Max
review: PEGI 12 ahh game, the story is for children, if my guy is a 5th year I'm expecting half blood prince type of story not philosopher's stone. Every student is written like robots and are too formal with each other, the professors are distinguished by race instead of personality, Hogwarts got professor Arab, professor Indian, professor African etc. The castle is designed well and is fun to explore but the outside isn't. I was expecting Bully but in Hogwarts but got generic open world exploration with Harry Potter skin, I "role-played" as a Hogwarts student but in no way felt like one. Only things that kept me going was the funny spells and the drip but that got old.

author: Evan Exa
review: Despite everything, this game has been one of the most immersive games I've ever played. I really feel like I'm a wizard at Hogwarts. The world is gorgeously crafted, the combat is so snappy and satisfying, and the attention to detail in the world (especially inside Hogwarts) is so impressive. I find myself trailing off the main story to do side content and explore so often because the world is packed with things to do. As a fan of the Witcher games, I appreciate the notes the devs have taken out of that book for this game to really bring it to life. Even if you only like HP mildly, there's plenty to enjoy with this game.

author: Carina Ayland
review: Truly a love letter to fans!The attention to details in this game and how it's made really brought me back to when games were made with love and care.It's not perfect, but the few downsides of the game are easily countered by the insane amount of content it has.It's an RPG with the best map I've seen since RDR2, the quality is superb in all the right places, the style itself is wonderful (10/10 eye candy), the story is engaging from beginning to end, and the game-play is wildly varied, with many options for you to chose what kind of play-style you want. There's some optimisation issues but that's to be expected, not everything can run smoothly on day 1 but I'm sure patches will smooth the kinks there is.I only hope that this title serves as a milestone and an example of both how to make a PROPER game, something everyone in the entire gaming industry has forgotten (games nowdays are ruled by money and the shareholders which is why we end up with mediocre or below average products not worth a cent), and that the next titles, if there will be, improve on this foundation with more content.Or better yet: that they do content updates, that would be wonderful.Such as more spells, more creatures, more foes, etc...It's also the only game worth every cent ever since Elden Ring came out. Though to me: ever since RDR2PS: to everyone mixing politics with the game, I wish a very kind ♥♥♥♥ you <3

author: Guzio
review: After years of messy games, horrible launches and fake adv, we got a product made with brain and love. It's a solid 7/10. More games solid like this please!When you think you have seen everything in the game, something new appears to engage you even more...BIG CONS:- 1 year exclusive content cut from PC- DenuvoWithout these mistakes, it would be 8/10...Probably GOTY

author: Wobbly_Goblin
review: Fun gameplay, good story (so far) and a great open world. And it works at launch.

I want to enjoy peaceful moments not just fighting all the time like many games.Would levetate a sheep again...

author: Shishana
review: German/EnglischDa eh mein Kommentar nicht gelesen wird hier mal das Butterbier Rezept für echte Hexen und Zauberer :31 Vanilleschote2 Tl Butter (weich)2 El Rohrzucker200 ml Schlagsahne400 ml Milch1 Tl Zimt (gemahlen)½ El Kakaopulver250 ml Malzbier1.	Vanilleschote längs einschneiden und das Mark herauskratzen.2.	 Butter in einem mittelgroßen Topf zerlassen. Zucker zugeben und bei mittlerer Hitze schmelzen und leicht karamellisieren lassen. Dabei gleichmäßig mit einem Kochlöffel rühren.3.	 Mit 100 ml Sahne ablöschen (Vorsicht, heißer Dampf!). Unter Rühren kochen lassen, bis der Karamell gelöst ist.4.	 Milch, Vanillemark, Zimt und Kakao mit einem Schneebesen verrühren, zur heißen Sahnemischung geben, aufkochen. Unter Rühren 3 Min. köcheln lassen.5.	 Topf vom Herd nehmen. Das Malzbier unter Rühren zugießen. Auf dem Herd bei mittlerer Hitze erneut erwärmen, auf keinen Fall mehr kochen lassen, da die Masse sonst ausflockt. Herd ausschalten.6.	 Restliche Sahne steif schlagen. Butterbier in hitzebeständige Becher oder Gläser füllen. Sahne darauf verteilen und sofort servieren.Since my comment is not read anyway, here is the butterbeer recipe for real witches and wizards :31 vanilla pod2 teaspoons butter (soft)2 tablespoons cane sugar200 ml whipped cream400 ml milk1 teaspoon cinnamon (ground)½ tablespoon cocoa powder250 ml malt beer1.Slit the vanilla pod lengthwise and scrape out the pith. 2. Melt the butter in a medium saucepan, add the sugar and melt over a medium heat until it caramelises slightly. Stir evenly with a wooden spoon. 3. Deglaze with 100 ml cream (be careful, hot steam!). Cook, stirring, until the caramel has dissolved. 4. Mix the milk, vanilla pulp, cinnamon and cocoa with a whisk, add to the hot cream mixture and bring to the boil. Simmer for 3 min. while stirring. 5. Remove the saucepan from the heat. Add the malt beer, stirring. Reheat on the cooker over medium heat, but do not let it boil again or the mixture will flocculate. Turn off the cooker.Whip the remaining cream until stiff. Pour the butterbeer into heatproof mugs or glasses. Spread the cream on top and serve immediately.

author: MindFlow
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a very solid AAA Open World title. It's also a pretty decent Harry Potter game, but it lacks in the RPG department. I'll get into all of that in more detail.The game is fast paced in combat and traversal (once you unlock the broom and maybe some upgrades), but likes to take it's time in other parts. Hogwarts alone has a seemingly infinite amount of puzzles, secrets and treasures, but the open world is also sprinkled with tons of minor side activities, that often don't rely on combat but rather a few brain cells and some patience. All in all the various aspects of the gameplay are all handled well and never feel boring or stale, as there is a constant switch. Once you start looking for specific side activities or have finished all quests, though, it may become the well known open world grind.Hogwarts Legacy provides all the ingredients that a modern RPG thinks it needs, but leaves out the real essentials. There is a small talent tree that can be almost completely unlocked in a single playthrough. The talents do not exist to create some kind of build or expertise, - they simply exist because they have to in a modern RPG. There's also gear which only has 2 stats, so that numbers go up. Its not fun or exiting, but developers think a modern RPG needs it. There are also upgrade to the gear so that the numbers can go up even more. Players will simply put on the next best thing they find, because there is literally zero thought put into the system.What Hogwarts Legacy does not have are meaningful choices or even consequences. No matter which dialogue options you chose, the game will always play the same. No matter which house you pick, it will only change the color of your school uniform and some lines spoken by NPCs. There are barely any quests with more than one way to solve them. Therefore it has no replay value at all, unless you want the "hidden" achievements for every house.It runs mostly well, but has the occasional stutter. Even though the game analyzes your hardware and puts on the approriate settings by default, it's not perfectly optimized. There are often mini loading screens when you open doors, which can be slightly annoying. If that's a problem for you, maybe wait a few patches.Huge parts of the game are riddles. They are mostly simple and require a keen eye rather than raw brainpower. If you can do arithmetics in the lower double digits, you're good enough for almost everything the games throws at you. Then there are some challenges that rely on reactions rather than wits or perception. They can be a bit tricky, but once you figure them out, they are also super easy. Combat is also rather easy even on the highest difficulty. The only real challenge that the game provides are battles with lots of enemies and even then the hardest opponent is the camera and the rather poor targeting system.Character creation is incredibly restrictive. There are a few preset faces but no sliders, even though they have been a staple of character creation for a decade and a half. There are a few pointless choices like having a voice that does not match the body or chosing the boys or girls dorm independent of your body. They are kind of odd, mostly pointless, but of course can be avoided to have an immersive experience.While Hogwarts looks great with lots of details, it feels kind of hollow. Other students will only talk to you, if they are involved in a quest. You can interact with some objects, but most are only decoration. That includes all benches, couches, seats and beds. The latter is probably the most jarring, as you cannot sleep in your dorm. But then again, nobody can. The dorm is always empty. Other students simply disappear at night. Combine this with the fact that the students in the common room will not talk to you and you have zero reason to ever visit your house other than dropping off a few tokens for a quest. The "Hogwarts" experience is completely missing.On top of that there is a ton of missed potential. NPCs will talk about things you've done as part of a quest, but you can never talk to them about it. There's for example a younger witch who loves playing gobstones, but has no friends to play with. The last students she could convince disliked the game so much that they hid her gobstones away and you are asked to retrieve them. But once you do, she will sit around in the courtyard and talk to herself about defeating any challengers, if only she could find any. Let me play a round of gobstones with her! Just a simple little game and a few lines of dialogue would go such a long way.Then there is a Ravenclaw student who gets bullied for being scared of Puffskein. He asks you to provide him with a trophy to proof that he has done something courageous. Once you do, he proclaims that his nickname will be gone once he shows the trophy to everyone in the common room. Wouldn't it be great if a Ravenclaw player could actually see that play out? The common room would actually feel alive. Oh, yes - and also put people in beds, please. Maybe a little chit-chat or banter with the roomies at night? Let me sleep in my bed at least after you made me pick a dorm! How hard can it be?Even worse: there is a "wait" functionality, where you sleep on the floor until the quest starts or day/night has passed. You can literally sleep on the dorm floor, but not in the bed one step in front of you.Then there is the diversity and representation issue. Obviously there are way too many foreigners around that should not be in the Scottish Highlands in the late 19th century: especially Acromantulas. Hagrid brought them to the Forbidden Forest and that will take place quite a few decades after Hogwarts Legacy.Jokes aside, the developers clearly wanted to play both sides. For the realism crowd, most NPCs are white. For the diversity crowd, most interactable NPCs - Hogwarts staff, shop keepers, quest givers - have a very high quota of representation. This goes so far that white professors are a minority in Hogwarts, which is breaking immersion.Of course there's also an elderly mixed-race lesbian couple and a trans-witch, which you will know the moment she opens her mouth. And while there is nothing wrong with having LGBT in a Harry Potter game - witches have always been seen as sexual deviants after all - there are still ways to do it wrong. While the lesbian couple is executed nicely, the trans-witch unfortunately is not. As witches and wizards don't have to rely on modern day surgery and hormone treatment but can use magic, their transformation will affect the whole body including vocal cords. A trans-witch will sound like any other witch. The fact that she does not is representative of modern trans folks, but immersion breaking by the rules of this magical world. Worst of all - the developers have managed to do it correctly in another part of the game: The game goes all in. They tried their hardest to include absolutely everything iconic about the Harry Potter universe. Most of it is executed well. Unfortunately it almost feels like they worked with a checklist. Everything is there, but they all need to stand on their own. The greater connection is lacking. At times it feels more like a Harry Potter skin for the generic Open World genre and less like a real Harry Potter game.It's a nice game. Good, but not perfect. The student life could have been more detailed and the house choice should have played a bigger role. Overall the relation to the class mates was severly lacking. So were consequences and role playing options. Recommended for a single playthrough, but currently not replayable.

author: Crazyfaith
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a recently released action role-playing game that has generated a lot of buzz within the gaming community. As a longtime Harry Potter fan, I was eagerly anticipating its release, and I must say, I was not disappointed.Set in the 1800s, the game offers a new and exciting adventure within the magical world of Harry Potter. Players take on the role of a new student at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, where they attend classes, learn spells, and go on various quests throughout the game's expansive world.The game's graphics are stunning, and the attention to detail is impressive. The environments are vast, and players can explore not only the school of Hogwarts but also the surrounding areas, including Hogsmeade Village and the Forbidden Forest. The storyline is engaging and immersive, allowing players to interact with iconic characters from the Harry Potter universe, such as Albus Dumbledore and Severus Snape.One of the game's best features is the freedom it offers players to create their own unique character and personalize their experience at Hogwarts. With a wide range of customization options, players can choose their own path, attend classes and learn spells that suit their playstyle, and embark on various quests that affect the game's outcome.However, the game has received criticism for its handling of certain characters and themes. Some players have expressed concern about the game's lack of inclusivity and diversity, as well as its portrayal of sensitive topics such as race and representation. These issues have led to a debate about the game's overall message and its impact on the Harry Potter franchise.Overall, Hogwarts Legacy is an impressive game that offers a unique and immersive experience for fans of the Harry Potter universe. Despite some valid criticisms, the game is still a must-play for Harry Potter fans, offering an exciting new adventure in the wizarding world.

author: CB2099
review: Takes a while to get going, with a quite prolonged gameplay introduction, but onces it does, it's firing on all cylinders. Really well made, intense and engaging combat system, a plethora of customization options but most importantly, amazingly detailed locations and evironnements including a pretty much 1:1 Hogwarts recreation. Good cast of characters even if the main protagonist is a somewhat bland.A little bit to many collectibles for my taste but they are helpful for character progression so not useless for once. Exploration is delightful, especially on mounts / brooms.Just missing some Quidditch (although the stadium is present and explorable in the game) and it could be an almost perfect HP game.

author: Johnny
review: The world, scenery, the general ambience is superb, one of the best of any game I've played, but unfortunately everything else is generic and dull.For a game that was marketed for being an open world RPG it seems to fail at the latter, I've never felt immersed or interested in any quest, the characters all feel the same, there's only the good and the bad guys, you don't make any meaningful choices, nothing you do changes the outcome of the story, characters don't react to your actions, there's no actual classes to take and no basic romance options (something Bully from 2006 did well at the time), learning new magic is lacklustre, the talent system is basic, making potions and herbalism is uninteresting and it never feels like the game takes place in the 1800s.Speaking of the quests, the game is filled with awful collection quests that are directly linked to character progression (like inventory space, magic capacity and even learning magic while also being a big source of XP), the rest of the game is filled with theme-park-like open world POIs, like enemy camps, dungeons (or hole in the ground with a chest) and spider nests that are copy pasted everywhere. The game is also a bit unoptimised at the moment, the existence of Denuvo doesn't help.The only thing that made me continue playing longer that I should have was how beautiful the world is. Hogwarts Legacy is NOT a bad game, but I personally wouldn't recommend it when older games in this genre are better, not to mention that the game is clearly made for a very young audience or one who has very few games on their belt, I would say it is an excellent gift for your younger cousin or partner.

author: Qain
review: Some people are going to hate this review, some others will appreciate the criticism, some others will just jump in on the hate. I care about the first two.Hogwarts Legacy is a modern take on recreating the feelings that any person (Potterhead or not) felt when reading/watching the Harry Potter series. Thankfully, it manages to do so in spades. However there are quite a few points that cripple my final opinion on the game.Let's start with the visual presentation. You will find yourself immersed in a living castle, riddled with people moving from class to class, practising their spells, reading, gossiping about the new student or commenting on the houses' characteristics. What truly stands out though, is that once you step outside the castle, the whole world opens up to you, allowing you to traverse it in its entirety with very little loading time in between, with the exception being entering a cave or a scenario that is relevant to the plot. The best thing? It all looks GOOD! The geography looks amazing, regardless of where you are looking from (walking, riding a broom or a creature). This is not relegated to the environments, with particle effects (mostly present when producing magic) that resemble the same art style shown in the movies, with amazing fidelity. --TEN THOUSAND POINTS TO AVALANCHE!--Where the graphics can be a bit disappointing however is in some face renditions, mostly when dealing with non-cinematic facial expressions, and your character's, which looks comical when compared to others. Another problem, and this one is far more serious, is with performance. When I first installed the game (on the 7th) the game ran amazingly at 1440p, 80 to 100fps even with RayTracing on up until I reached Hogwarts, where the stuttering became so severe that I was looking at single digits of FPS for tens of seconds, up to minutes, depending on the scene, with no particular influence of player input. It took several days of tweaking and patches to figure out those issues, and while it's still not perfect, it was at least playable enough for me to finish the game. --ONE KA-JILLION POINTS TAKEN FROM AVALANCHE!--Soundtrack is, put simply, incredible. It perfectly encapsulates the *magic* that the movies portrayed while not being overly dense. Using the same beats and chimes from the original saga, it instantly transports the player to THAT place, thus helping with the feeling that you are a wizard in the wizarding world. It also introduces new original songs which fit the overall theme, as well as reuses some old classical songs (an instrumental reimagining of Lacrymosa, a piano rendition of Chopin's Nocturne Op9 and others). Sounds in general are great as well, adding impact to the spells and making them "punchy", and voices are really well acted, though once again, the main character lacks some gravitas regarding some situations and is not very expressive overall. --ONE THOUSAND SEPTILLION POINTS TO AVALANCHE!--Story wise, the game is set in Hogwarts and its surroundings in the late 1800s, when names such as Voldemort were simply unheard of. Taking a page off a typical D&D session, the story sets your own character as a student who is starting school as a fifth year, with the unique quality of being able to both see and wield ancient magic. Due to how you are inserted in the story, it is rather easy (and safe) to create a conflict based on it without harming the rich lore behind the universe. You will also encounter several students who.... require your help and provide some sort of context regarding the socio-political situation within both school and its surroundings. Extra points to Avalanche for trying to address the controversy regarding Rowling's statements on gender identity by introducing certain characters, and instantly taken away given the time period and the overall socio-political background for the time. --ZERO POINTS TO AVALANCHE!--Gameplay is where the game falters, badly. When you are within Hogwarts, the amount of tasks you are given seem.... tolerable at first; looking for butterflies which follow your Lumos spell, following key-shaped fireflies to their corresponding locks, you'd think it's not THAT bad, just a few hours of traversing (and getting to know) the castle. The problem arrives when you get a sense of scale with the broom and begin to realize just how many Points of Interest you will find as you travel along the map. "That cave looks interesting!" you might say to yourself, and as you approach and kill off a few spiders and enter ... only to find a short corridor that leads to a chest with equipment 5 levels below you.The same thing occurs with like.... 90% of the POI. Merlin trials for example (feather icons) take only a few minutes each, and contribute expanding to your gear inventory, which is very limited. Problem is that there are 95(!) of them scattered throughout the whole map, as are 16 daedelian keys, 20 ancient magic hotspots, 83 floo powder locations (fast travel)... the list goes on and on. What happens in the end? Choice Overload. You start to gauge the benefits of completing them, and you notice how out of the say 50 caves you've explored, 5 had something interesting, or how little these POI contribute to your overall experience. That's what I will call from now on, Open World Syndrome. If you take away the Wizarding World Universe, you have a generic open world game created in the same era as Far Cry 3.--TEN BILLION KA-JILLION POINTS TAKEN FROM AVALANCHE!--Sadly, it doesn't stop there. There are several inconsistensies regarding gameplay, some of which are married to the story:-You can "save" and "look after" fantastic creatures from poachers, but you can poach creatures yourself as well. --TEN POINTS TAKEN FROM AVALANCHE AND SOLD TO THE POACHERS!!---You can learn the unforgivable spells (Imperio, Crucio and Avada Kedavra), but by that point, you've killed enough people to make Voldemort kindly ask you to chill out and have a milkshake. --FIVE HORRCRUXES TAKEN FROM AVALANCHE!---You can behave like a proper ASS, refusing to help people or asking for more money/keeping what they asked you to get for them, yet your decisions have absolutely NO influence over your morality or the story itself. --FIFTEEN MORALLY AMBIGUOUS POINTS FROM AVALANCHE!---Other than two particular characters (Ominis and Sebastian and maaybe Poppy), any other NPC that could have been a companion (you don't get any) has very little background story to be interesting enough and follow their quests. --THREE POINTS TAKEN FROM AVALANCHE!---Mounts other than the broom have absolutely no advantage other than being part of the universe and come waaaay too late in the story. --ONE SADDLE-MOUNTED POINT FROM AVALANCHE!---Using spells is a huge mess. Since you are limited to four spells per set (limitation that comes from console I suppose), you have to constantly change your spellset in order to keep combos. This would not be a problem if using those spells didn't involve holding the right trigger (using Kbm is much better though). If you don't do it, you will trigger other actions (such as casting Protego, jumping, rolling, or worse yet, Lumos in the middle of a fight). --FIVE HUNDRED MILLION  POINTS FROM AVALANCHE!!-- Yet this is somehow counteracted by how FUN the combat can be once you get the hang of it --TWO POINT FIVE HUNDRED MILLION  POINTS TO AVALANCHE!!--In the end, I felt the game was dragging for too long even before the 15 hour limit and only pushed forward because the story in the end gets interesting enough.So... what's my final verdict? I lost track of the points. All I know is that the final result is a negative number.If you are adamant about experiencing the Wizarding World and don't mind the Open World tropes, get Hogwarts Legacy. If you are like me though, go ahead and skip this one, or get it at a great discount.

author: Terrapin
review: I'm not a big Harry Potter fan, and expected to refund this game after my 2 hour trial. But to my surprise, it's a good game. You can tell that a lot of effort went into making this game and it is one of the more polished AAA titles upon release that I have played in a while. The writing, design, graphics and gameplay are all topnotch. It is a bit of an "RPG lite" experience and is fairly demanding on your rig but after 8 hours I'm happy with my purchase and look forward to the rest of the adventure.

author: Schmaylor
review: Bad game? Definitely not. Worth buying? Debatable.I enjoyed the game when I first started it, but you reach a point where you're 60 hours in and you finally realize that you're not having fun. If this sounds familiar, it's probably because you've been sucked into the endless gameplay loop of Assassin's Creed: Odyssey or Assassin's Creed: Valhalla. This game is the same. This is an Assassin's Creed game. The similarities aren't even subtle. Awful "rarity" based loot system that has ruined countless other games, map icon collect-a-thons for characters who don't matter. The game's one selling point was being a student at Hogwarts, which it fails to deliver on. You interact with no one. You talk to no one. Students you walk by don't even have names. You can only make friends with quest NPCs, and you don't even have actual choice in this game. It's another game that insists on having dialogue options, while making each one totally meaningless.

author: cjknapp
review: 10/10This Game does everything you want it to if your a huge fan of the Harry Potter series.  I imagine its an excellent game if you know nothing about it.  But for the last two weeks I have felt like Bastian from the never ending story.  I would lock myself away, forget any responsibilities and dive into Hogwarts legacy.  First of all, the game is massive.  allow it to overwhelm you and then just let it take you where it does.  There is enough direction that you could finish the story in 40 to 50 hours if its your first time playing, your not using a guide and trying to speed through.  But this game is more than just the story,  it feels like your at hogwarts!  all the mysteries to unlock, friends to make,  things that match up with the stories and the cinema so well.  this game has stunning visuals,  The combat is excellent in my opionion.  I feel like a wizard and its a lot of fun. no complaints at the moment, I am almost at 100% completion on my first wizard and I have started a second.  I feel like the only complaint I will have is when there is no more content.  feels like a couple hundred hours away tho.just make sure you have a half way decent computer.  i know for a fact it runs pretty good on a 1060 6gb (just make sure ray tracing and microsoft HD are turned off) and it runs amazing with a 2070 Super 16gb in  4k on a 65' 4k TV.

author: Glizzy Macguire
review: Good god.My expectations for this game were not high and I was still let down. This world has a beautiful facade covering a swarm of boring mechanics. The magic was nice to look at and the Slytherin boys story was slightly compelling but the rest was just bland and repetitive. Your character is some milquetoast hero who is seemingly a natural master of magic while having the personality of a soggy piece of cardboard. You can make some slight changes to him or her at moments where the game gives you the options to either A. Be NiceorB. Be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥However the rest of the time you are literally a stick floating upright in a muddy river of bad storytelling.Maybe if they had spent less time with useless distractions like merlin trials and summoners court they could have possibly added quidditch? Or given us a real reason to explore the caves for something other than a useless wall hanging or a piece of clothing to sell at the nearest vendor for some gold?5/10 pretty sometimes, but mostly boring. I rushed myself through the final bits of the game just to get it over with and see if the ending redeemed the rest of the game. It did not.

author: Doc
review: So theres a lot to say about this game, ill try to make it as short as possible.First of, if you like the world of Harry Potter alot, just get it its a fun few hours and youll probably have a good time.Going more in depth tho, oh boy.Story:99% of the time i couldnt give a ♥♥♥♥ about any of the characters, the start is the first problem. After Proffesor Figs presumably long year friend dies, you just go on about your journey as if nothig happened, he even seems happy and cherrish while running around with you. His best friends died moments earlier, and there is not a single hint of sadness in his voice or acting. Thats just the start of many problems. The game takes a major backstab in what was established by games like Witcher 3 regarding decisions, you can select different dialog but it has no consequences you are feeling whatsoever, the ending aswell, you just get a different cutscene, its just, lazy. Normally i root for characters, have my preferences and try to be the good guy and help people and such, In this game, i just did whatever cause none of the characters could interest me in any ways, They are all very bland and shallow.Now to get a bit more technical:Combat, it is ... ok, theoretically there are "many" enemies and attacks / spell combos you can use, but in the end you either fight Spiders, Goblins, or Wizards, thats it. you tend to use the same spells over some time whatever tends to accomandate your playstyle, i will give it to them that the spells are well made, its fun using them and combining some, exploiting some enemies weaknesses to certain spells, but even the "Boss" fights are just super seized regular enemies, which doesnt make them stand out whatsoever.World: The World is nice, its not bad for sure, but outside of the places you know from books and films its just generic stuff, like very generic, a few villages a few caves some landscape that it, there is nothing remarkable, memorable about the map that stands out, big missed oppurtunity imo.Also diving couldve been such a huge and fun aspect of the game, discoering stuff in the lake and rivers, but no its just an animation an a loot item, such a lazy way to do it and a big missed oppurtunity.Technical:Voice:Voice acting is super boring, no one the voice actor seemed very well engaged, it might be due to the terribel audio which i will come to. The main characters voice is also really generic and boring, which might be due to the flexibility of gender and tone you can select for the MC, but it hurts the game more than it does it good. I never could connect with the MC in any meaningful way, and the voice played a big part in that.Audio: I haven't played a AAA game with such a bad audio design in a long time. I played on speakers and headphones and most problems appear on both systems. The volume mixing is awful, you have effect sounds and dialog that is super silent, then in a cut scene it blasts your ears out, Your spells are at moderate volume, one particular spell is super loud, there are so many inconsistencies between different actions, cutscenes, voices, effects its just a chore to listen to it. I fiddled a long time with the audio settings but no good middle ground could be found.Visuals:Not much to complain here, its nothing outstanding, especially for a title like this, but its ok. The lightning seems rather below standard but that might just be the look they wanted to go for, nothing exceptional, nothing too awful. Missed out on some huge scene opportunities tho, Like huge battles, Shots from the air that are impressive and stunning, i missed some really nice shots and there were a lot of chances for it. Room of Requirement:I dont know who thought this was a good idea. I dont want to play Sims, i want a good RPG, it may appeal to some people, but if that effort wouldve rather been put into other parts of the game they couldve accomplished a lot more. Yeah I just dont think it should exist in the way it is, Big time waste.Potions:Its a joke, a bad one at that. I wondered there was no DLC for faster brewing and plant growing, i dont want to sit around for 10mins waiting for plants to grow, or potions to finish. What in the actual?? Yeah you could start it and go back after doing some exploring or quests, but, no, just no. Not in a single player game for gods sake. You should buy and or pluck plants and brew potions instantly. Its the only way, made the game so annoying i cant even describe it.Exploration:Its just boring, i usually am a 100% dude, i love to roam a world and just do stuff, nothing quest related even, just go around and see the world, in this game its just a chore, i did it until i had the upgrades i wanted and then i couldnt be bothered to do it again. There are many ways to do it better but its just bad as it is.Quests:I can only really remember 1 minor side quests that wasnt one of the bigger ones that was memorable, again comparing to something like Witcher, its not even in the same universe, and with a world as rich as the HP one i think a lot more time and effort shoulve been put into it, it made the world seem dull and boringGames:The lack of any meaning full game like Quidditch (how is this not in the game????) or something even mentioned like gobstone is baffling to me.Conclusion:If you are not a huge fan of HP get it in a sale, If youre not into the HP franchise dont get it all, it wont give you much pleasure, I think they had an oppurtunity to make a remarkable game, and missed by a mile, maybe DLCs or updates will do something, but i doubt it

author: Britfox
review: Don't get me wrong, the game looks fantastic and the attention to detail in the castle, hogsmeade and its surrounding areas is insane, especially for someone who loved the Harry Potter films and books as a child. There are a lot of fun easter eggs and references that fans of the franchise will appreciate.Unfortunately once the rose-tinted glasses of nostalgia wore off for me I started to notice the game at its core for what it is, a rather generic (gameplay-wise) and uninspired open-world game filled with tedious side missions and fetch-quest content that is common-place in these sorts of games.The combat also suffers horribly from the really limited spell slots the game offers you, and I found myself having to frequently switch out spells to deal with certain situations because you just don't have enough space for all the important ones on your hotbars, and this constant breaking of gameplay flow really got on my nerves after a while.Its such a shame, because the developers have clearly spent a lot of time and effort making the game look and feel like the game all Harry Potter fans dreamed of as a child, but the gameplay falls very very flat, at least for me.

author: Havi
review: Beautifully crafted and brimming with amazing details, Hogwarts Legacy is a must-play for any fan of the wizarding world. From its stunning environments to its authentic lore accuracy, the game immerses you in the magic of Hogwarts. With a vast world to explore and countless collectibles to discover, I spent 65 wonderful hours achieving 100% completion. If you're looking for an unforgettable adventure, don't miss out on this game!

author: ⚧️𝓚ι𝓃z ❣
review: A game made for fandom (yes myself am a fan) and without being harsh... trash (to subject to criticism or invective) . I find the game to be ponderously tedious leaving myself bewildered where the magic has flown off to. The game play is modest at it's best, casting spells can be fun but the enemies are mindlessly unchallenging. Adventuring  around Britain in the 1800's  environment and geographic locations are monochrome distinctive I cant even imagine authentically living there.For myself that's all I have to say for the game being highly disenchanted. I was stupefy thinking this game will awe me but it's not and now I have to Avada Kedavra it off my hard drive.

author: MakaiAsh
review: The good: Beautiful environment, smooth/engaging combat, awesome soundtrack, HUGE map to explore, decent voice acting, and cute animals/beasts. Not to mention the only slap on the hand you get from performing Avada Kedavara is Professor Garlick saying, "Oh dear, I am afraid you've rather veered outside of the curriculum!"The bad: Linear, weak & lazy story/plot, not a choice matters game, no sell all button, poor pc optimization, morality in game does not matter, and some sub-quests seem cut short.Overall, I still recommend the game for hardcore HP fans such as myself. Though for those who may not be familiar with the lore may not find it as appealing due to all the issues I mentioned above. Still a lovely game. I am hoping they do a DLC or major update to add more content to the game and fix some quality of life things in-game. ;]

author: Gree∂
review: It took me 80 hours on hard to get all achievements. I loved the game, but some things need improvement.Pros:+ A whole AAA game world to explore+ Fun combat+ Those who love stealth won't be dissapointed+ Arsenal of spells to obliterate your opponents+ Lots of side activities like gardening/potion making, saving/breeding of magical beasts, building your own Room of Requirement+ Interesting side storiesCons:- Main story kinda sucks, it's short and most of the content can only be unlocked through main story progress, exploring the world without progressing will make you suffer (you will have to re-explore each location after each story update as you can't open doors, collect statues, whatever until)- Your actions have 0 consequences, you can't role-play an evil character as all of the NPCs love you regardless of your dialog choices, usage of Unforgivable Curses an so on.- Pretty linear story line, the ending is decided based on 1 dialog and still changes nothing- AI of enemies sucks sometimes- Treasure vaults suck, often puzzles are broken, loot is missing, it appears they were autogenerated on the release day without any testing, there's no checkmark on the map when the vault is looted- Grind to get achievements- FPS drops

author: dasrehimblutagain
review: It's not that I really would not recommend this game... The world including Hogwarts itself and small villages is beautiful. You can't help but walk around and explore it. The combat is decent and even allows to combine spells to achieve a (sometimes) meaningfull effect.But everything else is bland to say the least. The protagonist has no personality. The roleplaying is nonexistent. In dialogs the only options you have are usually a goody two-shoes response and a mean response. And whichever you choose - won't in any way affect the world around you.There is no meaningful conseqences of your decisions and actions. Although I'm by far not a fan of imposing morals on a player, this game is in dire need of a morality system to make it more meaningful. NPC are forgettable. There is absolutely no emotional bond to them. Time and again, I found myself wondering why teachers call these people my "friends". Seeng as even their personal quests never managed to give me a feeling of accomplishing something great or important together. And that there is no meaningful interaction with them between the quests. All quests are mostly divided into four types:1) go talk to someone 2) go acquire this thing and use it X times to proceed with another quest3) dungeons with intermittent puzzle/combat gameplay4) go find X amount of things hidden across the world and get usually nothing of any significance to the gameplay or to the story.The loot is abundant and even overflowing. But limited in variety. Clothing properties and design can be changed for almost any item, and things with better stats can be found approximately every 10 minutes. Thus, no piece of gear has that individual value that makes you want to hold onto it, upgrade it, and think twice before replacing it. The best thing that can be said about crafting is that it is present in the game.The world, although teeming with monster dens, enemy camps, and the "Collect X anount of Y" quests' objectives, feels empty. Open world enemy encounters are generic, add nothing to the story and quests, and yield the same meaningless loot upon completion. To sum up: the game is for you if you'd like to get lost in a magically beautiful world and just wander around, or if you are a die-hard fan of this universe. But do not expect it to stir you intellectually or emotionaly.

author: SH3MA
review: Harry Potter fan here.I was playing this game on the first week, with all the problems, maybe until now something have changed.My review not including mods, just the clean game.Pros:- the most atmospheric game in HP universe.- create your own character and feel a part of this magical world.- huge world to explore (mostly Hogwarts).- you can fly on a broom and enjoy the magic world from the books.- the most detailed and beautiful Hogwarts ever.- interactions with all the stuff around you, also the small ones, like play with cats, with globus, drink a cup of tea and this is only in Hogwarts, there is also Hogsmeade with bunch of interesting stuff.- much customization.- beautiful graphics.Cons:- terrible female face textures.- boring missions (go there, bring me that and so on).- they made the storyline look longer, otherwise we could finish the game in 4 hours.- no realistic interaction with other students or teachers (while it's the most important in being at school). You can use avada kedavra and other prohibited spells in front of other students and teachers, nobody will react on that. Yea, so I'm killing everyone, so what?- the game becoming boring, because it's super repetitive.- open world, but there is not so much to do.- you need until 70+- hours to close ALL of the content in the game, including ALL of the collections (which is more than 1k items).To sum up, I can't recommend this game, especially not for such a price.For me it's not worth it, and I paid 55 euro, it's a lesson for me to have patience.If atmosphere is everything you need in a game, then feel free to take this one.I also thought that's I will like it very much, even if something will be bad, because I was waiting for so long to this game, but in the end I've played 20 hours and I don't feel motivated to open this game again, and that's why I don't recommend it.

author: CallMeTristan37
review: An excellent interpretation of the Wizarding World and an exceptionally fulfilling experience as a whole, Hogwarts Legacy is precisely what you would want in a video game set inside of the world-renowned, beloved Harry Potter universe. The main story is a masterfully crafted narrative of our witch or wizard and their peculiar attunement for a mysterious branch of sorcery, known as ancient magic. We arrive at Hogwarts school of Witchcraft and Wizardry at the end of the 19th century as a latent fifth year, during a particularly hostile goblin rebellion instigated by one of the game's main antagonists; a devious goblin named Ranrok. During the game, we go to classes, make friends, complete tasks and learn and master many aspects of magic. We, along with the occasional help of our professors, friends and other companions, use these skills against the forementioned revolution and other wicked enemies. From the marvelous combat involving spells and weaponized botany, to the exhilarating flying upon a myriad of swift brooms or enthralling magical beasts, unto exploration of a large, diverse and vigorous map, laden with hidden secrets, demanding trials, valued treasures and dangerous encounters.  From the bottom of my heart, I truly recommend this game to anyone even slightly interested in open world fantasy RPG:s and especially to all Harry Potter book and movie fans. The portrayal of the world and story the fine people at Avalanche Software have created is truly magical.

You get spammed with new Gear all the time and selling them is the only source of income, which is rather odd.All in all, the game does many things right and exceed what I expected. Other things could have been better though. 9/10

author: Log Halley
review: 8/10game is good, wish it focused more on being a student at hogwarts and less about being a hero/chosen one saving the lands of Scotland its too little of a student wizard RPG, and too much of a generic fantasy open world action gamegonna drop tons of complaints in no particular order- the game is too little simulative. cant sleep, cant sit, cant even emote for screenshots— we can eat, but its just grabbing bites of decorative items. whats the point of the great hall? — the castle at night is completely empty including dorms. wheres everyone gone? — also there's no curfew at all. which i found weird because i played other harry potter games. — classes are underdeveloped. theres only 1 each, and then the assignments. you go, kill 2 wolves, come back and you learn a spell. could have been fun, its just a chore this way— no house cup— no quidditch— no potions minigame - the loot/gear system sucks, and cosmetic being tied to it sucks more— equipment with quality tiers doesnt fit the setting at all, no reason why putting on glasses should increse my defence— anytime i change gear, i have to go back and change the appearance of the item. most people dont want to wear funny glasses, but need them for stats, so we have to put them on and then change the appearance to have back our look— also there's too much gear, and most of it is pointless. so many times i get into a dungeon, i solve a puzzle, i win a fight, and my reward is a jacket with worse stats than the one i have. this happens hundreds of times, filling up my inventory, making me go back and forth from hogsmeade to sell the stuff, with no button to sell it all, which means all the items have to be sold one by one, and there's hundreds— too many cosmetics clip with each other. some scarves are nice, but they dont fit my other clothes- the open world is handled the ubisoft way— its big for the sake of being big, and its filled with hundreds of pointless copy-pasted activities. there are way way too many copy-pasted merlin trials, and their unskippable cutscene kills me a little every time it plays— also dungeons, and in a way hamlets. copy-pasted content made to fill a map that's too big for no reason- MC is a psychopath— this character kills hundreds and blames them after— i cant understand how avada kedavra is unforgivable, but reducing someone to the size of a mouse and stepping on them to death isnt— we kill bad evil poachers, while we kidnap animals building our noahs ark to farm their ingredients. the excess animals we "rescue", we sell for gold. totally unlike poachers right— i know this is a game, but how our story is that we're a wizard for a few days and we already manage to kill both goblins and adult wizard could have been handled better— also the character repeats his reaction lines too much. same for the floo powder lady.- no companion system— we get people with us on some missions, but most of the time we're alone. i played the harry potter games on ps2 and our character was almost never alone. skyrims been out a few months, shouldnt be complicated to copy the way companions work— also houses are made pointless. i get that you didnt want to make every slytherin evil and every gryffindor good, but you went way too far in the other direction, making houses just colors to wear. there’s also very little friend/enemy dynamic with other students— also where's the companion from ravenclaw? we get 1 character with a questline from every other house, other than ravenclaw. maybe i missed it but i dont think so. amit is fun, he should have more quests— why no pets? we're at hogwarts, yet we cant have a owl, a mouse, a cat. we can name animals in the room of requirements, but our interactions are limited to magically feeding and brushing. cant even pet them. - character creation sucks a lot— too little options, and my characters look different than it did in the character creator. seems like hes been taking daily sunbaths for 2 weeks between when i created him and when i got to play him- broom controls are bad, and the up/down being tied to the right stick means we wont ever be able to control the camera to look up or down- alohomora is a spell used to open locks, it shouldnt lead to a lockpicking minigame— also alohomora having 3 tiers sucks. unlocking it and then still being unable to open all doors made it feel wrong, and it adds the chore of looking for demiguises before exploring more- olivander becomes useless after the game. wish he would at least sell wand handles- wish we had a POV mode to take screenshots. anytime i take one, i get the back of my character taking half the pic
