author: Fanciful Imp
review: + Beautiful looking game+ Combat can be fun for a bit- Empty game- Boring quests- Repetitive open-world design- No real challenge- Tediously bad puzzles- No replay valueA beautiful game with absolutely zero substance. It's almost like the developers took every thing that makes an open world game bad and compiled it into one single game. Well, congratulations to them because that is exactly what they achieved with Hogwarts Legacy. Hogwarts is EMPTY. Imagine making a game "Hogwarts" Legacy and the majority of the playtime is OUTSIDE of Hogwarts. That wouldn't be such a big deal if the developers actually made you do stuff in it, but guess what? It's EMPTY. There is no incentive to be in Hogwarts whatsoever other than collecting Ubisoft-eseque collectibles or interacting with main characters to progress the story. And boy, oh boy, did they put every piss-poor type of collectible that is present in open world games all into this one. There are no engaging mini-games in Hogwarts, no fun activities, no interesting lessons, no house cups to compete in... absolutely nothing to do in such a otherwise highly detailed castle. It's beyond underwhelming and confusing as to why I'm even roleplaying as a student, and the House you go with serves no purpose other than "Hey look, I'm Gryiffindor... Yay?" You don't even learn spells during classes in Hogwarts; instead you have to perform mobile game quality quests to earn new spells (kill x 5 times in this way). It's not like the spells are fun to use anyway considering the majority of them achieve the same results.As for the open world exploration? EMPTY. It's a collectible fest. What were they thinking? The side quests are garbage fetch quests, there are bunch of pointless, boring and tedious activities plaguing the map. Don't get me started on the below average quality puzzles, which would be fine if there weren't too many of them, all of which are there to simply waste your time and pad out game time. It's incredibly unfortunate because the world design is phenomenal and one the best I've seen. But nothing other than shopkeepers can be interacted with. This whole game is just "see but don't touch".The combat is fun for a while but eventually, its gets old real quick. It was never challenging to begin with and you just get more and more powerful the more you progress your stats. New spells won't be enough to keep you interested. I couldn't care less about the story or any of the characters I have interacted with. They're all agreeable, one dimensional characters, and the main character, YOU, is the best wizard/witch in the whole universe. There are no consequence to anything you do, even if you choose an "evil" dialogue option or use forbidden spells.I feel like their design philosophy for this game was "Let's put everything so that players can't complain that there is nothing." What I mean by that, is that they did way too much than necessary to the point it started to affect the game's quality: Too many upgrades from too many sources, too much of the same spells, too much of the same quests, too many chests behind too many locked rooms (which, unsurprisingly, also needs too many upgrades to unlock). It seems like they did too much of all the terrible open world design combination to compensate for game's emptiness.This game has NO replay value and frankly, I don't even feel like continuing playing anymore. You can plough through the main quests and probably have a good times, but as for completionists like myself, this game is a nightmare to explore. I don't recommend the game at full price, wait for a sale.

review: Pros:+ great looking game (sometimes)+ combat is pretty fun when you get the hang of it+ the world looks great and Hogwarts is pure nostalgia for people who grew up with the books/movies and always wanted to explore the school in a videogame+ story is predictable but fun enough+ cool little minigame that lets you customize everything about a room, expanding as you progress the main story+ cool little monster catching minigame that lets you capture, breed and take care of beastsCons:- lockpicking minigame that will get on your nerve- your actions have no real consequences, neither does your house (only some quests have a different ending but it's minimal)- best skills are locked until you are almost at the end of the game- assassin's creed style open world, it's full of repetitive tasks - performance seems to vary for people, was having major stutters until I upgraded to 32 GB of ram (recommended system requirements is a joke and it should be 32GB of ram)- voice acting of your character is a letdown, everyone is dying around you and he just talks like it's no big dealSidenote:Overall a 7,5/10. The game is fun if you like the Harry Potter world, just don't expect a Witcher, Mass Effect kind of game where your actions matter.

author: PhoenixCyanFire
review: This is a good game, but the reason I am giving it a negative review is because of the fact that as of right now, the game is very poorly optimised for PC. Regardless of hardware. The game has a lot of bugs, and it doesn't feel very fleshed out and finished in some areas. I am sure future patch updates will fix these issues, but I cannot currently recommend the game on PC in its current state. You are better off buying this game for console in its current state.- Infinite loading screens during the room of requirement- Ungodly amounts of stuttering- Outdated DLSS Files- Horrible Optimisation- Not all cutscenes are skip-able- Consistent FPS Drops- Visual glitches - Ridiculously long loading screens (Practically unplayable on HDD unless you are willing to wait upwards of 10+ minutes)- Infinite Loading Screen glitch occasionally happens during some quests, for me, It happened when I tried to take Sebastian to Hogsmede- Censorship can be annoying for some players- PS5 Exclusive content isn't available on PC without modding it in, which is likely against ToS- Really annoying Audio bugs causing the Player character to have a very Robotic mechanical like voice- Characters popping in and out of the world, and sometimes falling through the ground^ IF some of these issues can be resolved, my review might change to positive. But again, in the game's current state ON PC, I do not recommend buying this.- I will be very clear, I am leaving JK Rowling out of this review because I separate art from artists, I do not support JK Rowling at all, but I still wanted to play the game. But my hatred for JK Rowling has zero impact on my review, this is a non-biased review.Edit: As of the most recent update most of these issues have been fixed. There are still a few issues, however MOST of them have been fixed, so I can recommend this game now.

And Hogwarts.. they made me feel that way.This game was worth it to wait for, after delay after delay and now that it has been released it feels so unreal. Hogwarts Legacy is best 70euros I have ever spended for any type of deluxe version of the game, the story (i finished it yesterday) was amazing. author: Scientist X
review: The world, the combat and the various activities you can do in this game are just amazing, it isn't one of those open-worlds where the icons on the map are overwhelming and become a chore after a while. Side missions are engaging with quite a bit of variety. They have nailed the  part of the game as well. You actually have to do  to be able to learn and unlock various spells. I just wish the spell management system via set was a bit better, it becomes a but cumbersome to juggle the sets in the heat of the combat.Now coming to the biggest issue - I have 5800x + 3080 + 64GB RAM and the game runs on an NVME, yet the shaders load slowly every time I launch the game. I'm playing at 4k with DLSS at Performance without any Ray-tracing (Ray-tracing absolutely sucks in this game) and yet FPS constantly drop to under 25, sometimes to 15 when loading a new environment/scene. After a while you don't notice the performance drop but it's horrible. Reminds me of the time when I played AC Revelation at 15 fps on a core2duo.I definitely recommend this game but the performance issues have to be fixed ASAP

author: Stampeder
review: An extraordinary game with extraordinary quality I've not seen in years from a developer I've not come into contact with before. Well done, Avalanche Software!Please keep up the good work and hope you guys will continue to polish the game further to iron out the oddities here and there, such as the mood-breaking return-to-neutral-expression-between-sentences facial animation on NPCs and the weird Ray Tracing issues in certain areas (one treasure vault was blindingly bright while certain part of the lake reflects light that it shouldn't be reflecting; oh, my scarf sparkles too).For those who are interested in a game based on the Wizarding World, look no further. The issues I mentioned are really just nitpicking. This game is of AAA quality right off the bat, and they already improved the PC issues on the actual launch day. You don't even get this quality in many of the supposedly AAA developers these days anymore.The money's totally worth it. Watching movies and buying books to read would easily cost more than this game's pricetag, and you can't even modify anything in the movies/books, but you can do things in a game. Don't say the price isn't justified.

author: The Emperor Of Milfgaard
review: My only concern was performance but it seems like it is fine. Granted I have a very beefy PC I still think having 120fps at 1440p on ultra with RT is good performance, granted you will need frame generation to get there.The graphics are amazing, the voice acting phenomenal, sound design in general is very well done, I love hogwarts, I love the landscape, I love the exploration aspect they went with.If you came looking for a game that isn't "woke", you are wrong here, because this game immediately has aspects that you can easily describe as woke. I don't like it, but it is not a deal breaker, since everything else about this game is great with one exception:Why the frick they give you alohomora so late I do not know. For everyone else: do not explore anything, rush main quests until you get alohomora, and then start exploring. It will save you a lot of pain and going through  everything three times over. This is just really stupid design if you ask me. They should give you alohomora right from the start without you having to unlock several levels of the spell.

author: average nuke enjoyer
review: After my time played so far, I am sold on this game. I'm enjoying the puzzles, the small details of magic all around Hogwarts, the combat is more or less what I expected, and the world is beautiful. The characters are quite a bit more diverse than they really should be given the setting, but it's not particularly detracting from my experience overall due to them not being my focus.I never liked Harry Potter for the writing and characters much anyways, certain key parts here and there, sure... But it was always everything else I liked, and this game is delivering on that so far. The books held me as a child through the theater of the mind constructing a magical world, and the movies held me even more. I hope Avalanche gets to make a sequel or some other game in the universe, because they've done a pretty good job when weighed against their development history. The only other thing I can find to be critical about that detracts from the experience is that the game does have genuine reports of performance issues. The one I've experienced is a periodic yet brief slowdown when the game starts building shaders as it needs to. It is a little bit annoying, but it's never happened to me in a moment where it was genuinely a problem. As for the boycott, I think it actually made the game sell more copies. L + Didn't Work + Ratio + Revelio + Accio + Diffindo + Incendio + Confringo

review: Most likely the game of the year. Without a doubt one of the most magical games this generation. Like a Harry Potter RDR2. I've never played anything like it. Only real negative so far is performance issues, but they should be resolved by an update.

author: Mr Radical
review: If you're not a fan of Harry Potter, this game doesn't really have anything new and fun to add to the table. The game seemed to be marketed as some sort of RPG, but it has incredibly little in the way of good actual RPG elements (like a compelling story with choices that affect it). There are lots of side quests of different sorts of puzzles, but there are tons and tons of them. The map is quite big and scenic, but it's all rather repetitive- for example, there are probably 15-20 villages, but there is very little to distinguish them. Also, as far as side characters, they completely disappear from the game once you've done their side quest. It would be nice if there were more activities to do with the characters that are supposed to be your friend, but there are almost none. Also, I'll be the millionth person to say that a Harry Potter game not having quidditch is one of the biggest misses imaginable. Growing up as a huge fan of Harry Potter, it was basically my favorite thing to imagine myself doing. They put a lot more effort into a system of growing plants, making potions, and tending to animals. The animal system is very in depth, but not terribly exciting as far as Harry Potter goes. Wouldn't it make more sense to find the animals, catalog them, rather than capture them and keep them in your pen? The combat system was heavily criticized online, but I think it's one of the thing about the game that was done quite well. I think once you learn a few spells, it gets quite fun. The dodging can be a little clunky, but the comboing feels very fluid and interesting. Some of the criticisms about the antisemitism in the story seem a little sensationalized, but I definitely think there are several elements to the story that are amiss (the bad guys are fighting for... equality?) sometimes once your character clears out a Goblin camp, they will say something like "It's too late for you to change your ways!" which sounds a little dark, and doesn't help the games image. On the plus side, at least, the inclusion of Sirona Ryan is a nice touch. It's a nice gesture by the game creators to have a transgender character who is an important part of the story, and an interesting character to boot. Still, I can't get it out of my head that one of the goblins says, "I agree with you, violence isn't the answer!" to the leader of the goblins, which is an incredibly milquetoast, neoliberal vision of the world. I suppose that fits with JK Rowling's style, much to the detriment of this game. Like I said, if you're a Harry Potter fan, it's probably worth playing. Otherwise, I wouldn't recommend this to RPG fans at all.

author: Grizzleyman
review: After 24 hours of game play I can say with confidence that this game is simply. Just. Fun.Sure there are some things about the game that could have been done much better, such as the itemization in the game, pet buffs, or even being able to add some smaller details within the games core to make it feel even more enjoyable when times in the game get stale and repetitive. Despite the cons, the game is seriously one of a kind. The only problem is FPS. For those who are having problems with FPS (I was having so much trouble getting stable frames over 30fps during some areas and cut scenes). I have a 3070 paired with 32 gb of ram and a decent cpu so I should be getting well over 60 frames even on max graphics. That was the complete opposite during the first couple of hours in the early access. Come to realize that majority of everyones FPS drops were coming from outdated graphics card drivers and just the game being poorly optimized in some instances. If you're still having problems with FPS and you run wallpaper engine in the background as I do with multiple monitors. Turn off Wallpaper Engine and try playing the game and see if that fixes anything (fixed majority of my major FPS drops in multiple cut scenes and areas). I recommend this game to anyone who is curious to purchase because in all honesty, there's something in this game for everyone to enjoy. I rate the game a 8.9/10

review: Not even that big of a Harry Potter fan, but got hit by a bit of nostalgia from playing the PlayStation One game.Took a chance and am pleasantly surprised, way better than I thought it would be.- Map is pretty big.- Hogwarts castle is huge.- First hour story was interesting.- Combat looked boring, but its not bad, better than Witcher 3 dodge mania.- Some side fetch quests, but combined with some interesting story.- Looks like you can plant your own crops, to make your own potions, always nice.- Gear seems a little too simple, but there is transmog.- Hard difficulty isn't hard.I think its pretty good, so if you're a HP fan you will probably love it.

author: Nightserg
review: Hogwarts Legacy is the perfect example of why you should not tell others what not to buy. It goes to show, no one cares or believes that Rowling is a bad person, and the Harry Potter franchise is still very dear to a lot of us. But online hate and all that aside, is Hogwarts Legacy worth it? Not as much as many would make you believe. It's a fine game, but it still suffers from the open-world fatigue and incredibly boring and repetitive things you do in it.  👍 +Sebastian side-quest+Combat can get crazy later on+Hogwarts and Hogsmeade are incredibly detailed👎-Main story-Boring, repetitive, and easy "puzzles"-Enemy varietyThe main story is as interesting as a wet fart. You play as a random character that you create, who finds himself caught in a strange plot set out by some goblin thugs. Things get revealed to you really quickly that you are special and you have ancient powers, because of "reasons" and you are tasked to complete several tasks to train your ancient powers as well as uncover what the goblins are up to. Not much else interesting happens in the main story at all, you fight goblins and some humans and you stop their evil plan to use ancient magic, and that's it. You'll never get attached to any of the characters, not even Professor Fig, mostly because you rarely interact with any of the main cast. The main story lacks a lot of what makes Harry Potter charming. The story feels like it was made on a factory line. The only redeemable story-related aspect of Hogwarts Legacy is the major side-quest involving Sebastian, a Slitherin student, and his sister. It's a long side-quest, and it will be the path for your character to learn powerful and forbidden spells if you should choose to. It was 10 times better than the main quest, had a more emotional impact, and Sebastian played quite well as your companion. It's a shame this path or quest you go on, was not connected completely to the main quest, and even worse, no major repercussions on whether you learn or not these spells. Story rating: 6.5/10I'll split the gameplay part into two: exploration stuff and combat stuff. The combat is great as you will learn quite a high number of unique and well-known spells. The spell system is basically like the ranged version of Batman Arkham games. You have a dodge, parry, or block system, you aim at your targets easily and just combo your spells, for example, you can use Levioso to levitate the enemy in the air and then just smash him on the ground or pull him toward you and then fireball him. All the spells have colors on them to indicate which spells to counter the enemy shields which are also colored. It's a bit tough at the start, but once you get into it, it becomes second nature to you. And just like in Arkham games, the ancient power functions like your ultimate spell which does random things to your enemies. You can also stealth a lot of the encounters but the enemy AI is practically brain-dead and it becomes so easy that you'll force yourself into combat. While the combat is indeed great and satisfying, the enemy variety is absolute dog sht. I haven't seen a worse game than this in a long time. All you're going to fight is goblins, some humans, and spiders the entire game. Bosses? Have fun fighting the same troll boss at least 10 times. It is a disgrace to the huge variety of creatures the franchise has. Absolute pathetic. The exploration is not so great, especially outside Hogwarts and Hogsmeade, and even in these two specific places outside of visuals which I'll talk about later, gameplay-wise it's boring as hell. There is nothing to do besides solve the same math door puzzles 100 times, taking a butterfly to its destination a million times, or unlocking a gazillion of chests. Outside of these locations get ready to do 100 merlin puzzles which are basic as hell, pop balloons, and collect other crap. Speaking of chests, you get clothes that you can equip on your character for different stats, however, you have a very limited amount of inventory for them and to unlock more, you have to do those tedious merlin puzzles. If I was a 10-year old maybe I wouldn't mind all of this so much but the open-world fatigue is real and it's not even a good open world. There are other mechanics like upgrading your spells, and having your own special room where you can craft potions, tame beasts, and design your own place as you see fit. They're all-time wasters with 0 value or impact on anything. Gameplay rating: 7/10Voice acting is pretty good, even your main custom character and I don't think I've ever heard someone sound uninteresting. Shame the writing isn't that good. The soundtrack is pretty good as well, it sounds very Harry Potter'ish if that is even a word, basically fits perfectly with the whole magical adventure. As for the sound effects, sadly not so great, especially in interiors when you're blasting spells left and right the bass is incredibly annoying and boom'ish, so much that it muffles the music, the voices, everything. Audio rating: 7.5/10Let's start with the best:  Hogwarts and Hogsmeade. Both of these locations are visually stunning and filled to the brim with huge amounts of details, great level design, and random encounters. A lot of effort went into making these two locations, no doubt but the problem is, you feel very detached from them as if you are not part of the world. In all the encounters you happen upon, you have no control, no reaction, nothing unlike all events in RDR2 for example. Outside of these locations, things start to get ugly and the generic open-world aspect starts to show its true fangs. Performance-wise the game is a mess, with lots of crashes and bugs, loadings in the open world, and ray-tracing features that are absolutely useless and look worse than without, with the exception of the reflections because they completely nerfed/removed most of the SSR features to make RT look better. Absolute shameful. We had working mirrors in games 20 years ago but now it's not possible without RT? Cmon. Typical UE4 bs. Graphics, performance and tech analysis score: 7/10Honestly, I was considering giving the game a thumbs down, but it's not bad, it's extremely overrated because of the online drama and because we finally got a Harry Potter game, but if none of that existed and this game would've been called anything else, I can guarantee you, the steam ratings would be much lower, at mixed. Even as a fan of the franchise, I'd say, get it on sale.

author: Ence
review: Hogwarts Legacy is definitely a must have game for all HP fans. When you are travelling around Hogwarts and its neighborhood, you can feel the spirit of the books and movies. The overall atmosphere of the castle and the world around are the most important aspects of the game and I give developers much credit for transferring Rowling’s world into a PC game the way they did.On the other hand, the game has some issues when it comes to other gaming features. From my point of view, the following are the most serious:After deep thinking, unless you are a true HP fan, I do not recommend to buy the game (at least not right now when the price is still quite high). After finishing the game, I must say I do not feel satisfied enough when I consider the money and time spent needed to play and finish it.

author: IIsmilesII
review: A beautifully made game that feels like a modern, late 2000s arpg with strong Fable vibes for me! So many things to love and only small things ever feel like they're missing (like not being able to sit) which really serve no purpose in an arpg, the game and world are just that great! The day one patch really helped performance for me as well and it now runs nearly flawlessly.

author: level 9 Drow
review: Thank the boycott for the Streisand effect, the game benefited a lot from the faux outrage. I was on the fence until that happened. Aside form that the game is beautiful looking and I never thought casting spells would be like Batman: Arkham Asylum style action combat. It felt more like fencing in melee than ranged fighting. Seriously, I want to live in Hogsmead please.

author: Kadaeux
review: Just tune out the alphabet people and enjoy this fantastic game. Truly immersive, passable writing, enjoyable story, PHENOMENAL combat system. I might be a little old for the target demographic as I found the puzzles too easy, but a very enjoyable game.

author: xRMGx
review: Alright, so since they are not going to allow me to refund the game because I have played over two hours, I will just blast it in my review and hopefully help someone else in my stead.  For the first time in years, I pre-purchased a game, Hogwarts Legacy, and I pre-purchased the deluxe edition because I knew I was going to be playing as soon as it released.  And, for the most part, the game has not disappointed.  It is beautiful, gorgeous even, and immersive.  The world-building is on par in its “epicness” to the likes of Skyrim and GTA.  Not to mention, the world feels very much alive with all of it its small details, sounds, etc.  It is very fleshed out and I truly feel like I am a part of it.  Indeed, it is quite noticeable the extent of thought, love, and hard-work that went into Hogwarts Legacy.  I can see myself investing hundreds of hours of my time exploring, questing, and just having fun.However, Hogwarts Legacy is a product of its time -- a late 19th century world clearly built in 2023.  First example of what I mean by that:  There are no pronouns, everyone is they or them or their.  Me, I am playing a 15-year-old boy, clearly, a 5th year male Hogwarts student.  However, I am not addressed as he or him by NPCs; I am addressed as they, them, and their.  And, yes, it is noticeable; it feels forced and un-natural.  And, no, there is no choice in how you are addressed.  We are supposed to be in 1890s Hogwarts but the dialog sure does not feel or sound late Victorian.  Second example:  This game, as we know, is taking place in the late 19th century, but there exists an openly transsexual NPC and there is another NPC that not only is openly homosexual but is also married.  During this era there would not have been openly trans or homosexual people, let alone homosexual marriage.  That is not meant to be offensive, that is a fact.  And facts are stubborn things:  Such "activities" would have been very much indeed closeted, if not illegal, let alone even existing.  And all of this, by the way, I personally did not know until after having discovered them within the game myself, hence, Steam, why I requested a refund with so much time played:  Because the developers and the publisher were not transparent in the development of their own game prior to releasing it!As for play-ability, I do not know if it is because of Denuvo for certain, but I am confident that it is considering my rig is a beast, not to mention state-of-the-art (spared no expense), but my game will CTD when loading my last save, either right before the save is loaded or shortly after getting into the game, especially after hibernating my PC and launching the game the next day.  Sometimes, it will not even let me load the game -- I click Play from my Steam Library, or double click the shortcut, my Steam status changes to in-game but then mysteriously drops without the game even launching.  In this case, I must completely restart my PC to get the game to launch.  The former, I just try and try again and eventually I can play.  There are also these massive frame rate losses that do occur seemingly at random, out of the blue.  I enter a classroom to speak to a professor, for example, engage in dialog with the professor, and my frames drop to 30-40.I also want to mention here, to drive home the point in the failure of transparency on part of the developers and publisher, Denuvo was imposed in the 11th hour.  I would not have pre-purchased if Denuvo was a thing from the get-go.  Indeed, this game has taught me to never pre-purchase a game, ever, no matter how it is perceived or presented -- wait for after release and wait for reviews after release before purchasing, lest something like Denuvo be added at the 11th hour, or the game be not what is perceived to be even with outrage mobs.So, in conclusion, the game is beautiful and immersive, but do not get me wrong:   it also is woke; it is agenda-driven.  If you are looking for a Wizarding World game to escape the contemporary politics of real life, this is not the game for you, stranger.  Hopefully with Denuvo they will just simply remove it at some point; if they do, that part of my review will become moot.  Nevertheless, I really hope this review helps someone in making an informed decision prior to purchasing.  Here’s to hoping Starfield will be better.  Cheers for reading, and happy gaming!Edit:  Curious that it's saying I received this for free.  I most certainly did not.  Maybe because I tried to refund it and was rejected???

author: Remoraid Simp
review: While I have enjoyed my time playing Hogwarts Legacy so far and would definitely recommend it as an entertaining and casual game that's content-rich and worth the $60 price tag, there are a number of things that have left me scratching my head throughout my time in the game so far and left me somewhat unsatisfied as a long-time Harry Potter fan. There are some spoilers below, so fair warning there. I first want to quickly highlight some of the things that the game does right, especially the combat. The combat is fluid, and the game does a really good job of making you feel powerful with only a few spells under your belt. The Talents (skill trees) are all pretty cool, adding to the combat in meaningful ways - cursing multiple enemies deals damage to all of them at once, the upgraded roll-dash is rad, extra layers for equipping multiple sets of spells, casting spells like Accio affects groups of enemies instead of just single enemies at a time, etc. The combat is fluid and largely interesting, and I think this is a real strong point of the game. The game has plenty of content in it, with hundreds of collectibles, a very sizable map, etc. There's plenty to keep you busy for dozens of hours, which is what I would expect from a $60 release in 2023. That said, there are a number of things that disappoint as well. One of my biggest problems with the game is that the loot system feels essentially meaningless. Every piece of loot that I've found throughout the game so far is a clothing item, a solid majority of which have terrible stats and end up being useless. The only consistent way of earning money in the game that I've found so far is by selling your clothing items to merchants, so 90% of the time you're just going to sell everything you find. Yet after selling your items, you're still able to equip the cosmetics from those items over the gear you're wearing through the game's secondary cosmetic menu along the lines of layered armor in Monster Hunter or transmog in Cyberpunk. So in the end, the general lifecycle for loot is: find a single random scarf in a chest at the end of a dungeon/quest, immediately sell it because of its terrible stats and that being your primary source of income, then equip its cosmetic anyways over the random hodgepodge of gear you have equipped. It makes a large percentage of the loot that you find uninteresting, since you know you're just going to sell it and still be able to use it cosmetically whenever you want regardless. Then you have the Merlin Trials, puzzles scattered throughout the map which, upon completing them, solely reward you with more inventory space for storing more clothing items. I never have any clothing items in my inventory anyways because they're largely pointless to keep and I need the money, so why would I go do the Merlin trials to get more space to store even more of them? In the end, the game disincentivizes both its looting system and one of its widespread puzzle systems/main early-game points of interest in one fell swoop. Another aspect of the game that's been somewhat underwhelming is the dialogue. Much of the characters' dialogue drags on and on, often over-explaining things that are immediately obvious while not addressing other pieces of information that would be useful. For example, I spent something like 20 minutes working through dialogue with Professor Weasley, listening to her over-explain how to decorate the Room of Requirement, but she never once took two seconds to inform me of the fact that I can skip time via my map. I never noticed or heard any mention of this until I was something like 12ish hours into the game, instead sitting on the floor in front of my classrooms at 2:00am to skip to daytime for class. You can't sleep in your bed in your dormitory as one would expect, so I just assumed the only way to skip time was to show up to a quest and sit on the floor. Random bits and pieces of small features like this could have easily been mentioned in dialogue with NPCs instead of them constantly over-explaining that there's a door 5 feet behind me that I should investigate. When so much of the dialogue is superfluous, I've largely started skipping through it to just get to the point and work through quests, which is rather disappointing considering how easily they could've done more to make the dialogue feel more meaningful.This also bleeds into the classes/quests. I went to my first Beasts class and spent a bit working through dialogue over-explaining things that I likely should've learned as a first-year student, just to be tasked with...brushing little puffball bros and feeding them pellets. You do this for two different kinds of creatures and class is abruptly dismissed. Afterwards, you have a conversation with a classmate (who makes sure to inform you that she imagines that the critter pellets taste like pudding) about poachers who kill the various cute critters and she tells you that she's going to investigate the poachers in the forest. And...that's it. You just tell her to keep you posted. No invitation to come with to back her up, no mention of where she's going to incentivize you to explore the map, no beginning to a new quest, nothing. No spells learned in class, no new features unlocked. Whole lotta nada. Why did I just spend 20 minutes sitting in class as a supposed fifth-year student, learning how to brush puffball homies and talking to my classmate about her grandma? Why does nothing come of my classmate telling me she's going to investigate a bunch of dark wizard ass poachers? I am the protagonist right? You see similar weird decisions all throughout the game: your dormitory serves no purpose, with no way to sleep in the bed and hardly any indication as to which room and bed are yours in the first place (but at least you can spin the globe that's sitting in the corner!). Your professors often teach you spells entirely unrelated to the classes that they teach - why is my Herbology teacher having me levitate wood boxes in her classroom with Wingardium Leviosa? Ain't that Charms? Why is my Potions professor teaching me a spell to push books around in his classroom? Why are all of the brooms literally exactly the same stat-wise, making the only distinction between them aesthetics? Why am I forced to spend 20 minutes putting 14 paintings on the walls and changing the color of the curtains in the Room of Requirement instead of doing literally anything else? Thematically, there have been a number of moments that don't feel like they belong in the world of Harry Potter. Why am I fighting ancient Zeffo guardians straight out of Jedi Fallen Order, chucking big energy balls at  a Wizarding World/Harry Potter game? Why do the ancient magic dungeons feel like they're pulled out of BOTW aesthetically? Why is the castle literally completely empty at night, with nobody telling me to stop wandering the halls or anything? Why is the famous changing staircase a circle that doesn't change at all? I mean, come on man, they got the staircase right for the PS2 games 15 years ago. There's no reason for it to have not been accurate here. The game clearly has passion behind it, and it is undoubtedly a good time and fun to play through, with plenty of content to justify the $60 purchase (hence why I'm recommending it despite my nitpicking), but enough things are fluffy, inconsistent, or thematically off that I'm definitely left with an uncanny valley feeling at times. As a lifelong, borderline obsessed Harry Potter fan, there's plenty of preexisting worldbuilding and lore to build off of, yet many elements of the main story feel out of place in the world of Harry Potter. Some parts of Hogwarts are recognizable, but a lot of it has less resemblance to the Hogwarts that we know through the existing Harry Potter media out there than I would have expected/liked. There's just enough slightly off to the game that makes it not hit how I hoped it would. Food for thought in the end.

author: Linnis
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a very well made game, for Harry Potter fans and folks new to the universe.Choose your house and explore the world as you wish, RPG style!- The map is huge and full of secrets to be discovered- There are many collectibles for explorers and completionists alike- The classes and quests are immersive and invite your curiosity- The brooms and mounts make moving around the world easy as you appreciate the stunning visuals of the game- Speaking of moving around easily, floo flames! Fast-traveling is a great option for those who would rather teleport places- The room of requirement brings the personalization aspect that many will like, with furniture, potions/plants stations and magical creature- Fights are fun with the variety of spells you can use to defeat enemiesWhile the game does miss Quidditch as many know and is in no way perfect, it is an amazing experience worth trying. I am not the hugest HP fan and still enjoyed it thoroughly.

author: antivan leather boots
review: it's a conflicted recommendation. yes, you should play if you love this universe. yes, i'm glad it was a success because it means we will get more of those game. but still...on one hand we finally got a big wizarding world game and the company itself made a decent product for basically their first big game, it's beautiful and breathtaking in some instances, i even cried a little bit flying on the broom for the first time in the open world. but on the other hand... the main story is so bad :( the characters are mostly bland and boring, only few okay-ish side quests and a bunch of annoying crap like floo powder lady, alohomora mini game each time and plenty of other things of same type. they could have literally just bought someone's fanfiction and made a game around it, there are plenty of those in Harry Potter fanbase that are actually very good. but instead they went with something they had to write themselves and imo completely failed. i won't go into detail because it will spoil major points but i have to say out of all videogames i ever played this story was the worst by far. i was level 30+ while still procrastinating main quests for level 12 which you can't even procrastinate that much or not do at all because otherwise you won't get other quests or be able to interact with many things in the world. it's really boring and unengaging. illusion of choice here is worse than Detroit Become Human, doesn't influence anything. a lot of disappointment in terms of immersion into the plot. no clue why even make it somewhat customized. could have just made established character since we are forced to be someone specific anyway.the dialogues are really bad and state of morals is completely unhinged and inconsistent. and the ending was worse than all of it, so disappointing and unrewarding and just... bad. i'm really upset with how many things turned out to be in terms of adventure and story. like... it looks like you're in Hogwarts, yes? but it feels like you're just basically in a museum, just looking at things and not really experiencing them. i dunno, maybe i'm just spoiled by Bioware at this point with the level of storytelling in games but everyone i know who played agrees the story is bad. but also i'll play with a piece of cardboard if the story is good so i guess it's all about preference.

author: Oninomiru
review: To be honest, I'm amazed. I didn't expect this game to be THIS good.Be aware though, this is an adventure game with a lot of puzzles and story. It just happens to have really amazing combat system. I also want to say that this game oozes love. Developers definitely were enjoying making this game and did put a lot of care in this title.+Combat system. Damn, it's so much fun. Basic spell casts, block, parry, perfect parry, dodge, dash/teleportation, counterhits against unblockable moves. A lot of special spell interactions too. Like how you can deal a lot of damage to an enemy if you freeze him and then cast cutting spell. Or how you can dodge from troll's blockable attack and use Flippendo instead, to make him hit himself with a giant club. Once you unlock 4 spell diamonds, combat system really opens up and every battle turns into that deadly fencing match with a lot of different spells. Probably my favourite aspect of this game so far.+Good enemy variety. Every type of wizard enemy has his own interactions that makes them unique. Same applies to other enemies as well. Boss fights were pretty enjoyable too, even though on a more simple side.+Puzzles. A lot of them. Like, really a lot of them. And they don't get old. I've spent a lot of time running around solving Merlin trials, or picking the locks (yes, it's a mini game too), or catching flying pages, moving boulders with different magic, catching creatures, etc etc.+Story. They really did well with the story. I enjoyed both main and many side quests.+Replayability. Different houses have unique quest in game. Also you can come to the cleared enemy camps and fight enemies again. Can replay arenas endlessly too.+Room of requirement and animal keeping. Honestly, I'm not much of a stardew valley dude, but this aspect is pretty fun even for me.+UI. Damn, UI settings are so good. You can disable or enable pretty much any UI element. Can turn off screen shake too. Thank you devs!+Vibe. This game absolutely manages to catch that wizarding world vibe and immerse you. As for negatives, there isn't much to be honest.-DENUVO.-Character customisation is limited to presets. I kinda wish games nowadays had character creation on par with Nioh 2 in terms of flexibility. Also first 3 skin tones are the same and they aren't that pale to begin with.-Talents and spells. I wish there was more of them. Like stuff that enemies cast too. Reducto, for example. Or others.-Slight stuttering in Hogsmeade in autumn season. Didn't have that in any other seasons.

author: BUMBLEBY CANON
review: I've always been a Potterhead (still have the 1st edition of the 1st book - the Portuguese translated version), I've read all the books, seen all the movies, played all the PC games, and still have some collectibles (I still get shirts from the franchise till today too!). When I was younger, I even memorized spells and was fascinated by the creatures and world-building the Harry Potter universe has. Whether people like J.K. Rowling or not for her political views, she is a genius and one of my favorite writers of all time! I am eternally thankful for what she created, and all the magical stories she wrote! Since ever, I've always dreamed about a game like this - a vast open world in and outside Hogwarts, where we can create our own character and pick her/his house + fly around on a broom or a creature. Hogwarts Legacy came to make my dream - and of many other Potterheads - come true! I have no regrets about pre-ordering the Deluxe Edition, this is such a beautiful game!I just have a few performance issues (my current specs are RTX 3070ti + 16GB 5200MHz DDR5 RAM + Ryzen 5 7600X + SSD Sata III), but I hope either NVidia releases drivers that fix this, or Avalanche Studios patches it up. Still, this does not take out the joy I have for this game!>>EDIT: Increased my RAM to 32GB, it runs very smooth now with everything on Ultra + Ray Tracing!There's a lot to explore, mysteries to solve, and spells to learn! Also, it's important to note that we can pet all the cats!!!Truly an unforgetful experience, a game of the year!

author: trusty_brutus
review: It's a dream come true for all HP fans

author: SaleXeriouS
review: Tearfully beautiful, visually stunning, excellently crafted open world that has exceeded all my expectations of this long anticipated game. It's a real dream coming true! INSANE level of details. Very rich environment/surroundings full of objects to observe and interact with, places to explore. NPCs feel alive with tons of interesting dialogues and animations (NPC A.I could be better though). Really HUGE world. The castle itself is an enormous maze you can easily get lost in. The size of the castle alone is more than satisfying to those who value big map size and is so large that you almost forget there are vast areas exist beyond waiting for you to explore. Breathtaking magical atmosphere. Adorable beasts. Living world. Tons of quests, collectables, customization, activities, secrets and puzzles.. and much more. Occasional FPS stuttering and drops (not often, and only for a few seconds). Needs a little more optimization and polishing. However not that bad and doesn't ruin your experience at all. Completely playable. I recommend turning ray tracing off for now until the game gets patched properly. But in general it runs pretty nice and smooth.

author: CinnamonRolls

author: Jynn
review: As I have now finished the game I will update this review. First a TL:DR Version:TL:DR: It's a good game, but not a perfect game. I enjoyed it, the Hogwarts castle is beautifully made with all the care and attention to detail a Wizarding World fan could want. The music is absolutely amazing, the environment is stunning. I wish they had spent more time in Hogwarts and the school aspect, i wish your interactions with NPCs were more in depth, and your choices made more a difference. Good game, not perfect, but still fun.Pros:+ Ansel Photomode works!+ Book accurate, including Ravenclaw colors and symbol+ Great music+ The castle is very well designed+ Large open world+ Ton of clothing customization+ Combat is fun, but challenging, with lots of combos and juggling possiblity + Peeves is here!+ The room of requirement has TONS of customization, truly can make it your own+ Most Puzzles are interesting and not too tedious+ You can pet cats!+ Animal collecting and breedingCons:- 1 crash in my entire playtime, so not too bad- Model pop in sometimes- Your character comments too much, especially during puzzles giving clues. I want to figure it out myself game!- Classes are very basic, mostly cut scenes. This isn't Bully or a school sim- Lots of repeated paintings in the castle- Voice pitch in character creation is robotic sounding- Stuttering on mid range computer during combat / NPC heavy areas - Character customization for face is very limited, but still decent- Cutscenes stutter and FPS drop worse than any other part of the game - For a game set in Europe in 1800s, some people might find the racial diversity immersion breaking- Can't interact with other students very much outside of quests- NPCs dont react to anything. Spells, breaking locks, etc- Your choices don't make that much of a difference- Open world missions and tasks can get very repetitive if you don't enjoy that kind of thing- Spiders, LOTS of spiders, for you Arachnophobes out thereBut for me, personally, the game scratches practically every itch I have for a game:+ Puzzles and mini games+ Dungeon crawling+ Pokemon (magical beast) collecting and breeding+ Decorating sim with the Room of Requirement+ Farming and crafting+ Fun combat

author: MC
review: Good game. Amazing open-world and stunning visuals at times. I really like the combat system, and exploring is fun.- Bad PC optimization as of now, very stuttery no matter what setup you play on. - RT effects look bad and noisy on most surfaces, rather play without RT effects.- NPC are kinda boring and prev-gen looking.

author: hablargy
review: Mostly all good here... if you love Harry Potter, this game is for you!The great:-immersive... magic is everywhere! I was once talking to a shopkeeper, and could see in the background a wizard wrestling a vicious cabbage in his garden. I feel as though I'm in the world. I like my character. I played through without spoilers to get the authentic experience, something I don't usually care about -I actually like the combat system for once. It's challenging on normal, but just the right amount of challenge. Visually combat looks really good too.-Very beautiful world, something that matters to me. Dark forests, windswept craggy coastline, old forgotten places-Very forgiving game. Difficulty settings you can change whenever. No timed quests. You can change night/day without penalty.-the Room of requirement is amazing!! Love the customization options. -the vivarium concept is outstanding! They're gorgeous inside and out.-the music and sounds are very pleasing. My character's voice is exquisite. I could listen to her talk forever-I love being able to customize my gear's appearance as I please, this feature is fantastic-I haven't seen a single bug. Just one dude floating next to a cliff. Well, he's a wizard, so maybe he was supposed to be.Areas for improvement:-It's VERY controlling about when you get what, and you have to wait until the end of the main story to get some extremely desirable things, so you don't get to enjoy them for very long. I don't want to wait til end of game for **spoilers** a ground mount, last vivarium, dark magic spells, etc.-The fully upgraded room of requirement doesn't have enough slots for all the beasts you'll want to keep. Not even close. With all the possible colors, they need to expand slots. There's tons of room in there-there are "rare" beasts to find, but they aren't very imaginatively done. Who cares about an albino niffler? This is a magical world. How about a purple spotted sparkling niffler? A blue glowing unicorn? The variety offered is like the difference between beige and brown. The regular animals are usually more colorful-no romance. They say they left it out because they're kids. But the kids are facing adult situations like killing and dying. And kids that age go to dances and stuff in real life. Don't be stodgy. I really enjoyed the date feature on the mobile game.-i hate puzzles. This game is puzzle heavy. If they're too hard or involved I just look them up. -I did manage to get a character I truly enjoy looking at, but it wasn't easy. Hopefully they'll eventually allow modding with sliders.-I hope they bulk it up. This isn't exactly Skyrim, where you could never finish every quest. It isn't too small to be worth the money, it totally is worth it. But... end game content in seriously lacking, relegated to mopping up after the party

author: Zbrggs
review: While engaging for a time, the game quickly becomes stale and repetitive. An overabundance of repetitive and tedious side activities detracts from the main story and leads to burnout without any feeling of reward. The lack of unique dialogue ruins what little RPG elements the game presents. At the risk of compromising my review, Rockstar could have re-skinned Bully and made a more interesting Hogwarts experience.

author: Max Harvey
review: BEAUTIFUL but BORINGIncredible work which is ultimately boring.  The artwork and design are amazing.  Every element of the game looks beautiful, right down to the menus.  The voice acting is superb.  The magic and crafting system is competent but nothing special.But the game is BORING.  The combat system is simplistic and not much more than button mashing, and where other systems would require tactics, this one just needs you to hit the dodge button at the right time.  You can explore the open world, but it's BORING.  There's not much variety and enemies just inhabit limited zones until you choose to go attack them.  And everything is far to spread out so you waste masses of time pointless running from place to place.  Plot development is GLACIAL and padded out with pointless BORING side quests.  And once you have interacted with a character, such as competing against another student, they will say exactly the same 3-4 lines every single time you interact with them.It's a great pity - the art design, voice acting, visuals, etc are AMAZING.  But game play was completely ignored. Once the novelty of being in a brilliant depiction of Hogwarts wears thin (which happens quickly), the game basically boils down to one long dull grind.I'm glad I've seen inside it, but I  really didn't get my money's worth.  Wait for it to go on on sale.

Probably yes, but I can't enjoy it because of the fluctuating frames. Since they didn't bother to improve the gameplay experience in the sold EA, I won't bother to improve this review later in the future.

author: djehmli
review: FIrst, I am not a Hogwart's fan.  Never read the books, didn't see the movies.  I purchased the game on a recommendation from a co worker.The game is story driven, though very easy to over level if you are following main story as well as side quests.  Over leveling meant encounters which should have been difficult were easy for me.  Note, this may not be the same for folks who got the game for the Lore and not video game savvy.Yes, modern social engineering is present in the game, take it, leave it, wasn't necessary nor did it 'add' anything to the story.Graphics - I had no issues playing Ultra with raytracing on.   The landscape was beautiful, but lighting between the world and the character is odd.  Outside of cut scenes it felt as if the character was in front of a green screen instead of being part of the land they were traipsing or flying around.Characters - skin textures (not colors ... textures) are flat, no depth, even when changing complexions.  However the NPC skins, especially aged had more depth.  It's like the avatar's normal maps were missing.Largest Con - Item handling.  Hate it, hate it, hate it.  No such thing as storage.  While you can keep the 'image' of the item, and reskin what you are wearing,  You cannot fling your robe across a chair, drop gloves on edge of desk.  Stack components on a shelf.  Blaergh blah bah hum bug.Lastly - replay factor, for me at least is lacking.  Unless you are hunting achievements.  I'll get my money's worth out of completing the story, but that is about it.  Shame really, game feels like it was so caught up in trying to keep everyone happy, there isn't enough 'oomph' in it, either at the story telling level or the gaming level for me to want to go back and watch the movies or read the books.  Revenue lost.

author: ShakaUVM
review: I have been itching for a roleplaying game recently, and when Hogwart's Legacy dropped, I thought I'd give it a shot despite some negative reviews online. Other than a few minor bugs (like hair and clothing twitching in place), it's a very solid, very polished game. It slowly unlocks more and more customization options as you play through the main storyline, so maybe I shouldn't be running around doing all the side quests, but it's very enjoyable to run around and find some ruins and then puzzle out how to get into the locked area with a treasure chest in it.And that's really what the game is about - puzzle solving. Combat is trivially easy (Press Block when it tells you to Block, press Dodge when it tells you to Dodge and you will win 100% of the time with 0% damage), but the game is not really about combat, it's about the giant puzzle box known as Hogwarts and Environs. Notably, all the leveling you get in this game are from completing challenges and solving puzzles, and not from combat (though there are combat challenges technically). So if you very thoroughly search Hogwarts, you can be way ahead of the level you're supposed to be, which is kind of fun, honestly.

review: A fantastic Harry Potter game in a Harry Potter universe. If you've ever been a fan of the series, this game will blow your mind. Hogsmeade started giving me terrible frames without DLSS once winter hit. I haven't tried the game with the newest Nvidia drivers.

author: Akiirah
review: LOWER END SYSTEMS:I'm only 20-30 hours in, but the game is extremely unoptimized at the moment for lower end systems. I'm using a 1660Ti, 32GB ram, and without "performance mods / fixes", the game crashes every 10-15 minutes (ie: you have to install Ascendio from nexus mods, modify the Engine.ini & CChromaEditorLibrary64.dll, turn on GPU "Hardware Accelerated GPU Scheduling", & change some Nvidia Global Settings). After the above performance fixes, the game (mostly) stops crashing, but I have to run it on 720p, with AMD 2 Upscale, Good Preset, (RTX off obviously). Anything higher, and the game crashes every 10-15 minutes again. Every time the game updates, I have to reinstall the performance mods. Denuvo DRM continually runs in the background, in short it scans your system looking for any tampering in the game files. Even though Empress (a cracker) recently "removed Denuvo DRM", there was no real performance gain, because the crack can only bypass Denuvo, but it continues to constantly run in the background. For those of you running the game at 120+ fps, a ~20fps performance gain is negligible, but for someone like me who barely runs the game at 20fps, it would be double the performance. It constantly stutters during cutscenes, and when loading new scenes. Don't get me wrong, I've really enjoyed the game post-fixes, the world is beautiful, and feels far more expansive than the movies, and for any Harry Potter fan -- it's nothing short of a childhood dream come true. But I would not recommend the game right now, or at full price. There's many other issues like the female models all use a copy-pasted Male animation rigs & weights, causing unexpected results, like the female models grimacing, making malicious, witch like faces in-game (Google it), and running around like a hooligan with no grace or femininity at all. There's no White / Pale Caucasian or Black skin tones, it starts from tan & ends at a dark brown. All these bugs are listed on the Hogwarts DB and will potentially be worked on in future, but modders seem to be addressing them way faster than developers are. I'd say give it 6-12 months and wait for a sale, hopefully WB removes Denuvo, and the game is in a much optimised state after updates & fixes. Otherwise, we're going to have to rely on the modding community to better the game. I will amend this review once the game is in a better place and I only discourage it in it's current state, and on lower end systems.  P.s If you have a higher end system, have FOMO / fear of missing out, and want to talk about it with friends, by all means get it.

author: ᴅɪᴅᴅʟᴇʏ
review: Phenomenal world design, directly drawn from the Harry Potter universe, but everything else falls completely flat. The characters are one-dimensional, without any additional complexity beyond "good" and "evil," and the dialogue is ridiculously childish to the point of lunacy. The main character is your generic self-insert chosen one protagonist, which can be executed fairly well, but isn't in this case. Your status as a "student" is completely inconsistent with the gameplay and power fantasy plot, while there is almost no interaction with fellow students in a realistic way besides them simply praising you as this yet unbeknownst prodigy. Roleplaying elements are "present," but they feel more haphazardly tacked on rather than actually adding anything of meaning (side quests are as generic as they can be, and dialogue choices offer no real choices or complexity). The gameplay is actually fairly well-executed, duels are fun and engaging, but certain fights certainly rely on sponginess, and the UI design is abhorrent (animations are impressively slow, while important gameplay elements are locked behind talents). Performance issues are present, but not unusably so, although it is comical for this to be an issue in a game with character models ripped straight out of 2015. Despite all this, it's definitely not a terrible game, with a very polished open world, beautiful art direction, and complete faithfulness to the Harry Potter lore, but it's by no means an especially great one, offering nothing new or special despite the illustrious Harry Potter skin. As far as licensed games go, this is a fantastic one, and Harry Potter fans will likely love it, but as far as games go in general, I'd find it difficult to recommend, even though I loved this series when I was younger.6.5/10

Combat works a lot better than I imagined 5/5. controls for pc feel better on controller. combat on mouse and keyboard takes getting used to if your a filthy casual. looking forward to multiplayer when it gets released but the single player experience has been a blast. I'm on recommended graphics settings and turned off the grain and motion blur to hopefully help with it. It didn't though. :') This is my biggest reason why I'm a "No".-Bugs: Every time I try to fast travel to a certain room, I stay on the loading screen and have to close out the game. *I just keep running into annoying little bugs. One example is somehow I flip one of the Merlin trial blocks off during a fight and I couldn't complete it. Had to return to this area to redo it.- Relationships with the students: I'm not asking for like romance. I would like more than just them asking for help with stuff and just hanging out with 2-3 of the students in the whole school.- NO QUIDDITCH?!?!?! -I'm only 18-ish hours in since I wrote this but something feels missing from the usual open worlds I enjoy. The open world task a bit monotonous? Lots of just running around? I can't tell yet but will amend this once I get a little more hours in. *Okay, It's cause I'm expecting more like Elder Scrolls and a more in depth open world. Which isn't this. I'm trying to get that itch of an expansive open world scratched. Well the good:-Harry Potter Open World game is a dream come true.-Great graphics.-Fighting is very fun and smooth.-Character creation. +___+-Account linking to your Pottermore account. So you get that real experience.-*Finally got to beasts care. *Also 60 hours in cause I get bored and leave the game on and somehow nap. :')

author: 5LoX5
review: Had high hopes but overall badly executed game. My overall score for this game is 6/10.I dont know where to start from so i am gonna just list all the negative stuff i encountered while playing the game.Firstly the main storyline is pretty badly excecuted, especially at the end of the game after the final boss fight there is no interaction with the keepers to conclude the story, the game just ends there.There is also a hasle of a sidequests to unlock some spells, mainly for alohomora felt like the most useless spell, completing the quest to get alohomora lvl 3 felt rly bad, all the rewards i got from opening lvl 3 locks is just a couple gold and maybe a item which feels pretty bad because all that time spent on the quest just to be able to get a couple gold felt pretty demotivating, the only use for aolohomora lvl 3 was to get one of Hogwarts secrets.A lot of things felt like they were there just to give you options, like catching beasts just to be able to put 4 of them in farm when it shows having much more slots, without the option to upgrade all for you to get some materials to upgrade items which felt worthless because they are lvl based meaning you upgrade the item and the next item you get is already better than it, not to mention upgrading stats just unlock the other stat to upgrade. Meaning if you have attack item upgrading it you get defense so it didnt felt usefull to upgrade items, making the pet system worthless.Combat felt nice at first but then you notice thats all there is to it, all the boss fights are pretty much the same in execution. During combat with multiple enemies the warning to parry/dodge isnt showing always you need to listen to audio que and even then you dont know are they targeting you or the ally you are fighting with.A lot of QoL are in need, don't know why they arent done yet, especially for selling items it feels demotivating to explore since you dont have a lot of inventory space and need to go sell items every so often, and selling requires you to hold the button for each item individually and yes i had inventory fully expanded.Exploration, yes it didnt feel good, there are a bunch of caves that i thought at beginning to be dungeons but all they are are you unlock the gate enter pick the item and thats it, in some there is sometimes puzzle but yeah thats it most of times. Good thing is if you revelio while in the air it shows you all the places you can go, except some, but there are very little fun adventures most of them being side quests.The game starts strong but falls down very quickly, had to make myself play in order to finish it. The game feels like gujian 3 but executed much more badly.

author: Evoattack
review: So for the potential it has, it's actually a terrible game.Yes, the graphics and the size of the world is beyond amazing and professor Garlick seems to be the new #1 cosplay target for e-girls.BUT, the immersion... the true hogwarts experience, nope. Not at all.- The quests are absolutely AFKable. Talk to person x. Bring me object y, defeat group z.- Collectibles/Challenges (100% achievements) are boring as hell. Merlin challenges are too simple, Items are completely random and there is no real value to selling them- Professors give housepoints, but the hourglasses don't do stuff and there is no housecup.- No quidditch regardless of there being a field (probably a future DLC, but the studios already said theyre not in a rush to make DLCs)- The repetitiveness of dialouges are terrible; seems like all roads lead to hogsmead.- The main story is boring up untill the last quest. The Sebastian storyarch is more interesting than the main story.- Combat is WAAAAAAAY too easy.- Room of requirement is useless. Because if you loom your gear to do more damage combat will just get even easier and who really needs potions apart from doing quests to get more spells.- The restricted section is only restricted when you go there for a quest. The forbidden ain't so forbidden at all and roaming the halls at night is also only a problem when you do it for a quest.Get it on a discount, but definitely not on full price.

author: Groovy Larry
review: Great game with a decent story. Fun combat and an enthralling world that is fun to get lost in. Best of all, no store or micro-transactions. The transmog system is top notch, so you can always look your best. Some technical issues that are little jarring, but never make the game crash or feel unplayable. Overall, its well worth the money

author: mooncrosser
review: Decent game, quests are fun, exploring the castle is a blast, combat is challenging. However there are also a bunch of filler content, exploring the world outside of the castle is a chore. Targeting system suck. You're saving beast from poachers by poaching them first. Platforming in the open world can be done by flying. Treasure vaults are a tunnel with a chest at the end (no enemies, no puzzles). Generally fun experience, but it's short from great.

author: soupsoupsoup
review: I was really hyped to play this game for the first time and was grinding it for a few days aswell, but I'd rather not recommend it than telling people it's worth it.It really doesn't seems like the hogwarts that Harry Potter fans know, the map might be big, but the enemies and the puzzles you stumble upon in the big wide world just feel dull. A positive thing I can say is that I really enjoy the combat system, it's fun to spam the opponents with your spells. The main quest is boring and don't get me started on the side quests. OFCOURSE you are the one student who gets everything right at the first time, WITHOUT ANY PRACTISE? Sure. I feel like it doesn't really matter what house you chose, you still talk in the same tone and treat everyone the same while sounding like a robot. The character customization is fine in my opinion.The idea of having a 3D-ish map is really cool, but I don't know how many times I missclicked a Foo-flame in hogwarts.You might have a unisex character, but are still not able to wear every outfit? What if Im a male character wanting to wear a skirt? Progressive, but not quite.That's my review (so far)

author: Glaivz
review: Imagine having the whole Wizarding World as your playground, no limit to your imagination and all you come up with is a boring, uninspired, generic Ubisoft Open World Game. A game about magic, completely lacking any magic. Give me a deep, choice driven RPG Give me an engaging Social Sim where i can make friends and enemies Start me as a first year, let me ride the hogwarts express. Give me Classes i can attend and OWLs i can take. Give me a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ curfew. And for the love of god, give me a half way decent story. Give me anything but this,

author: Tone
review: All around very good Action RPG. The world, although smaller, feels bigger than let's say the latest Assassin's Creed installments and is on par in activities and side quests with Cyberpunk (with way less bugs as well).You need around 60hours to play through the story and side quests. Have fun!

author: RobbyBunny
review: Before diving into the review, it's important to address the controversy surrounding the author of the original Harry Potter books and her exclusionary statements. It's entirely understandable for those hurt by her opinions to boycott this game. This review, and the praise and criticisms within it, in no way reflects my views on the statements and opinions held by the author and I stand in support of anyone unwilling to purchase this game for that reason.Hogwarts Legacy is a nostalgic experience for Harry Potter fans, with stunning graphics and attention to detail in the world of Hogwarts. The open world allows players to explore the castle and grounds, uncovering hidden secrets and discovering new areas as they progress through the game. The spell system is simple at first but becomes surprisingly intricate and detailed as players progress. The puzzle elements in the game add a new level of challenge and depth to the gameplay.The original music remixed into the game adds to the overall nostalgia and atmosphere, making it an immersive and faithful experience for existing fans and new players. The tutorial, while detailed, can be a bit frustrating as players lose control of their character at times to progress the story. The collectibles in the game add to the overall lore and provide a sense of discovery for players but it can feel like they are included primarily to pad out the length of the game and can feel repetitive at times. The game has a wide range of accessibility settings, including a granular difficulty slider, making it accessible to a wider range of players, including those with disabilities.However, there are some larger drawbacks to the game as well. The severe performance issues caused by the Denuvo anti-cheat system can be a major hindrance, and the NPCs often feel like set pieces rather than living, breathing characters. They don't interact with the player, making the world feel less alive. The main antagonist feels a bit childish, but the overall narrative is engaging and interesting.Another minor annoyance is the inability to pause the menu during cutscenes to adjust settings, including volume. This can be a mild nuisance for players who need to make adjustments in the middle of a scene.In conclusion, Hogwarts Legacy is a beautiful game that is a must-have for Harry Potter fans. The attention to detail, spell system, puzzle elements, and overall narrative make it an enjoyable and nostalgic experience. The accessibility options and granular difficulty slider make it accessible to a wider range of players. However, the severe performance issues and lack of interaction with NPCs are significant drawbacks that should be considered before purchasing.
