author: Inddie
review: if you like harry potter, this is a fantastic game. but thats where a lot of the appeal lies.Putting the setting aside, the gameplay and story arent much to write home about. you have a hand full of spells, just enough to annoyingly take up more space than you have for them. requiring you to switch out hotbars as needed (4 isnt enough imo).The combat is engaging enough but repetitive. Playing on normal difficulty its fairy easy. just spam your spells while hitting 'q' and 'x' as the indicator appear. and while i havent tried it myself i dont imagine harder difficulties are much better. just more enemy health and less reaction time if i had to guess.to reiterate, from a point of view the ignores the nostalgia factor of the setting, the game is mediocre.BUT if you are even sort of a harry potter fan, then you will LOVE the game. it gives you so much more to explore and discover about a world you're already interested in.also the game has performance issues in the form of FPS lag spikes on occasion, but setting NVIDIA DLSS to performance mode helps a lot, as well as some unofficial mods that help performance. im only giving the game a positive recommendation because i know that existing harry potter enthusiasts will enjoy it regardless of any of the issues.

author: thunda
review: Lets start with the pros:- Hogwarts itself looks great, at times I felt like I was in a Harry Potter movie- Music is decent, they remixed the classic HP tunes- Graphics are decent to great- Voice acting is pretty goodBut unfortunately once you look past the surface, a lot of problems start to appear. Unless youre a blind fanboy. One of the biggest issue if not the biggest is the empty open world littered with completely pointless stuff like Merlin's Trials, Treasure Vaults etc. Stuff straight out of Ubisoft's book for "How to Pad Your Game's Length".It would be alright if for example the Merlin's Trials were like 8 trials total, all wildly different. Merlin's Trials are simple puzzles you have to complete in droves to unlock more of your very limited inventory space. After you've done 3 different Trials, you've done them all. Unfortunately there are over 90 of these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ trials.Treasure Vaults are like Merlin's Trials but even simpler and and the reward is opening a door in to a tiny "dungeon" (and I mean tiny, takes 5 seconds to reach the loot) where one piece of loot awaits you, usually just something trash (its all randomized so you can even savescum before opening any container)And there's tons of these, just littered everywhere. And you cant turn them off. When youre flying on your broom and press R to reveal nearby interesting locations, a huge mass of these icons pops up in your face and you just want to quit playing.Side quests are nearly all simple fetch quests, some dont even bother hiding it. I just currently got a literal fetch quest where I have to make a delivery in a far away place. I know I wont finish this quest.There are over 150 so called "field guide pages" to collect in Hogwarts alone. These net you XP which is needed to level up. 90% of the content in this game is Ubisoft style completely pointless garbage. And I really mean around 90%. 5% is fetch quests and actual good content is the remaining 5%, the main quests which are actually fun to play.Forget about anything interesting happening anywhere, the NPC's are all just as soulless as for example in Cyberpunk. There is no AI whatsoever. Forget even about stuff like for example in Witcher 3, where even small bandit hideout location often had a bit of attached lore in the form of a diary of their latest victim etc, just fleshing out the world. None of that here.I'm 17 hours in and I just have no interest playing anymore, its very formulaic, very tiresome, and apart from the occasional fun main questing, overwhelming majority of the content is braindead boring. And I didn't even mention the performance issues. They can fix the performance but they wont fix the game design choices made.

review: Professor Garlick is all the diversity we need

author: Primitiveghost

author: lplum17
review: I'm writing this review for people who are not obsessed with the world of Harry Potter. I played this game for 40 hours at the time of review and I played mostly with a keyboard and mouse. Do not pay $60 for this game unless you're a die hard fan.Pros: Graphics are great. Minor bugs, only required a reload once due to a quest companion running in a circle it was more funny than annoying. There are lots of autosaves if you lose power etc. Broom riding is smooth once you get used to it. The magical Beasts and the room of requirement are sick. There are several spell combos you can pull off which makes decision making while swapping between spell sets important.Cons: The flying mounts do not feel as fast or control nearly as well as the broom, this made an "epic moment" stale instantly. There are only 3 useful talent trees and talent points are limited as leveling up becomes much slower and talents are not available until level 20ish (if you do every side mission along the way). I played the opening parts of the game on normal until I got comfortable with the keybindings and then I switched to hard mode. The difference in difficulty is non-existent. Casting dark magic in front of your companions can trigger an audio queue (over and over again...) but I've yet to see any sort of repercussion for using an unforgivable curse which makes it again.... stale. There are no reputation systems, dark/light side systems, there is no depth. The moment you get bored of combat. There isn't a compelling reason to play other than completion.

author: SeCritSquirrel
review: Don't listen to all the negativity and hate on the internet about this game. Aside from it being the 'Harry Potter' Universe game we've always wanted. It easily has more diversity and inclusion in it then all the books combined, plus there's a portrait in Hogwarts of what looks to be JK Rowling burning at the stake. The diversity/inclusion I speak of is not in an "Intrusive, woke, agenda setting" kind of way, just normal. Like ya, there's POC, and pronouns and people of different gender profiles *surprise pikachu face*, as if that's not how real life already is. Pros:-Story-Graphics: Amazing in 4k Ultra-Customization and Transmog system: The item system is intuitive and the transmog system is simple and effective.-Combat: Takes a bit to get used to but it's super smooth on K&M-Best Keyboard & Mouse port I've seen yet-Exploration and environment: Can literally spend hours just exploring Hogwarts and still not even scratch the surface-Use of magic to explore the world and solve riddles and puzzles-Fast travel: Not a generic fast travel system. They actually use the 'Floo powder' system in a great way.Cons:-Character creation voices: Could be better, and there are some in-game audio issues related to it.-Controller play style: It's surprisingly garbage compared to Keyboard and Mouse-No quidditch: will likely be an expansion if I had to guess, though they do make an effort to explain it away in the beginning of the game.Minor cons:-Some audio and visual bugs-Wish they had more hairstyles-Wish the 'Sorting Hat' ceremony was a bit more in-depth. But I get why they made it the way they did.-Most of the NPCs are fairly generic and you can't interact with them. Wish the NPCs had A.I. similar to GTA or something.-Some stuff you can jump or vault over, other things you can't. A bit restricting or railroading at times in terms of exploration.

author: aerolius
review: Great game.+ Fascinating story+ Great combat system+ Little to none bugs+ Simply gorgeous+ Attention to detail- Hard difficulty was a bit too easy

author: chuck
review: This game is just as hateful and bigoted as the criminally insane sociopaths on twitter would like you to believe. Excellent! Making a male character, calling him a witch, rooming him in the female dorm, and proceeding to be a sex pest is such a poignant characterization of the bathroom debate in the <current year> that one can't help but laugh. 41/10, all transexuals are groomers.

author: Andrew
review: Let’s keep it short. We all love this game, you know it, I know it, we all know it. However:In no way shape or form does it matter which House you pick for the end story or generally for the in-game experience. Yes, you do get few lines "Yes we Slytherins are better etc etc" but that doesn’t really feel like the game is acknowledging my choice, I’m still dealing with the same protagonists in the same way. (I just finished as a Slytherin, and am about to play as a Ravenclaw). When I reached the end, “evil ending” doesn’t really matter, yes, your eyes glow red for a sec in that cut scene but you don’t get cool new power, nothing really happens, “good ending” feels more dignified towards professor Fig, and honestly, I picked that one since it made more sense.Unforgivable curses are amazing, but the things that you can do with ancient magic feel more “unforgivable” :D you literally have the ability to disintegrate someone from existence, or to slam his body repeatedly against the ground. The only people who care if you know unforgivable magic are ashwinders and Ominis on occasion, literally nobody else cares. Too many caves and Merlin trials, you really didn't need to put soo many, or at least make those more rewarding please 😊 I really don’t care about Quidditch :D never liked it, but the broom experience is amazing in on itself. More magic slots are needed, and more spells please :D Alohamora needs to be an early spell, and tbh I don’t care about the “spinning tumblers” too much, yes that can be annoying sometimes, I hate the fact that Alohamora had “three levels of difficulty”. And finally, more lore please, more magic, more lore 😊 The game is amazing, beautiful, soo many things to explore, it really makes you feel like a witch/wizard. I literally tell people “don’t buy this, you will lose yourself” :D.

review: This game is everything I had hoped for. The only thing I don't like is that I can not sell potions I make or ingredients I collect. You can only sell Gear, so it makes it hard to make money to finish some quests. Other than that, so far I am really enjoying myself. author: FYRNØX
review: Probably the best Hogwarts experience out as of the time of this review, but I think it's missing quite a bit. If you aren't a Harry Potter fan, this is simply a decent RPG game. If you're a Harry Potter fan, you'll probably be slightly disappointed that it's not as immersive as you thought, but you'll still enjoy it. I think this game could have benefited from more strict and immersive rules (for example, a REAL curfew system) and maybe more frequent/daily classes you can attend, if you so choose to. More spell variety would be nice, since many of the spells are simply the same except with a slightly different tweak. Would have been nice if there was more of a use for locations an everyday student should go to, like the dormitories. Hopefully future modding can implement these things. Additionally, there are also many differences between Hogwarts from the books/movies and this game, it feels a tad smaller than I expected, but honestly a lot of this could just be the magical nature of the castle and the era, and maybe they based it more on the books than they did the movies (at this point I'm nitpicking, it's still a really cool castle to explore). Plotwise, this game is severely lacking. The best plot in the game isn't even found in the main story.TL;DR, my only gripe has been how I have barely felt like I'm immersed as a student at Hogwarts and more like I'm immersed in an RPG game themed in the Harry Potter universe. That and week 1 performance issues (why the hell does this game recommend more than 20 gb of RAM, and why is my 3070 struggling with it)? As it is now, it feels just like any other RPG game which follows the same formula. Hopefully future updates come (which I doubt they'll do), or modding makes the game better.

author: Noktomo
review: Despite the "bad" rep this game has, I want to ask every person that tried to force other people not to buy/play this game if: they use twitter, if they have brand clothes (made by children), if they use cosmetics (that are tested on animals beforehand), if they use palm oil (that is one of the big reasons why the rainforest gets continuously deforested), if they BOYCOTT anything at all that could have questionable "big" people or companies sitting behind? No. It's easier to spread hate about a game instead, attack people and streamers who waited years for this.I literally waited for over 15 years for a game like this and I LOVE it. Am I transphobic? No. Do I have trans friends, yes. Does it *ing matter? NO. Will I still play this game and recommend it to anyone who likes open world adventures? Hell yea!Some people need to wake up again and focus their hateful energy towards the real problems of the world. It's so easy to say "you're a bad person if you play this game", without realizing how hurting this might be for some people.Yes J.K. earns money with the brand, but the developers were the ones working hard on this game to make it possible for us to live out our inner child again. This is what I pay for. Now to the game itself: You can explore literally everything, take many sidequests or just follow the storyline. I'm 20h in and I just unlocked broom flying. Much more to come, I'm excited. So much detail and love is put into the castle itself.  It lures you to come back each time you've learned a new spell and try out if it works with certain riddles.Graphics are beautiful, I recommend to leave the image calibration on default for more depth and richer colors!Its wonderful.9/10 recommended.  -1 Because you can't have love interests. lmao.

The only thing I don't like is how crowded the Hogwarts map is, I wish it was a little more in depth. The way points really get in the way sometimes. Seems like you should be able to have an inside castle view. Despite that I was really shocked as too how much they delivered in this game

author: UnofficialName
review: The game has an incredible aesthetic - the castle in particular - and the gameplay is pretty fun. You can explore, solve puzzles, duel other wizards, fight monsters with dodge rolls and spell parries. Anyone with even passing interest in RPGs or Action RPGs will probably like this game.HOWEVER - the performance is pretty trash. Going from 144+ frames to less than 30 is unacceptable. It can be alleviated by dropping some setting to LOW, but it still feels rather unpleasant due to the frame inconsistency. It's one big hairy fly in an exceedingly good soup.If they get this patched up soon, I'll easily give it a thumbs up.

author: PrimeDoge
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a great start for modern Harry Potter games, however it's far from perfect. The world is beautiful and so detailed it's straight out from the books/films, it's shows the love and dedication of the devs. The gameplay is awesome, casting the spells you know from HP is so much fun and pretty much carries the whole game. BUT next time it won't be enough. The story and almost every character is extremly shallow, uninteresting and dull. The game just feels too nice. Everyone (except ofc the bad guys) is super kind to you and all you can do is nice things. Yeah you can learn the unforgivable spells (and no one bats an eye when you use them...) and you have the choice to do the "evil" path, but everyone's like "hey that was rude! anyway thanks, you are the best!" and in the end you are still the hero. The only mission that felt interesting and real was the Sebastian side quest and maybe Poppy's. Next time we need more depth both stroywise and characterwise. Decisions needs to have more weights and consequences.In summary: a beautifully detailed game for HP fans with enjoyable combat. but the story and characters needs to be improved.

author: TympanicPulse
review: This is a rant with what some might consider spoilers:This game was given to me by my boyfriend and I was excited to play it. But after putting quite a few hours in, it's very obvious that this game was rushed and not tuned at all. They gatekeep tons of things behind quests that feel arbitrary because the story itself is weak as hell.  Nothing you do has any consequences in the game. Reading the map is really hard. They have contradictory information, like your collections are not totals in the game, it's just a random amount that they deemed enough for a collection. Which does make it very confusing to know if you have actually found what you need to find or if you want to 100% finding stuff then GOOD LUCK! There are inconsistencies in the map, like some of the field guide pages have an icon that you can select to help you find it, but then lots of other field guide pages are completely invisible with no map marker, not to mention the fact that you have to be right on top of the page and facing the correct direction for it to appear, leading to me running around in circles trying to find something that I'm right on top of because I'm not facing the exact pixel they want. It should be a radius affect, Also, the little pages disappear immediately, whereas chest and locks and other things will stay lit up for several seconds when you use the reveal charm. Why the discrepancy? They wasted money on paying Simon Pegg to be the headmaster because the headmaster has like 10 lines and none of them require Simon Pegg. They wasted time and money making every single staircase in the trials move for no reason other than to make it pretty. When they should've spent that time making the story more interesting. Why doesn't my character have a background? No mention of parents or where I come from or how I found out about magic or who I was before I'm getting on a magical carriage. I talk to so many people in the game about their families but mine, for better or worse, is entirely absent from the story. All the characters are just completely flat with very little to absolutely no character growth at all. You, as the main character, do not have character growth. Also, all the women stand with their hands crossed over each other in a very submissive, waitstaff, choir girl way and it absolutely disgusts me. The male characters all stand normally with hands are their sides and they gesture normally when they talk. Not enough voice options. I also agree that I don't like the house elves plight. I know it's part of the overall world, but I like to believe that there has always been that student or group of students who wanted to free them every year even if it doesn't happen. I do not believe that Hermione is the first one to think this in the books after the school has been open for hundreds of years. Lacks dynamic and morality. Ranrok, the antagonist is lame.  He constantly is on screen in cut scenes wanting to fight me and then the next scene is me fighting the people he was talking to. Like, where did he go? And he just wants power, no real reason. They try to make using the unforgivable curses like a big deal, but its not because like I said, there are no consequences in the game for any of your actions. I really wanted to like this game. And it was cool to see Hogwarts on the screen and be able to run around, but the story itself is really lacking, and I totally see some of the prejudice that people were concerned about towards women and stereotyping groups of people. Also, they are already talking about HL2 but no mention of DLC for HL. That's a huge red flag to me from game developers. Hope this helps your decision :)

author: lol.its.viv
review: So, I'd like to start by mentioning that I bought this game (deluxe edition) before I really looked into the controversy surrounding it. Once the early access period started and the game started blowing up, I started learning more about the prevalent antisemitism and the problems with supporting the game. Now, the open world is great. It's a fun open world, the combat flows nicely, and I like Natty and Sebastian. However, when I started playing the main story of the game I got really uncomfortable. The characterization of the goblins and the general premise of the goblin revolution rubbed me the wrong way. The quest with the house elf who served the Black family also made me very uncomfortable in how the house elf was treated and how the situation was generally received. I like the inclusion of LGBTQ+ characters, however just including a character does not overshadow the fact that there are very problematic and uncomfortable themes in this game. Aside from that, personally the voice acting in the game is very flat and the character animations during dialogue scenes are extremely lack luster. It felt like watching a pair of posts have a discussion when the content they were talking about should have had more emotion behind it. There were also some volume balancing issues that were hugely annoying. Going from playing to a cutscene the volume would shift drastically. Overall, I really wish I had done my research before playing this game as I would not have wasted $80 on a game that supports antisemitism and transphobic agendas and, frankly, has lack luster dialogue animations and voice acting.  To the animators and graphic designers, the game is stunning and combat is great. I truly did enjoy the room of requirement and the vivarium. However, I feel bad for even buying this game due to its problematic nature and the message my actions sent. I have since uninstalled the game and I am truly sorry I bought it in the first place. I personally do not recommend this game but everyone is free to make their own choices.

author: Gretschory
review: UPDATE:With the current patch they messed up the textures loading. So this game became UNPLAYABLE. I do not know what they did, they said they fixed performance related bugs. Oh hell yeah the performance is brilliant if it does not load ANY TEXTURES!Okay I can't play very far. I am a victim of this random in game stutter no matter what graphic settings I choose. Unless this is getting fixed I can't say very much about the game except it looks nice. There is also an issue with the pitch of the voice meaning every tick left or right from the default pitch will make the voice sound robotic. The Pop in is almost GTA San Andreas worthy. Textures literally pop in right in front of you. The random and not consistently reproducable stutters and FPS Drops also seem to affect the physics, meaning I do not think it is Texture related or anything. TL;DR: It is a very bad port. I do not know what the developers are doing, but fixing is not it ;)

review: I pre-purchased HOGWARTS LEGACY Deluxe Edition - Played it and it was like 5 hours worth it to continue the journey of the game.Hogwarts Legacy is an extremely beautiful game that features a not-so-open world, full of life and places to explore. author: colarentic
review: Disclaimer: I am not a harry potter fan, though I did enjoy the movies and books when they came out.This game is your typical open world game. It has a linear set of main quest missions, with a bunch of side quests sprinkled in. My overall impression is it is very much the same as many other open world and AAA games out there, without much innovation. The best thing this game has it has going for it is it nails the atmosphere of harry potter in the character acting and such. You can tell as much from the trailer. Otherwise, I've kind of grown bored of the game 10 hours in.The biggest downside of this game is the performance. It was released in a completely unready state, I honestly suggest waiting for performance fixes for this game if you want to play it. When you start the game it appears to run perfect at the recommended settings, but the second you get to hogwarts you'll see problems. This game seems to struggle when loading the transition between two areas, which happens all the time in hogwarts. You'll notice once you enter a new room or go outside, the game dips from 120fps or whatever your normal fps is, down to 10-20fps. Then, after 10s of seconds it goes back up to your normal 120fps again. There is some critical code optimization that needs to happen in this game.Interestingly, even if I set the game to all low settings, the graphics still look like ultra settings, even after rebooting the game. Seems buggy.

author: Meat Shop
review: Just another uninspired AAA video game. Id wait for a sale to play. Boring story and characters, it seems the writers forgot that this game was about the harry potter universe. Its astonishingly unoriginal, and considers collecting a certain amount of objects or killing a certain amount of enemies to make sense as homework for your classes. The school aspect of Hogwarts is missed completely, and the excitement of wand duelling a worthy opponent is nonexistent as you instead mow down armies of uninteresting goblins and poachers.Im a story/immersion focused gamer, so for me, this game did not capture what made Hogwarts so special in the books or movies. The school looks great, but is devoid of life. I wish they hadnt made the world so large and instead focused on Hogwarts grounds, allowing for more concentrated expirience.I have a lot of disdain for these AAA gaming companies who are perfectly happy releasing games that are just 'ok' instead of TRYING to make something new.

author: Rio
review: I am not a Harry Potter fan nor a hater. For what this game is as a game, it's very underwhelming.Fast travel takes away sense of space. Does not matter if world is big or small, when you're teleporting aroundAutomatic time skip takes away sense of time. Does not matter if it's day or night, time means nothing because it's fast-forwarded to a suitable one.NPCs are forever squatting at the same places, doing the same things, or just not there until you time skipped.With the points above, the world feels small and suffocatingly static.Exploration is revelio revelio revelioCombat is okay I guess, but keyboard controls are a bit clunky. But nothing great either.Despite modern graphics, I did not enjoy the sceneries. Skyrim beats it hands down for style.Can't give any points for soundtrack tooIn a mage school, you won't even need two hands to count how many books did you read.Dialogues are cringy and interactions with other people are superficialAnd most of all, magic is.. surprisingly not magical at all in a game about mages. I'd expect being a mage is about supernatural utility, one person, powerful and unrestrained, affecting a world in a way that usually only a community can. Not about pewpewing baddies. In this game, however, the world has magic, not you. Your's is just a remote control with two buttons to play scripted changes.

review: I've never seen a single Harry Potter movie - Only read a single book in like 4th grade. Yet this game still manages to immerse me and have me enjoy every single minute (though poorly optimized at times). The story is fantastic, the voice acting is as well and the environment brings to life the 'YOU'RE A WIZARD *insert name here*!!'.Customization is amazing, allowing you to keep the look of every item you touch even if you sell it. Changing an items appearance is free, and you can do it as many times as you want and whenever you want. The only downside is looking a bit goofy/MC when you're in a classroom full of people in school uniform and you're dressed entirely different.Even if you're not a fan of the movies/books, this game might still be for you. If you're looking for a fun Wizard/Witch RPG game, this is certainly it. Hours of fun, tons of side stuff to do, puzzles everywhere that are (decently) engaging.Overall: 9/10

author: TheTitaniumDragon
review: Hogwarts Legacy is an open-world RPG set in the Wizarding Universe of Harry Potter, a century before the events of the book series. This is a game that is designed for fans of that universe – Hogwarts Castle, the centerpiece of the series, is marvelously detailed, and the game is full of the whimsy that the brand is known for. Visually, the game is a marvel, full of intricate details – Hogwarts Castle is the single best looking area in any video game, ever, and the world at large is quite nice.The game has you play as a fifth year student – a 16 year old – of the visual appearance and name of your choice. You get to get sorted into your house (though in reality, you can choose it), get a wand, and get to explore Hogwarts. You learn spells, and instead of fighting like a FPS or a standard action game, the game has a wholly original combat system based around matching shields and managing spell cooldowns and choosing your targets. It actually works well, and unlike most games which either abstract it a lot or feel like third person shooters, it actually feels like it is its own thing.But, while this game is a visual masterpiece, it falls a bit short on the actual experience. The game has a really good opening sequence, full of marvelous visuals and a lot of interesting set pieces, but after you get through the tutorial and start in on the game proper, you realize that there were some sacrifices made along the way to get this out the door, and this unfortunately makes the game world feel much less alive than it should.The other students are basically scenery – you barely interact with them, and the only times you really do is quests, of which there are an enormous number. Few of your fellow students or professors get much characterization – really, only four or so characters in the game really get explored all that much, and even then, one of them is terribly bland, and all but one of them have very bland designs.There are no companions here – there are some quests where you are accompanied by one of four fellow students, or by a professor – but they don’t last all that long, and they don’t do enough to characterize most of them. Ironically, the Slytherin companion is the most interesting one – and in fact, there are two interesting Slytherin characters, which works very well as they have a pre-existing friendship and you are sort of “intruding” on it, which creates an intersting dynamic. Moreover, one of them is very much into Dark Magic and is very emotional, while the other rejects it as dangerous. The one who is into it befriends you and influences you to try and find a cure for his sister, Anne, who has been cursed, at whatever cost – but even as he seduces you to the Dark Side, it kind of becomes clear that he is going too far and nothing he is doing is ultimately going to work out.Unfortunately, while this is a good tragedy, it is interspersed with a general plot that is nowhere near as good. One of the other students is okay – she has a bunch of beast-related sidequests – while the third is a fairly lame do-gooder whose characterization isn’t exactly exciting, and who is presented as some exotic figure – except the school is *extremely* international (much more than in the series) resulting in her not seeming so exotic at all. It just doesn’t work.There’s theoretically one more companion, but his existence is so fleeting that he shows up basically one and a half times. It is obvious he was meant to play a bigger role, but it seems like whatever subquest he was getting got cut – either because it wasn’t very interesting or because of a lack of time.Indeed, it is very obvious that the game was meant to have a companion system, where you brought people around with you; there’s remnants of dialogue from that, and unfortunately, without it, the world feels very sterile. You can’t interact with anyone but shopkeepers outside of quests, and so while the world is pretty, all there really is to do is to run around collecting stuff – which there is a plethora of, but it is mostly the same stuff, over and over again, outside of Hogwarts.The greater open world is honestly pretty weak – it looks good visually, but gameplay-wise, there’s just not enough enemy variety to sustain the game. The game could do some interesting puzzles, but there’s only a handful of them, mostly in Hogwarts, with most of the rest just being “use spell on object”. The actual combat is okay at first, but by the end you are just an overpowered wrecking ball and nothing can stand in your way, even without the use of Dark Magic, and the lack of enemy variety makes it increasingly repetitive the longer you go on.The overall plot of the game is only okay as well. It starts off very strong, but unfortunately, your lack of bonding with characters greatly undermines the core plot – bad things happen to people, but it’s hard to care because you have no reason to care about these people. Some of the side plots are stronger than the main plot, and don’t end up tying in as strongly as they should have, and in the end, you have this climactic scene with a bunch of characters that you interacted with three times in the game at most, because you literally can’t interact with them outside of their very limited quests.The game also doesn’t really deliver on the notion of being a student – indeed, your character is implausibly powerful for a 16 year old, and takes out veritable armies of goblins and dark wizards single-handedly. The classes are very limited and superficial, and you have little interaction with most students or professors, which is a shame, as Hogwarts was far more interesting than the all too repetitive open world.As a result, the game at times had a hard time holding my attention – I have “171” hours in this game, but the actual 100% time was 77 hours, with the rest being alt-tabbed out. And of that, I’d say that about a third was high quality quests, and about two-thirds was wandering around exploring the open world to collect stuff that was, frankly, kind of pointless.Finally, the game has some performance issues. It does not run terribly well, and if you are running an older rig, expect to have to upscale the graphics to get something other than a slide show.Overall, I think this is a valiant effort, but the shortcomings hold it back from greatness. It’s worth playing if you’re into the Wizarding World and don’t mind open worlds, but I would recommend focusing on the quests, particularly the main quest, and mostly ignoring the open world – there’s not much that’s all that fun out there.

author: ark
review: Okay, 19 hours in I've got a good idea of how the game feels. The gameplay is fun but the first hour or 2 where you're doing the introductory quest can be slow because of the dialogue and cutscenes (Don't get me wrong the story is really interesting, but if you're looking to get into the gameplay immediately then you need to get through the introductions first). The fights are really fun and make you feel like you're in a duel against other wizards. The combat is not deep it's quite literally just spell casting. There are no melee weapons, but there are plants and potions that will aid you in combat. There's no mana system or stamina system it's all about whether or not you can outcast an opponent and time your blocks correctly (kinda like shadow of mordor/war) you can dodge and counter/block. I personally had issue loading into areas on the first day of launch on the 7th, but it's steadily gotten better the more i've played. Hopefully Avalanche releases some updates to fix some of the memory leak issues. However, i'm sure they'll push out optimization updates as soon as they get enough player data and input. I'm genuinely a fan of the Harry Potter books and the game really actually feels like Hogwarts so far. It's also a completely open world. I'm doing the main quest right now but nothing's stopping me from going to Hogsmeade or just wandering around doing side missions or looking for collectibles. The game gives you a lot of freedom when exploring too. Once you're given your first broom you can basically fly anywhere you want (Except for the no-fly zones which stay canon to the movies/books). Besides the stuttering the game has me hooked and is a perfect 9/10Although J.K Rowling's name is attached to the series, the developer and publisher of this Hogwarts Legacy deserve all the praise it's getting for their hard work. Simply forget about her and the game is one of the most enjoyable of 2023 so far. It'll be hard to top it.

author: Starliner
review: I have sunk 28 hours into the game so far and I must say, I am thoroughly impressed!!! The game transports you straight into the magical world of Harry Potter, like no previous entry has before. It's a true masterpiece.From the stunning graphics to the intricate storyline, everything about this game is incredibly well done. The characters are incredibly well-developed, and you can really feel their emotions and motivations as you play. The game's open-world design allows you to explore Hogwarts and its surrounding areas in ways I never thought possible, and the spellcasting system is both intuitive and challenging.But what truly sets this game apart is its attention to detail. The developers have truly done their homework when it comes to the Harry Potter universe and it shows. From the little quirks of the professors to the way magic is used, everything feels authentic and true to the original books.Overall, I highly recommend this game to any fan of the Harry Potter franchise, as well as anyone looking for a well-made, immersive game experience. Hogwarts Legacy is a true testament to what can be achieved in the gaming industry, and it sets a new standard for what a game based on a beloved franchise should be.

This game is so beautiful and just brings smiles at every turn. It's so much fun. Every view is phenomenal. The combat and exploration are on point. You can tell a lot of effort was put into the design of the world, each and every building, landscape,castle, etc...So much detail. It's amazing. This is a game we all needed. It over delivers. It's better than every game on the market since RDR2 (except Elden Ring). Seriously. It's good.Source: 25hrs play so far (I am a walker). It's perfect for gamers like me who RP, and walk the world like real life.

author: Batberg
review: Let me preface this by saying I'm in no way a Harry Potter fan - but I am a fan of RPGs and open-world games, and I've played a lot of them. Hogwarts Legacy is a love letter to the world of Harry Potter - taking place before Potter's time, the game has you fight against a goblin rebellion by harnessing ancient magic. The nature of this magic isn't clear, but of course, your character is the Chosen One, so...The gameplay is incredibly basic. Spam cast magic, with the occasional switching of spells in order to form impotent combos that don't really do much damage to your enemy. Your character is a Hogwarts student , and yet he is learning the magic of a first year - yet, at the same time, he can learn the unforgiveable curses and use them without punishment or repercussion. Combat is slow and clunky, and there isn't enough variety to really keep me interested. The game is mostly about exploration. Find this, collect that. Hogwarts is filled with secrets to seek and puzzles to solve, but they don't feel organic - rather, they feel as if they were added in order to make the game artificially longer. Movement is really slow, which just makes me less likely to want to collect everything.This is where the game stands out. As a fan of huge, sprawling maps, Hogwarts itself feels too small for my liking, but the detail that has put into building the castle is phenomenal. Staircases, corridors, towers, and parapets all come together to form a wondrous piece of architecture - and you get to explore it, albeit, feeling less like a Hogwarts student and more like a placeholder for someone more important. Hogsmeade is less beautiful, but still a spectacular sight. The game is filled with bland NPCs, and the secondary characters are not much better. Dialogue sounds artificial, almost robotic, and before long I was spamming the skip button because of how long the conversations are.I cannot recommend Hogwarts Legacy to anyone with an ounce of sanity. The game is clearly unfinished - features promised by the developers -  - have not been included in the full game, obviously coming as a DLC at some unknown point in the future. The combat is clunky. Exploration seems to be key to the gameplay, but it is so slow. The game itself is optimised poorly. THE GAME IS BORING. Out of my four hours, at least an hour and a half of that was spent in cutscenes, by the way. Please don't buy this game.Oh, and to the reviewer who likened this game to the Witcher 3. Not only is that a grave insult to CDPR, but what kind of drugs were you taking when you wrote your review?

review: Hogwarts Legacy is Action RPG set in J.K. Rowling's world of harry potter.While the game let you plays as student in hogwarts school, this game is by any means not a school simulator with action like "Bully". Think of it more like "skyrim / witcher 3".Pros(+):+ Big map area with very detailed environment.+ One of best game graphic released to date.+ DLSS, FSR, XeSS+ Great combat and snappy movement.+ Transmog feature so you won't looks silly with your randomized loot.+ Bunch of side quest and activity to do.Grey (?):? Control kinda clunky since attack and choosing spell is same button (with controller).? The game is mostly dialogue based and exploring the world.? Colored rarity gear + leveled gear.? Very rare but annoying FPS drops.? Non-scheduled school class, you can come anytime as long it's daytime.Cons(-):- Lack of photo mode as this review written.- Most enemy acts same, combat get repetitive real fast.- Houses you choose for your hogwarts school doesn't affect much, or any.The game is pretty much worth full price if you're a potterhead, while i'll suggest to wait for atleast 30% sale if you're just average RPG enjoyer.ps: Lack of combat in this game makes me rate this game sleep/10

author: kevin
review: Let me get this straight - I love this game. It is almost certainly the greatest Harry Potter game ever created, and I really do wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone interested in trying, or are already interested in the Wizarding World universe. However, despite recommending it, I'm also giving it a negative recommendation (ironic, I know). However, this is for good reason. This game takes a lot of inspiration (in my opinion) from the Witcher 3, from the quest structure, quest log, repetitive places of interest, and even the absence of many choices. My main critique of this game was that this game was marketed as having choices that would directly affect the future of Hogwarts - this couldn't be further from the truth. This game is so incredibly linear in terms of storytelling, and the few times the game seems like it's giving you a choice to be somewhat evil, it still winds up being lighthearted. There is no player freedom. It looks like you can say something mean to someone, you choose that option, and then you end up saying something nice anyway. It makes no sense. Another concern, and the final nail in the coffin that made me so angry with this game (despite how much I love it) is that your house really does NOT matter. Regardless of the house that you choose, you still end up on the same missions with the same people, and there are no students in your common room that you can befriend. In fact, your common room is useless beyond the first few quests. Essentially, choosing your house is just choosing your favourite colour. Expanding on the previous point of your house not mattering, my character was sorted into Slytherin, and I wanted to roleplay as a typical, snarky Slytherin student. Instead, regardless of the character you make, they will talk as though they're a shy 12 year old who kisses the feet of everyone asking for help. This game does not deserve the RPG tag, and I'm disappointed in the developers for marketing the game as a "choices matter" video game - it doesn't. The dialogue options should have been cut, because it doesn't change anything. I do really enjoy this game, I do recommend it, and I will complete it, but I have to leave this here as a warning to all players that the game is not what it was marketed to be. It is still quite enjoyable, but it's not what was promised.

author: cameronfrost00
review: First of all, steam only lets you give a yes or no answer to whether you recommend this game, so this review isn't entirely negative. Ill start off with what I liked:- The open world is very well crafted, it's not big but they make it feel big which you can go out an explore from the start. - The story is ok, but nothing special. - The combat is fun and relatively well designed. - The puzzles aren't too repetitive and are pretty interesting, reminding me a bit of GOW. Now the negatives, and oh boy there's a lot:- Frankly this game is way over hyped, yes it exceeded expectations but only because they were low to begin with. - The quests aren't really quests but feel more like tedious errands you have to do for people in order to progress through the game. This was one of the most awful aspects for me, and really tested my patience. Things like "go use a mandrake root on some enemies" only so you can run back to an npc to get the new spell wingardium leviosa, even though there's seemingly no reason why you had to do these chores in the first place. Every side quest is more of chore you have to do for someone, like go find an item at x and bring it back to a and then go and find another item etc. Even the classes feel tedious and boring, because i know ill have to do one of these stupid assignments after every one of them. In other games, they would fit more into optional challenges players can do to earn achievements or filler, but here they form the bulk of the content. 10 hours in, i was tired and desperately hoping that if I progress far enough something interesting will happen. - None of the npc content was intriguing to me at all, and they are usually very shallow. For example, there's a part when you have to answer trivia about the wizarding world and one of the questions was 'what are the deathly hallows', and one of the options was horcruxes. I chose this option because I thought it would be interesting to see the npc's react to you knowing about horcruxes, which from the book were supposedly a big no go topic, but the npcs have absolutely no reaction and just say oops you're wrong. Why add horcruxes as an option and then completely ignore an opportunity to show interesting canon reactions, like i may as well have said slugs. This brings me to the next part:- If you actually want to role play as a dark wizard the game will not let you. Yes, you can use the unforgivable curses but they're locked behind a side quest that will literally take you to the end of the story by the time you can use spells like avada kedavra. Funnily enough though, this side quest had more character development than the main story. The spells are treated pretty much like every other spell anyway, there's barely any response from npc's and will react pretty much the same as every other spell you use. I used crucio on someone next to the damn professor and he didn't care or react at all. - In terms of dialogue, it's like your character is constantly high or something because he's always smiling and never really reacts angry, scared or anxious no matter the situation. I liked a few npcs but most were pretty much the same in that regard. It takes a lot out of the experience because the story tries to make you feel like it's important, but then the characters react like its another Tuesday. - There isn't really any grind or reward for gear like other rpgs, it's simply finding gear in some random chest and then equipping whatever gives you better stats.- Most of the open world side content is filler. Go clear camps to get runes to apply to your gear, over and over again. It seems they locked your inventory capacity just so they could fill more content, so you have to run around doing 'merlin trials' just so you can increase inventory slots, which makes no sense when they give you a bottomless bag to put animals in. - Getting new spells would feel rewarding if you weren't fighting the same enemies you were in the first hour of the game at the end of the game. Overall, it's a game i'd buy after playing every other good rpg out there and was bored looking for something to play. I wouldn't even say it follows canon that well. Don't buy it thinking you're getting something as detailed as RD2, GOW or Elden Ring, but it's by no means a terrible game and I can appreciated the effort the devs put into making it.

author: xBGLx狂犬
review: I WISH I COULD’VE PLAYED THIS GAME 20 YEARS AGO. WHAT A GREAT TIME TO BE ALIVE!Remember old first three games, and how I liked them and this one is better in mostly every aspect. Map is big enough to explore, music is great, overall atmosphere is fantastic. It’s so addictive just to gather resources, finish challenges and some sort of tasks. There are a lot of small details about the world which are noticeable for books and movies fans and enjoyers. About mine experience with technical side: mostly 60 fps, small drops 1-3 fps when I am fast travel somewhere or when I get into new location. I’ve locked fps to 60 in game with vertical sync on, motion blur off, all settings are on medium except textures (high). Res: full hd. Specs: i5 10400, rtx2060s, ssd, win 10, 24 gb ram.Of course there are some things I wish would’ve been better or changed at all:-map(when you press m) is quite bad, especially Hogwarts map. It’s quite misleading and hard to backtrack anything in castle.- potions making, I wish it will be like Oblivion at least or like Kingdom Come where you are actually making potions instead of just waiting 30 secs.. boring, could’ve been better.- not many good secrets and secret passages in the castle itself, it feels great but with new technologies they can make Hogwarts even better, unfortunately they didn’t- no chests or other things to gather your gear, you can only sell it or destroy it, and Merlin’s trials aren’t that much effective to increase your slots..- they could’ve done lessons more interesting to attend + add some books in the library so people could read them, like in Skyrim for example.- no Quidditch, broom flights feels great, but I hope they will make quidditch as a separate DLC or may be in future games.To sum up, strong 8 out of 10 from me, great game regardless of it’s problems and long awaited game in Harry Potter universe. I think most of the HP fans will like it and I recommend it to kids too, great game to just explore and fight some enemies.P.S. thanks for Japanese voice-overP.P.S. let us remember wise words:

author: Nikushimi
review: I am still not sure if I like this game or not.Pros: - The castle and the atmosphere is just breathtaking- Hogsmeade is super cute- the forbidden forest is exactly how I imagined it- running around and exploring inside the castle is super awesome- the different seasons are well made (winter and autumn are my favorites)Cons:- The story is super boring and it ticks every cliché in the fantasy genre- the main character excels in EVERYTHING and has no own background. Just a plain boring main character- I miss a cool rival like Draco Malfoy. Everyone is super nice and no one has real ambitions. Give me some slytherin vibes.- The gear system is like all over the place. You get too much stuff and it feels kind of worthless. - it is supposed to be a school, but you don't have any schedule or homework at all.- You can't talk to anyone. You really get NPC vibes there and it feels empty. You can't built any relationships/friendshipsSome minor cons but they bug me like crazy.- You can own a damn zoo, but can not keep an owl or so?!- No one sleeps in the common rooms- No one has to go to class. You never see a full class or someone actually teaching- Spoiler!! The way you enter hogwarts for the first time was a huge disappointment. Not riding the hogwarts express, no traveling via carriage towards the castle...- no detention, no owl post, no chocolate frogs... - No patronous charme (?) Hellooo???I really like running around the castle but the story and the character alltogether are super boring and it lacks edge and some rivalery between houses.

author: Stabbykinz
review: So this one was...tough. There's a fair amount to like about the game. The visuals are stellar, the world is very pretty to explore and soak in, the combat is pretty thrilling and spectacle when you're fending off multiple enemies at a time. The wizard fashion is easily my favorite part along with the interior decorating for the Room of Requirement, even if the decorating is a bit limitedBut the game's title is completely misleading. This isn't a Hogwarts game, nor is there a Legacy. I'm writing this review with 23 hours clocked in at the moment, and the issues were slow to arise, but glaring as the illusion of this game drops. I'm not going to cover the spec issues and poor optimization, they put in DRM software so I was already expecting frames to be all over the place. (Surprisingly it wasn't all the time, but I won't be talking much more about those details.) With that much time sunk in, the biggest glaring issue I've come across in this title is that I don't know the main villain's motivation, I don't know the side villain's motivation, and I don't even really know what truly sets apart ancient magic from regular magic. But it gets worse, and I'll try to keep it readable, if not brief.The game starts with you already being a fifth year. This...was honestly disappointing. I figured it would have been the case since the character creation already has you mostly grown up, but I was really hoping to experience a more modernized gaming experience of -Hogwarts-. But, alright, I can probably forgive that, even with the character creation being limited from what had been previously showcased before. But...then the game just tosses you in? There's no real build up, or background choices, you're just someone that got picked as a fifth year, and then you can see ancient magic, and the Sorting Time? It's a bit jarring, but at least the voice acting for my lass is decent. But soon enough you're a stellar student breezing through very basic assignments, getting showered in praises in spells, and it just...feels very weird. The game's got some pretty bad protagonist syndrome, but it gets worse, ironically, when contrasted with the professors, a couple students, and the background NPC's.I have to take further points away from Hogwarts Legacy, because the vast majority of the side students are kinda grating to listen to, and you don't get super close to them, as far as I know.. Side quests across the board are a bit inane so far and have mostly involved characters going 'I can't be bothered to do this thing, go do it and find out what the thing is'. I  give points back for the Professors and Natty. Ronen is especially one of my favorites, well voice acted, and brought so much energy that I was actually excited to do classes for a bit. Most of the classes are one/two-off though, even Natty's charm and delightful lore couldn't really lift my spirits when I found out that I wouldn't be interacting with them as often as I thought. Further more, listening on the NPC students in conversation, getting howled, or interacting with folks in Hogsmeade really made them feel grounded and part of the world...And I think that's what broke my immersion. That's what was wrong with my character. They have no Over the course of my twenty hour plus experience, I realized that my character has nothing really tying them to the world or the story beyond "I can see wibbly wobblies in the air!". Their past might as well not exist, they exceed at everything despite only having veeery rushed training versus the students who have been at it for . They don't have any  in fighting the antagonists, or finding out why they have the SPECIAL E Y E SSS (my brand!). They are pretty much an engine for the story to keep trucking a long and a yes-woman for all of the authority figures, ready to help and do things because they can and the story demands it. The NPC's feel more grounded and believable than my own character, which makes the contrast so grating that it breaks my immersion. I get that wearing the 'hero hat' immediately destines the PC to become powerful through the course of the game, but it feels like the game does everything its power to alienate you from the other students and characters from the get-go.But that's just the  alienation. Let's talk about the physical.Funny enough, the ancient magic thing is not the worst part, considering how they barely go into details about what is, not even in bread crumbs of info as you progress. The worst part is that this is an open world. Not Disco Elysium's non-linear open world, I mean pick-any-Ubisoft's kinda open world: mile wide, inch deep, ♥♥♥♥ all to really do. It's pretty to look and and trounce around in, but aside from wiping out wildlife and poachers, or delving into dangerous places for the next piece of fall fashion, going out into the world (aside from Hogsmeade and a handful of villages)...doesn't really do much for you unless you're looking for ingredients? But you  to go out there for a lot of the main quests which means less time at Hogwarts, an experience which was already fairly bare-bones to begin with without you literally absconding whenever you want and not giving a ♥♥♥♥ or getting punished for curfew breaking. I really think the game would have fared better with  far more focus on  and giving you certain locals to explores as the story calls for it.So to boil it all down: your characters feels groundless and improbable, pretty much a walking Mary Sue/Gary Stu/They-ry Glu, with no real motivation or stake in the story. 20+ hours in and the game still refuses to give even bread crumbs on the motivation of either antagonist, nor do you see them. No real distinction between ancient magic or regular magic, even with what little the game shows. No connections with any of the students outside of two of them, and it's pretty obvious who. Professors are amazing but your interactions with them are limited to serving the progression of the 'story' and getting more spells. The game literally requires you to go out of Hogwarts regularly, ignoring curfew, no real point in interacting with other classmates and no getting points for your house to my knowledge. The whole experience starts off really well and fizzles out over time as you realize that the story is flat, you've got no ties to it or the world, the Hogwarts experience is so accelerated and anemic, it feels like a  to everything else...and there's not  else to begin with. If I had to sum up my experience in a few words, it feels like I spent a lot of money on a wizard fashion and combat simulator with some very watered down plot. Which sucks, because I was genuinely excited for the game, and I really wanted to give it a chance. Maybe my opinion'll change as I get deeper in the game but I doubt the issues that have plagued this game for the first twenty three hours will suddenly improved over the next twenty three. I think I'd rather play Stixhaven or Kids on Brooms at this rate.I am definitely using this game for making character refs, though.

author: Oki_Dingo
review: Edit: With all three Ray Tracing features turned off, setting my TV(LG C2) to 60hz, and turning V-Sync on I am able to get it to stay at 60fps. However there are still a lot of stutters in the castle. Actually looks better with RT off, there was a lot of shimmering going on with it on. I will change my recommendation once the game is updated and optimized.Original: Not sure what kind of systems people are running, or maybe they find 30fps on low settings acceptable. I have a 10850K, RTX-3090, and 32gb of RAM. I should be able to play this game fine, like all other games. in stead I have spent 4 days trying to tweak settings and get the frames stable. I can get what seems like ok stable frames rates, turn a corner and they tank to the upper 10's and 20's. I figured I would what for the day-1 patch before passing judgement or requesting a refund. My friends on PS5 are having a super smooth experience. I bought this game on steam so I could play it on steamdeck, since it's verified.....verified hot garbage!!!! on low setting with everything off and windowed 720p you are lucky to run at 30fps with frame dips everywhere. Now as for the game, it seems super fun.

author: Psycho
review: Dear grandmasters of Hogwarts,​Hogwarts Legacy is amazing but I would like to request that you please add beards to the game, so I can create a character named Hairy Potter. I have made the character with the options that are currently available, but he is not as hairy as I would like him to be. He only has an afro, no beard at all. :(​And you may be thinking... "The characters are school children, how could they possibly grow a beard? It wouldn't make any sense." And to that I retort, I had a best friend in middle school named Anthony who had a full Mario mustache.​Sincerely,A sad, beardless Hogwarts student

author: Drake Ravenwolf
review: I'd describe it as 3rd person Skyrim with almost Dark Souls style (ranged) combat assuming you play this on HARD, which you def should.  Even on HARD, it feels just a smidge too easy; I chose to do the Dueling quest without a companion which pits you against 4x other caster enemies and as long as you time your "block" spell correctly - you can do that without taking any damage at all.  Still fun gameplay imo, absolute LOADS of collectibles to explore and find and it's all kept track of so you know what you might be missingAs for the "politically devisive" aspects; the first time you meet the trans character it is very jarring - like why is this a thing?  And everyone always referring to you as "They/them" instead of he/she is def annoying, but if you ignore those aspects, I'd still recommend this game to anyone who likes the Harry Potter books or just likes this style of gameplay.PS there is a mod available if you want to actually play as a white person; the default "whitest" setting is still quite tan, and there is a reason everyone praises how attractive Professor Garlick is (all the other female npcs... aren't)Keep in mind; there are still loads of performance issues at the time of this writing.  Some people cannot see more than the epilepsy warning before crashing, others have constant stuttering issues, your mileage may vary, but I'd hope they'll all be fixed with some more patches

author: CEI Hero
review: Playing on hard. This game starts out amazing. Its like watching a movie, but the combat is challenging, dynamic, fast paced, and addicting in a way that old hack and slash games used to be. Here's where it gets lame: The challenge burns out FAST. By level 19 I stopped picking up gear and looting chests because it was simply not needed in order to keep killing enemies. I stopped leveling things and unlocking spells because there was no need for my character to get stronger. Just to give it a foolproof test, I ran to the edge of the map. All of the edges. Which did not take me long, which was even more depressing. In all the land, I could not find a foe that I could not best, even in "end game content" areas, so to speak. This made the game hollow. Then I realized: there are only FOUR types of enemies. You read that right, 4. Bipedal humans (or other wizards and witches), giant frogs, giant spiders, trolls. After you learn their moves, you just breeze through any part of the map. Oh yeah and goblins. so 5. Anyway: 1.) Too easy2.) Small World Map3.) Needs more enemies 4.) Game too shortConcept is fantastic, whereas elden ring was a "souls" type game based off a popular book and movie franchise, hogwarts legacy is a "scrolls" type game based off a popular book and movie franchise. But they should have taken the PVE enemies more serious. That specific dynamic is the foundation of what keeps you advancing your character, ie: playing the game. And maybe I'm wrong about all this, but I shouldn't be able to sprint anywhere on the map and survive willy-nilly, when I just started the game a few days ago, so, there's my final point.

author: Nyuu ♥
review: Good game, lacking a bit of upgrades for spells / brooms and customization (not a lot of wand design, only a the handle can change) but not so much a big deal and it feels great.Although a reputation system would be a big+ aswell to avoid lockpicking or casting forbbiden spells infront of your teachers without any reaction.The story feels flat, I don't care about any characters, You don't feel like a student in 5th year (learning lumos in 5th year lmao) your house have no impact, classes are boring and useless, no house point system.. NPCs are idling in the castle without any interaction possible so in two words "" at all for me.Side quests are so bland go kill goblins / dark mages in a camp and done or press a button to resolve a puzzle and loot an item in a cave thats it.Loot have no sense, and is scaled on your current level so you should keep some chests if you want better stuff later... Legendary is a joke and you'll find plenty of "legendary" stuff, in fact so much you'll find yourself selling legendaries for some inventory spaces. There is no combo of items or themed sets of item giving some stat boost or any effect.The HP lore is underexploited, somethings are only mentioned for the nostaligia effect but there isn't many actual enemy creatures (no dementors :'( no pixies, no werewolf no gytrash etc )  Main enemies you'll encounter are And on top of that the game crash way too often (more than 15 times in 37h ) sometimes even in loading screens.. and yet I still wanted to launch it back to play the game.But one day a crash turned into a blue screen which is wayy more annyoing.. and still after a reboot I could still play the game. However the next day the game crash again with a blue screen but this time after rebooting my save was gone.. And that draws the line for me I'm not willing to invest 40 hours back into a game that will eventually crash 50 more times and erase my save without any warnings.Even after checking for files and retriving 2 files I guess it wasn't my save.Stability issues aside I still think it's a good game because I had some fun playing it while it lasted but it could've been WAAY better if they pushed it a bit further and a bit deeper plot- wise and not keeping it as simple as possible.

author: Pion
review: Like most modern games, a lot of love has been put into the graphics, and almost none has been put into creating good gameplay. Hogwarts is incredibly beautiful and the surrounding area is rather large.Been looking forward to being a student at Hogwarts? I have, for literally more than 2 decades. This one still disappoints. Your first potion making class is a press-the-right-button-cutscene.. Your undercover dueling club is a infinite tries, and then everybody becomes extremely impressed when you suceed at your 10th try, like you are the god of dueling. And the difficulty is scaled by adding 4 people to fight you, so a "duel" is you vs 4 other people, you can bring a friend if you want. But somehow they always outnumber you. Fighting, it looks pretty and feels OK at best, and fighting is clearly the most developed of the game mechanics in the game.The broomstick flying is horrendous - Both on gamepad and key/mouse, the controls are terrible, they can not be changed on gamepad and only a few of them can be changed on M/K. And there's a lot of invisible walls, want to go through those cool little archways in the bridge? Too bad, not allowed. Want to do some cool diving maneuvers, well the game will make sure you only angle to about 45 degrees downwards, because more would be.. fun?They could have done so much with this great set, but they seemed to have spent too long on overscoping instead of nailing some core game features.Immersive roleplaying experience? Not really, unless you love waypoint markers telling you where to go exactly instead of actually looking around and exploring the world. And if you want to play without the waypoint markers, good luck then. Just after you arrive at Hogwarts, Professor Fig will send you an owl (read: you will get a voice message like you had a cell phone or something) telling you to come to his office. With 0 explanation of where that'd be and no options to ask anyone. The game assumes you play with waypoints on, it does not assume you want to actually explore by yourself. My character keeps talking to himself like some crazy guy. And it gets repetitive.This game has A LOT of issues, and yet it's so beautiful, it sort of makes me sad that I don't want to spend more time in this pretty game. 2 years more development time, maybe it would have been great. As it is, it's decent at best.

author: McJoseph
review: This will be a rant, I'll try to TLDR it and give some generalizations first. I will 100% miss things but I will include what sticks out the most to me this second.OVERALL: 9/10, well worth $60 even if you don't like HP, just as a fantasy open-world RPG. I have enjoyed every one of the 20, then 30, now 40 hours spent in this game and I mainly went side-questing and exploring instead of story.As an aside I play on "Hard" difficulty and am on my first run as a Slytherin.======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======CATEGORIES: Steam Deck experience, PC Experience (combat, bugs, visuals, favorites, complaints)======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======Steam Deck Experience: Probably about 5 of my hours so far, controls were very easy to adapt to from PC, ran extremely smoothly and had no Deck-specific complaints. Especially with this being a single player non-internet game I can easily imagine this being my go-to Steam Deck game.======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======PC Experience:     Combat: Very early in the tutorial you are shown how to fight, block, and do basic attacks. Easy to learn, and a nice introduction. As you progress and learn more spells, blue bar special moves (not specified for spoiler reasons), shielding/cursing, and environment interactions, combat goes from "spam my favorite chain" to "pay attention, play to your strengths, and exploit weaknesses". Personally, I struggled against specific bosses and Battle Arenas which only increased my enjoyment compared to the small encounters I quickly overcame. Fights that took me two or three tries, pouring out my inventory to turn the tide had me ecstatic to earn a victory.     I am also usually extremely bad at stealth options in games but this works exceptionally well. I can clear entire camps without being detected or at least make a hard fight more in my favor by taking some out beforehand. Even "Infamous Foes" could go down with no effort with a well-executed assassination.Pros:- Easy to learn, hard to master. Play "Story" difficulty if you really don't like it, I love it.- You fight how you want. I intended on not using Plants or Potions but then discovered how useful they are. How your spells interact are up to your casting order.- Dark Arts are completely your choice, and while they are exceptionally powerful the recharge time makes up for it.- Enemies scale. I massively over leveled doing side quests where at Level 30 (out of 40) I was doing Level 12 Main Quests. Enemies were still either 20ish for easy or 34ish for more difficult encounters. Amazing.Cons:- Ran into some issues with Advanced Dodge Roll when bosses would attack where I would get hit anyway. Annoying but a learning moment.- Hard is hard. Less reaction time, more aggressive spells,  hits hurt more. I'm often chugging Health Potions since most hits take >2/3 of your HP. Again, other difficulties are available.[Again, this is all I can think of at the moment. Play for yourself]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======Bugs: Pros:- Personally experienced 0 crashes, and all bugs have been visual- Places I think I've been softlocked the game teleports you to last safe ground so no reload or reset requiredCons:- You'd have to visit others reviews, personally no issues.======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======Visuals:I did upgrade my PC purely to place this game, but wow are the visuals worth it. I was so happy Graphics defaulted to Ultra. The lighting is fabulous, moving inside-outside or vice versa transitions very smoothly.Pros:- Spell effects, character details, environment effects, everything is gorgeous- Smooth transitions- Seasonal changes are especially beautiful (snow, autumnal colors, etc)Cons:- Hardware intensive- Seriously don't blow up your PC======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======Favorites: I mentioned I spent most of my time side-questing. That means I was so content just exploring, flying around, gathering materials, doing puzzles, etc etc I didn't mind not doing the main plot. One of my favorite parts was when I fought a bandit camp higher level than what I should've been near and was able to beat it with some careful planning and executions.The "base of operations" in this game is exceptionally well done in my opinion. The resources are easy to gather for the ones in the world, and while initially expensive to make local harvesters the rewards easily pay it off in the future. "Rescuing", taming, and farming beasts is also exceptionally rewarding.Enemy Encyclopedia is especially helpful detailing often uncommon ways to beat enemies, or how to weaken them for more damage.Open Exploration, the world is very large and fast travel is easy. Broom flight is fairly early on and the other mounts later but they all have their perks. Also there's so many different brooms to choose from.Character Customization / Equipment: There are SO MANY options to discover for outfit parts, and the "equip for stats, vanity for looks" method is perfect. If we just go off equipment, my character looks absolutely goofy all the time, but instead I was a full-plate Knight in a green Snake scarf running around fighting bad guys. Equip for stats, pick your vanity, sell the rest, rinse and repeat."Morality": Obviously outside of Dark Arts or Not usage, most of the time on Quest turn-in there are 3 options:1. "I did X thing, have a nice day" (Positive)2. "X was really tough, can I get a reward?" (Positive still, but more money)3. "X is mine now." (Negative, STILL GET NORMAL REWARD)It was very entertaining the first time I refused to tell someone how to solve something they found and told me about, then later heard them complain I was insufferable. Great NPC interaction with no real consequence.Or choosing NOT to learn the Unforgiveables really has no downside outside of your preference.======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======Complaints:  Again, specific things I can think of right now.- Gear slots are so small, even with expansion over time it is a little annoying to be mid-quest and see "gear slots are full"- Common repeating voice lines. "Seems like every road leads to Hogsmeade" "You cannot IMAGINE how inconvenient travel was before I invented Floo Powder!" - You have to minigame pick every lock even as you upgrade the skill for higher ones. Just let me auto-unlock the lesser ones if I'm at a high level already.======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======[]======So yeah that is my review currently. Thanks for reading, I tried to organize it. This is definitely my longest review ever but with how long people hoped this game was good and how excited I am to play it, it is well deserved.Make your own opinions and drink water :)

review: The game is made with lots of love and attention to detail. Graphics are not spectacular but allow for lots of immersion in the school and outside areas. There are some moments of graphics clunkiness, but not to become an issue and overall it is a pleasure to explore. Combat is surprisingly complex with the initial impression of being simple. author: Veoxic
review: The attention to detail in this game and how faithful they stayed to the books is unreal. The devs really did an amazing job. Game stutters a bit sometimes when loading new areas but day one patch already sorted most of the problems. Found zero bugs so far about 22 hours. Definite GOTY material

author: Liefde
review: Hogwarts Legacy is more an interactive lightnovel, than a game. You're a character in an open map that's filled with fetch quests, mini-games and things to kill/collect.There's little to no player agency & the world doesn't really react to you, in fact, aside from cutscenes, mini-games and combat; you'll basically not exist to the outside world.You're barely in class and the classes you do take are cutscenes that you watch in order to deliver your fetch quests.Gear is inconsequential as are most RPG mechanics in the game.The story itself is alright, but nothing mindblowing. It's the standard: You're a special chosen one who can do special things no one else can. Great world, but I'd hesitate to call it a game. My recommendation is to only buy when discounted.

author: Jose Ternel
review: As much as I like the aesthetic of the game and the re-creation of Hogwarts and surroundings, the gameplay is stale, with a combat system that could've been much better but is under-exploited, the set of enemies is very limited and they have features that are not so distinctive, but above all the open-world content is dull and stale. I would still recommend the game to a fan of the Harry Potter franchise, but not at full price, far from it, and I would strongly advise not to target 100% and to skip the open world content. Some quests are fun, character interactions is ok-ish (however the constant praising of the player pretty much for doing nothing is annoying), and the story, although I have not completed it yet, seems ok so far, but not great. Overall, it could have been a good game, instead its a mediocre or below average game in a well-done Harry Potter universe, which makes it "passable" at best.
