author: anarchy753
review: At this point, I've finished a 100% run, and rerun the first 2-3 hours for each house in order to get the unique house quest/achievement for each.Pros:I love the style of the exploration. Both in and out of the castle felt significant and they managed to have two very different scales still feel relatively similar in value. The open world map is well done, and unlike other recent titles all of the locations feel hand-made, as opposed to something like Assassin's Creed Odyssey or Elden Ring which fill a much larger map by copy-pasting the same camps/dungeons/assets ad nauseum.While it is clear that most dialogue options don’t have an overarching effect, the actual dialogue choices are strong. Most games will give you the most bland a-or-b decisions, but there were a number of key moments where you were given a really good compromise between what seems like the obvious choices.The main story felt great within the universe while still being a completely unique concept. The story itself wasn’t the most engaging but it gave a cohesive reason for progressing. The side quests were incredible, and to be honest, the Sebastian Sallow questline completely overshadowed the main story. It had brilliant characters, it was emotional in a realistic way and it genuinely makes you consider your choices.I didn’t like the gear system, but you unlock transmogs for everything you find, as well as “collection” ones that are a transmog without an item. Being able to keep appearances I like without it affecting stats is great.Combat was generally fun, following the Arkham-style of basic attacks, specials, and emphasis on countering but in a much more ranged form. Some of the spells felt like they lacked a reason to exist (Incendio vs Confringo, Levioso vs Wingardium Leviosa) but at the same time it gives you options in how you play without forcing you to use identical spells to everyone else.Cons:The entire gear system is a mess. From the start of the game you have a wildly limited capacity to hold things, and no immediate way to sell them. (You begin with 20 slots, 6 of which are taken by what you have equipped) If you choose to explore the castle early on you will be punished by this. It expands later but it feels like there’s only a cap for the sake of being irritating so that a side activity can reward you with less annoyance.Upgrading gear gives it such a tiny boost, by the end of the game, stats-wise, you have 8 things equipped instead of 6 if all 6 are upgraded to max. There’s a LOT of extra trait upgrades, 2/3 of which are completely useless because I’m never going to spend resources on a level 1 or 2 trait when it is exactly as easy to install the level 3 of the same trait. Most of the traits are also terrible, why would I invest in giving 1 specific spell a small damage boost when for the same cost I can buff every damaging spell I have? It’s also worth noting that upgrades require the Room of Requirement beast care, and for the max upgrade you basically don’t have access to the beast required until 1 or 2 main quests before the end of the entire game.There’s a lot of small points where options just haven’t been considered to be less annoying. Once you can add traits to gear, any non-legendary gear is pointless as they don’t allow level 3 traits, so a “sell all X quality” items button at stores would be nice rather than needing to sell everything one by one. Transmogs also have to be applied to every piece you equip, and as you get a piece with better stats about every 5 mins, that’s often. It would be great to be able to apply a transmog to a slot in general and not have to redo it every time. Alohomora can be levelled up to get through higher tier locks which are basically just progression blockers until mid-game. The mini-game for locks is dull as hell, never gets harder, never changes, never becomes interesting, but you’re forced to do it hundreds of times just because. An option like “I’ve done the same minigame 10 times, skip this from now on” would be great.Lastly, I don’t really know if I’d put this as a pro or a con, because it fits into both depending on the player. I personally felt there were just a few too many ‘nods’ to the Harry Potter series. Like yes, it’s the same universe, the same school, but at a point it’s like herbology is repotting Mandrakes, Care of Magical Creatures leads to Hippogriffs, Nearly Headless Nick is trying to join the Headless Hunt and has BASICALLY his entire dialogue from the second book, every character has a surname relating them directly to a Harry Potter character. Like who the hell is Professor Weasley? Why is she so type-casted as Molly Weasley when she HAS to be related to Arthur instead? At some point it feels like the writers really need to step out of the shadow and do more with the elements we haven’t seen. Focus on creatures that weren’t the main creature in the movies, just do something a bit different. In that respect it again pulls me toward the Sebastian Sallow story because he’s a completely unique character going through a situation that’s entirely unseen in the series.Overall, great game. A little short story-wise, but plenty of side content that still felt meaningful within the world.

author: AmberGrizz
review: At first I looked at the trailers and I'd like "nah, it's so-so. The combat must be repetitive" when in reality, NO.The combat system is quite enjoyable. You can be very creative with the combos to some enemy types.Let's talk about pros and cons.- Great visuals and details- Good combat design- Great puzzles- Map is huge- Worth replaying in another house- Can have your own - And can build your own "Room", that brew potions, grow mandrakes, etc.- Lots of side activities- The Wizarding World is very immersive - Very hardware demanding game (32GB of RAM is recommended)- Inconsistent framerates (I got 180-200fps in closed areas while 59-70 in Hogwarts castle with RTX3080Ti)- Side activities are repetitive (especially Merlin Trials)  other than that, they are okay- Our character facial reactions are inconsistent- Hogwarts Legacy is a great AAA game and should be the standard of all AAA games. This is the kind of game worth paying and playing. The price is not too expensive (Around 50$ for me). Unlike the other game, what's that called?  thing? Charging you 70$ for that poop. :D

author: MikeyMike211

author: ALinkToTh3Past
review: I have to admit, this game has been super fun. If I were to have any complaint about the game I could only point to one or two things. Number one being inventory space starting out is very small. I'd find myself in the middle of nowhere and I can't carry anything so I either have to destroy something or find somewhere to sell it. My 2nd thing would probably the way the spells are used.Having to constantly swap by holding over on the Dpad can be a bit of a pain while in battle or when you're trying to do a combo because you can only hold 4 spells per equip space. All in all, I'd give this game a solid 8/10 possibly 9/10 ( I haven't beaten it yet.) It has plenty of stuff to do, things to find and enemies to fight so you don't get bored super quickly. If you're a fan of Harry Potter this game is definitely worth the money imo.

author: Spork
review: On hard mode five hours in, level 9, and on my way to hogsmead I must say this is a very fun game. Easy to learn and engaging in everyway from the collectibles to the mystery surrounding the environment and story, I'd recommend it if it weren't for so much difficulty in managing my framerate. In less populous, tighter enclosed spaces my game can run on ultra RTX, vsnc off but theres an incredible amount of tearing and sudden drops in framerate. Even when I drop everything to low, RTX off with vsnc enabled, when I am outside I am still experiencing drops from 60 fps down to as little as 35 or even 20. Motion blur, chromatic abberation, etc all turned off as well - Im running off an NVIDIA 3070Ti, I don't think I should be having so many issues, though I do understand that it is only 2 days from full release. If any devs read this please give us an update on any upcoming patches!

author: TunaFTW
review: Don't usually do reviews but this one deserved one for sure....The game itself is absolutely incredible if sitting up at night reading the books was never not enough for you to get immersed then this basically is the closest thing we have ever got (so far) to literally running around how we pictured it in our heads.The detail is outstanding in every aspect from game-play to graphics. I am currently running a Ryzen 9 3900x, 1080ti and 32gbs ram. I average about 70-115 on ultra while running in 1440p so that should hopefully give you a little idea of how well optimised this game is. Main story missions when I may be in a more secluded area for the mission the game runs like butter especially dungeons and caves, cannot fault it Ive had ZERO crashes, or shutters as of writing this review, A game made and optimised properly that's for sure.I do not want to spoil anything as even 20 hours In I feel like I have done absolutely nothing progression wise as I get distracted by something new every time I go down a new hall way in the school it really is a very special game that will be played and talked about as one of the greatest games of all time.

author: ЯF™ | Europe
review: // général //Le jeu est très beau, la musique est exceptionnelle, les atmosphères sont donc réussies notamment avec toutes les références aux livres et aux films. Malgré tout, beaucoup de petits détails de conception viennent casser l'immersion et c'est dommage. C'est donc un bon jeu pour un fan du monde d'Harry Potter mais un moyen pour quelqu'un qui se concentre sur l'aspect RPG-immersif. // scénario//Par contre, le jeu s'essoufle vite sur un scénario qui peut se montrer ennuyant, soit sur les quêtes annexes soit sur la fin du jeu. Les dialogues sont sympathiques mais sans plus, les choix n'impactent pas le jeu du tout et c'est dommage. // gameplay //Le gameplay est réussi. Le niveau de difficulté n'impacte malheureusement que les combats. Par contre, les combats sont très réussi, ils sont dynamiques et intéressants avec la combinaison de sorts. // personnage //Egalement, la personnalisation du personnage laisse à désirer, entre les tenues, les choix de voix binaires qui se trouvent toutes être un peu robotique (et ça casse l'immertion).

author: Mikey
review: Played the game for 2 hours and in all honesty had to refund it after that. The game felt mediocre at best. First of all there was the awful optimisation. I run a beyond decent rig, 2080 GTX and an i7. Despite of this, my fps reached 30 at most and 5 at worst (mostly at the start of every cutscene, which were a LOT in the first 2 hours, it was like watching a damn movie?. I also was not allowed to take my own name because apparently it contained profanity. (Also, weirdly enough, the game does not support full screen? We looked online but did not find a fix, best option we got was windowed fullscreen, tanking down the performance even further...)After that, the game dragged on for a while and we started to notice the horrible voice acting in your main character and most of the students. monotone and very uninterested. Second to that, the weirdest thing of all was that you could notice the pitch change in your own voice. Say if I were to pick a low pitched voice, you could actually HEAR the bass effect IN-GAME on your own voice, as if you were speaking through a voice changer app...After tanking through 2 hours of gameplay and 25 fps average, the game world still felt a bit stale to what i had expected. It felt empty and meaningless, like I was not a real part of it. Rather a scripted cardboard castle. The game then decided it was time to bug out ALL the trees outside of the castle, to which they all pretty much buggingly exploded and leaves were penetrating the inside walls. As soon as I actually had to step outside my FPS dropped to 10. As funny as it was to see I ultimately decided this was definitely not worth the 60 bucks. I'd wait for the price to drop or for the first month of hotfixing, after that it'll probably be a very nice game.

author: Ralathar44
review: As of roughly 6.5 in this game is basically a high quality love letter to the IP.  The feel and atmosphere is fantastic, the amount of detail is and care is jaw dropping, the visuals are quite good, and its a good game that rewards exploration too.  Even the combat, the weakest part, is still not bad and is getting better as they add more to it.  Its also very inclusive with a wide range of races, a good mix of male/female roles done well, and even a trans bartender who's treated with respect both in terms of personhood and in terms of them being formidable.The people trying to cancel this game and attacking other people for playing it couldn't have chosen a worse game to pull that nonsense on.  Trying to cancel high quality inclusive Harry Potter IP in the name of protecting inclusiveness is the epitome of self sabotage lol.

author: SchwiftyD
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a game that exceeded my expectations in every way possible. From the moment I stepped into the magical world of Hogwarts, I was transported to a place that was both familiar and new. The attention to detail in this game is absolutely remarkable, and it's clear that the developers have a deep love and appreciation for the Harry Potter universe.The gameplay is top-notch, with a mixture of action and RPG elements that will keep you engaged for hours. The spells are intuitive and fun to cast, and the creatures you encounter are beautifully rendered and terrifying in equal measure. The choice-based narrative is another standout feature, allowing you to shape your own story and determine the outcome of the game.The music and sound design are also excellent, with themes and sound effects that will immerse you in the world and leave you with memories that will last a lifetime. The voice acting is also superb, bringing the characters to life in a way that feels authentic and true to the source material.Overall, I would highly recommend Hogwarts Legacy to anyone who is a fan of the Harry Potter universe or just looking for a fantastic gaming experience. This game is a true masterpiece, and I can't wait to see what the future holds for the franchise.

review: I'm really enjoying the game so far. The art style, lore, music, and overall experience is fantastic. There are some major performance and bug issues in the game, but it doesn't hinder the overall enjoyment of the game too much.8/10EditJust finished the game.Changed review score to 7/10.The game is extremely linear and repetitive. Your "choices" if you even want to call them that don't matter. Your house doesn't matter. Game is an endless run and fetch cycle with brief moments of fighting. Playing on "hard" I was one or two shoting all enemies without much of a problem. I still find the game enjoyable and a definite must buy for any Harry Potter fan, but I will say the magic runs out quick.

author: Candy
review: its great, 8/10. cons:-some pictures repeat in the same areas/corridors-you can't deviate to far from quest objectives-the camera feels like a dark souls port. -combat with standard keyboard and mouse is a joke, pick up a controller or rebind keys-combat is 90% dark souls roll-once you get used to combat the fighting is super easy regardless of difficulty-stealth is way too op, needs balancingpros:-the story was great and well done-the collectibles are a useful learning tool and not totally irrelevant -once you get used to combat the fighting is super easy regardless of difficulty-the gear customization is nice to not look like a fool, unless you like that-exploring the world has been and still is fun-if you're not in a quest, its skyrim or shadow of war/mordor 100%-the character's backgrounds were great and well donei recommend if you want hp skyrim, shadow of war/mordor, open world fun. or if you like the series.

author: LT. CMDR Storm
review: If you're into learning more about the Wizarding world or you just want to see what the world was like  120 years before the books or if you're a muggle want to act out your fantasies of being a magic folk. Then play this video game. I myself am 14 hours in at the time of this review and I am loving the world, the lore, the characters that I get to meet along the way. My favorite parts of the game, without giving anything away, is the worldscape, it is breath taking. My other favorite part is the puzzles. The door puzzle took me a while to solve them on my own and without looking them up.

author: VulgarMonkey
review: This doesn't deserve a negative review, but I am surprised that the more critically-inclined of you haven't at least knocked this down a peg.Firstly, this is presumably a dream game for any Harry Potter fan. Notably it's not in the era of the books/movies, but everything outside of the familiar characters are present. Classes, Broom Flying, Beasts, Spells, Plants, The Room of Requirement, Hogsmeade, etc etc. There hasn't been a game so epicly recreating the Harry Potter universe that I'm surprised this wasn't done sooner.But to be frank; I think the Harry Potter IP carries the living F out of this game. At some point I had to acknowledge that I wasn't having that much fun. The RPG elements are too shallow. There's no significant ability customization. There's no moral alignment/consequences for clearly evil actions/spell use. The pacing is wildly off (receiving gear with Trait slots long before I unlocked the ability to fill them, as well as being wildly over-levelled for the main story by only doing side quests as they presented themselves). There's the typical 'Ubisoft' style open-world fetch/errand quest (which seemingly has gotten a pass so I'd like everyone to remind themselves when the next Assassin's Creed comes around to lay off the regurgitated criticisms please).Like I said, these things are ignored across the board because it's Harry Potter - and a game like this has been well overdue. But when you pull away the outer layer you're left with a game that, by strict comparison, is without much substance. This is by no means a bad game, but it's not a great game. Calling it GOTY material is insanity. If this was a brand new IP, or even an existing IP from a hypocritically slammed franchise (see: Assassin's Creed), this would not be as favourable with it's audience.As someone who notoriously doesn't like Harry Potter, but will put interest into any game made with such clear passion, I've gotten so far into it before realising I'm just not actually enjoying it that much.Harry Potter fans will absolutely love it though - that pre-existing fandom will carry this over the line. Without it though, I'm falling short.

author: 90SGUY
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a dream come true for many Harry Potter fans. The game is set in the magical world of Hogwarts and the developers have done an amazing job in bringing the beloved world to life. The attention to detail in everything from the setting, to the puzzles, to the combat and gear, to the clothing, is truly remarkable. The passion behind creating this dream and giving it life is palpable and it shows in every aspect of the game.One of the highlights of Hogwarts Legacy is the level of detail in the environment. Walking the halls of Hogwarts, exploring the castle and its grounds, and interacting with the world and its characters feels like you're truly a part of the magic. The puzzles are challenging and rewarding, and the combat and gear system adds an exciting new dimension to the game. The clothing options also allow players to fully immerse themselves in the world and express their own personal style.I hope that the developers continue to add new content to the game in the form of updates and possibly even sequels. The potential for new adventures, characters, and experiences is truly endless. Overall, Hogwarts Legacy is a fantastic and immersive game that is sure to leave a lasting impact on fans of the Harry Potter series.

author: Robbie
review: Highly recommended for anyone who is a fan of the world of magic and for anyone in general who loves open world RPG games because this is an absolute banger!Combat is incredible and intuitive with numerous different spells to mix up your combos.You can go to classes and the game is packed with cutscenes that are enjoyable to watch.You're free to roam around in the open world and experience it as you see fit.Tons of puzzles and challenges for you to conquer with your wit.Dungeons for those who are interested in exploration.Music is banging and gives you a real feel for Hogwarts.You can fly on your broom or gryffon whichever you prefer and do little races for upgrades.Your gear has a rarity system making you want to find better loot with some offering buffs.Character customisation is good and lets you pick from numerous faces and styles.Honestly, just get the game even If you're not a fan of Harry Potter because If you're a fan of RPGs then you'll love it.

author: JaBuLs
review: Well, this game is incredible. I was hoping it would be a solid game but holy crap, it completely blew all of my expectations away. First off, the world itself is amazing! Filled with tons of little details everywhere you look, from a random pot floating around watering plants to enchanted brooms sweeping floors. Everything feels like it's magical in some way. Graphically the game is quite impressive in both art design and technical prowess. Everything is detailed, vibrant, and it runs buttery smooth AND there's super ultrawide support!!! The combat take a bit to get used to but once it clicks, man, its a blast...literally. There's a solid variety of spells you can master and some can easily be missed depending on what quests you take or skip. The gear system is solid but nothing too incredible. You have your basic stat improvements and as you get further you can enhance your gear with various effects. The best thing about the gear system is the transmog system. You can make any gear piece look like any other gear piece you've ever acquired for that slot. There's wand and broom customization, you can also greatly customize your room of requirement and the beast room that is attached. There's so much to do and see in this game, even though I take my time with everything I always feel like I might be missing something. Also, none of the side quests really feel like the generic cookie cutter kind. Maybe I'm biased since I grew up with this series as the books were releasing, idk. Altogether, fantastic game made even better if you're already a fan of the IP. Highly recommend buying this one and since it's in such good shape, no need to even wait for patches for once.

author: Dikinbaus
review: Amazing that a major developer is finally able to release a fantastic game that is not a pile of turd. Insane amounts of fun, good game mechanics and lots to do. Thank you Portkey/Avalanche.

author: imb58
review: I got the same feeling I had when when first playing Skyrim or the original Tomb Raiders reboot .  You know you have a winner.    Its the most enjoyable game I have purchased in years. Money well spent.

author: Husky
review: This game is amazing. Would definitely recommend to anyone who is into the Harry Potter universe.I cannot really comment too much on the story as I'm taking my time completing it all but so far it's pretty good.Pros - The combat is really entertaining, fast past. It's easy to learn but hard to master - Good balance in the puzzles, not too hard but the solution isn't immediately obvious - I love being able to explore Hogwarts, Hogsmeade and the surrounding area on foot, a broom or a mount. The freedom is amazing - The room or requirement being your own little place is amazing, love being able to catch beasts that you can look after and even breed to get ingredients - The ability to add traits to your clothing and the ability to upgrade them adds another level of customisation which is really fun to explore - Love being able to figure out how to counter each enemy you come across and totally destroy them. The arenas are an amazing place to test your skills, especially on hard where you have to know spell combos and know how to counter each enemy while dodging and blocking attacks. I have not have this much fun in a long time in a single player gameCons - One of the biggest things that ruin the combat for me is this bug where I dash around quite a bit and I suddenly randomly lock onto a particular target that I have no way of unlocking and so my character is stuck facing a particular direction. Ruined multiple arena runs because of this. Only happened on hard diff when I'm trying to do challenge runs and I dash a lot - You are unable to use spells to interact with random characters, spells only work on enemies or beasts (kind of). This isn't a deal breaker, it just would be fun if you could interact with the other characters in the environment - No Quidditch. Kind of sad that they didn't add this buuuut they did add broom trials which is fun for now - I don't know much about how the castle looked around this time and this isn't something major but I will mention it. The moving staircase looks so much different compared to the movies, more spiral in nature and some of the floors don't have any rooms - Sad that you cannot have a dragon as a pet. I was so happy at one point until I realised you cannot keep a dragon. It would be even better if you can ride one - I feel like the trait system and the whole customisation of spells could have been done better. For instance maybe a path (if you want to have a spell be more about aoe or single target damage etc.) to add different playstyles. Right now most of them are just aoe versions and it seems like eventually you would just unlock most of them by the end of the game

author: SudoSamurai
review: It's been a long time since I played a game that felt like so much love and care and attention to detail went into it. This game is a love-letter to the wizarding world. It's addictive and fun. Combat is fun and has progressive depth. Puzzles are a great use of magic. Story isn't resting on the laurels of any previous entries or characters and is intriguing with real tension, stakes, and danger. THE MUSIC and ATMOSPHERE are incredible. One of the best games I've ever played. 9/10Points taken for some rough looks on facial expressions or animations, some clipping and a few bugs, but mostly because no Quidditch/broom controls need work. I'm assuming they couldn't fit Quidditch in within their schedule and hopefully it comes in an expansion or sequel.

author: MikBug458
review: The desire of the developers to lovingly craft an interactive version of a setting so many people fell in love with is obvious from the get-go. The game isn't perfect, and does rely on some open-world tropes similar to those found in Arkham games and other such titles, and the enemy types start to feel same-y after a while, but despite this the combat system is enjoyable and deep so these never become points of frustration.The characters were crafted with care for the setting and the world is filled with so many interesting things to discover. The game also confronts some of the more problematic elements it inherited from the books. The mistreatment of house elves is painted in no uncertain terms to be barbaric and cruel, and while a main antagonist is leading a goblin rebellion, there are other goblin characters that can be befriended, and the main character can express sympathy for the mistreatment of goblins by wizard-kind while it is shown that most goblins denounce the terrorist tactics of Ranrok (Goblin antagonist).If you aren't a fan of HP, then once the world opens up a bit into the game you'll have a lot more fun, but for HP fans, the first section that keeps you in Hogwarts is incredible in how alive the entire place feels.Even if you don't want to buy the game and decide to sail the seas instead, play the game, it's worth it.

author: Sheepii
review: I've played through the game, and beat it. I do love the hogwarts universe, and with that, I would give it an 8. But, taking out the bias entirely, I give it a 6/10. Lots to be improved, but I think we're in the right place to improve it. Pros:+ Good Combat+ Beautiful Game+ Seemless UI+ Has good cutscenes+ Story is engaging, and huge+ Has little to no loading time+ Fast travel takes out the unnecessary 'drown in travel' ideologyCon:- Some aspects seem too simple (Talents, leveling, gear system, minigames)- Arbitrary fetch quests to improve your stuff- The plot and protagonist's motives can be confusing to follow at times- Enemies are placed in places for no good reason- No quidditch (or multiplayer)- The characters are either dramatic or overtly joyful*Good Combat*Combat can be tricky to master for most games, as most RPGs are typically just, attack roll (and the harder games like Elden Scrolls are just attack roll better). HL adds a level of complexity that is unique to combat, not by drowning the process, but by adding just enough to make you think a little more. *Beautiful Game*I think this goes without saying. It's a lifesize scale of hogwarts. They did it justice. It did take out key things from the game, ie the changing staircases, the willow, but overall, it did match the expectations of everything, and the makeup of the castle made sense. *Seemless UI*There are some things that I find quirky about the AI, specifically the spell picker, and getting on a broom (pls make a hotkey for this), but the overall concept is intuitive, and easy to follow. *Has good cutscenes*They exasperated expenses into creating some of the coolest scenes I've seen. *Story is engaging and huge*The story has an interesting way of making the main plot (no spoilers) feel much bigger than it is. It leaves you constantly chasing answers, which makes the fluidity of the content much more enjoyable. Some of it though, can get a bit repetitive. *Has little to no loading time*Interesting concept of making doors loading screens. Never seen that before. *Fast travel takes out the unnecessary 'drown in travel' ideology*Listen, you know who you are game developers. Stop making half the content walking around the damn map. It's one thing to pace out a little bit for scenic purposes, but some of these damn developers take it to the next level of stupid that it rips the fun right out of the experience. It's lazy story development, by adding unnecessary buffer time, simply because you can't make enough content. Alright, rant over. This game does a perfect job of demonstrating the different ways of travel, so much that it may even be excessive. No one should really be complaining that travel is a problem in this game, when you can fast travel from anywhere on the map, to near precise points of interest. On top of that, you can walk, fly broom/mounts. Hell, for some quests, they'll just straight up teleport you to where you need to be, or open up portals to your destination. Big thumbs up. **Cons***Some aspects seem to simple*The minigames are a joke. There's no skill curve to them, they exist purely to be a minor inconvenience. I'd like to see more thought provoking mini-games, but that's a lot easier said than done. The talents feel pointless, I spend more time in there thinking about what I want to waste my talent points on, because outside a select few talents, I dare say most of them are useless, and provide less of a reason to upgrade. Quality of life upgrades are where you should improve the experience for players, without giving them an actual advantage. With talents, what you could do is instead of these arbitrary, 'U dO mOrE dAmAgE', you could have something like, 'You can fly out of combat', or  'You gain momentum on a broom by going down' or even 'you get to kill the clown that keeps annoying the piss out of you in the cast-' nvm. Regardless, I feel we can do better in this department. Leveling, oh boy. You do one side quest, and you're basically outscaling the main quest line. You should scale your quests better. The gear system is horrendous. I don't know who thought it was a good idea to add spider protection onto a cloak, but they should feel bad. There are such niche purpose to having certain things, that it gets unneedlessly overshadowed by the more obvious, 'just do more damage hurr durr' aspects of the gearing system. Maybe aspects outside of defense and offense can be introduced, like 'you make 5% extra gold on sales, because ur a trader harry. IMAWOT', or some ♥♥♥♥ like that. But, I guess that brings me to my last point. What is the point in all the cosmetics, with zero ease of life upgrades. Sure, you can upgrade your broom (thank god for that), but cmon. Everything seems so baseline, that even the spells blend together and have no real significance outside the utility that some provide. *Arbitrary fetch quests to improve your stuff*Look, I get it. Every RPG in existence will have fetch quests. But, every single one? To gain any spell, you need to perform some tedious task of gathering enough money to buy something, to use it once, then never use it again. It never reflects on the story, they just say, "alright, well I guess you know the spell now" without any rhyme or reason as to how that happened, or plot development. Either the main character is by far the most powerful wizard ever, as I can master spells in one day, or there's something seriously wrong with the reflection of character progression. I'm going with the latter. *The plot and protagonist's motives can be confusing to follow at times*This can be a positive and negative. I don't really know what I'm doing, or why I'm doing it seems like a common theme in the story. Which, if that's what you're going for, you've done a stellar job. The storyline will often switch wildly, simply because they're trying to touch on the many aspects of the universe, which can heavily diversify the plot, and (honestly) lazily linking them together in some ambiguous fashion. The biggest issue I've found with the story is that it doesn't really feel like it's your story. It feels like you're apart of other people's stories, and you are the side character. I feel at times through the story progression that I'm just riding the wave, going down a tunnel, or exploring some tomb because well... I'm following some other dumbass that's doing it. It puts a damper on the significance of the main character, which by design is suppose to be the most significant. At highlighted points of exposition, it's goes on about how the humans and goblins are working together, only to counter that point in the next scene.*Enemies are placed in places for no good reason*Throughout the map there are enemies basically sprinkled about. There might be camps that exist, but they don't really make sense as to why they would be there. The dialog in some of these places are atrocious, but I get it, you're not going to have 1000 unique voice lines from your enemies... unless??? nah jk.. lol.... unless?? What if you just did it, you know? Just like actually put effort into making enemies, so the unique experience of dialog isn't just 'hey come out here, I know you're hiding', maybe it wouldn't feel so unimmersive. *No quidditch (or multiplayer)*Self explanatory

author: Arkey
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a magical experience that transports you to the world of Harry Potter.The attention to detail in the game is phenomenal, from the spell-casting mechanics to the authentic representation of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. The open-world exploration is breathtaking, filled with secrets to uncover and memorable characters to meet. The story is engaging and filled with choices that truly affect the outcome.In terms of performance, I haven't had any problems so far, I play on Ultra in 2k, but without raytracing and with DLSS enabled!My system has the following specs:Overall, I highly recommend this game to any Harry Potter fan or anyone looking for a captivating RPG adventure.

author: Raven™
review: PSA: Playing this AMAZING game does not make you a transphobe, contrary to popular belief. It's a game, not a political statement, dummies. Stay mad and if you think otherwise, please get your head checked because I'm starting to think its a mental illness.Also, going around spreading spoilers on social media... Maturity Level 100.Anyway, onto the review itself...The game is incredible. Literally a Potterheads dream come true. If you have the slightest interest in Harry Potter, please pick it up. Although it has nothing to do with the established canon, and I dare say, it works pretty well in its favor, its simply a must play. The combat is rock solid, exploring is rewarding. Characters are somewhat bland and you might be irked by the fact that there is seemingly no morality system but don't let that stop you from playing, please.The performance, in my 27 hours of playtime, has been mostly okay. I got a beefy rig but I still had a few drops here and there. I assume with a patch and some general optimization, it'll be amazing.Yer a lizard, 'Arry

author: Pointless.
review: NO SPOLERS!THIS IS A REVIEW FOR PEOPLE WITH POTATO PCS! Ryzen 5 4600 processorgtx165016gbssd minimum settings still beautiful you will get around a steady 60-75 fps. you could play around with settings to get a better quality but i did not.Now the review itself after around 40 hours this game is amazing. the last game i played that had SO MUCH to do was probably skyrim. there is tons of stuff. whoever has 30 or 40 hours and says yea it was great did basically nothing except main quests. TOTALLY worth every cent. That is as much as i can say without actually spoiling anything. have fun!

author: RavenShin
review: already played this game for almost 10 hours and honestly it's all i could've asked for from a harry potter game.there, within the first few missions, already is characters that are part of the LGBT+ community. including a trans woman who is voiced by a trans female voice actress and that is an amazing step for the wizarding world. all characters i have met so far have been amazing and not a single one forgettable. some characters also have links to characters we already know and love that aren't so obvious.game-play wise this game has not missed a beat. the controls have been so smooth and the spell casting has been done in a really interesting way that makes it simple yet engaging throughout.loading times between rooms are barely noticeable. if i hadn't seen the small loading symbol i would've thought there was nothing there with how seamless it is.and of course you get to pet all the cats!!!overall an amazing game and excited to continue and see what else this world has to offer!

author: Addicted
review: Awesome!!!!!I’m still at the beginning and only made a few quests of the main story but after almost 16 hours I have to say that this game is one of the best Singleplayer games I’ve ever played.The quests are surprisingly varied and the story behind them is understandable. The Map has a good size and Hogwarts seems to be really huge. All in all it makes a lot fun to discover every corner. Even if you’re not a Harry Potter Nerd like me.There are some thing which are repetitive but that’s normal for this type of games.The fighting system is quite intuitiv. I play difficult hard and it’s competitive in some moments so you doesn’t have any dark souls moments ;)Im very surprised by the „housing“ system! It’s very detailed and gives u some kind of survival and building a home feeling.I have a rtx 3060 and an i8770k and having some framedrops but nothing worse.9/10 for now

Controls are okay for mouse and keyboard too.It is light crpg , full of action, quests and things to do, you won't be bored with it.If You are still waiting go grab this game, it's really magical, story is nice, and subquests are fine.Im playing since Amiga 500 times, and saw many good games, this one is one of them.I hope for future, long story driven dlcs like the ones for Witcher 3.It's must have if you are crpg fan, to make a break from some of the more serious roleplaying games.It plays well on AMD Ryzen 5800x, 3070rtx and 32gb ram plus ssd. From me it's strong 9/10. Game is amazing, if You are Potter universe fan, you must play it.Worth of Your precious time for sure.

author: Vaskito
review: For a general audience, this is a pretty solid game, with well known RPG elements.For Harry Potter fans, this is 20 year old dream coming true. It's story is captivating, the soundtrack is familiar and new at the same time and on the same level as the original John Williams scores. The game has a lot of canonical details put into it which will warm the hearts of Potterheads. It's a visually stunning game which gives justice to what we've seen in the movies, with great magic and transition effects. Combat is fun and engaging. If you're a Harry  Potter fan, and if you enjoy games with RPS elements, I high reccomend this game. The PC version has some FPS issues, which will surely be fixed with the upcoming patches and optimized drivers.Easily a 9/10 game

author: Tobias
review: So far very good game, the devs really put a lot of love into it!A lot of fun things to discover, extremely immersive and lots of unlocks!The game does require a heavy rig, I have a rtx 2060, amd ryzen 7 5800x and 16gb of ram.It seems that the game is using most of my ram, and also putting my cpu to the test. My cpu is however bottlenecked by my gpu, so technically it is putting my gpu to the test.My cpu ran at 76%, ram at 85% and gpu at 44% :)Game is still highly playable for me, and I get constant 60+ fps at 1440p, however I've experienced a bit of lag in duels.Even with the minor lag I've experienced, I would 100% recommend the game!About 4 hours in, and the experience has been amazing so far:)

author: User
review: No game in recent years is considered so controversial as Hogwarts Legacy. I will not write about it, you can find enough on the Internet.I honestly see this game as what it is: entertainment.The Game itself is the first strong candidate for the Game of the Year Award 2023.It has a well written and told Main Story and a lot of great Side Quests wich sometimes reach the Quality of some Witcher 3 Sidequest, the World invites you to explore and most of the Characters are memorable. It combines many well working mechanics and succeds to capture the magic of the Harry Potter Universe.It's also quite inviting you if you don't know the books. I personally only knew the movies and had no problems following the peculiarities of the wizarding world.The Graphics are stunning and full of small Details and some rare yet stunning effects and mechanics (you will like it if you know how such programming mechanics work). If your Computer can handle them. The System Requirements are definitly not a joke and if you don't stick to them you won't have a good time. So know your Hardware and their counterparts. If a single part not matches the given requirements -> turn down to the next lower recommendet settings. If you have up to date current gen Hardware its the most beautifull game to date with great Performance. My 4080 is capable maxing out the game and provides high frame rates mostly far beyond 100fps in UWQHD and around 90-120fps in UHD. Including Raytracing and HDR for the extra eye candy without stuttering, lags or other disturbing factors. Solid 10/10 from me Thats how a game should look like in 2023. The Soundtrack is highly inspired by the Movie Soundtracks and fits every Moment and every Scene. The only thing that bothers me is that you can't use different languaged subtitles. The German voice actings in video games are mostly bad, Hogwarts legacy isn't a  exception. The English Voice Acting is great with some nice Details in the different used accents.The Combat System is refreshing different and thankfully at least for me highly intuitive. It's not overcomplicated and not oversimplified. At least for me (definitly not a die hard Harry Potter Fan) the game lives up the hype. As far as i see everything wich was promised is there.Get it if you like such games (and if your PC can handle it)Even the price is fair since there is possibly a high replay value because ever House has a sligtlhy differnet Story Progression and different House Quests as well.

author: lörd farkwa ‡
review: Amazing. So well done. This will easily be a 200+ hour game (playing time, not inflated steam time). I'll give an honest review from a ~500 steam game "game jumper" and someone who thinks Harry potter is fun, but not really a potterhead.First off, it looks beautiful. The trailers looked odd? I guess is the best word. I was worried it would look rough. No, it's absolutely a beautiful game. However, I am using a 3090. My cousin (2070) has had issues. The castle is gorgeous. There are so many small details.The environment is huge and there is a lot to do. I was also worried that a lot of the gameplay would be in the castle. The beginning is pretty castle-inside-only, but you do move outdoors and then spend most of the main game out of the castle. The castle IS gigantic but there is a huge world outside, too. I am 15 hrs in and have only explored like 1/5th of the map.The player "housing" and beast keeping is cool. It's not too too in-depth, but it is useful. I spent a little time decorating my room and placing furniture. I have been capturing some cool animals so I can farm them for fur. I also have a nice plant growing operation for potion making.Combat is the perfect balance. It's dark souls-ish in the sense that you absolutely NEED to dodge and block attacks or you will die. But you don't spend 4 hours fighting 1 mob only to die by rolling off of a cliff. Potions are important, especially for boss fights.I had someone complain to me that there are only like 20 spells and that is too few. I disagree. The way combat is and the action bars are, having more spells would make the game unplayable. You can focus your talent points and items to use specific spells too.The story and atmosphere are amazing. Going to class is fun. Going to town is fun. Talking to people is fun. I am an impatient gamer and I usually skip cutscenes and blow through dialogue. Not here. I watch everything and listen to everything. I feel invested in what is happening, like I am watching a movie.Not many downsides. If I had 1 complaint it would be flying. The broom handles like a clunky mobile game. You dont hold W to go forward, you press shift to either stop or stay moving forward. It feels off. I am constantly crashing into stuff and flying into walls when I mean to stop because I'm holding "S" instead of tapping shift to stop. Some puzzles are repetitive and I get bored doing them for the 47th time, but it's not the end of the world.Ive only ran into 1 bug so far, and my brother had the same exact bug elsewhere in the world. I was running behind the great hall when suddenly I fell through the ground and died. I panicked as I hadn't saved in hours. But luckily somehow the game knew and autosaved as I fell (same happened to my brother). When i loaded in I was in the same spot but didn't fall through the ground. Overall this game is amazing. Buy it. You will not regret it. I promise you.

author: Darth_Roxx
review: I'd rate this game a 6/10. They have done a good job of envisioning and bringing a Harry Potter world to life. It's nice to look at and explore. However, after a while, it tends to become very repetitive and boring. :/ I was enjoying the story at first then that also became boring. Most of the exploration/open world activities get repetitive after a while. Do a merlin quest. Grab some beast. Get some chest. Kill the same bad guys. None of the characters are memorable. I kind of like Sebastián and Ominis, but even they didn't get developed too much. I like the tidbits of knowledge you get about the house founders as you play through some quests, but other than that, I don't feel like anything I did had any real meaning. It didn't change the storyline that much. I struggled to finish the game because I was just really bored. Still, I do think it's a decent game, and you may be better off doing the side quests and main quests only and don't do a lot of exploration as you will get burnt out by how repetitive it is. I think I'll play it again once there are maybe more updates and more mods to make the game more interesting. Right now, it's akin to a wide ocean that is not very deep at all. You have so many things to do, yet they are all repetitive and get tiring after a while. I really wanted to like it a lot more. There are way better open world games, so I think that's why as well I feel this one just missed the mark a bit. If you're a super Harry Potter fan, you may look past it. I'm a fan but not big enough to look past how boring the game became. Also, it is poorly optimized. Even with a 3090 and some settings tweaked, this thing drops fps lower 30 sometimes which sucks a lot.

author: blatoa
review: Brilliant game! Best single player game i've played in a long time

review: Game has bad optimization.

author: Moon
review: Im not a fan of Harry Potter but this game is pretty fun but its anemic in some rpg elements. Pros:- Great world design and environments, especially the 2 main "hub" areas.- Combat is fun- Immersive world Cons:- Horrible performance issues, I have a good rig and it runs quite bad sometimes- Voice acting feels "fake british"- The Open world is kind of boring and not that interesting- Skillpoint limitation: there isnt enough skills in the game for you to limit them Mr Devs its not like ill go oh noooo i should do a second playthrough with skills XY instead of AB- Awful sequence breaks and quest bugs which hold you prisoner who cant progress unless u know some workaround - and even that wont work sometimesI will recommend when its fixed.

author: Jimmy Chonga
review: I pre-ordered the deluxe edition of this game. I waited months to play it. I wanted this game to succeed.Out of the 18 hours of playtime logged at the time of this review, I have had maybe 3 total hours of actual gameplay. The stuttering and crashing have made this game unplayable. I've spent more time tweeking settings and updating drivers than I have actually in game.I'm extremely disappointed and aggravated because from what I can see, the game looks fun. Had I known that almost a month after launch I still wouldn't be able to play it, I never would have bought the thing. I feel like I've thrown my money away and this will probably be the last time I pre-order a game or maybe even pay for one at all.

author: GabbySky
review: lore wise and attention to detail - the game is great. Very good adaptation.wont recommend this purchase until they fix the crashing issues, setting setting to lowest makes it crash alot less often... .

author: Zachary3D
review: Best game I've played in probably a decade,and I'm not even a die hard HP fan.9.8/10

author: Charybdis
review: Right now i'd say the game is a solid 9/10, simply because the fps drops make some fights close to impossible to win for meonce they fix that the game is pretty damn close to perfect(playing on hard, 2-3 hits and i'm down, fps drop makes it so i can't see anything for a few seconds....)

author: Kaiser_Tomas
review: I have to give credit where due, the artwork is astonishing. Truly a beautiful recreation of Hogwarts, the art team should be damned proud of themselves.Unfortunately that's about all the game has to offer, as other than being beautiful, it is extremely boring. -  "Go to some cave which looks and feels just like the last one, fight a bunch of guys, earn some uninteresting dialogue". No quest tries to do something different or introduce a new special mechanic. By the end i was just trying to complete everything as fast as i could cause i wanted to finish it and stop playing. -  It almost seems like it would be a smart combat that forces you to adapt to your enemies, but there is almost nothing like that. True some enemies have certain weaknesses, however they are quite hard to exploit since you have a small window to cast a particular spell, on top of that, these exploitations are generally not worth the trouble so you`ll end up just spaming whichever spell cools off first. And the game never forced me to change this with tough combat, this brainless method got me through to the end.- Along with my last point, comes the fact that there is  the game will try to tell you that there are X different types of goblins, XX different types of mages, and XX different types of animals or beasts, but in the end they all play out the same. There is no noteworthy difference between a goblin soldier and a goblin assassin other than some may have a shield which requires a certain type of spell (out of 3) to deactivate. Honestly more of a chore than an engaging combat mechanic. -  with no real risks or twists, quite the opposite of the original harry potter storylines. The main quest is also filled with plot holes, for example, the ministry saying there is no goblin threat and refusing to send help, all the mean time EVERY hamlet around Hogwarts is being harassed by violent goblins who will not doubt to try and kill children.-  I only found Sebastian's quest to be interesting since it had a gray morality, completing it resulted in progression by allowing to learn Dark spells and flush out characters. - Other than sebastian, the other  that it makes them boring. It makes them uninteresting and quite simply unhuman. No one is that good a person.- For a game that considers itself an RPG, the  No decision you make changes the game, and there is not much decision to make either way. When choosing dialogue options your choices are "Be the nicest person ever", "Agree without being so nice". There are no real friendships to make since choices don`t matter. "You don`t wanna be Natty`s friend? We don`t care, we are choosing for you and she will be your best friend" "You don`t like a certain character`s attitude and would like to be an ass to him? well sorry, can`t do that. Everyone is your friend". Hell within Hogwarts you can`t even have an enemy/rival as Malfoy was to Harry. Everyone is either your best friend, or the super boring bad guy who is just bad for the sake of being bad.- I understand the devs deciding this wouldn`t be a Hogwarts experience so I`m not gonna ask that of them. HOWEVER, this is a Hogwarts game and  Let me give you some examples. Classes only occur within the first hour of the game as simple 5 minute cutscenes. Certain missions in the game imply students can`t be up at night so you have to sneak, yet when free roaming if the day night cycle runs its course and nightime begins, you can just run around Hogwarts and no one will stop you. What makes the Forbidden forest the forbidden forest? Well i guess just the name cause other than that it is just like every other area of the open world. There are no house points, and no real impact on the house you choose. As another example, you can learn the unforgivable dark arts curses, yet you can use avada kadavra while fighting alongside a professor or classmate and they not bat an eye. These may seem like little things, but its all these little things that simply break the immersion and in my eyes are the biggest issue of this game.-  especially in scenes where the character is supposed to be shouting (its almost like when its 2 am in your house, and you wanna act like you are shouting but do it at a low volume since everyone is asleep). On top of that, you`ll get tired (and quite frankly pissed) by all the repeated one liners some characters will make throughout the game. For example each time you go past a fast travel spot (including after having just fast traveled), the foo flame statue will say one of 3 lines. This is EVERY TIME YOU FAST TRAVEL OR RUN PAST IT. As you can guess, thats a lot of time it says it. Same thing happens every time your character goes to Hoggsmeade (the main town), he'll say one of 2 lines. At this point this has become a meme.-  in the end most spells are the same. Damage or lift your enemy. The only exceptions to this are one that freezes, one that transforms enemies, and the 3 dark arts spells. All the rest do pretty much the same.-  Around mid game, the game tries to show you that you can use animal resources to improve your gear. However, each time you enter a cave, you'll find at least 10 chests which will certainly hold better gear than the one you are wearing. In the end this upgrading mechanic feels simply useless. You`ll always find better gear out there. Not that it makes much of a difference either way as the bonuses and effects of gear are practically non existent. I swear i played with a 80 offense cloak and accidentally equipped my first lvl 0 cloak and didn`t even notice until i opened the gear menu again 3 hours later.-  The game is one very long game. I honestly don`t tend to complain about the length of games and i do try to be as completionist as i can. However, this game offers a large numer of puzzles that are more of a chore than something fun to do. You can go through the world picking up flying pages, picking up stationary pages, picking up ancient magi balls which offer no challenge, do merling trials which are basically all the same yet the devs decided to put  (I`m not exagerating it is really 95 of them) in the game, etc. All these open world mechanics are just boring and have no real reward or sense of completion- This might be a personal nit pick but  and flying with the broom is SOO slow compared to what we are used to from the harry potter movies. Still a pity there was no quidich, but i guess they just ran out of time.Honestly i`m pretty shocked this game had such great reviews, i mean 93% on steam is nothing short of amazing. But i simply can`t understand it. Is it just me that finds all these problems? Or were we simply so desperate for a Harry Potter game that we were willing to look by all these issues?This is the first time I give a negative review, so i hope this helps for something. And if you do buy it, I do hope you enjoy it.

author: SE4N0
review: Fun at first ... but its basically just another open world game, even has the old ass creed batman combat ( with extra steps granted but still you can just wait and counter all game like in those games.) Great first impression but ultimately very empty feeling. Runs like absolute ♥♥♥♥ as well

author: Umi
review: This was a promising game that I approached with an Open-Mind. I personally have only ever briefly read the books as a child, and have never watched a Harry Potter movie. I can say for certain that this was a very mediocre game, if it wasn't for the fact that it was in the Harry Potter world it would have bombed with negative reviews.My plan was to 100% complete this game to give a proper review, however I simply couldn't bring myself to complete repetitive Merlin trials, bandit camps, loot rooms-All copy and pasted mind you, nearly every single one of them. Most of the side-quests lacked world building, excitement, or even entertainment for that. The 3 main side-quests tied to achievements however I enjoyed very much, such as Sebastion's quest line, Poppy's quest line, and Natsai's quest line.The story for me was a 7/10 it wasn't bad, but I simply wish I had more control over what happened in the world. The feeling of choice was extremely lacking in this world, and the fact that I could use certain spells and not have consequences tied to them. The voice acting on the part of the main character you control is god awful, I couldn't tell if it was a real person or AI-Generated, simply boring voice work.The developers put 90% of their effort into building the world/environment, and 10 percent on everything else combined. The graphics in my opinion are also lack-luster. Looking at other games released before its time, it's optimization and graphics in general felt 2015 era. Not in all cases however, the world and game is beautiful regardless of that.The combat on the other-hand is okay, however the fact that trolls and bigger enemies, can TELEPORT to you across the arena to hit you in an instant without you being able to react to it is INSANE. IM A WIZARD... SO HOW CAN A BIG MOB TELEPORT TO ME WHEN I TELEPORT DASH AWAY?Apologies if this review is all over the place, I may change my review in time depending how this game's DLC and future look. But for now it will stay negative. People need to stop allowing game developers to half-ass games, especially on a franchise as big and beloved as Harry Potter. TL;DR Lack-Luster game design, gameplay, copy and pasted quests/locations/characters, Lazy voice acting and build design. Not worth 60$.

author: Local man ruins everything
review: Boring and repetitive "puzzles" with a very basic combat system. As wide as an ocean and deep as a pond. Better games to play for a similar or superior experience.

author: Patryk.Jedi
review: Amazing so far!

author: MrBunbury
review: This game is, at best, average.  The main plot is incredibly milquetoast, and drags its feet like crazy.  The only stand-out story was the side-quest to get the unforgivable curses.The gameplay is competent, but I found myself dominating every single fight.  On normal difficulty, even higher-level red-numbered "boss" enemies provide no challenge.Technically this game ran like ass.  I have a number of issues with it, on a machine that plays every other game in my library without issue.  I'm running an RTX 2060-S.I couldn't even play at 1920x1080 on Medium settings.  This is honestly a first for me with this computer.  In order to achieve ANY kind of reasonable frame-rate, I was forced to play at 720x576 upscaled.  Even then, certain fights still turned into a slideshow unless I cranked some setting down further to Low, and once had to downscale to an even lower resolution.I tried at one point to watch youtube on a second monitor while doing random world quests.  It caused both the game AND the youtube video to stutter, drop frames, and full-on freeze.  I've NEVER had a game impact other applications in just an aggressive and invasive way.  It seems like this game was reaching outside of it's box into memory and resources it should not have had access to.When exiting the game, it would not actually close the process behind the scenes.  Steam would show the game as Running forever until I manually force-closed it.All-in-all, it was a mediocre game that ran like ass.  Wasted time well enough, but nowhere near worth the price tag.

author: ALWAYS BLACKOUT
review: Game breaking bug on Third Trial (Niamh's) forces you to restart a long-a** quest. Terrible for such an expensive game. And it was fun too. Too bad.

author: AlmightyThighs
review: got an under the map glitch that is unfixable and renders your entire character useless, id have to restart with a new character which im just not doing because i had 38 hours on this one and im not doing all that again.

author: Dr. Insanious
review: Hogwarts level design is a marvel, but that's about it. The game is horrible optimized, even with a high end PC. Particles are the worst, only reason for hours is price tag. Wait for sale or fix for optimization.- Don't expect to use any of your brain cells playing this game, everything is going to be stuffed down your throat. Doing a puzzle? You'll get the solution by your character thinking out loud. Even on the hardest difficulty and all choices have ZERO consequences.EDIT: I know this is my personal view, but calling this game a RPG is a disgrace. It's like playing Assassins Creed: Valhalla, you're a "viking" on paper, but thats it. It's just one massive grind of either getting cosmetics or useless "upgrades" hidden behind a tedious task. Notice how all the good reviews is about how beautiful the game is and that you can pet cats.... Who cares, if that the reason for paying this amount for a game, then I guess i'm getting too old and goblinish...

author: Griffin Abstract
review: So this whole "experience" was ass to me, I really became disillusioned after about 70 hours during my forced second play through after my save file was nuked by a pc crash that probably was the games fault, can't be entirely sure about that though...I'll try to sum up all of my pros, and more importantly, my cons, without much further ranting, but do remember that everything I'm writing here is my personal experience with the game, if you enjoyed it that's great for you and I wouldn't ever want to take that from you. also some slight spoilers about game play ahead, you have been warned- the writing is shallow, cliche, and overall bad. story as well as side quests, I won't bore anyone with details here- the optimization, directly after release at least, is pretty bad. I played on recommended settings and 5 fps during cut scenes and game play were not uncommon, to an extent that makes the game practically unplayable. and that's even after applying some fixes I found online that helped at least a little- the game play gets old after about 30 hours even with all the spells at your disposal, which to be fair is about the time you need to complete the game when you ignore most of the side quests- the world relies heavily on fetch quests to have any content, to an extent that just makes everything feel like a chore at some point- the npcs are terribly buggy and don't contribute to immersion at all- the beast keeping/breeding system and the potions/herbology system are very underwhelming in general- the whole game is awfully unpolished, there pretty much isn't any part of this game that works 100%- the hard difficulty wasn't really all that hard for me personally, the late game especially is way too easy at some pointthe game does have a few pros as well though, sadly not enough to make me recommend the game to anyone, but here they are:- the world, when you can actually see it through the frame drops, is enormous and gorgeous. hogwarts castle in particular is a sight to behold- flying on your broom is incredible and for 90% of my play through, I didn't use fast travel because going places on my broom was way more fun for me- some of the spells can be combined to make some really cool combos- they actually give you a choice on whether you want to use and learn the unforgivable curses- the level where you - the room of requirement has some really cool design and is relatively customizable, definitely the best part of the game for me and a nice little creative outlet between missionsso yeah, you can really tell that this is avalanche softwares first game of AAA magnitude and all in all I really can't recommend this game to anyone if I'm being honest, but as I said earlier, this whole thing is very subjective and if you really want it, don't let me stop you. also if you're still reading this, why?on a completely different note, I grew up loving harry potter and the world and I still do, but it's really overhyped and I really cannot describe how much I dislike the author, and creating a whole game about one of the most problematic things about it, as in the goblins, really isn't a good idea to me. but here we are. have a good one

author: Fargo The Loaf
review: Absolutely spectacular game.  At the time of this review, I've played about 21 hours and have only just scratched the surface.  It's an amazing feeling to live and participate in the world that we've read about and watched extensively!  Even if you didn't, you'd still get so much from this game.  The exploration is  with dynamic, candid events including students gabbing, broom-riders zipping overhead, and suits of armor scoffing and brawling.  Every time I jump into the game I turn off my additional monitors for that increased immersion that it has honed so well.The combat is fluid, responsive, and zippy. Power attacks  feel potent with enhanced "thumpiness" and "oomph".  Targeting took a few minutes to Get used to, but now it's second nature.  I freaking LOVE parrying enemy spells.The story is wondrous!  Fully voice acted, facial expressions are vivid, and I'm totally engrossed.  It just keeps wowing me.I fell through the world once while running around the side of the dark arts side of the building, but I'm chalking it up to a professor thinking I was up to no good. ;)If you couldn't tell, I have nothing but good things to say about the game, 100% recommend to you, your friend, and your mother.  Happy casting! o7

author: Webster
review: Here's my final take on Hogwarts: Legacy after finally hitting ~40+ hours (still haven't finished the game).A few items to note:I played on the hardest difficultyI disabled the minimap functionI'm R/G colorblind, so take any reference to color with a heaping spoonful of umami.In a triumphant return to the World of Wizardry, Hogwarts Legacy does it's level best to make you feel like you're a student in the titular school. It does this by incorporating a need for education, by serving the purpose of training you in the over two dozen spells in the game. That is to say, that the education system stops there. Any who come to Hogwarts: Legacy expecting a simulation of classroom life will be soured by the experience. Your chosen house makes very little difference in the gameplay experience, in truth, your house really has no value at all in the overall scheme of the game, since most of your time will be spent outside the school performing tasks that are unrelated to education.However, Hogwarts Legacy does manage to capture what it's like to be a Special Child like 'ol lighning scar himself. You are set against the backdrop of the school, and given the barest amount of instruction in how to handle the myriad of messes you'll find yourself in. I oftentimes found myself stumped or confused as to how to solve a puzzle because I hadn't completed the requisite course to acquire the spell needed to solve it. You'll also be getting attacked by basically everything that exists outside of the many spotted hamlets and towns in the Scottish Highlands; be they brigands or bandits, poachers or dark wizards, spiders or trolls. The fun within this game lies in the combat. Don't get me wrong, the dialogue is great, and the story is damn good. But the combat here is unlike anything I've played in my storied history of playing video games. You'll find yourself frequently rushing to pick the correct spell, or quickly aborting an expelliarmus in order to cast a protego, to avoid being disarmed yourself.The game does an amazing job of making the combat feel like real wizarding combat, sure. You can possibly survive in a fight against a dozen dark wizards, but you're going to have a difficult time, as every diffindo or crucio cast your way will create a hazard requiring a dodge, and all other spells will need to be blocked with protego. Now, it sounds on the face to be a straightforward think, this combat. The change comes, however, in the form of spell interactions. You see, a hastily cast glacius could lead into any number of others, such as a simple basic cast, or maybe an incendio. However, if you instead opt for a diffindo, descendo, or depulso, you'll be pleasantly rewarded with bonus damage due to the interaction of slamming or slashing the ice, causing it to shatter. These interactions are many and virtually none are explained by the courses, these are the things you must teach yourself. And all this is without getting into the fact that spells can be uniquely effective on certain creatures in certain cirucmstances. For example, cast a flippendo right after blocking a troll's club with a perfectly timed protego? Great, you just flipped that troll's club right up into his smug face. Cast a descendo while a spider is preparing a strike, bam - you've just buried that spiders fangs into the ground. This goes a long way toward making the combat feel real. That being said. The game does have some pretty glaring gaps that prevent it from being a complete experience. The lack of depth in the gear system is my biggest gripe, with the lack of quidditch being a close second. But there is one area that the game succeeds entirely, and that is being good. It's hard to remember the last time we had a really good magic-based RPG experience. So Hogwarts Legacy manages to squeeze itself in at the exact perfect time to be appreciated for what it does well.9/10

author: RazulDarkwood
review: I want to start with this - I am didn't grew up with Harry Potter I watched the movies and I don't care about politics. I am a gamer I prefer to leave my comment after I've played around 2/3 of a game at least in order to have a grounded view over things. The game reminds me of Fable 3 (which I like a lot, which may also surprise some people). The sense of adventure is using from this game however I have to admit that there are moments when the immersion in the world breaks and that is around 50/50 percent thanks to the bad optimization, however I see that the devs work on workarounds and patches in order to improve this, the other 50% is thanks how the game is structured. Someone said in the beginning that some quests may become unavailable after some time so I tried playing most of the side quests from the beginning which stripped the main story to its bare bones at the end and made me fly through it thous making it feel short. The story is ok, its not ground breaking and I don't think its a bad thing here. The game makes the world shine, its fine that you are THE ONE, however I love it that compared to the world you are still nothing. The enemies won't just lie and die because you are THE CHOSEN ONE, they will fight you with all they got. The thing that drags the game to the ground are the NPC's lack flavor. Out side of those that are the main focus in your quests and the teachers, every other NPC is just there... they are rarely memorable. The things that I liked most was that around 80% of the puzzles are unique in one way or another. Some repeat, yes, however those that do are usually really good so its understandable to repeat them once or twice. Some dungeons are like missed opportunities though. Its ok to make something to open the dungeon, but at least put another puzzle inside not just a box with loot, it feels underwhelming. The lower part of the map feels rushed. I guess that is when they made a delay, we know they even cut a portion of the map so I guess they rushed the one below just to have as much content as possible. The lower part was also the place where I found most bugs. Even with everything that I mentioned the game was MADE WITH LOVE! I can't deny that the devs showed great amount of love and attention to detail for which they have my respect. I rarely see such love in games nowadays. If you want a nice fantasy story try the game, you won't regret it. Don't expect Mass Effect level of story, but those that like Fable series level of story telling I think they will love this game.

author: alexkon3
review: Easily recommended. I grew up with Harry Potter even tho it wasn't really that important to me, I was more a Lord of the Rings kid. Still this is the game that I always wanted from the franchise. This game really does feel like a passion project of the devs and you can see it from all the small details that liter the world. Hogwarts itself is probably the most impressive structure I have ever seen in a game, period. You can go pretty much everywhere without fail its incredible. Combat feels fun and engaging and the spells are just fun to use.PC performance could be better but the optimization is not terrible, which is a bit refreshing for a modern AAA game, I did not have any bugs and glitches besides an NPC being stuck and walking on the spot, which was solved by reloading. I really do hope this game gets a bunch of DLC cause I would buy them. (pls add the Zouwu from the Fantasitic Beasts movies, thx :) ) Also I would've loved to get a non fantastic pet even if its just a prop for my room. Overall probably the best game since Elden Ring for me personally

review: I am absolutely not a Harry Potter fan. I skipped the last movies, never touched the books and rather gave all the merchandise a wide berth. Found the hype generally also exaggerated ...BUT damn me if this game is not the best after Elden Ring. I'm very simplistic... I see a good looking game where I can cast spells and get magical beasts I WANT THAT good looking game where I can cast spells and get magical beasts. I haven't had any game breaking bugs thankfully, although my graphics card will probably explode if I even consider turning any graphics setting higher than medium.... Nevertheless, the creation of the own character, the quite open game world and of course the combat is a nice refreshment. I love the companions (Sebatsian best boi, change my mind.) which would be nice though if you could take the companions with you permanently ^^All in all a great game and probably the wet dream for real Harry Potter fans. But I think even without this (still sometimes overrated) franchise, the game could stand on its own and that speaks volumes about the excellent work that is in there !
