author: Kobie-XIV
review: Hogwarts Legacy 9/10 SCORE FANTASTIC GAME.In almost every way, this is the Harry Potter RPG I’ve always wanted to play.Like many, I’ve been waiting for a truly excellent Harry Potter game since I was in the third grade. In that time, we’ve gotten some respectable LEGO Potter games, an underwhelming EA Sports Quidditch game for some reason, and even suffered through the fevered nightmare that is Harry Potter Kinect. But none of these has come close to fulfilling that fantasy of receiving a Hogwarts admission letter that opens the door to a secret world. With Hogwarts Legacy, I’m happy to say that we finally got a Harry Potter game that captures some of that magic. Its open world map absolutely nails the vibe of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, it has spellcasting combat that’s stupefyingly good,The characters that inhabit it are charming and unforgettable, and it is positively brimming with countless diversions to soak up dozens of hours of your time. It may not be the most impressive technical achievement and it is certainly cursed with a lack of enemy variety, but none of Hogwarts Legacy’sissues can cast a Descendo charm on this triumphant visit to the Wizarding World.Right in line with most Harry Potter tales before it, Legacy’s plot has more holes than a fishnet stocking and sorta just expects you to accept that its magical world makes no sense. This mystical third-person action-adventure RPG begins with you transferring to Hogwarts as a fifth-year witch or wizard (for unexplained reasons) to do everything from attending classes to fighting giant spiders with a magical stick to flying around on a hippogriff. The fantastic character creator has plenty of options for you to craft your ideal witch or wizard (apart from a fairly limited voice selection), and as soon as you do they’ll immediately become entangled in a conflict between the Wizarding World and an evil goblin. On top of that, because being in a secret society of wizards is apparently not exciting enough, you soon discover that you’ve got some freaky super-charged magical abilities that allow you to do extra cool stuff that also isn’t really explained.If you’re like me, you wont roll your eyes during moments when you’re introduced to 100 years’ worth of dead characters lecturing you from paintings about the importance of some stuff that happened a long time ago and how you have to save the world or whatever.For you none lore hounds once that’s over with Legacy mostly redeems itself with a fantastic cast of non-painting characters that help boil things down into a not-too-convoluted good-guys-versus-bad-guys conflict that ends up being an enjoyable tale, even if it's not particularly profound or original.Most characters are memorable and instantly endearing.“The characters you’ll spend most of your time with are the classmates who will befriend you on campus, accompany you on certain quests, and help you hone your abilities as a magic user. Most are memorable and instantly endearing, like Sebastian the cocky and morally pliable Slytherin, or Natsai the clever and unflappable Gryffindor, and spending time with them and improving your social links through their relationship questlines made my stay at Hogwarts all the more enjoyable.Concerning J.K. RowlingThe elephant in the room with Hogwarts Legacy is Harry Potter’s creator, J.K. Rowling, whose comments about things I do not pretend to understand I reviewed the game as a fan of the series of films and books and a persons opinions have no bearing on me as a person or the studio who made the game who include people of all backgrounds.Expectedly, I even found myself looking forward to hanging out with my professors, whether it was my main man Professor Fig, who serves as both something of a mentor and as a sidekick, or the wise-cracking charms teacher Professor Ronen, who made me love him mostly by making fun of me. Each of these characters feels like an indispensable piece of the school, and you can find them wandering the halls doing their thing and choose to spend time with your favorites. It’s a huge and important part of the Hogwarts fantasy that Legacy just knocks out of the park.The world is packed with nearly everything I wanted in a Potter game BUT NO QUIDDITCH.“Even better, though, is the world itself, which is just packed with nearly everything I wanted in a Potter game and more. You’ll find yourself exploring Hogwarts’ stone-cobbled halls and secret passageways, flying around the Forbidden Forest on a broomstick, and exploring dark caves lit only by the glow of your Lumos spell. The developers at Avalanche have so brilliantly captured the look and feel of the Wizarding World that I was amazed at just being there, no matter what trivial errand they had me wrapped up in.That immersion can occasionally be broken by Legacy’s dicey performance, though, which suffered from just about every issue that makes the performance review team cry during my my buddies time playing on PlayStation 5. Those greatest hits include frame rates had inconsistency, weird issues where the lighting switches from too dark to too bright, aggressive pop-in while moving around the map quickly, and more. There’s even this weird thing where every door in Hogwarts has a brief loading screen.It’s understandable since there’s so much packed into this beast of an adventure, but the PS5’s promises of the death of loading screens haven’t quite been lived up to here as it’s clearly struggling to keep up with the spell craft and whimsy of the Wizarding World I would play one a system that can handle the game and for me that was PC but some are limited by the console of choice you play on and some pre-Patch issue are now fixed such as theBeyond the performance issues people have on console, Legacy is also a fairly good of an adventure in general. You’ll probably fall through the map a time or two, or see a character or object get caught in the environment but these days that is expected on console and I for one do not want to see the game on PS4 and XB1 as they are 10 year old consoles.I didn’t encounter anything game-breaking or so common that you’ll likely want to curse its name, but things like this do happen enough to be an irritation I played on PC on a 4090 i9 CPU and have no issues all settings on MAX.Combat is fantastic, challenging, and utterly captivating.“As someone who finds the wand-whipping combat in the movies fairly dull, I was very concerned about Hogwart Legacy’s ability to keep my attention after slinging spells for dozens of hours, but I can admit when I’m wrong – the combat is fantastic, challenging, and utterly captivating. There’s a lot more to it than shooting balls of light out of a stick! Instead, the trick is in dodging and countering enemy attacks while pulling off creative combos. For example, you can pull enemies towards you with Accio, light them on fire with the close-range Incendio, then blow them away with the explosive Bombarda spell. Chaining together abilities to make your opponents look like complete fools never stops being amusing, especially as you unlock talent tree perks that enhance your skills with modifiers that make your elemental spells fork to nearby enemies or transform into AoE attacks.VerdictIn nearly every way, Hogwarts Legacy is the Harry Potter RPG I’ve always wanted to play. Its open-world adventure captures all the excitement and wonder of the Wizarding World with its memorable new characters, challenging and nuanced combat, and a wonderfully executed Hogwarts student fantasy that kept me glued to my controller for dozens of hours. It’s certainly weighed down by technical issues on console and a lack luster main story for people who ignore side quests and some poor enemy variety, but even those couldn’t come close to breaking its enchanting spell over me.

author: aliragh1
review: Okay so first off i bought this game on recommendation.I was told it was so much fun and addictive, the open world is huge and beautiful and filled with all kinds of stuff to do.I was told it would be challenging and it would take a lot of time to finish the game.My biggest worry was that i would't find it challenging as i have had this problem with multiple games lately.So i bought it and started to play on the hardest difficulty i could choose from and was pleasantly surprised by the looks of the game which were as said absolutely beautiful.I enjoyed the first hour or 2 just roaming the castle and searching for hidden spots and secrets and possible minigames.As soon as i got outside of the first few hours having finished the castle and the Hogsmead quests i was now free to roam the world and my amazement turned to boredom sadly.The games combat is addictive for sure and fun at start, you get to equip 16 spells of your choise at anytime granted that you have unlocked and learned those spells first and you have unlocked additional spell bars of which you are given 1 at start and 3 more through playing the game.  Each bar has 4 slots you can equip spells onto and there are numerous combinations you can try on your foes that each in their own right have numerous different outcomes and cinamatics.But that combat gets very boring very fast, mainly because it's just not challenging at all.Every enemy you encounter is very predictable and you can pretty much see them preparing to attack you for 2 sec or so, so using the defend charm or just rolling out of danger makes you pretty much invulnerable( beat the first boss, some giant stone statue that was standing in the center of the room all the time stomping his foot predictably, already at lvl 27 found every possible type of enemy also the infamous types on the worldmap, beat everything with little to no  effort and am seemingly unable to die)btw i was already at almost lvl20 just by opening chests and finding hidden and floating pages, but whatever i guess that's just how they decided to make the game function.The open world is beautiful to a certain degree, some places are absolutely amazing to roam through like the castle itself and the forbidden forest, but aside of those few areas the rest is pretty generic, very bland and empty with just grass, hills, flowers and roaming wildlife and i don't know what big means to other ppl but imo the world is not big at all and it makes itself  look even smaller because of the flying mechanic(you can literally fly from 1 end of the map all the way to the other end in less than 5 min)The map is scattered with small caves and very easy ''i guess you could call them puzzles'' to solve with various type of rewards given, mostly tho about 90% of the rewards are shirts, shoes, hats or gloves that in my case are almost always worse that what im already wearing and nothing more than just meaningless fodder to sell.These caves are easy to find even without the use of a minimap, the puzzles to open them are ridiculously childish and the size of them is insanely small and in almost all of them you find a single chest with some random meaningless clothing.Of all the things i was told only 1 imo seemed to be true to a degree, which is that the game does have it's beauty.Other than that it's childishly easy in every way ( combat, enemies, puzzles, exploration, challenges)The world is small, lineair and filled with the same puzzles and caves and ruins everywhere so looking at it like that, there really is not much to do at all unless you consider doing the same thing in 100 different locations as being ''something else to do''During playtime i kept getting bored all the time which resulted in me just watching tv or doing something else while still running the game, that to me is a sign of a boring and unchallenging game that is unable to keep me focused on it.There is a lot in this game that is just meaningless fodder designed to just fill up the lack of depth and gaming imagination, things like all the different kind of wand handles, the pets you can save and the 1 million chests with 1 million shirts stuffed in them that all of these things actually add nothing to your character or your story.At a certain point this game just playes like a giant scavenger hunt and that in it's own right can get pretty addictive untill you realise that what you are scavenging is the same as what you already own.Sadly i paid for this game and am now obligated to finish it to at least get the most out of my money, but the hardest thing about this game is actually nothing in the game itself but rather to keep the urge to play.Can not recommend this to actual gamers and the funny thing is those that recommended the game to me are all now either done with it and moved on to different games or just dropped it because their vieuw of it being a great game has also changed and they are unable to force themselves to keep playing

author: Chrissy
review: One of the most notable strengths of the game is its immersive open-world game play. Players will be able to explore the Hogwarts castle and surrounding areas, interact with characters from the Wizarding World, and cast spells using an advanced magic system. The game promises to provide players with a deep and engaging experience that will allow them to create their own Hogwarts story.Another strength of the game is its attention to detail and authenticity. The game's developers have worked closely with Warner Bros. and J.K. Rowling to ensure that the game remains faithful to the world of Harry Potter while also introducing new elements and characters. The game's visuals and sound design are also top-notch, creating an immersive atmosphere that will transport players to the Wizarding World.However, as with any game, there may be some potential weaknesses that could impact the player experience. For example, the game may have a steep learning curve for players who are not familiar with role-playing games or complex magic systems. Additionally, the game's release date has been delayed several times, which may lead to frustration or disappointment for eager fans.Overall, "Hogwarts Legacy" has the potential to be a highly immersive and engaging video game that will appeal to both fans of the Harry Potter series and gamers in general. With its attention to detail, authentic world-building, and open-world gameplay, the game promises to deliver a unique and unforgettable experience for players.

author: Poe
review: Overall Score : 7.5/10Verdict and TL;DR --> A flawed game with a majestic setting.Review:At times I wanted to bash this game but at other times I wanted to praise it so here we are. The story isnt anything remarkable. It serves its purpose and thats pretty much it. I must admit however that the pacing is on point. Never did I feel like the game tried rushing anything or extending certain things. It all makes sense in the context of what the story is and thats a big bonus. I will also say that the ending to the game added a couple plus points for me. It had me care for what happened in a moment where I was approaching an apathetic state towards the story. Gameplay is good in some areas and bad in others. The spells are majestic and its amazing what they managed to do. On the other hand, fights are way to easy, especially bosses. They literally have 4-5 moves at most and dont do anything worth of note. I wouldnt mind this that much if most bosses werent Damage Sponges and it took ages to kill them and these fights turned into bore fests more often than not. I get that the combat is more rhythm oriented and its a "puzzle" as youre going to be forced to use different spell combinations to battle enemies but its still worth a mention as something that irked me.The world is beautiful, Hogwarts is as amazing as youve ever seen it. You can explore any part of it, sneak through every crevace fly over any tower etc. Its a Potterheads dream. Aside from Hogwarts I had a difficult time caring for any of the other environments but they were also serviceably done so there isnt much to say here. As an ending note I must say I didnt really understand all the praise for the open world of the game. Sure its beautiful but aside from that its kinda repetitive in what it can offer you. A gaggle of enemies here, a gaggle of a different species of enemies here, merlin trial, ancient magic spot repeat. There really isnt anything there to keep you at the edge of your seat while you explore the world it all just devolves into a collectathon wether that be merlin trials, astronomy tables or just enemy kills. Its all just collectibles from doing a certain task X amount of times.

author: Israefel
review: Hogwarts Legacy sets the standard for future games in the wizarding world.  It is by no means perfect - there are only a few potions you can brew and plants you can grow for such a vast context, your own backstory as the main character is nonexistent, you can be polite or rude to side characters but it has zero effect on the outcome of their quests or stories, enemies get a bit repetitive, gear is basically throwaway, 'unforgivable' curses can be thrown about with zero consequence.  All this being said, the game is incredibly fun to play and the 'semi' open world is rich with things to discover.  Combat is fun and fulfilling though power creep does come up later in game.  There are TONS of collectibles, many secrets, the world itself does feel alive and fun to explore.  Hogwarts alone can take hours and hours to explore and unravel its secrets.  Spells are utilized throughout the open world not just in combat but in puzzles and once you unlock them all you can use them in a variety of ways to get where you need to go.  The room of requirement is ridiculously customizable and you can spend hours there taking care of magical beasts (that you first go out and capture), brewing potions, growing plants, and just changing the decorations.  A solid addition to the wizarding world overall, 10/10 the game delivers.

Take that! J.K. Rowling!

I plan on putting in a lot more hours because this game is one in a few that hasn't gotten old/boring. My only complaint is fps lag spikes randomly when ray tracing is on. I would love to play it smoothly with ray tracing it looks amazing! I upgraded my graphics card twice to sub do this problem with no luck. I can play on ultra with 100% scaling ray tracing off smoothly ~120 fps, the minute i turn on ray tracing it will run smoothly until it spikes and my graphics card drops from 280 watts down to 120 watts and i think it has something to do with the drivers for nvidea, seems like a common bug. Newly released game so it's ok for now but PLEASE FIX! ryzen 7 5800x overclocked  @4.85 Ghz32gb 3200 Mhz ram Rtx 4070 ti *Game is downloaded onto Samsung 990 pro Nvme*

However there are alot of game elements that can't be interacted with,  that would make you feel more part of the world in other RPGs like being able to sit, that lets you feel and be part of the world. and interacting with other NPCs and have them react. Over all love it just not sure how much replay value as their isn't a morality system or large efects the player can have on the world and how it treats the player

The game performance was very inconsistent which would be great for the game devs to address. Overall a great game.

author: NaClholic
review: - By  was a pleasant surprise that had a lot more to it then I had originally thought I was going to get out of it. While the "learning in class" aspect that was sold as a concept by the game is there, it is lacking in the depth I would have liked to see from the game. While I understand having an entire class of learning about the lore of the world you inhabit would be  time consuming and boring, it would have been nice to have a short excerpt of something to sell the idea rather than just a cut-scene of happy go lucky kids learning. The story was engaging and you never stray too far from it at any point and the progression to go along with it fit the narrative well. While I wish there was more creative solutions to taking care of enemies rather than the simple loop of combat and avoiding them, the combat was actually a league far above what I thought was capable with a single-player action game based around magic. The movements and animations are well made and snappy as well as all the spells you learn having some use to initiate a combo on any foe you come across. This game is also perfect for those that love to be rewarded for taking their time to explore and be rewarded  with countless puzzles, prizes, and unique interactions all across the castle and landscape, not letting more than a few yards feel like unused space and taking full advantage of the resources and world that has been built by the giants before them. All in all a whopping 8.5/10 and good buy on or off sale for a relaxing third-person experience you can come home from work to.

author: Snowblind
review: So, this shouldn't be a special occasion, but it is so I'm going to address it. This is the first AAA game I've played since probably RDR2 that seems like it was released as a finished product. Bugs were few, benchmarking happened when I booted it up and it runs great on the PC, and it just had a noticeable lack of jank that I found refreshing. On top of that, the game is actually good. I do believe a lot of the choices that are made are kind of there as an illusion, but the interactions and the story so far are good enough when they play out that I don't really mind. The castle is huge, the surrounding areas are beautiful, and the little montages of the students attending classes really made it feel like the first times I watched the movies. Really captured the vibe of attending Hogwarts. Music is good, it's immersive, and the combat is flashy while also being difficult enough that learning enemy weaknesses and spell combos are worth it. Skill trees could be a bit more fleshed out, but are far from bad how they currently stand. Haven't even done the Room of Requirement stuff really yet, and haven't been catching animals, so still some aspects of the game that will be completely new. Loving it so far, 8.5/10.

author: Clarissa
review: A review from a person who has finished the whole game!Pros:- Really nice storyline that is well written and comes full circle at the end. The companion sidequests also add a lot to the overall story as well.- Really detailed and immersive world. Exploring every nook and cranny of the castle itself and surrounding areas is very satisfying. I love the seasonal changes as well and it makes me want to explore certain areas again to see what they look like with these changes.- Combat is satisfying and challenging.- The puzzles are complex, varied, and really fun. I love the gameplay of figuring out what spells you should use in order to solve themCons:- Would benefit from a morality system, it really breaks immersion with no consequences of using the Unforgiveables. It would've been really cool to make them OP but have them damage your relationships- Flying controls are very janky on PC and non-intuitive. You can make it slightly better by changing keybinds, but would've been a lot better if they had it in-built with mouse control.---Overall a really great game with a really great story that I would recommend. I think some of the negative reviews come from huge HP fans who had really high hopes, which is understandable. It's not revolutionary or anything like that, it's just really good for what it is - a fun, action combat RPG

author: Khaled the Dude
review: I only watched the first 4 Harry Potter films, so I do not consider myself a Harry Potter fan, but I am a fantasy open-world RPG enthusiast.What I liked:- The story is atleast Harry Potter quality.- Combat is good for magic-based combat.- The puzzles are engaging.- The world is beautiful and fun to explore.- You can pet cats.What I wish to see if the developers decide to make a sequel:- More player agency in story direction.- Companions.- More focus on adventuring and world interactivity.- Expanding magical beasts care options.

author: BlacKHeaRt
review: This is one of the best and most immersive open world RPGs I have played for a while since Witcher 3 and RDR 2. The game seems to offer a story with an interesting plot, an immersive open world with lots of activities, enough exploration and surprises to have fun with, as well as a combat system that can be very intense. What I like the most is the flow of the game though as most of the said activities can be found in modern MMO titles but the way the game utilizes and combines them with the main story does not bore me at all!!With the aforementioned highlights considered, If you are a Harry Potter fan, plain and simple, just buy it.

author: seanrmc93
review: If you read the Harry Potter books multiple times like I have, you will adore this game. The amount of minute details from the books (and films) they were able to cram into this game is truly a joy to behold. During development, this game received a lot of criticism for pushing back the release date. After exploring the world they have created, especially Hogwarts Castle itself, this game feels like it benefited from those push backs. As I found more and more of the small details and little embellishments hidden throughout, I got the feeling that as they worked through what they were behind on, they simultaneously elaborated on the world, and went above and FAR beyond. Thank you to the developers for building this world of wonder for us all to explore and enjoy.

author: illi
review: A fairly solid game that gets infinitely better if you are a Harry Potter fan, because the best thing about it is being in the wizarding world and Hogwarts. If you are not a fan, I imagine it might be hit or miss. The open world is quite vast and not limited to Hogwarts and close areas - I was honestly quite shocked when I saw the size of the map. You get your broom to fly around fairly early so I imagine it had to be huge to make it feel big enough for it. It is full of points of interest that give you stuff to do there, most of it however I felt was uninspired and mostly the typical open world "map puke" padding. I understand they needed wider world to make some quests and not making all center just around Hogwarts, but on the other hand I'd bu quite OK to just have Hogwarts, Hogsmead, Forbidden Forest and surrounding areas accessible and still think of it as big enough.Main story is.... okay. For me the side quests were the stars, especially those centered around my classmates and which I'd call "main side quests". There are your filler side quests there too, but the questlines where you develop friendships with other Hogwarts students, alongside the "quests" that simulate classes to learn new spells are very well done and simulate the Hogwarts feeling perfectly.Talking of spells: there. Is. So. Many! And it's great balance too - some from books, some from movies and there is even Flipendo for those who remember the now ancient Harry Potter movie tie-in games. While it gets difficult to juggle all of them as time wents on and your arsenal broadens, the combat is overall really good and each enemy has specific combo you should use on them to exploit their weaknesses. Combat was one of the great surprises for me as I never really imagined it being so good.All in all, this is a good pick for anyone that loves open world games RPGs (though theRPG elements are on light side) and don't mind the now typical open world design of "lets puke points of interest with almost coppied challenges all over the place". But it's an absolute must for any Potterhead out there purely for the cheer joy of wandering Hogwarts.

author: NerdyIsWhatIDo
review: Absolutely loving this game! It's got all the magic you'd expect from something set in the Wizarding World while still being new and interesting. Can't recommend enough if you're a fan of Harry Potter and RPGs.

author: Phantomplatypus
review: Really wanted to love this game. Hogwarts environment is really well done, but I don't want to play a game just for its eye candy. Other than the way Hogwarts looks the game is thoroughly non-engaging. The story is bland and not immersive, the side quests are as well. Too many repeating side activities. Like the Merlin puzzles, which become more of a chore than a challenge. There are no consequences to anything you do as a player, which kills all replay-ability. The "choices" are not true choices as they change nothing. The gear system is abysmal and pointless.Some final words on the main story: Honestly, if the focus of the game was attending classes (where my performance in that class actually mattered) and exploring/doing quests in my spare time this game would be 10x more interesting. Especially because the combat system is quite good. But as it is, once you reach mid-game you are basically a teenage wizard demi-god dispatching whole groups of dark wizards and goblins like its nothing (played on hard btw). And then the story just peters out. My character trained less than Rey and somehow feels stronger than she was....Environment and aesthetic: 10/10Actual gameplay: 4/10

author: Daniel
review: Was excited for this game but I was overall disappointed.-The targeting system is terrible, push right stick to select targets but then it just auto changes targets randomly anyways.-You have choices for dialog during conversation, but non of your choices matter. conversations and actions all end the same.-Playable character's voices sounds like a slightly upgraded siri. painful to listen to.-Mini games and side quests are super boring.-Also the game is super easy. which would be great for easier difficulties but if you select normal or hard, the playable character shouldn't be immediately telling you exactly what to do without giving you some time to try to figure it out on your own. all puzzles are pointless because it's basically auto solved for you.Could have been a great game with lots of fun side quests with groups of students and challenges but developers got real lazy and unimaginative on this one.

author: Sallow
review: I finished the game and damSPOILERS and rant (I have 80+ hours in it right now and I have no intention to abandon it.)I have ssssome thoughts about this Ominis deserved MORE SCREEN TIME. And also. Why the hell does it seem to me like some quests were simply removed with him? Like multiple times the character tells you - go talk to him if so and so and you just simply can't. as well as over students deserved more screen time? Some of them are really cool, I wish their stories would be as well made as Sebastian's.Speaking of the devil - why our actions have 0 real consequences... Like there were so many times when you could've made a difference but replaying the missions 5+ times I don't see any lmao possibility lmao. What was the reason to give the MC abilities to speak for themselves. MC is so blank at 70% of the time because of this... And strikes me as a Mary Sue. I just wish we had more.... down to earth main story.BUT...I really enjoyed the game and probably this is going to be my fixation for a while. I didn't see the game as boring as my friends didThe details in the game are 10/10.The locations are beautiful and captivatingThe gameplay is amazing and you really feel an impact (especially with the unforgivable curses💚)The characters are diverse and really unforgivable.  I wish there would be more interactions. author: Frenchie
review: First half of this game was absolutely wonderful, so much to discover thick rich storyline.Second half/Endgame pathetic by this point I'd done the same thing over and over again so many times I was bored stiff. *slight spoiler* the final boss battle was absolutely pathetic took about 10 mins to do and then bam it was over not retries needed. Glad I played it but will not be completing to 100% there just isn't enough variance to it to keep you interested, I mean come on throughout the entire game there's approx 6 enemy types that's it, goblins, darkwizards, spiders, trolls, inferi and dugbogs and once you learn the mechanics of each of them they become very very easy to defeat, troll especially take a bit of time to defeat just due to their huge health but mechanically very simple to do. Overall it was just a bit meh by the end. ps. dialogue also becomes very tired after a while and you will find yourself skipping through a lot of the drivvle dialogue you're constantly forced to sit through.

author: kenbcn
review: Amazing! A lot of fun. Every aspect of the game has been put through a lot of thought and effort.  Everything you do feels rewarding and satisfying. It's relaxing but at the same time there is a lot to do and plenty of features. So far the story is wonderful, the characters are great. The animation and voice are fantastic, the writing incredible, the combat is so much fun! When I see that my progress (my percentage of completion) goes up I feel sad because I don't want the game to end. Don't download this game if it ever gets cracked, this guys they really deserve to get paid for this wonderful job. I don't think it matters if you are a HP fan or not, this game will please anyone who loves magic, fantasy, adventure, quests, crafting, levelling/skills, loot, good story, writing, animation, writing, amazing graphics, very good controls and more. It's also very intuitive. At the beginning you might feel like "wow, there is a lot of stuff going on!", but you quickly learn everything. In short, worth every penny, amazing game, go get it!.(A couple hours later in the game)I just keep getting amazed by the amount of detail in this game! Every object, every action, environment, conversation, character... I can't believe how well done this is. I am totally submerged in this world. I NEVER leave reviews, I don't know if I am just lazy or what, but this time, I just can't help but to share how it feels to play this game. This totally needs to go on my top 3 games of all time, I just don't know which one to remove...DA3, The Witcher 3 or Skyrim...(Quite a few more hours later...)OK., I did find something that drives me insane and don't like. First, beware that I am not a pro, so maybe this is part of the problem. So...FLYING with a broom: the WORST controls ever. I find it so difficult to move around and the controls aren't right. Instead of using a right click to point and move towards a direction, you have to use half your keyboard to make a turn. It's frustrating. Still love the game though.

author: Californ1a
review: Solid game, very much worth playing, though the gameplay was not quite as in-depth as it could have been. The story and quests felt like they took a backseat to exploration and combat. If you're into exploring, then it's great, and the castle is like a huge maze to try to learn the layout. However, outside the castle, there's a lot of running around the map doing various tasks that aren't part of any quest and end up just feeling like busy work to complete the field guild (and even quite a lot of tasks that aren't tracked in the field guide but are needed for achievements anyway).The combat is probably the best part, learning which spells to use and figuring out what combos work well together is a lot of fun. Main issue with the combat is with the keyboard controls - the game limits you to having only 4 spells active at a time, and unlocking separate bars for different spells rather than allowing you to bind each spell to a key individually, so you'll be swapping between bars pretty often or will want to set up a macro to swap bar, fire a different spell, then swap back on a single key. It's also very easy to find overpowered combos that can potentially make the game feel too easy, but it's a singleplayer game so if you want to go all-out, then it does have that ability.On quests, the main story is very short; if you ignore sidequests and don't explore the castle much then you'll finish very quickly. Even if you include sidequests, it is very lacking in the number of quests compared to other open-world rpgs. There's less than 100 total quests, including both main and side. Compare that with something like Skyrim, where even just the unmarked/miscellaneous quests far outnumber HL's total. Counting only the marked quests in Skyrim is around 250-350, depending which DLCs are included or not. There's a couple of small "unmarked quests" in HL, but most of them are just giving an npc a potion.One of my main complaints is that the world doesn't feel as lively or immersive as it could have been. There are random npc events where npcs will talk to each other and such, but they're very static - the same random events will always happen in the same locations and none of the npcs really move around very much aside from a few that can spawn on roads between hamlets, or combat enemies. You can't even see any students sleeping in the dorms at night, all the beds are empty and the school grounds are also just empty at night, as if the students just disappear. All the shopkeepers are stood static as well, they never close their shop at night or go to sleep, they don't even walk around inside the shop. Most the npc events around the castle are pretty good, you'll stand there and listen to them chat early on, but after a few hours you'll have seen most if not all of the random npc events already so they get stale quick because they never really move around to do events in different areas.My second main complaint is with the entire southern half of the map, it just feels entirely underutilized. There's only a small amount of main quests that go down to the south, but it feels like they could have had their quest areas moved somewhere up north. Same with the couple sidequests that are in the southern half, they feel like they could have easily been placed somewhere up north. Then, without the few quests down there, the southern half primarily just feels like a way to pad out more "busy work" field guide tasks. It feels like the southern half really needed some large unique landmark area in it, similar to hogwarts or hogsmeade, but instead it just feels like an area used to dump extra bandit camps and merlin trials.Also on the immersion front, and tying into the combat, there aren't a lot of different enemy types, especially bosses with unique attacks. The vast majority of enemies are spiders, goblins, or human, with a few trolls. It doesn't take very long to learn all their attack patterns and how to best deal with each of them. By the time you get to the part of the story that goes to the southern half of the map, you've probably already fought nearly every enemy type. The southern half of the map could have expanded the enemy roster to include more unique types and different attack patterns.There are changing seasons, but only during the main story. Once you finish the main story, you're stuck in 1 season. You never get to see the Halloween or Christmas decorations, or any of the snowy landscapes, ever again, without starting a new save.I really like the cosmetic system where every piece of gear you obtain, even after you sell or destroy it, can be used as a cosmetic override for the gear you're actually wearing. This really helps discourage hoarding gear, though I did have a few instances during a couple dungeons where my gear slots still filled up and I had to destroy some gear so I could keep collecting chests before the end of the dungeon. There's also a small annoyance with cosmetics that'll probably get ironed out at some point, but whenever you equip new gear, you have to go back in and set the cosmetic override again; it doesn't just globally apply the cosmetic on top of all gear, it's individual.Overall, there's a lot to explore, especially around the castle. If you're into the lore, there's a lot to read about all the various setpieces throughout the castle. It's a lot of fun to fly around on a broom, land in a bandit camp, and do some spell combos. If you just do the main story, sidequests, and some of the field guide, it's definitely a good game, but it does get really tedious when completing the field guide and achievements; there's a lot of extra stuff that just felt like padding for what should have been more quests or other content. I enjoyed it, though it definitely devolved into a collect-a-thon near the end.

author: Cleptomania
review: This game is not really good. There are tremendous technical issues, causing random lag that makes the game almost unplayable at times on my system(Running an Intel I7-9th gen, an RTX 3080, an SSD and 16gb Ram). Besides that, the story is rather mediocre at best, especially considering that there are no consequences. Only two or three choices change some outcomes, and most of these are very minor at best, giving the game very little replay value. The mechanics are very well done, but the game just lacks too much of the wizarding world. The Open World, after you have completed the story, is relatively emtpy and boring, which I find really sad, considering what could have been done with it.That being said, Potterheads will still love it. And if you are a big fan of the world, like me, this game might be for you. BUT: Don't expect too much. And be prepared to make some compromises.All of this is of course excluding the numerous controversies sorrounding the game and people behind it, though I don't believe this is the right place for anyone to get into those.

author: ParticuLarry
review: First I had huge troubles with the game. Constant laggs, clipping through the game world when the assets wouldn't load. Traversing Hogwarts and Hogsmead was the worst. I fixed it by upgrading my RAM to 64 GB since no other fix fixed anything. Neat.It finally didn't lagg anymore. So I was finally able to play the game as it was intended. No hard feelings, let's just go into it unbiased.What awaited me were boring "riddles" and dumb fetch quests for the biggest part of the game. Especially annoying were the Demiguise which you could only try to find at night. I had to use a guide for that, because gathering them upgrades your alohomora. If you don't want to waste your time backtracking all the time, of course you NEED to have it on max. So finding enough demiguise was actually extremely important, and speedrunning through hogwarts and hogsmead to get enough of them was extremely stressful. This was the most annoying part of the game imho.The ancient magic quests were also boring since you can just broom broom and do it easily.The astronomy challenges were - again - locked behind the day/night cycle, so there's no way I'm doing that again. The demiguise stressed me out enough already.The itemization is extremely dumb. Exploring doesn't make sense since you'll just find green garbage that clutters your inventory quickly even if you finished enough Merlin trials to have a decently sized inventory. That also means you have to sell your stuff all the time, especially so before you start quest lines. Again, this is boring, since at some point you have far too much money anyway.You also can't just configure a look and keep it all the time. No, whenever you get an upgraded item you need to change it if you want to keep the look you decided on. If you don't do that you'll walk around like a clown all the time, which breaks the immersion easily. And since changing it in early game with every upgrade was so annoying, at some point you stop caring and just accept that you're a clown. Another system the fun was sucked out of because you had to engage with it all the time. Now to the good parts.The story is really good. The supporting cast is likable and unique enough. The quests of Sebastian, Poppy and Natty fit well to the overall story with each having their own arch enemy. It's all tied together neatly, and this part is actually worth praising.The game's strength regarding gameplay were definitely the caves. The parts where you couldn't just fly past all enemies and actually had a good experience of exploration. There were also a few parts I didn't like, but for 99% of the time, I greatly enjoyed the big caves. Too bad there aren't more in the game.I also enjoyed the music, especially when riding a beast. Final thoughts:I think I would've enjoyed the game more if you couldn't just take your broom right from the start and bypass any content, any scenery, any fight just like that. It allows you to just skip most of the content without having to walk ever again. The exploration part falls really flat, since the highlights are marked on the map and these "highlights" not actually being highlights. They're mostly boring filler content.And this is probably my biggest gripe for the game: You have so many things to fetch. Be it pages, demiguise, merlin trials, astronomy alters, beasts for materials... It's just the same over and over again. And the worst part is that collecting all this stuff is extremely important for you to gain levels, so you can equip better stuff and become stronger. This notion of: "you HAVE to go and collect everything" is just not fun for me. It comes down mostly to grinding, but not in the fun part, since it's all the same over and over again, as I stated earlier.Same goes for the enemies btw. You have like 4 different enemy types and that's what you'll have to fight against for 90% of the game. There are minor variations with shields in different colors, and some enemies being too big to be lifted, but for the most part it looks and feels all the same.Additional info: I played through the game on hard mode and I was bored most of the time. At some point I just wanted to finish the story at least. Sebastians story was what kept me going. Was it worth it? Yeah. But I could've just watched the cutscenes on youtube. No need to actually spend 60 bucks on that.

author: Burt Macklin
review: Game of the Year.  It's great.  I'm looking for the Lake DLC where we can actually explore the waters.  Quidditch would be cool but not as cool as actually getting in that lake.  Gotta say I am so happy this isn't a "Harry Potter" game.  Set 100s of years in the past, the majority of book cannon doesn't exist.  This gives fans of the world a fresh experience of the universe and I am excited to play it over at least 2 more times and I haven't even finished my first play through.  I would recommend this game to everyone regardless who they are.  Hogwarts is just good clean fun.  The game allows you to play in a whole host of different ways, which is why I stated earlier I plan to complete it 2 more times, at least.  If you are on the fence, get off it and get the game.  If you like fantasy, if you like spying, stealth, steamrolling, crafting systems, farming, exploring, 100% completing, racing, speed running, puzzles, and more this game has it all and you can definitely find an area that keeps you playing and lose track of time.  I am so happy this game has gotten the overwhelming response it has, hopefully the Devs are out there creating more for us to do as we speak I have money waiting for them.

author: Katzro
review: So, to start, let me establish that I am not much of a Harry Potter fan. I only ever saw the first movie after the franchise initially "got big", and never had much interest in anything else, aside from one of the games, I think one based on the first movie, but it was more of a puzzle platformer type deal than anything else.That being said - this game is AWESOME.I'm not a professional reviewer so I'm not going to pretend I know about technicalities...The game looks gorgeous, and the soundtrack does what it's supposed to do, supporting appropriate moods at the appropriate times. The world building itself is amazing; it's rare that a game can just almost instantly grab me, but Hogwarts Legacy did.The combat system is relatively simplistic, but it still manages to be fun. I can see side-quests and puzzles and the like maybe getting a little bit repetitive, but that tends to happen with every game if you play enough of it, as for the main story - it manages to keep me engaged, and I'm only speaking for myself here so....yeah - story's good too.There are, however, two things that I am rather disappointed about:1. There is no Quidditch. I'm sure I don't need to elaborate on why there should be! Perhaps in a piece of DLC, or even better, a sequel.2. After unlocking more spell slots in your talents, the game does a bit of a poor job actually communicating to the player that those slots can be used; maybe I'm a little slow, but in my opinion having the "Forbidden" sign mark the slots first and foremost conveys the message: "This is not usable!" and not the message: "Please slot your spell here!" Since I've talked about the 2 things that I most disliked, I think I should mention the two things I like the most:1. The transmog (gear appearance change) system is very simple and efficient, and I think pretty much all RPGs should try to use a version of it going forward.2. Hogwarts castle itself is absolutely beautiful. Everything from the scale, to the design, to the ambiance works perfectly to create a location where you just...want to be, really, for as long as possible.Lastly, there's talk of a multitude of issues with the PC version. Since buying the game, the only real problem I've been having is some stuttering, usually when initially loading into the game, and I've had one crash to desktop, after trying to reload the same checkpoint a number of times in quick succession...I THINK getting a bit more ram would solve the stuttering issue for me. As for bugs...a couple times when loading into another location (like an underwater cave, for example) I had issues with the camera, as it would get stuck at a certain angle, and not move no matter what, making it impossible for me to actually see my character anymore - weird...but reloading the game fixed it.Aside from that, I've had no issues running the game on the best detail level.All in all, this game is a great game. Whether you want to wait for a sale or not is up to you, but I do not regret paying full price for it.I'll see you in class...Also, Ravenclaws rule! Change my mind.

author: pavel1269
review: Pretty good game.Not a fan of HP? Easy 7/10 as a solid game with 40-ish hours of content to do most of the stuff.Fan of HP? Combat from previews looked boring but i could not be more wrong. It is the best combat system i ever played. Not too punishing and hard and not left button spam either just feels like a perfect balance. To add a nice touch, over the course off a game you unlock bunch of spells and some spells are just better against some enemies.World is very good. Hogwarts and surrounding are amazing. The farthest locations not so much but fine. You can upgrade and enchant your gear. Materials for it are plenty available so no need to hoard and never use it. Upgrade whatever as its super easy to get more materials again. There is an alchemy with few potions with plenty of materials easily available. Most game systems feel very polished and well integrated.Generally as you loot better gear you want to wear the best currently available item which will make you look like a creepy person worshiping lizard people. After i received a comment that i should not look like Indiana Jones but a student, turns out there is perfect transmog system to eliminate this entirely. You choose what you want to look like and even hide equipped item altogether. You will be able to choose a lot of any item you had or unlocked.Story is ok. What about decisions? You are The hero, deal with it. Did not bother me just bear that in mind.edit: Fixed by latest patch.Few quality of life changes i'd live to see are:- Transmog should retain after gear change.- After a few Merlin trials the animation is really tiresome.- Alahomora for 50th time is really boring. Fast unlock after 10th time of respective level?Oh and the professor you work most with is straight out Regis from Witcher 3, wizard, sure not a vampire, change my mind.

review: THIS GAME IS DOPE !!! Super fun , everyone should play it.

author: redcrayonnn
review: The game starts off slow, but as the world opens up the more addicted I grow to it.What to expect, spending 8 hours just exploring the castle finding puzzles and things making hard to leave. when you venture into the world, you'll quickly be just as busy with random puzzles. The combat is like dancing, and very in depth and detailed. The castle is everything you will have wanted it to be, and your story... while feeling semi guilded at this time,  ;eaves room for you to be who you want to be. My mindset has been a lesson from Albus Dumbledoor in the books. author: Inquietus
review: I don't usually review games so keep this in mind. I love the game i think its amazing in every way except 1 massive flaw. The game is unplayable unless you are either super lucky or have a really powerful pc. That flaw is Denuvo, and it literally kills fps on most computers. Massive fps loses by 20fps with it tanking at random down to 10fps on a laptop with a 2080super 16gigs ram ddr4 3200ghz with a i7cpu at 1080p and on my desktop with  EVGA FTW3 3090TI, intel core 13k cpu, 32gb ddr5 6200ghz ram, on a SSD at 1080p i go from 190fps down to 120fps at random with harder spikes sometimes bringing me down as low as 30fps. Thats not including loading inbetween moving through areas. Meanwhile ps5 can run the game in graphics mode at perfect 60fps and they do not use denuvo. So Unless they remove denuvo i cant honeslty say but this game. That being said gameplay wise this game is on point with lore, with content, with combat, with customization. its what ive always wanted as a fan of this world.There are a few things that need improvements like loot, and a few other small things. The game does baby you alot but after a while it becomes unnoticeable. The map size and content is massive. There is so much to see and do. The combat is simple but fun and a challenge in hard mode. the story is amazing so far and the side quests are all fun and unique. There are no weapon mods or types only gear changes. There is a upgrade system but it seems a little too sub par. The fashion system is pretty massive but it could do with more styles. I really wish you could wear a cape and robe. Over all the gameplay is a solid 10/10 from me because after all those little issues its so easy to get lost in the game. Before you know it youve spent 4 hours and you still are not even close to being done. I love the game. But again until denuvo gets removed the game has a 50/50 chance of not being able to run on your pc. Denuvo might also be causing a massive memory leak. Additionally you cant play offline because of Denuvo dont even try youll lose your progress trust me ive been there and it screwed me. Also could do with a hell of alot more gear slots or less gear but more vendors, or an ability to break down gear to use for the gear you want to level. But again just the little things. Buy at your own risk.

author: Luigi
review: Hogwarts Legacy is an enchanting game that offers players the chance to immerse themselves in the magical world of Harry Potter. From the moment you step onto the grounds of Hogwarts, you are transported to a world of wonder and adventure that fans were dreaming about.One of the best features of this game is its gameplay. The controls are intuitive and easy to learn, allowing players to explore the vast and detailed world with ease. The combat system is also satisfying, with a range of spells and abilities that make each encounter feel unique and exciting.The graphics in Hogwarts Legacy are decent, with intricate details that bring the world of Harry Potter to life. The attention to detail in the environment is truly impressive, making the experience feel like a true journey into the wizarding world.The atmosphere of the game is perfect, with a sense of magic and wonder that permeates every aspect of the experience. The soundtrack is also excellent, adding to the immersive quality of the game.The only downside I could point out is its optimization. However, this can be improved using mods.Overall, Hogwarts Legacy is a must-play game for Harry Potter fans.

author: Extra Big Swimjim with Cheese
review: No spoilers.Hogwarts Legacy (HL) is a decent game but it is distinctly overhyped, between people reacting to its IP and surrounding political controversies. It is a standard action-adventure game, very reminiscent of the gameplay loop and B-card story of games like Infamous... this would be a solid 8/10 in the Xbox 360 and PS3 eras, but it feels very archaic now. I imagine most players of the game were about 10 years old when those games came out, so that also adds to the overhype, through nostalgia, when they see a new game that has the same old features and flaws from that generation.At times, the story feels like you're living out your own Harry Potter adventure. But the writing is so straightfoward, much of the time, that it feels more like it was written by George Lucas than J.K. Rowling. Superfans of the Star Wars Prequel trilogy will feel right at home with the game's story of mild angst and blatantly obvious controversy, as well as eye-roll-inducing allusions to real world issues. Characters are sometimes well written, but suddenly they'll go flat and their motivation becomes "I must defeat X by myself, but everyone treats me like I'm fifteen!" This happens with multiple characters. Additionally, the one shifts heavily from being very childish and not taking things far enough, to becoming almost overly dark; basically, it's tone deaf. The gameplay is mostly dull from beginning to end. The spells don't feel particularly impactful, and the forbidden ones don't illicit the dread or brutality they're described as in the books. The fighting is a ranged variation of the other Warner Brothers games, such as Batman Arkham and Shadows of Mordor, except it's even simpler than the rock paper scissors gameplay in those. It's easy to the point that two or tree usable items will get you through most fights on the hardest difficulty. There are some fights that overcome the game's inherent simplicity by simply adding a lot more enemies, which is still easily thwarted by drinking a damage immunity potion and dropping a couple cabbages on the ground. Even if you don't use items, the gameplay loop is just cycling skills while parry or dodging every second. The place HL shines, oddly enough, is a decorating minigame that's very intuitive to use. I don't usually care to decorate in any video game, but it feels so nice in this one that I can't help but do it for up to thirty minutes at a time.The setting is the game's best feature. It lacks the granduer of any of the areas described in the books or seen in the movies, though. The dining hall looks tiny, as well as many other areas that I won't say which return from the series. Most of the detail seems to have gone into the more distant hallways of the school and the Slytherin areas. For as many assets are in the game, and there are quite a few, many are copy-pasted next to each other, completely breaking immersion. Even in areas which are particular references to the books/movies or which are supposed to be specific in-game character spaces, repeating assets are present, insuring that few of the spaces feel like real places. It feels more like the developers made themselves a little "we tried" cake and clumsily placed it in nearly every room.Someone in lead development for HL got it into their head that kids just really like caves. As such, the game is a long series of cave delving corridors between a few missions that take place in the castle or villages, and, rarely, the forest (unless it's a forest cave!). You fight your way through a half-dozen spiders per room, twist down some backrooms-like empty corridors with nothing in it but a new hat and a "puzzle" that consists of pushing one button. Still, some of this cave delving feels like you're doing something dangerous and forbidden, but only toward the beginning of this fairly long game. Laughably, characters will sometimes enter a slightly larger area of the game and then "ooh" and "aah" about how beautiful the cave is, despite the room having few discernibly different features from the rest of the cave.The open world is particularly atrocious. Most of the "puzzles" here consist of walking/flying into things, delving more virtually identical caves (some of which are totally empty besides a box with an item), picking up and moving an object, or left-clicking up to nine objects with your wand. If you're bent on completing this open world's objectives, likely so that you can unlock more carry space for selling the tons of useless clothes the caves give you, you're going to sit through about 64 animations of a leafy gazebo spawning... someone in development thought that was a necessary thing to make you watch. Puzzles outside the open world, primarily in the castle, are easy. Like all these Warner Brothers games, there's a detective mode that essentially solves all the puzzles for you. It's not an optional cheaty feature either, you have to use this mode to solve puzzles, or you're going to be wondering around for ages looking for a motionless gray moth on a gray wall. There's a "code cracking" puzzle that has a single digit cipher, so that once you figure it out, you're going to be running around the castle doing basic addition about 20 times; how exciting.There's a lot of bugs. Performance is hit or miss; one day it'll be fine, the next it'll be all frame tanks. Lots of quest, objective, item, and mission breaking bugs that will see you restarting missions or waiting in hopes that an objective will fix itself. I ran into a game breaking bug within the first 12 minutes of the game; although, not any since. But I have had frequent issues where an objective wouldn't update or an item would disappear. There's also a lot of physics hijinx if you bother to hang around populated areas, like a kid suddenly deciding to levitate into a bicycle pose and then no-clips through three houses. Or you'll look behind you and there's potion ingredients you picked off the ground a while ago following you.In general, Hogwarts Legacy is pretty mid-tier title compared to games of the past, but in an economy where the singleplayer game is nearly dead, it might as well be a 10/10. Yet, I think the medium of games deserves better than this paint by numbers style of development. The medium of stories about witches and wizards also has a lot better representation already available than this title.  It lacks gameplay and feature diversity quite a bit. But it's impossible not to recommend, because it's one of the only triple-A video games released in the last four years.

author: GoncaloNL
review: Starting with the best that the game has to offer, Hogwarts castle, it is extremely well done and detailed, one of the best structures I have ever experienced in a game, it is large and complex, with a lot of density and verticality, exploring it is something quite “delicious”, has a lot of variety in artistic terms and still comes with a relative amount of puzzles, iconic items from that universe and several surprises in general. In addition to the castle, the game has another central point beside from the world itself, which is Hogsmeade, it is also very well characterized and presented, despite not being large or complex, it is a region with several easter eggs and points of interest equally iconic.Continuing on the exploration and moving on to the entire region beyond the castle and Hogsmeade, it all conforms to the art direction established by these two points of interest. The map is big enough and with a lot of things to do, it has merlin trials, enemy camps, caves, small villages with secondary quests and so on... still, even with a reasonable variation of things to do (with each one of those things to have its own variety), after completing 30%-40% of this world and having already experienced almost all of these activities, the game falls into that “syndrome” of repetition of most open world games, with a large amount of icons polluting the screen and consequently taking away that feeling of natural exploration, as we already know exactly the type of activity without even getting close to them. After a certain point, completing the map becomes "homework", with virtually negligible loot to collect.The game also has a system of seasons, which changes the look of the map quite a bit, it is a good artistic detail that makes exploring the map a little more interesting. But what makes navigating the map delightful is its gameplay.The gameplay is very fluid, both on land and mainly in the air. Flying with the broom is simply phenomenal, invoking it is a very quick process, being able to activate it almost any time, including from the water. You can still upgrade it to increase speed and acceleration, basically the broom and its navigation is one of the main factors for the game to work.Combat is impressively well done and satisfying, it's kind of a beefier version of the Batman games. When you have a lot of enemies on the screen can get a little boring, yet with the amount of spells, potions and plants to use in battle, it makes this one of the highlights of the game.The game's bosses are a bit tedious, with few variations of their moveset, and sometimes the lock in becomes a problem, as it is not possible to adjust the aim when it is activated, when there is a boss + enemies, we lose the notion from where are we taking or giving damage.The first missions of the game have a very tutorial “tenor”, the problem is that this same line continues for about 3h-4h, and we only have access to another dungeon and the broom, 4h-6h after the start. Many of the missions involve going to point A just for an npc to give us a little information so that we can go to point B, this turns out to be tedious because the game almost shelters us to constantly use fast-travel. Another annoying thing related to the missions is the level lock, forcing the player to do secondary things.The game's story isn't bad, but it's forgettable in my opinion, I couldn't connect with most of the characters and I found the whole main context a little generic, in addition, our actions don't seem to have significant consequences. Some details are not very logical and the classic “we have no time to lose, let's do this now” also happens here, however, it is an open world game and it leaves the option of going to do other things and returning to that quest hours later. The highest point in terms of the narrative turns out to be Sebastian's questline, which we have some good decisions to make.In terms of puzzles related to the main missions (and some secondary ones), even if none are very challenging, the character doesn't shut up for 1 second, giving non-stop tips on what to do, which isn't very cohesive taking into account most of the Castle's puzzles.The game has a lot of loadings and cuts, which ends up taking away some of the immersion. It has a cut to enter and exit the dialogs, these that have occasional sound problems, sometimes the sound comes out good, sometimes it has a giant echo and others it is louder or quieter.There is also a problem with lighting, whenever we walk through a door from inside to outside "we get a flashbang" right in our face.Another slightly annoying thing is the repetition of small dialogues by the character when he sees or interacts with some elements of the world, which happens all the time.

author: El Squid
review: For all the rabid little weasels that are going to rise up and say I am a bad person for buying this game, okay.  I'm a bad person.  Don't care.  Been called a lot worse by people I actually care about.  Go pound sand.Not a Potter fan, but I am really liking this game.  If you enjoy open world, crafting and/or fantasy RPGs, this is your game.  Bought extra copies for a friend and my daughter-in-law, both of whom are Potter fans.  They are loving it as well.I have had no issues at all.  No bugs,  No graphics problems using a 3070 card.  In fact, my buddy, who uses a 2000 series NVidia card, is playing this with no issues.  Beautiful graphics, lots of side quests and tons of customizable cosmetics.  After the long parade of bitter disappointments, particularly Fallout 76, it is refreshing to get a game that is excellent on launch, not in some future date.  It is about time.

author: Rytoxz
review: Hogwarts Legacy is undeniably excellent and a genuine must-play if you’re at all a fan of the Wizarding World. Getting your first wand, flying around on a broom, or simply taking in the Hogwarts grounds is truly breathtaking. It is however an imperfect game: great gameplay, average story; amazing open world, excessive busywork tasks; interesting characters, not enough development of them. This review contains mild spoilers.StoryThe introduction for the game is wonderful showcasing the magical setting and setting up the premise nicely. The pace does however slow down by quite a bit over the next few hours, yet you never feel bored as there are constantly new things to discover via quests, characters, or just general exploration. This is a storyline where you have a special ability that others don’t, and there are multiple times throughout the game where you must suspend your disbelief that a simple 5th year Hogwarts student is doing all this. The characters you meet – three of which have developed side stories – are likeable, but many characters just don’t have much of an impact in the game or you don’t spend enough time with them. Aside from that, the story is somewhat predictable but good enough to keep you engaged for the time it might take you to play through it all.ExplorationOnce the initial tutorial and introduction parts are complete, you basically have complete freedom to roam the open world. Hogwarts castle is unequivocally one of the best video game locations ever made, with nearly every room open for exploration and incredible depth to each area. Many hours in, I was still being amazed that there were new locations to find, and I was always eager to explore them just to see what the level designers had created or to find more collectibles. The grounds around Hogwarts are also nice to traverse, though the open world looks visually quite similar with not too much variation past just “green hills”. There is a coastal part of the map in the bottom-right which feels a bit different, but in general (and as expected really) it’s all just highlands. Hogsmeade is a great town to visit truly highlighting the magic of the setting and adding depth to the world with almost every building being openable. Many doors throughout the game are however locked behind a levelled lockpicking skill. This was a frustrating design decision as you had to collect statues throughout the game – some of which were locked behind lockpicking doors – before you could level up your lockpicking stat. This acted as a huge barrier to exploration progression, and I felt this was a low point for the general pace of the game. Otherwise, whether it be sneaking, walking, running, flying, or constant “revelio-ing” around the world, I thoroughly enjoyed just exploring and not feeling like every area was a pointless copy and pasted zone of collectibles. My only negative really is the sheer number of tasks: 95 Merlin trials became too much, and I think if they just slightly toned this down it would feel less oppressive.GameplayAside from the numerous main quests and side quests – including things like broom flying challenges or puzzle rooms, the game is made-up of a collectibles and challenge system that rewards progression via cosmetic unlocks, armor traits, or building items. I have 100% completion in the game, and due to how I was playing focussing on the collectibles, it was only at the very end of the game where I needed to look some stuff up to finish my collections. It doesn’t really feel like a chore, and the rewards are nice – though I do wish they were just auto-claimed. A portion of the meta game is around the Room of Requirement (which just kept expanding much to my amazement) where you have very good customisation and build options, as well as rooms to store, feed, breed, and play with the animals you can nab. There are also traits which act as a skill tree and when I saw a whole part dedicated to the dark arts I knew what I would be spending my points on. Otherwise, the game has a fairly simple gear system with the usual Destiny-esque rarities and power level, but it also has transmog so you can keep gear and looks separate – though I wish the transmog was slot based and not item-based as you are constantly having to re-apply your looks when you change gear. There’s enough depth to keep you interested but it’s also accessible enough for anyone to play.CombatI was very worried leading up to launch that the combat would feel shallow, but it is surprisingly good. I played on controller, though I feel keyboard and mouse is probably the better call here. You have (once unlocked) four sets of skills that you can slot four spells into each – in general 16 total equipped spells is fine but you will occasionally need to switch some stuff out. Combat has some tactics to it: you need to match spell colors to break shields, you need to dodge or parry at the right time based on the attack type, and you need to use certain spells against some enemies. You never feel overwhelmed, but I think a lot of that is down to the very easy difficulty of the game – even on “hard”. The auto-targeting is generous but not too annoying, and being able to lock-on to targets and dodge independently is appreciated. When you start to combo skills in late-game – especially unforgivable curses and ancient magic – combat gets even more engaging and still feels fair based on enemy numbers and types; of which there are a good amount of unique enemies with different abilities and combat styles. I really enjoyed combat in this game, and only in a few cases did it feel like enemies were bullet sponges. The few boss fights the game had were also decent with the final boss being something that did impress me despite being quite simple.Graphics and PerformanceGraphically I don’t think the game looks insane, but it definitely looks very good. The most impressive thing is the minute detail in locations with lots of small items that adds to the scenery. Characters are also fine, and lip-syncing is okay. I played at 1440p ultra with DLSS 2.5.1 quality on a system with an i7-13700K and RTX 3080. Whilst I would say that general performance was good, the game is very VRAM heavy (especially with raytracing) and even with my setup it’s just on the edge of being fully playable; do not be afraid to turn down texture resolution. Rushing around in Hogwarts could also lead to some occasional stutters (even on my NVMe) as the game has simply zero loading screens and streams in areas as you move – be somewhat thoughtful to the engine. Settings wise, it has a good number of options to configure and generally seems to scale well across graphics presets. OverallI really liked this game, but then I also like Harry Potter. With the marvel of the world aside, I do still think it holds up as a fully playable and enjoyable, completely offline, MTX-free video game. It is rare that we get a release that is generally bug-free, well optimised, and not excessively monetised (do NOT buy the deluxe pack). Hogwarts Legacy has broken Steam records, sale records, and despite controversies has cemented itself as being a GOTY contender. Good work Avalanche Software and I hope there will be DLC or a sequel in the future.

author: Rhalic
review: Rocks, came in as not the biggest Harry Potter fan but I was won over.- Combat is freaking awesome, smooth and enjoyable, almost worth playing the game for the combat alone- Exploration is quite developed and while I found some activities a little more dull (though not many) the rewards for them we're almost always worth it in interesting ways- Decent Story with the occasional nice flairs of dialogue (especially with Sebastian Sallow)- The main story takes about 20 hours with some level gating, the quests were pretty good with some pretty fun and creative ones later in the story- Ran well on my machineOverall its a really good game, and even if you aren't a harry potter fan I'd say its worth a go, and if you ARE a harry potter fan its an absolute must. The recreation of hogwarts and its surrounding lands really show a level of love from the developers that I don't think is seen too often in other games.Now just gotta hope they add Quidditch in some sort of dlc

author: Nyano [pândăpeoizbândă]
review: Coming from someone who read the books, watched the movies, and played all PC games along the way....Story/Scenery:10This game is REALLY great. Starting with the story, scenery, is really full of memorable moments, characters are really nice made + voice actors are doing a really good job. If you enjoy the Harry Potter lore, you will defo enjoy this plot, I mean... I love the Potter books, but can't really understand why Rowling sometimes did not commit on her story. Some of her writing decisions...around the villans and slytherins lack complexity and are just poor written But the game... I actually enjoyed the plot and the characters way more.Gameplay: 10Learning the spells, discovering hidden secrets in Hogwarts, solving puzzles and fighting, are really good. Especially fighting...once you get the hang of it, you'll play on the hardest difficulty and enjoy the ♥♥♥♥ out of potions + plants that enhance your fighting style what damage you can send.Also,not to forget the diversity of things that you can do in the world.Graphics/Enviroment/Hogwarts castle 11/10:Castle is better than the movie castle. most def. In game there are no tricks, to have all the cinematic scenes to have Hogwarts in the background, so the castle actually makes sense, while I played, Hogwarts felt alive.LASTLY:Most of the 1 STAR reviews are ACTUALLY fixable with mods, community is really good in this game:People that complain about dificulty -> there is a mod for thatPeople that complain about alohomora puzzle -> there is a mod for that also (I'm also using that)People that complain about spell casting, graphics, fog or whatever -> there are actually mods for changing anything in game, if you actually prefer to play the game difrently.

review: after (almost) 10 hours, i think i can give the game a review.the game is definitely good. it has some weak points, but a lot of strong points.weak points include:- repetitive voice lines - menus are kind of annoying to navigate through, might just be me because i don't fancy the Assassin's Creed style equipment menu. (bonus: the whole "transmog" thing is really annoying to switch back to once you get new gear.)- houses mean.. nothing. i've watched gameplays and it's all the same.- the main story is mediocre, it's not bad but it's there.however, strong points are:- the combat, it's very satisfying and in general just good.- exploration- side quests, honestly found them more fun to do than the main story- graphics look very nice, especially hogwarts and hogsmeadeget it if you want a good adventure, i personally don't like harry potter at all but the game is pretty good.
